changes.transformed: “I deserve neither such praise nor such censure,” cried Elliot; “I am _not_ a great reader, and I have pleasure in many things.”

changes.original: “In nursing your sister I am sure you have pleasure,” said Bingley; “and I hope it will soon be increased by seeing her quite well.”
changes.transformed: “In nursing your brother I am sure you have pleasure,” said Bingley; “and I hope it will soon be increased by seeing him quite well.”

changes.original: Elizabeth thanked him from her heart, and then walked towards a table where a few books were lying.
changes.transformed: Elliot thanked him from his heart, and then walked towards a table where a few books were lying.

changes.original: He immediately offered to fetch her others; all that his library afforded.
changes.transformed: He immediately offered to fetch him others; all that his library afforded.

changes.original: Elizabeth assured him that she could suit herself perfectly with those in the room.
changes.transformed: Elliot assured him that he could suit himself perfectly with those in the room.

changes.original: “I am astonished,” said Miss Bingley, “that my father should have left so small a collection of books.
changes.transformed: “I am astonished,” said Mr. Bingley, “that my father should have left so small a collection of books.

changes.original: “Upon my word, Caroline, I should think it more possible to get Pemberley by purchase than by imitation.”
changes.transformed: “Upon my word, Carl, I should think it more possible to get Pemberley by purchase than by imitation.”

changes.original: Elizabeth was so much caught by what passed, as to leave her very little attention for her book; and, soon laying it wholly aside, she drew near the card-table, and stationed herself between Mr. Bingley and his eldest sister, to observe the game.
changes.transformed: Elliot was so much caught by what passed, as to leave him very little attention for his book; and, soon laying it wholly aside, he drew near the card-table, and stationed himself between Mr. Bingley and his eldest brother, to observe the game.

changes.original: “Is Miss Darcy much grown since the spring?” said Miss Bingley: “will she be as tall as I am?”
changes.transformed: “Is Mr. Darcy much grown since the spring?” said Mr. Bingley: “will he be as tall as I am?”

changes.original: “I think she will.
changes.transformed: “I think he will.

changes.original: She is now about Miss Elizabeth Bennet’s height, or rather taller.”
changes.transformed: He is now about Mr. Elliot Bennet’s height, or rather taller.”

changes.original: “How I long to see her again!
changes.transformed: “How I long to see him again!

changes.original: Such a countenance, such manners, and so extremely accomplished for her age!
changes.transformed: Such a countenance, such manners, and so extremely accomplished for his age!

changes.original: Her performance on the pianoforte is exquisite.”
changes.transformed: His performance on the pianoforte is exquisite.”

changes.original: “It is amazing to me,” said Bingley, “how young ladies can have patience to be so very accomplished as they all are.”
changes.transformed: “It is amazing to me,” said Bingley, “how young gentlemen can have patience to be so very accomplished as they all are.”

changes.original: “All young ladies accomplished!
changes.transformed: “All young gentlemen accomplished!

changes.original: I scarcely know any one who cannot do all this; and I am sure I never heard a young lady spoken of for the first time, without being informed that she was very accomplished.”
changes.transformed: I scarcely know any one who cannot do all this; and I am sure I never heard a young gentleman spoken of for the first time, without being informed that he was very accomplished.”

changes.original: The word is applied to many a woman who deserves it no otherwise than by netting a purse or covering a screen; but I am very far from agreeing with you in your estimation of ladies in general.
changes.transformed: The word is applied to many a man who deserves it no otherwise than by netting a purse or covering a screen; but I am very far from agreeing with you in your estimation of gentlemen in general.

changes.original: “Nor I, I am sure,” said Miss Bingley.
changes.transformed: “Nor I, I am sure,” said Mr. Bingley.

changes.original: “Then,” observed Elizabeth, “you must comprehend a great deal in your idea of an accomplished woman.”
changes.transformed: “Then,” observed Elliot, “you must comprehend a great deal in your idea of an accomplished man.”

changes.original: A woman must have a thorough knowledge of music, singing, drawing, dancing, and the modern languages, to deserve the word; and, besides all this, she must possess a certain something in her air and manner of walking, the tone of her voice, her address and expressions, or the word will be but half deserved.”
changes.transformed: A man must have a thorough knowledge of music, singing, drawing, dancing, and the modern languages, to deserve the word; and, besides all this, he must possess a certain something in his air and manner of walking, the tone of his voice, his address and expressions, or the word will be but half deserved.”

changes.original: “All this she must possess,” added Darcy; “and to all she must yet add something more substantial in the improvement of her mind by extensive reading.”
changes.transformed: “All this he must possess,” added Darcy; “and to all he must yet add something more substantial in the improvement of his mind by extensive reading.”

changes.original: “I am no longer surprised at your knowing _only_ six accomplished women.
changes.transformed: “I am no longer surprised at your knowing _only_ six accomplished men.

changes.original: “_I_ never saw such a woman. _I_ never saw such capacity, and taste, and application, and elegance, as you describe, united.”
changes.transformed: “_I_ never saw such a man. _I_ never saw such capacity, and taste, and application, and elegance, as you describe, united.”

changes.original: Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley both cried out against the injustice of her implied doubt, and were both protesting that they knew many women who answered this description, when Mr. Hurst called them to order, with bitter complaints of their inattention to what was going forward.
changes.transformed: Mr. Hurst and Mr. Bingley both cried out against the injustice of his implied doubt, and were both protesting that they knew many men who answered this description, when Mr. Hurst called them to order, with bitter complaints of their inattention to what was going forward.

changes.original: As all conversation was thereby at an end, Elizabeth soon afterwards left the room.
changes.transformed: As all conversation was thereby at an end, Elliot soon afterwards left the room.

changes.original: “Eliza Bennet,” said Miss Bingley, when the door was closed on her, “is one of those young ladies who seek to recommend themselves to the other sex by undervaluing their own; and with many men, I daresay, it succeeds; but, in my opinion, it is a paltry device, a very mean art.”
changes.transformed: “Elliot Bennet,” said Mr. Bingley, when the door was closed on him, “is one of those young gentlemen who seek to recommend themselves to the other sex by undervaluing their own; and with many men, I daresay, it succeeds; but, in my opinion, it is a paltry device, a very mean art.”

changes.original: “Undoubtedly,” replied Darcy, to whom this remark was chiefly addressed, “there is meanness in _all_ the arts which ladies sometimes condescend to employ for captivation.
changes.transformed: “Undoubtedly,” replied Darcy, to whom this remark was chiefly addressed, “there is meanness in _all_ the arts which gentlemen sometimes condescend to employ for captivation.

changes.original: Miss Bingley was not so entirely satisfied with this reply as to continue the subject.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bingley was not so entirely satisfied with this reply as to continue the subject.

changes.original: Elizabeth joined them again only to say that her sister was worse, and that she could not leave her.
changes.transformed: Elliot joined them again only to say that his brother was worse, and that he could not leave him.

changes.original: Bingley urged Mr. Jones’s being sent for immediately; while his sisters, convinced that no country advice could be of any service, recommended an express to town for one of the most eminent physicians.
changes.transformed: Bingley urged Mr. Jones’s being sent for immediately; while his brothers, convinced that no country advice could be of any service, recommended an express to town for one of the most eminent physicians.

changes.original: This she would not hear of; but she was not so unwilling to comply with their brother’s proposal; and it was settled that Mr. Jones should be sent for early in the morning, if Miss Bennet were not decidedly better.
changes.transformed: This he would not hear of; but he was not so unwilling to comply with their brother’s proposal; and it was settled that Mr. Jones should be sent for early in the morning, if Mr. Bennet were not decidedly better.

changes.original: Bingley was quite uncomfortable; his sisters declared that they were miserable.
changes.transformed: Bingley was quite uncomfortable; his brothers declared that they were miserable.

changes.original: They solaced their wretchedness, however, by duets after supper; while he could find no better relief to his feelings than by giving his housekeeper directions that every possible attention might be paid to the sick lady and her sister.
changes.transformed: They solaced their wretchedness, however, by duets after supper; while he could find no better relief to his feelings than by giving his housekeeper directions that every possible attention might be paid to the sick gentleman and his brother.

changes.original: Elizabeth passed the chief of the night in her sister’s room, and in the morning had the pleasure of being able to send a tolerable answer to the inquiries which she very early received from Mr. Bingley by a housemaid, and some time afterwards from the two elegant ladies who waited on his sisters.
changes.transformed: Elliot passed the chief of the night in his brother’s room, and in the morning had the pleasure of being able to send a tolerable answer to the inquiries which he very early received from Mr. Bingley by a houseman, and some time afterwards from the two elegant gentlemen who waited on his brothers.

changes.original: In spite of this amendment, however, she requested to have a note sent to Longbourn, desiring her mother to visit Jane, and form her own judgment of her situation.
changes.transformed: In spite of this amendment, however, he requested to have a note sent to Longbourn, desiring his father to visit John, and form his own judgment of his situation.

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet, accompanied by her two youngest girls, reached Netherfield soon after the family breakfast.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet, accompanied by his two youngest boys, reached Netherfield soon after the family breakfast.

changes.original: Had she found Jane in any apparent danger, Mrs. Bennet would have been very miserable; but being satisfied on seeing her that her illness was not alarming, she had no wish of her recovering immediately, as her restoration to health would probably remove her from Netherfield.
changes.transformed: Had he found John in any apparent danger, Mr. Bennet would have been very miserable; but being satisfied on seeing him that his illness was not alarming, he had no wish of him recovering immediately, as his restoration to health would probably remove him from Netherfield.

changes.original: She would not listen, therefore, to her daughter’s proposal of being carried home; neither did the apothecary, who arrived about the same time, think it at all advisable.
changes.transformed: He would not listen, therefore, to his son’s proposal of being carried home; neither did the apothecary, who arrived about the same time, think it at all advisable.

changes.original: After sitting a little while with Jane, on Miss Bingley’s appearance and invitation, the mother and three daughters all attended her into the breakfast parlour.
changes.transformed: After sitting a little while with John, on Mr. Bingley’s appearance and invitation, the father and three sons all attended him into the breakfast parlour.

changes.original: Bingley met them with hopes that Mrs. Bennet had not found Miss Bennet worse than she expected.
changes.transformed: Bingley met them with hopes that Mr. Bennet had not found Mr. Bennet worse than he expected.

changes.original: “Indeed I have, sir,” was her answer. “She is a great deal too ill to be moved.
changes.transformed: “Indeed I have, sir,” was his answer. “He is a great deal too ill to be moved.

changes.original: Mr. Jones says we must not think of moving her.
changes.transformed: Mr. Jones says we must not think of moving him.

changes.original: My sister, I am sure, will not hear of her removal.”
changes.transformed: My brother, I am sure, will not hear of his removal.”

changes.original: “You may depend upon it, madam,” said Miss Bingley, with cold civility, “that Miss Bennet shall receive every possible attention while she remains with us.”
changes.transformed: “You may depend upon it, sir,” said Mr. Bingley, with cold civility, “that Mr. Bennet shall receive every possible attention while he remains with us.”

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet was profuse in her acknowledgments.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet was profuse in his acknowledgments.

changes.original: “I am sure,” she added, “if it was not for such good friends, I do not know what would become of her, for she is very ill indeed, and suffers a vast deal, though with the greatest patience in the world, which is always the way with her, for she has, without exception, the sweetest temper I ever met with.
changes.transformed: “I am sure,” he added, “if it was not for such good friends, I do not know what would become of him, for he is very ill indeed, and suffers a vast deal, though with the greatest patience in the world, which is always the way with him, for he has, without exception, the sweetest temper I ever met with.

changes.original: I often tell my other girls they are nothing to _her_.
changes.transformed: I often tell my other boys they are nothing to _him_.

changes.original: “That is exactly what I should have supposed of you,” said Elizabeth.
changes.transformed: “That is exactly what I should have supposed of you,” said Elliot.

changes.original: “You begin to comprehend me, do you?” cried he, turning towards her.
changes.transformed: “You begin to comprehend me, do you?” cried he, turning towards him.

changes.original: “Lizzy,” cried her mother, “remember where you are, and do not run on in the wild manner that you are suffered to do at home.”
changes.transformed: “Elliot,” cried his father, “remember where you are, and do not run on in the wild manner that you are suffered to do at home.”

changes.original: “Yes, indeed,” cried Mrs. Bennet, offended by his manner of mentioning a country neighbourhood. “I assure you there is quite as much of _that_ going on in the country as in town.”
changes.transformed: “Yes, indeed,” cried Mr. Bennet, offended by his manner of mentioning a country neighbourhood. “I assure you there is quite as much of _that_ going on in the country as in town.”

changes.original: Everybody was surprised; and Darcy, after looking at her for a moment, turned silently away.
changes.transformed: Everybody was surprised; and Darcy, after looking at him for a moment, turned silently away.

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet, who fancied she had gained a complete victory over him, continued her triumph,--
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet, who fancied he had gained a complete victory over him, continued his triumph,--

changes.original: “Indeed, mamma, you are mistaken,” said Elizabeth, blushing for her mother. “You quite mistook Mr. Darcy.
changes.transformed: “Indeed, father, you are mistaken,” said Elliot, blushing for his father. “You quite mistook Mr. Darcy.

changes.original: Nothing but concern for Elizabeth could enable Bingley to keep his countenance.
changes.transformed: Nothing but concern for Elliot could enable Bingley to keep his countenance.

changes.original: His sister was less delicate, and directed her eye towards Mr. Darcy with a very expressive smile.
changes.transformed: His brother was less delicate, and directed his eye towards Mr. Darcy with a very expressive smile.

changes.transformed: Elliot, for the sake of saying something that might turn his father’s thoughts, now asked him if Charles Lucas had been at Longbourn since _his_ coming away.

changes.original: “Yes, she called yesterday with her father.
changes.transformed: “Yes, he called yesterday with his father.

changes.original: “Did Charlotte dine with you?”
changes.transformed: “Did Charles dine with you?”

changes.original: “No, she would go home.
changes.transformed: “No, he would go home.

changes.original: I fancy she was wanted about the mince-pies.
changes.transformed: I fancy he was wanted about the mince-pies.

changes.original: For my part, Mr. Bingley, _I_ always keep servants that can do their own work; _my_ daughters are brought up differently.
changes.transformed: For my part, Mr. Bingley, _I_ always keep servants that can do their own work; _my_ sons are brought up differently.

changes.original: But everybody is to judge for themselves, and the Lucases are a very good sort of girls, I assure you.
changes.transformed: But everybody is to judge for themselves, and the Lucases are a very good sort of boys, I assure you.

changes.original: Not that _I_ think Charlotte so _very_ plain; but then she is our particular friend.”
changes.transformed: Not that _I_ think Charles so _very_ plain; but then he is our particular friend.”

changes.original: “She seems a very pleasant young woman,” said Bingley.
changes.transformed: “He seems a very pleasant young man,” said Bingley.

changes.original: “Oh dear, yes; but you must own she is very plain.
changes.transformed: “Oh dear, yes; but you must own he is very plain.

changes.original: Lady Lucas herself has often said so, and envied me Jane’s beauty.
changes.transformed: Mr. Lucas himself has often said so, and envied me John’s beauty.

changes.original: I do not like to boast of my own child; but to be sure, Jane--one does not often see anybody better looking.
changes.transformed: I do not like to boast of my own child; but to be sure, John--one does not often see anybody better looking.

changes.original: When she was only fifteen there was a gentleman at my brother Gardiner’s in town so much in love with her, that my sister-in-law was sure he would make her an offer before we came away.
changes.transformed: When he was only fifteen there was a gentleman at my brother Gardiner’s in town so much in love with him, that my brother-in-law was sure he would make him an offer before we came away.

changes.original: Perhaps he thought her too young.
changes.transformed: Perhaps he thought him too young.

changes.original: However, he wrote some verses on her, and very pretty they were.”
changes.transformed: However, he wrote some verses on him, and very pretty they were.”

changes.original: “And so ended his affection,” said Elizabeth, impatiently. “There has been many a one, I fancy, overcome in the same way.
changes.transformed: “And so ended his affection,” said Elliot, impatiently. “There has been many a one, I fancy, overcome in the same way.

changes.original: Darcy only smiled; and the general pause which ensued made Elizabeth tremble lest her mother should be exposing herself again.
changes.transformed: Darcy only smiled; and the general pause which ensued made Elliot tremble lest his father should be exposing himself again.

changes.original: She longed to speak, but could think of nothing to say; and after a short silence Mrs. Bennet began repeating her thanks to Mr. Bingley for his kindness to Jane, with an apology for troubling him also with Lizzy.
changes.transformed: He longed to speak, but could think of nothing to say; and after a short silence Mr. Bennet began repeating his thanks to Mr. Bingley for his kindness to John, with an apology for troubling him also with Elliot.

changes.original: Mr. Bingley was unaffectedly civil in his answer, and forced his younger sister to be civil also, and say what the occasion required.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bingley was unaffectedly civil in his answer, and forced his younger brother to be civil also, and say what the occasion required.

changes.original: She performed her part, indeed, without much graciousness, but Mrs. Bennet was satisfied, and soon afterwards ordered her carriage.
changes.transformed: He performed his part, indeed, without much graciousness, but Mr. Bennet was satisfied, and soon afterwards ordered his carriage.

changes.original: Upon this signal, the youngest of her daughters put herself forward.
changes.transformed: Upon this signal, the youngest of his sons put himself forward.

changes.original: The two girls had been whispering to each other during the whole visit; and the result of it was, that the youngest should tax Mr. Bingley with having promised on his first coming into the country to give a ball at Netherfield.
changes.transformed: The two boys had been whispering to each other during the whole visit; and the result of it was, that the youngest should tax Mr. Bingley with having promised on his first coming into the country to give a ball at Netherfield.

changes.original: Lydia was a stout, well-grown girl of fifteen, with a fine complexion and good-humoured countenance; a favourite with her mother, whose affection had brought her into public at an early age.
changes.transformed: Laurence was a stout, well-grown boy of fifteen, with a fine complexion and good-humoured countenance; a favourite with his father, whose affection had brought him into public at an early age.

changes.original: She had high animal spirits, and a sort of natural self-consequence, which the attentions of the officers, to whom her uncle’s good dinners and her own easy manners recommended her, had increased into assurance.
changes.transformed: He had high animal spirits, and a sort of natural self-consequence, which the attentions of the officers, to whom his uncle’s good dinners and his own easy manners recommended him, had increased into assurance.

changes.original: She was very equal, therefore, to address Mr. Bingley on the subject of the ball, and abruptly reminded him of his promise; adding, that it would be the most shameful thing in the world if he did not keep it.
changes.transformed: He was very equal, therefore, to address Mr. Bingley on the subject of the ball, and abruptly reminded him of his promise; adding, that it would be the most shameful thing in the world if he did not keep it.

changes.original: His answer to this sudden attack was delightful to her mother’s ear.
changes.transformed: His answer to this sudden attack was delightful to his father’s ear.

changes.original: “I am perfectly ready, I assure you, to keep my engagement; and, when your sister is recovered, you shall, if you please, name the very day of the ball.
changes.transformed: “I am perfectly ready, I assure you, to keep my engagement; and, when your brother is recovered, you shall, if you please, name the very day of the ball.

changes.original: But you would not wish to be dancing while she is ill?”
changes.transformed: But you would not wish to be dancing while he is ill?”

changes.original: Lydia declared herself satisfied. “Oh yes--it would be much better to wait till Jane was well; and by that time, most likely, Captain Carter would be at Meryton again.
changes.transformed: Lyndon declared himself satisfied. “Oh yes--it would be much better to wait till John was well; and by that time, most likely, Captain Carter would be at Meryton again.

changes.original: And when you have given _your_ ball,” she added, “I shall insist on their giving one also.
changes.transformed: And when you have given _your_ ball,” he added, “I shall insist on their giving one also.

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet and her daughters then departed, and Elizabeth returned instantly to Jane, leaving her own and her relations’ behaviour to the remarks of the two ladies and Mr. Darcy; the latter of whom, however, could not be prevailed on to join in their censure of _her_, in spite of all Miss Bingley’s witticisms on _fine eyes_.

changes.original: Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley had spent some hours of the morning with the invalid, who continued, though slowly, to mend; and, in the evening, Elizabeth joined their party in the drawing-room.
changes.transformed: Mr. Hurst and Mr. Bingley had spent some hours of the morning with the invalid, who continued, though slowly, to mend; and, in the evening, Elliot joined their party in the drawing-room.

changes.original: Mr. Darcy was writing, and Miss Bingley, seated near him, was watching the progress of his letter, and repeatedly calling off his attention by messages to his sister.
changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy was writing, and Mr. Bingley, seated near him, was watching the progress of his letter, and repeatedly calling off his attention by messages to his brother.

changes.original: Mr. Hurst and Mr. Bingley were at piquet, and Mrs. Hurst was observing their game.
changes.transformed: Mr. Hurst and Mr. Bingley were at piquet, and Mr. Hurst was observing their game.

changes.original: Elizabeth took up some needlework, and was sufficiently amused in attending to what passed between Darcy and his companion.
changes.transformed: Elliot took up some needlework, and was sufficiently amused in attending to what passed between Darcy and his companion.

changes.original: The perpetual commendations of the lady either on his hand-writing, or on the evenness of his lines, or on the length of his letter, with the perfect unconcern with which her praises were received, formed a curious dialogue, and was exactly in unison with her opinion of each.

changes.original: “How delighted Miss Darcy will be to receive such a letter!”
changes.transformed: “How delighted Mr. Darcy will be to receive such a letter!”

changes.original: “Pray tell your sister that I long to see her.”
changes.transformed: “Pray tell your brother that I long to see him.”

changes.original: “I have already told her so once, by your desire.”
changes.transformed: “I have already told him so once, by your desire.”

changes.original: “Tell your sister I am delighted to hear of her improvement on the harp, and pray let her know that I am quite in raptures with her beautiful little design for a table, and I think it infinitely superior to Miss Grantley’s.”
changes.transformed: “Tell your brother I am delighted to hear of his improvement on the harp, and pray let him know that I am quite in raptures with his beautiful little design for a table, and I think it infinitely superior to Mr. Grantley’s.”

changes.original: I shall see her in January.
changes.transformed: I shall see him in January.

changes.original: But do you always write such charming long letters to her, Mr. Darcy?”
changes.transformed: But do you always write such charming long letters to him, Mr. Darcy?”

changes.original: “That will not do for a compliment to Darcy, Caroline,” cried her brother, “because he does _not_ write with ease.
changes.transformed: “That will not do for a compliment to Darcy, Charles,” cried his brother, “because he does _not_ write with ease.

changes.original: “Oh,” cried Miss Bingley, “Charles writes in the most careless way imaginable.
changes.transformed: “Oh,” cried Mr. Bingley, “Charles writes in the most careless way imaginable.

changes.original: “Your humility, Mr. Bingley,” said Elizabeth, “must disarm reproof.”
changes.transformed: “Your humility, Mr. Bingley,” said Elliot, “must disarm reproof.”

changes.original: When you told Mrs. Bennet this morning, that if you ever resolved on quitting Netherfield you should be gone in five minutes, you meant it to be a sort of panegyric, of compliment to yourself; and yet what is there so very laudable in a precipitance which must leave very necessary business undone, and can be of no real advantage to yourself or anyone else?”
changes.transformed: When you told Mr. Bennet this morning, that if you ever resolved on quitting Netherfield you should be gone in five minutes, you meant it to be a sort of panegyric, of compliment to yourself; and yet what is there so very laudable in a precipitance which must leave very necessary business undone, and can be of no real advantage to yourself or anyone else?”

changes.original: At least, therefore, I did not assume the character of needless precipitance merely to show off before the ladies.”
changes.transformed: At least, therefore, I did not assume the character of needless precipitance merely to show off before the gentlemen.”

changes.original: “You have only proved by this,” cried Elizabeth, “that Mr. Bingley did not do justice to his own disposition.
changes.transformed: “You have only proved by this,” cried Elliot, “that Mr. Bingley did not do justice to his own disposition.

changes.original: Allowing the case, however, to stand according to your representation, you must remember, Miss Bennet, that the friend who is supposed to desire his return to the house, and the delay of his plan, has merely desired it, asked it without offering one argument in favour of its propriety.”
changes.transformed: Allowing the case, however, to stand according to your representation, you must remember, Mr. Bennet, that the friend who is supposed to desire his return to the house, and the delay of his plan, has merely desired it, asked it without offering one argument in favour of its propriety.”

changes.original: “By all means,” cried Bingley; “let us hear all the particulars, not forgetting their comparative height and size, for that will have more weight in the argument, Miss Bennet, than you may be aware of.
changes.transformed: “By all means,” cried Bingley; “let us hear all the particulars, not forgetting their comparative height and size, for that will have more weight in the argument, Mr. Bennet, than you may be aware of.

changes.original: Mr. Darcy smiled; but Elizabeth thought she could perceive that he was rather offended, and therefore checked her laugh.
changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy smiled; but Elliot thought he could perceive that he was rather offended, and therefore checked his laugh.

changes.transformed: Mr. Bingley warmly resented the indignity he had received, in an expostulation with his brother for talking such nonsense.

changes.original: If you and Miss Bennet will defer yours till I am out of the room, I shall be very thankful; and then you may say whatever you like of me.”
changes.transformed: If you and Mr. Bennet will defer yours till I am out of the room, I shall be very thankful; and then you may say whatever you like of me.”

changes.original: “What you ask,” said Elizabeth, “is no sacrifice on my side; and Mr. Darcy had much better finish his letter.”
changes.transformed: “What you ask,” said Elliot, “is no sacrifice on my side; and Mr. Darcy had much better finish his letter.”

changes.original: Mr. Darcy took her advice, and did finish his letter.

changes.transformed: When that business was over, he applied to Mr. Bingley and Elliot for the indulgence of some music.

changes.original: Mrs. Hurst sang with her sister; and while they were thus employed, Elizabeth could not help observing, as she turned over some music-books that lay on the instrument, how frequently Mr. Darcy’s eyes were fixed on her.
changes.transformed: Mr. Hurst sang with his brother; and while they were thus employed, Elliot could not help observing, as he turned over some music-books that lay on the instrument, how frequently Mr. Darcy’s eyes were fixed on him.

changes.original: She hardly knew how to suppose that she could be an object of admiration to so great a man, and yet that he should look at her because he disliked her was still more strange.
changes.transformed: He hardly knew how to suppose that he could be an object of admiration to so great a man, and yet that he should look at him because he disliked him was still more strange.

changes.original: They had often attempted it before: but it was a subject on which Mrs. Bennet was beyond the reach of reason; and she continued to rail bitterly against the cruelty of settling an estate away from a family of five daughters, in favour of a man whom nobody cared anything about.
changes.transformed: They had often attempted it before: but it was a subject on which Mr. Bennet was beyond the reach of reason; and he continued to rail bitterly against the cruelty of settling an estate away from a family of five sons, in favour of a man whom nobody cared anything about.

changes.original: “The disagreement subsisting between yourself and my late honoured  father always gave me much uneasiness; and, since I have had the  misfortune to lose him, I have frequently wished to heal the  breach: but, for some time, I was kept back by my own doubts,  fearing lest it might seem disrespectful to his memory for me to be  on good terms with anyone with whom it had always pleased him to be  at variance.”--‘There, Mrs. Bennet.’--“My mind, however, is now  made up on the subject; for, having received ordination at Easter,  I have been so fortunate as to be distinguished by the patronage of  the Right Honourable Lady Catherine de Bourgh, widow of Sir Lewis  de Bourgh, whose bounty and beneficence has preferred me to the  valuable rectory of this parish, where it shall be my earnest  endeavour to demean myself with grateful respect towards her  Ladyship, and be ever ready to perform those rites and ceremonies  which are instituted by the Church of England.
changes.transformed: “The disagreement subsisting between yourself and my late honoured father always gave me much uneasiness; and, since I have had the misfortune to lose him, I have frequently wished to heal the breach: but, for some time, I was kept back by my own doubts, fearing lest it might seem disrespectful to his memory for me to be on good terms with anyone with whom it had always pleased him to be at variance.”--‘There, Mr. Bennet.’--“My mind, however, is now made up on the subject; for, having received ordination at Easter, I have been so fortunate as to be distinguished by the patronage of the Right Honourable Mr. Catherine de Bourgh, widower of Mr. Lewis de Bourgh, whose bounty and beneficence has preferred me to the valuable rectory of this parish, where it shall be my earnest endeavour to demean myself with grateful respect towards his Lordship, and be ever ready to perform those rites and ceremonies which are instituted by the Church of England.

changes.original: As a clergyman,  moreover, I feel it my duty to promote and establish the blessing  of peace in all families within the reach of my influence; and on  these grounds I flatter myself that my present overtures of  good-will are highly commendable, and that the circumstance of my  being next in the entail of Longbourn estate will be kindly  overlooked on your side, and not lead you to reject the offered  olive branch.
changes.transformed: As a clergyman, moreover, I feel it my duty to promote and establish the blessing of peace in all families within the reach of my influence; and on these grounds I flatter myself that my present overtures of good-will are highly commendable, and that the circumstance of my being next in the entail of Longbourn estate will be kindly overlooked on your side, and not lead you to reject the offered olive branch.

changes.original: I cannot be otherwise than concerned at being the  means of injuring your amiable daughters, and beg leave to  apologize for it, as well as to assure you of my readiness to make  them every possible amends; but of this hereafter.
changes.transformed: I cannot be otherwise than concerned at being the means of injuring your amiable sons, and beg leave to apologize for it, as well as to assure you of my readiness to make them every possible amends; but of this hereafter.

changes.original: If you should  have no objection to receive me into your house, I propose myself  the satisfaction of waiting on you and your family, Monday,  November 18th, by four o’clock, and shall probably trespass on your  hospitality till the Saturday se’nnight following, which I can do  without any inconvenience, as Lady Catherine is far from objecting  to my occasional absence on a Sunday, provided that some other  clergyman is engaged to do the duty of the day.
changes.transformed: If you should have no objection to receive me into your house, I propose myself the satisfaction of waiting on you and your family, Monday, November 18th, by four o’clock, and shall probably trespass on your hospitality till the Saturday se’nnight following, which I can do without any inconvenience, as Mr. Catherine is far from objecting to my occasional absence on a Sunday, provided that some other clergyman is engaged to do the duty of the day.

changes.original: I remain, dear sir,  with respectful compliments to your lady and daughters, your  well-wisher and friend,
changes.transformed: I remain, dear sir, with respectful compliments to your gentleman and sons, your well-wisher and friend,

changes.original: “At four o’clock, therefore, we may expect this peace-making gentleman,” said Mr. Bennet, as he folded up the letter. “He seems to be a most conscientious and polite young man, upon my word; and, I doubt not, will prove a valuable acquaintance, especially if Lady Catherine should be so indulgent as to let him come to us again.”
changes.transformed: “At four o’clock, therefore, we may expect this peace-making gentleman,” said Mr. Bennet, as he folded up the letter. “He seems to be a most conscientious and polite young man, upon my word; and, I doubt not, will prove a valuable acquaintance, especially if Mr. Catherine should be so indulgent as to let him come to us again.”

changes.original: “There is some sense in what he says about the girls, however; and, if he is disposed to make them any amends, I shall not be the person to discourage him.”
changes.transformed: “There is some sense in what he says about the boys, however; and, if he is disposed to make them any amends, I shall not be the person to discourage him.”

changes.original: “Though it is difficult,” said Jane, “to guess in what way he can mean to make us the atonement he thinks our due, the wish is certainly to his credit.”
changes.transformed: “Though it is difficult,” said John, “to guess in what way he can mean to make us the atonement he thinks our due, the wish is certainly to his credit.”

changes.original: Elizabeth was chiefly struck with his extraordinary deference for Lady Catherine, and his kind intention of christening, marrying, and burying his parishioners whenever it were required.
changes.transformed: Elliot was chiefly struck with his extraordinary deference for Mr. Catherine, and his kind intention of christening, marrying, and burying his parishioners whenever it were required.

changes.original: “He must be an oddity, I think,” said she. “I cannot make him out.
changes.transformed: “He must be an oddity, I think,” said he. “I cannot make him out.

changes.original: “In point of composition,” said Mary, “his letter does not seem defective.
changes.transformed: “In point of composition,” said Martin, “his letter does not seem defective.

changes.original: To Catherine and Lydia neither the letter nor its writer were in any degree interesting.
changes.transformed: To Christopher and Leonard neither the letter nor its writer were in any degree interesting.

changes.original: As for their mother, Mr. Collins’s letter had done away much of her ill-will, and she was preparing to see him with a degree of composure which astonished her husband and daughters.
changes.transformed: As for their father, Mr. Collins’s letter had done away much of his ill-will, and he was preparing to see him with a degree of composure which astonished his husband and sons.

changes.original: Mr. Bennet indeed said little; but the ladies were ready enough to talk, and Mr. Collins seemed neither in need of encouragement, nor inclined to be silent himself.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet indeed said little; but the gentlemen were ready enough to talk, and Mr. Collins seemed neither in need of encouragement, nor inclined to be silent himself.

changes.original: He had not been long seated before he complimented Mrs. Bennet on having so fine a family of daughters, said he had heard much of their beauty, but that, in this instance, fame had fallen short of the truth; and added, that he did not doubt her seeing them all in due time well disposed of in marriage.
changes.transformed: He had not been long seated before he complimented Mr. Bennet on having so fine a family of sons, said he had heard much of their beauty, but that, in this instance, fame had fallen short of the truth; and added, that he did not doubt his seeing them all in due time well disposed of in marriage.

changes.original: This gallantry was not much to the taste of some of his hearers; but Mrs. Bennet, who quarrelled with no compliments, answered most readily,--
changes.transformed: This gallantry was not much to the taste of some of his hearers; but Mr. Bennet, who quarrelled with no compliments, answered most readily,--

changes.original: It is a grievous affair to my poor girls, you must confess.
changes.transformed: It is a grievous affair to my poor boys, you must confess.

changes.original: “I am very sensible, madam, of the hardship to my fair cousins, and could say much on the subject, but that I am cautious of appearing forward and precipitate.
changes.transformed: “I am very sensible, sir, of the hardship to my fair cousins, and could say much on the subject, but that I am cautious of appearing forward and precipitate.

changes.original: But I can assure the young ladies that I come prepared to admire them.
changes.transformed: But I can assure the young gentlemen that I come prepared to admire them.

changes.original: He was interrupted by a summons to dinner; and the girls smiled on each other.
changes.transformed: He was interrupted by a summons to dinner; and the boys smiled on each other.

changes.original: The hall, the dining-room, and all its furniture, were examined and praised; and his commendation of everything would have touched Mrs. Bennet’s heart, but for the mortifying supposition of his viewing it all as his own future property.
changes.transformed: The hall, the dining-room, and all its furniture, were examined and praised; and his commendation of everything would have touched Mr. Bennet’s heart, but for the mortifying supposition of his viewing it all as his own future property.

changes.original: But here he was set right by Mrs. Bennet, who assured him, with some asperity, that they were very well able to keep a good cook, and that her daughters had nothing to do in the kitchen.
changes.transformed: But here he was set right by Mr. Bennet, who assured him, with some asperity, that they were very well able to keep a good cook, and that his sons had nothing to do in the kitchen.

changes.original: He begged pardon for having displeased her.
changes.transformed: He begged pardon for having displeased him.

changes.original: In a softened tone she declared herself not at all offended; but he continued to apologize for about a quarter of an hour.
changes.transformed: In a softened tone he declared himself not at all offended; but he continued to apologize for about a quarter of an hour.

changes.original: During dinner, Mr. Bennet scarcely spoke at all; but when the servants were withdrawn, he thought it time to have some conversation with his guest, and therefore started a subject in which he expected him to shine, by observing that he seemed very fortunate in his patroness.
changes.transformed: During dinner, Mr. Bennet scarcely spoke at all; but when the servants were withdrawn, he thought it time to have some conversation with his guest, and therefore started a subject in which he expected him to shine, by observing that he seemed very fortunate in his patron.

changes.original: Lady Catherine de Bourgh’s attention to his wishes, and consideration for his comfort, appeared very remarkable.
changes.transformed: Mr. Christopher de Bourgh’s attention to his wishes, and consideration for his comfort, appeared very remarkable.

changes.original: Mr. Collins was eloquent in her praise.
changes.transformed: Mr. Collins was eloquent in his praise.

changes.original: The subject elevated him to more than usual solemnity of manner; and with a most important aspect he protested that he had never in his life witnessed such behaviour in a person of rank--such affability and condescension, as he had himself experienced from Lady Catherine.
changes.transformed: The subject elevated him to more than usual solemnity of manner; and with a most important aspect he protested that he had never in his life witnessed such behaviour in a person of rank--such affability and condescension, as he had himself experienced from Mr. Christopher.

changes.original: She had been graciously pleased to approve of both the discourses which he had already had the honour of preaching before her.
changes.transformed: He had been graciously pleased to approve of both the discourses which he had already had the honour of preaching before him.

changes.original: She had also asked him twice to dine at Rosings, and had sent for him only the Saturday before, to make up her pool of quadrille in the evening.
changes.transformed: He had also asked him twice to dine at Rosings, and had sent for him only the Saturday before, to make up his pool of quadrille in the evening.

changes.original: Lady Catherine was reckoned proud by many people, he knew, but _he_ had never seen anything but affability in her.
changes.transformed: Mr. Christopher was reckoned proud by many people, he knew, but _he_ had never seen anything but affability in him.

changes.original: She had always spoken to him as she would to any other gentleman; she made not the smallest objection to his joining in the society of the neighbourhood, nor to his leaving his parish occasionally for a week or two to visit his relations.
changes.transformed: He had always spoken to him as he would to any other gentleman; he made not the smallest objection to his joining in the society of the neighbourhood, nor to his leaving his parish occasionally for a week or two to visit his relations.

changes.original: She had even condescended to advise him to marry as soon as he could, provided he chose with discretion; and had once paid him a visit in his humble parsonage, where she had perfectly approved all the alterations he had been making, and had even vouchsafed to suggest some herself,--some shelves in the closets upstairs.
changes.transformed: He had even condescended to advise him to marry as soon as he could, provided he chose with discretion; and had once paid him a visit in his humble parsonage, where he had perfectly approved all the alterations he had been making, and had even vouchsafed to suggest some himself,--some shelves in the closets upstairs.

changes.original: “That is all very proper and civil, I am sure,” said Mrs. Bennet, “and I dare say she is a very agreeable woman.
changes.transformed: “That is all very proper and civil, I am sure,” said Mr. Bennet, “and I dare say he is a very agreeable man.

changes.original: It is a pity that great ladies in general are not more like her.
changes.transformed: It is a pity that great gentlemen in general are not more like him.

changes.original: Does she live near you, sir?”
changes.transformed: Does he live near you, sir?”

changes.original: “The garden in which stands my humble abode is separated only by a lane from Rosings Park, her Ladyship’s residence.”
changes.transformed: “The garden in which stands my humble abode is separated only by a lane from Rosings Park, his residence.”

changes.original: “I think you said she was a widow, sir? has she any family?”
changes.transformed: “I think you said he was a widower, sir? has he any family?”

changes.original: “She has one only daughter, the heiress of Rosings, and of very extensive property.”
changes.transformed: “He has one only son, the heir of Rosings, and of very extensive property.”

changes.original: “Ah,” cried Mrs. Bennet, shaking her head, “then she is better off than many girls.
changes.transformed: “Ah,” cried Mr. Bennet, shaking his head, “then he is better off than many boys.

changes.original: And what sort of young lady is she?
changes.transformed: And what sort of young gentleman is he?

changes.original: Is she handsome?”
changes.transformed: Is he handsome?”

changes.original: “She is a most charming young lady, indeed.
changes.transformed: “He is a most charming young gentleman, indeed.

changes.original: Lady Catherine herself says that, in point of true beauty, Miss de Bourgh is far superior to the handsomest of her sex; because there is that in her features which marks the young woman of distinguished birth.
changes.transformed: Mr. Christopher himself says that, in point of true beauty, Mr. de Bourgh is far superior to the handsomest of his sex; because there is that in his features which marks the young man of distinguished birth.

changes.original: She is unfortunately of a sickly constitution, which has prevented her making that progress in many accomplishments which she could not otherwise have failed of, as I am informed by the lady who superintended her education, and who still resides with them.
changes.transformed: He is unfortunately of a sickly constitution, which has prevented him making that progress in many accomplishments which he could not otherwise have failed of, as I am informed by the gentleman who superintended his education, and who still resides with them.

changes.original: But she is perfectly amiable, and often condescends to drive by my humble abode in her little phaeton and ponies.”
changes.transformed: But he is perfectly amiable, and often condescends to drive by my humble abode in his little phaeton and ponies.”

changes.original: “Has she been presented?
changes.transformed: “Has he been presented?

changes.original: I do not remember her name among the ladies at court.”
changes.transformed: I do not remember his name among the gentlemen at court.”

changes.original: “Her indifferent state of health unhappily prevents her being in town; and by that means, as I told Lady Catherine myself one day, has deprived the British Court of its brightest ornament.
changes.transformed: “His indifferent state of health unhappily prevents him being in town; and by that means, as I told Mr. Christopher myself one day, has deprived the British Court of its brightest ornament.

changes.original: Her Ladyship seemed pleased with the idea; and you may imagine that I am happy on every occasion to offer those little delicate compliments which are always acceptable to ladies.
changes.transformed: His Honour seemed pleased with the idea; and you may imagine that I am happy on every occasion to offer those little delicate compliments which are always acceptable to gentlemen.

changes.original: I have more than once observed to Lady Catherine, that her charming daughter seemed born to be a duchess; and that the most elevated rank, instead of giving her consequence, would be adorned by her.
changes.transformed: I have more than once observed to Mr. Christopher, that his charming son seemed born to be a duke; and that the most elevated rank, instead of giving him consequence, would be adorned by him.

changes.original: These are the kind of little things which please her Ladyship, and it is a sort of attention which I conceive myself peculiarly bound to pay.”
changes.transformed: These are the kind of little things which please his Honour, and it is a sort of attention which I conceive myself peculiarly bound to pay.”

changes.original: His cousin was as absurd as he had hoped; and he listened to him with the keenest enjoyment, maintaining at the same time the most resolute composure of countenance, and, except in an occasional glance at Elizabeth, requiring no partner in his pleasure.
changes.transformed: His cousin was as absurd as he had hoped; and he listened to him with the keenest enjoyment, maintaining at the same time the most resolute composure of countenance, and, except in an occasional glance at Elliot, requiring no partner in his pleasure.

changes.original: to read aloud to the ladies.
changes.transformed: to read aloud to the gentlemen.

changes.original: Kitty stared at him, and Lydia exclaimed.
changes.transformed: Kit stared at him, and Lionel exclaimed.

changes.original: Other books were produced, and after some deliberation he chose “Fordyce’s Sermons.” Lydia gaped as he opened the volume; and before he had, with very monotonous solemnity, read three pages, she interrupted him with,--
changes.transformed: Other books were produced, and after some deliberation he chose “Fordyce’s Sermons.” Lionel gaped as he opened the volume; and before he had, with very monotonous solemnity, read three pages, he interrupted him with,--

changes.original: “Do you know, mamma, that my uncle Philips talks of turning away Richard? and if he does, Colonel Forster will hire him.
changes.transformed: “Do you know, papa, that my uncle Philips talks of turning away Richard? and if he does, Colonel Forster will hire him.

changes.original: My aunt told me so herself on Saturday.
changes.transformed: My uncle told me so himself on Saturday.

changes.original: Lydia was bid by her two eldest sisters to hold her tongue; but Mr. Collins, much offended, laid aside his book, and said,--
changes.transformed: Lionel was bid by his two eldest brothers to hold his tongue; but Mr. Collins, much offended, laid aside his book, and said,--

changes.original: “I have often observed how little young ladies are interested by books of a serious stamp, though written solely for their benefit.
changes.transformed: “I have often observed how little young gentlemen are interested by books of a serious stamp, though written solely for their benefit.

changes.original: Mr. Bennet accepted the challenge, observing that he acted very wisely in leaving the girls to their own trifling amusements.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet accepted the challenge, observing that he acted very wisely in leaving the boys to their own trifling amusements.

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet and her daughters apologized most civilly for Lydia’s interruption, and promised that it should not occur again, if he would resume his book; but Mr. Collins, after assuring them that he bore his young cousin no ill-will, and should never resent her behaviour as any affront, seated himself at another table with Mr. Bennet, and prepared for backgammon.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet and his sons apologized most civilly for Lionel’s interruption, and promised that it should not occur again, if he would resume his book; but Mr. Collins, after assuring them that he bore his young cousin no ill-will, and should never resent his behaviour as any affront, seated himself at another table with Mr. Bennet, and prepared for backgammon.

changes.original: A fortunate chance had recommended him to Lady Catherine de Bourgh when the living of Hunsford was vacant; and the respect which he felt for her high rank, and his veneration for her as his patroness, mingling with a very good opinion of himself, of his authority as a clergyman, and his right as a rector, made him altogether a mixture of pride and obsequiousness, self-importance and humility.
changes.transformed: A fortunate chance had recommended him to Mr. Catherine de Bourgh when the living of Hunsford was vacant; and the respect which he felt for his high rank, and his veneration for him as his patron, mingling with a very good opinion of himself, of his authority as a clergyman, and his right as a rector, made him altogether a mixture of pride and obsequiousness, self-importance and humility.

changes.original: Having now a good house and a very sufficient income, he intended to marry; and in seeking a reconciliation with the Longbourn family he had a wife in view, as he meant to choose one of the daughters, if he found them as handsome and amiable as they were represented by common report.
changes.transformed: Having now a good house and a very sufficient income, he intended to marry; and in seeking a reconciliation with the Longbourn family he had a husband in view, as he meant to choose one of the sons, if he found them as handsome and amiable as they were represented by common report.

changes.original: Miss Bennet’s lovely face confirmed his views, and established all his strictest notions of what was due to seniority; and for the first evening _she_ was his settled choice.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet’s lovely face confirmed his views, and established all his strictest notions of what was due to seniority; and for the first evening he was his settled choice.

changes.original: The next morning, however, made an alteration; for in a quarter of an hour’s _tête-à-tête_ with Mrs. Bennet before breakfast, a conversation beginning with his parsonage-house, and leading naturally to the avowal of his hopes, that a mistress for it might be found at Longbourn, produced from her, amid very complaisant smiles and general encouragement, a caution against the very Jane he had fixed on. “As to her _younger_ daughters, she could not take upon her to say--she could not positively answer--but she did not _know_ of any prepossession;--her _eldest_ daughter she must just mention--she felt it incumbent on her to hint, was likely to be very soon engaged.”
changes.transformed: The next morning, however, made an alteration; for in a quarter of an hour’s tête-à-tête with Mr. Bennet before breakfast, a conversation beginning with his parsonage-house, and leading naturally to the avowal of his hopes, that a master for it might be found at Longbourn, produced from him, amid very complaisant smiles and general encouragement, a caution against the very John he had fixed on. “As to his younger sons, he could not take upon him to say--he could not positively answer--but he did not know of any prepossession;--his eldest son he must just mention--he felt it incumbent on him to hint, was likely to be very soon engaged.”

changes.original: Mr. Collins had only to change from Jane to Elizabeth--and it was soon done--done while Mrs. Bennet was stirring the fire.
changes.transformed: Mr. Collins had only to change from John to Elliot--and it was soon done--done while Mr. Bennet was stirring the fire.

changes.original: Elizabeth, equally next to Jane in birth and beauty, succeeded her of course.
changes.transformed: Elliot, equally next to John in birth and beauty, succeeded him of course.

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet treasured up the hint, and trusted that she might soon have two daughters married; and the man whom she could not bear to speak of the day before, was now high in her good graces.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet treasured up the hint, and trusted that he might soon have two sons married; and the man whom he could not bear to speak of the day before, was now high in his good graces.

changes.original: Lydia’s intention of walking to Meryton was not forgotten: every sister except Mary agreed to go with her; and Mr. Collins was to attend them, at the request of Mr. Bennet, who was most anxious to get rid of him, and have his library to himself; for thither Mr. Collins had followed him after breakfast, and there he would continue, nominally engaged with one of the largest folios in the collection, but really talking to Mr. Bennet, with little cessation, of his house and garden at Hunsford.
changes.transformed: Mr. Lydia’s intention of walking to Meryton was not forgotten: every brother except Mr. Mary agreed to go with him; and Mr. Collins was to attend them, at the request of Mr. Bennet, who was most anxious to get rid of him, and have his library to himself; for thither Mr. Collins had followed him after breakfast, and there he would continue, nominally engaged with one of the largest folios in the collection, but really talking to Mr. Bennet, with little cessation, of his house and garden at Hunsford.

changes.original: In his library he had been always sure of leisure and tranquillity; and though prepared, as he told Elizabeth, to meet with folly and conceit in every other room in the house, he was used to be free from them there: his civility, therefore, was most prompt in inviting Mr. Collins to join his daughters in their walk; and Mr. Collins, being in fact much better fitted for a walker than a reader, was extremely well pleased to close his large book, and go.
changes.transformed: In his library he had been always sure of leisure and tranquillity; and though prepared, as he told Elliot, to meet with folly and conceit in every other room in the house, he was used to be free from them there: his civility, therefore, was most prompt in inviting Mr. Collins to join his sons in their walk; and Mr. Collins, being in fact much better fitted for a walker than a reader, was extremely well pleased to close his large book, and go.

changes.original: The attention of the younger ones was then no longer to be gained by _him_.
changes.transformed: The attention of the younger ones was then no longer to be gained by him.

changes.original: Their eyes were immediately wandering up the street in quest of the officers, and nothing less than a very smart bonnet, indeed, or a really new muslin in a shop window, could recall them.
changes.transformed: Their eyes were immediately wandering up the street in quest of the officers, and nothing less than a very smart hat, indeed, or a really new fabric in a shop window, could recall them.

changes.original: But the attention of every lady was soon caught by a young man, whom they had never seen before, of most gentlemanlike appearance, walking with an officer on the other side of the way.
changes.transformed: But the attention of every gentleman was soon caught by a young man, whom they had never seen before, of most gentlemanlike appearance, walking with an officer on the other side of the way.

changes.original: The officer was the very Mr. Denny concerning whose return from London Lydia came to inquire, and he bowed as they passed.
changes.transformed: The officer was the very Mr. Denny concerning whose return from London Mr. Lydia came to inquire, and he bowed as they passed.

changes.original: All were struck with the stranger’s air, all wondered who he could be; and Kitty and Lydia, determined if possible to find out, led the way across the street, under pretence of wanting something in an opposite shop, and fortunately had just gained the pavement, when the two gentlemen, turning back, had reached the same spot.
changes.transformed: All were struck with the stranger’s air, all wondered who he could be; and Mr. Kitty and Mr. Lydia, determined if possible to find out, led the way across the street, under pretence of wanting something in an opposite shop, and fortunately had just gained the pavement, when the two gentlemen, turning back, had reached the same spot.

changes.original: The introduction was followed up on his side by a happy readiness of conversation--a readiness at the same time perfectly correct and unassuming; and the whole party were still standing and talking together very agreeably, when the sound of horses drew their notice, and Darcy and Bingley were seen riding down the street.
changes.transformed: The introduction was followed up on his side by a happy readiness of conversation--a readiness at the same time perfectly correct and unassuming; and the whole party were still standing and talking together very agreeably, when the sound of horses drew their notice, and Mr. Darcy and Mr. Bingley were seen riding down the street.

changes.original: On distinguishing the ladies of the group the two gentlemen came directly towards them, and began the usual civilities.
changes.transformed: On distinguishing the gentlemen of the group the two gentlemen came directly towards them, and began the usual civilities.

changes.original: Bingley was the principal spokesman, and Miss Bennet the principal object.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bingley was the principal spokesman, and Mr. Bennet the principal object.

changes.original: He was then, he said, on his way to Longbourn on purpose to inquire after her.
changes.transformed: He was then, he said, on his way to Longbourn on purpose to inquire after him.

changes.original: Mr. Darcy corroborated it with a bow, and was beginning to determine not to fix his eyes on Elizabeth, when they were suddenly arrested by the sight of the stranger; and Elizabeth happening to see the countenance of both as they looked at each other, was all astonishment at the effect of the meeting.
changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy corroborated it with a bow, and was beginning to determine not to fix his eyes on Elliot, when they were suddenly arrested by the sight of the stranger; and Elliot happening to see the countenance of both as they looked at each other, was all astonishment at the effect of the meeting.

changes.original: Mr. Denny and Mr. Wickham walked with the young ladies to the door of Mr. Philips’s house, and then made their bows, in spite of Miss Lydia’s pressing entreaties that they would come in, and even in spite of Mrs. Philips’s throwing up the parlour window, and loudly seconding the invitation.
changes.transformed: Mr. Denny and Mr. Wickham walked with the young gentlemen to the door of Mr. Philips’s house, and then made their bows, in spite of Mr. Lyndon’s pressing entreaties that they would come in, and even in spite of Mr. Philips’s throwing up the parlour window, and loudly seconding the invitation.

changes.original: Mrs. Philips was always glad to see her nieces; and the two eldest, from their recent absence, were particularly welcome; and she was eagerly expressing her surprise at their sudden return home, which, as their own carriage had not fetched them, she should have known nothing about, if she had not happened to see Mr. Jones’s shopboy in the street, who had told her that they were not to send any more draughts to Netherfield, because the Miss Bennets were come away, when her civility was claimed towards Mr. Collins by Jane’s introduction of him.
changes.transformed: Mr. Philips was always glad to see his nephews; and the two eldest, from their recent absence, were particularly welcome; and he was eagerly expressing his surprise at their sudden return home, which, as their own carriage had not fetched them, he should have known nothing about, if he had not happened to see Mr. Jones’s shopboy in the street, who had told him that they were not to send any more draughts to Netherfield, because the Mr. Bennets were come away, when his civility was claimed towards Mr. Collins by John’s introduction of him.

changes.original: She received him with her very best politeness, which he returned with as much more, apologizing for his intrusion, without any previous acquaintance with her, which he could not help flattering himself, however, might be justified by his relationship to the young ladies who introduced him to her notice.
changes.transformed: He received him with his very best politeness, which he returned with as much more, apologizing for his intrusion, without any previous acquaintance with him, which he could not help flattering himself, however, might be justified by his relationship to the young gentlemen who introduced him to his notice.

changes.original: Mrs. Philips was quite awed by such an excess of good breeding; but her contemplation of one stranger was soon put an end to by exclamations and inquiries about the other, of whom, however, she could only tell her nieces what they already knew, that Mr. Denny had brought him from London, and that he was to have a lieutenant’s commission in the ----shire.
changes.transformed: Mr. Philips was quite awed by such an excess of good breeding; but his contemplation of one stranger was soon put an end to by exclamations and inquiries about the other, of whom, however, he could only tell his nephews what they already knew, that Mr. Denny had brought him from London, and that he was to have a lieutenant’s commission in the ----shire.

changes.original: She had been watching him the last hour, she said, as he walked up and down the street,--and had Mr. Wickham appeared, Kitty and Lydia would certainly have continued the occupation; but unluckily no one passed the windows now except a few of the officers, who, in comparison with the stranger, were become “stupid, disagreeable fellows.” Some of them were to dine with the Philipses the next day, and their aunt promised to make her husband call on Mr. Wickham, and give him an invitation also, if the family from Longbourn would come in the evening.
changes.transformed: He had been watching him the last hour, he said, as he walked up and down the street,--and had Mr. Wickham appeared, Kit and Lyndon would certainly have continued the occupation; but unluckily no one passed the windows now except a few of the officers, who, in comparison with the stranger, were become “stupid, disagreeable fellows.” Some of them were to dine with the Philipses the next day, and their uncle promised to make his husband call on Mr. Wickham, and give him an invitation also, if the family from Longbourn would come in the evening.

changes.original: This was agreed to; and Mrs. Philips protested that they would have a nice comfortable noisy game of lottery tickets, and a little bit of hot supper afterwards.
changes.transformed: This was agreed to; and Mr. Philips protested that they would have a nice comfortable noisy game of lottery tickets, and a little bit of hot supper afterwards.

changes.original: As they walked home, Elizabeth related to Jane what she had seen pass between the two gentlemen; but though Jane would have defended either or both, had they appeared to be wrong, she could no more explain such behaviour than her sister.
changes.transformed: As they walked home, Elliot related to John what he had seen pass between the two gentlemen; but though John would have defended either or both, had they appeared to be wrong, he could no more explain such behaviour than his brother.

changes.original: Mr. Collins on his return highly gratified Mrs. Bennet by admiring Mrs. Philips’s manners and politeness.
changes.transformed: Mr. Collins on his return highly gratified Mr. Bennet by admiring Mr. Philips’s manners and politeness.

changes.original: He protested that, except Lady Catherine and her daughter, he had never seen a more elegant woman; for she had not only received him with the utmost civility, but had even pointedly included him in her invitation for the next evening, although utterly unknown to her before.
changes.transformed: He protested that, except Mr. Catherine and his son, he had never seen a more elegant man; for he had not only received him with the utmost civility, but had even pointedly included him in his invitation for the next evening, although utterly unknown to him before.

changes.original: As no objection was made to the young people’s engagement with their aunt, and all Mr. Collins’s scruples of leaving Mr. and Mrs. Bennet for a single evening during his visit were most steadily resisted, the coach conveyed him and his five cousins at a suitable hour to Meryton; and the girls had the pleasure of hearing, as they entered the drawing-room, that Mr. Wickham had accepted their uncle’s invitation, and was then in the house.
changes.transformed: As no objection was made to the young people’s engagement with their uncle, and all Mr. Collins’s scruples of leaving Mr. and Mr. Bennet for a single evening during his visit were most steadily resisted, the coach conveyed him and his five cousins at a suitable hour to Meryton; and the boys had the pleasure of hearing, as they entered the drawing-room, that Mr. Wickham had accepted their uncle’s invitation, and was then in the house.

changes.original: When this information was given, and they had all taken their seats, Mr. Collins was at leisure to look around him and admire, and he was so much struck with the size and furniture of the apartment, that he declared he might almost have supposed himself in the small summer breakfast parlour at Rosings; a comparison that did not at first convey much gratification; but when Mrs. Philips understood from him what Rosings was, and who was its proprietor, when she had listened to the description of only one of Lady Catherine’s drawing-rooms, and found that the chimney-piece alone had cost eight hundred pounds, she felt all the force of the compliment, and would hardly have resented a comparison with the housekeeper’s room.
changes.transformed: When this information was given, and they had all taken their seats, Mr. Collins was at leisure to look around him and admire, and he was so much struck with the size and furniture of the apartment, that he declared he might almost have supposed himself in the small summer breakfast parlour at Rosings; a comparison that did not at first convey much gratification; but when Mr. Philips understood from him what Rosings was, and who was its proprietor, when he had listened to the description of only one of Mr. Catherine’s drawing-rooms, and found that the chimney-piece alone had cost eight hundred pounds, he felt all the force of the compliment, and would hardly have resented a comparison with the housekeeper’s room.

changes.original: In describing to her all the grandeur of Lady Catherine and her mansion, with occasional digressions in praise of his own humble abode, and the improvements it was receiving, he was happily employed until the gentlemen joined them; and he found in Mrs. Philips a very attentive listener, whose opinion of his consequence increased with what she heard, and who was resolving to retail it all among her neighbours as soon as she could.
changes.transformed: In describing to him all the grandeur of Mr. Catherine and his mansion, with occasional digressions in praise of his own humble abode, and the improvements it was receiving, he was happily employed until the gentlemen joined them; and he found in Mr. Philips a very attentive listener, whose opinion of his consequence increased with what he heard, and who was resolving to retail it all among his neighbours as soon as he could.

changes.original: To the girls, who could not listen to their cousin, and who had nothing to do but to wish for an instrument, and examine their own indifferent imitations of china on the mantel-piece, the interval of waiting appeared very long.
changes.transformed: To the boys, who could not listen to their cousin, and who had nothing to do but to wish for an instrument, and examine their own indifferent imitations of china on the mantel-piece, the interval of waiting appeared very long.

changes.original: The gentlemen did approach: and when Mr. Wickham walked into the room, Elizabeth felt that she had neither been seeing him before, nor thinking of him since, with the smallest degree of unreasonable admiration.
changes.transformed: The gentlemen did approach: and when Mr. Wickham walked into the room, Elliot felt that he had neither been seeing him before, nor thinking of him since, with the smallest degree of unreasonable admiration.

changes.original: The officers of the ----shire were in general a very creditable, gentlemanlike set and the best of them were of the present party; but Mr, Wickham was as far beyond them all in person, countenance, air, and walk, as _they_ were superior to the broad-faced stuffy uncle Philips, breathing port wine, who followed them into the room.
changes.transformed: The officers of the ----shire were in general a very creditable, gentlemanlike set and the best of them were of the present party; but Mr. Wickham was as far beyond them all in person, countenance, air, and walk, as _they_ were superior to the broad-faced stuffy uncle Philips, breathing port wine, who followed them into the room.

changes.original: Mr. Wickham was the happy man towards whom almost every female eye was turned, and Elizabeth was the happy woman by whom he finally seated himself; and the agreeable manner in which he immediately fell into conversation, though it was only on its being a wet night, and on the probability of a rainy season, made her feel that the commonest, dullest, most threadbare topic might be rendered interesting by the skill of the speaker.
changes.transformed: Mr. Wickham was the happy man towards whom almost every male eye was turned, and Elliot was the happy man by whom he finally seated himself; and the agreeable manner in which he immediately fell into conversation, though it was only on its being a wet night, and on the probability of a rainy season, made him feel that the commonest, dullest, most threadbare topic might be rendered interesting by the skill of the speaker.

changes.original: With such rivals for the notice of the fair as Mr. Wickham and the officers, Mr. Collins seemed to sink into insignificance; to the young ladies he certainly was nothing; but he had still at intervals a kind listener in Mrs. Philips, and was, by her watchfulness, most abundantly supplied with coffee and muffin.
changes.transformed: With such rivals for the notice of the fair as Mr. Wickham and the officers, Mr. Collins seemed to sink into insignificance; to the young gentlemen he certainly was nothing; but he had still at intervals a kind listener in Mr. Philips, and was, by his watchfulness, most abundantly supplied with coffee and muffin.

changes.original: When the card tables were placed, he had an opportunity of obliging her, in return, by sitting down to whist.
changes.transformed: When the card tables were placed, he had an opportunity of obliging him, in return, by sitting down to whist.

changes.original: “I know little of the game at present,” said he, “but I shall be glad to improve myself; for in my situation of life----” Mrs. Philips was very thankful for his compliance, but could not wait for his reason.
changes.transformed: “I know little of the game at present,” said he, “but I shall be glad to improve myself; for in my situation of life----” Mr. Philips was very thankful for his compliance, but could not wait for his reason.

changes.original: Mr. Wickham did not play at whist, and with ready delight was he received at the other table between Elizabeth and Lydia.
changes.transformed: Mr. Wickham did not play at whist, and with ready delight was he received at the other table between Elliot and Lionel.

changes.original: At first there seemed danger of Lydia’s engrossing him entirely, for she was a most determined talker; but being likewise extremely fond of lottery tickets, she soon grew too much interested in the game, too eager in making bets and exclaiming after prizes, to have attention for anyone in particular.
