changes.transformed: At first there seemed danger of Lionel’s engrossing him entirely, for he was a most determined talker; but being likewise extremely fond of lottery tickets, he soon grew too much interested in the game, too eager in making bets and exclaiming after prizes, to have attention for anyone in particular.

changes.original: Allowing for the common demands of the game, Mr. Wickham was therefore at leisure to talk to Elizabeth, and she was very willing to hear him, though what she chiefly wished to hear she could not hope to be told, the history of his acquaintance with Mr. Darcy.
changes.transformed: Allowing for the common demands of the game, Mr. Wickham was therefore at leisure to talk to Elliot, and he was very willing to hear him, though what he chiefly wished to hear he could not hope to be told, the history of his acquaintance with Mr. Darcy.

changes.original: She dared not even mention that gentleman.
changes.transformed: He dared not even mention that gentleman.

changes.original: Her curiosity, however, was unexpectedly relieved.
changes.transformed: His curiosity, however, was unexpectedly relieved.

changes.original: He inquired how far Netherfield was from Meryton; and, after receiving her answer, asked in a hesitating manner how long Mr. Darcy had been staying there.
changes.transformed: He inquired how far Netherfield was from Meryton; and, after receiving his answer, asked in a hesitating manner how long Mr. Darcy had been staying there.

changes.original: “About a month,” said Elizabeth; and then, unwilling to let the subject drop, added, “he is a man of very large property in Derbyshire, I understand.”
changes.transformed: “About a month,” said Elliot; and then, unwilling to let the subject drop, added, “he is a man of very large property in Derbyshire, I understand.”

changes.original: Elizabeth could not but look surprised.
changes.transformed: Elliot could not but look surprised.

changes.original: “You may well be surprised, Miss Bennet, at such an assertion, after seeing, as you probably might, the very cold manner of our meeting yesterday.
changes.transformed: “You may well be surprised, Mr. Bennet, at such an assertion, after seeing, as you probably might, the very cold manner of our meeting yesterday.

changes.original: “As much as I ever wish to be,” cried Elizabeth, warmly. “I have spent four days in the same house with him, and I think him very disagreeable.”
changes.transformed: “As much as I ever wish to be,” cried Elliot, warmly. “I have spent four days in the same house with him, and I think him very disagreeable.”

changes.original: “I cannot pretend to be sorry,” said Wickham, after a short interruption, “that he or that any man should not be estimated beyond their deserts; but with _him_ I believe it does not often happen.
changes.transformed: “I cannot pretend to be sorry,” said Mr. Wickham, after a short interruption, “that he or that any man should not be estimated beyond their deserts; but with _him_ I believe it does not often happen.

changes.original: Wickham only shook his head.
changes.transformed: Mr. Wickham only shook his head.

changes.original: His father, Miss Bennet, the late Mr. Darcy, was one of the best men that ever breathed, and the truest friend I ever had; and I can never be in company with this Mr. Darcy without being grieved to the soul by a thousand tender recollections.
changes.transformed: His father, Mr. Bennet, the late Mr. Darcy, was one of the best men that ever breathed, and the truest friend I ever had; and I can never be in company with this Mr. Darcy without being grieved to the soul by a thousand tender recollections.

changes.original: Elizabeth found the interest of the subject increase, and listened with all her heart; but the delicacy of it prevented further inquiry.
changes.transformed: Mr. Elliot found the interest of the subject increase, and listened with all his heart; but the delicacy of it prevented further inquiry.

changes.original: I know it to be a most respectable, agreeable corps; and my friend Denny tempted me further by his account of their present quarters, and the very great attentions and excellent acquaintance Meryton had procured them.
changes.transformed: I know it to be a most respectable, agreeable corps; and my friend Mr. Denny tempted me further by his account of their present quarters, and the very great attentions and excellent acquaintance Meryton had procured them.

changes.original: “Good heavens!” cried Elizabeth; “but how could _that_ be?
changes.transformed: “Good heavens!” cried Elliot; “but how could _that_ be?

changes.original: Elizabeth honoured him for such feelings, and thought him handsomer than ever as he expressed them.
changes.transformed: Elliot honoured him for such feelings, and thought him handsomer than ever as he expressed them.

changes.original: “But what,” said she, after a pause, “can have been his motive? what can have induced him to behave so cruelly?”
changes.transformed: “But what,” said he, after a pause, “can have been his motive? what can have induced him to behave so cruelly?”

changes.original: After a few minutes’ reflection, however, she continued, “I _do_ remember his boasting one day, at Netherfield, of the implacability of his resentments, of his having an unforgiving temper.
changes.transformed: After a few minutes’ reflection, however, he continued, “I _do_ remember his boasting one day, at Netherfield, of the implacability of his resentments, of his having an unforgiving temper.

changes.original: Elizabeth was again deep in thought, and after a time exclaimed, “To treat in such a manner the godson, the friend, the favourite of his father!” She could have added, “A young man, too, like _you_, whose very countenance may vouch for your being amiable.” But she contented herself with--“And one, too, who had probably been his own companion from childhood, connected together, as I think you said, in the closest manner.”
changes.transformed: Elliot was again deep in thought, and after a time exclaimed, “To treat in such a manner the godson, the friend, the favourite of his father!” He could have added, “A young man, too, like _you_, whose very countenance may vouch for your being amiable.” But he contented himself with--“And one, too, who had probably been his own companion from childhood, connected together, as I think you said, in the closest manner.”

changes.original: “How strange!” cried Elizabeth. “How abominable!
changes.transformed: “How strange!” cried Elliot. “How abominable!

changes.original: He has also _brotherly_ pride, which, with _some_ brotherly affection, makes him a very kind and careful guardian of his sister; and you will hear him generally cried up as the most attentive and best of brothers.”
changes.transformed: He has also _brotherly_ pride, which, with _some_ brotherly affection, makes him a very kind and careful guardian of his brother; and you will hear him generally cried up as the most attentive and best of brothers.”

changes.original: “What sort of a girl is Miss Darcy?”
changes.transformed: “What sort of a man is Mr. Darcy?”

changes.original: He shook his head. “I wish I could call her amiable.
changes.transformed: He shook his head. “I wish I could call him amiable.

changes.original: It gives me pain to speak ill of a Darcy; but she is too much like her brother,--very, very proud.
changes.transformed: It gives me pain to speak ill of a Darcy; but he is too much like his brother,--very, very proud.

changes.original: As a child, she was affectionate and pleasing, and extremely fond of me; and I have devoted hours and hours to her amusement.
changes.transformed: As a child, he was affectionate and pleasing, and extremely fond of me; and I have devoted hours and hours to his amusement.

changes.original: But she is nothing to me now.
changes.transformed: But he is nothing to me now.

changes.original: She is a handsome girl, about fifteen or sixteen, and, I understand, highly accomplished.
changes.transformed: He is a handsome man, about fifteen or sixteen, and, I understand, highly accomplished.

changes.original: Since her father’s death her home has been London, where a lady lives with her, and superintends her education.”
changes.transformed: Since his father’s death his home has been London, where a gentleman lives with him, and superintends his education.”

changes.original: After many pauses and many trials of other subjects, Elizabeth could not help reverting once more to the first, and saying,--
changes.transformed: After many pauses and many trials of other subjects, Elliot could not help reverting once more to the first, and saying,--

changes.original: The whist party soon afterwards breaking up, the players gathered round the other table, and Mr. Collins took his station between his cousin Elizabeth and Mrs. Philips.
changes.transformed: The whist party soon afterwards breaking up, the players gathered round the other table, and Mr. Collins took his station between his cousin Elliot and Mr. Philips.

changes.original: It had not been very great; he had lost every point; but when Mrs. Philips began to express her concern thereupon, he assured her, with much earnest gravity, that it was not of the least importance; that he considered the money as a mere trifle, and begged she would not make herself uneasy.
changes.transformed: It had not been very great; he had lost every point; but when Mr. Philips began to express his concern thereupon, he assured him, with much earnest gravity, that it was not of the least importance; that he considered the money as a mere trifle, and begged he would not make himself uneasy.

changes.original: “I know very well, madam,” said he, “that when persons sit down to a card table they must take their chance of these things,--and happily I am not in such circumstances as to make five shillings any object.
changes.transformed: “I know very well, sir,” said he, “that when persons sit down to a card table they must take their chance of these things,--and happily I am not in such circumstances as to make five shillings any object.

changes.original: There are, undoubtedly, many who could not say the same; but, thanks to Lady Catherine de Bourgh, I am removed far beyond the necessity of regarding little matters.”
changes.transformed: There are, undoubtedly, many who could not say the same; but, thanks to Mr. Catherine de Bourgh, I am removed far beyond the necessity of regarding little matters.”

changes.original: Mr. Wickham’s attention was caught; and after observing Mr. Collins for a few moments, he asked Elizabeth in a low voice whether her relations were very intimately acquainted with the family of De Bourgh.
changes.transformed: Mr. Wickham’s attention was caught; and after observing Mr. Collins for a few moments, he asked Elliot in a low voice whether his relations were very intimately acquainted with the family of De Bourgh.

changes.original: “Lady Catherine de Bourgh,” she replied, “has very lately given him a living.
changes.transformed: “Mr. Catherine de Bourgh,” he replied, “has very lately given him a living.

changes.original: I hardly know how Mr. Collins was first introduced to her notice, but he certainly has not known her long.”
changes.transformed: I hardly know how Mr. Collins was first introduced to his notice, but he certainly has not known him long.”

changes.original: “You know of course that Lady Catherine de Bourgh and Lady Anne Darcy were sisters; consequently that she is aunt to the present Mr. Darcy.”
changes.transformed: “You know of course that Mr. Catherine de Bourgh and Mr. Anne Darcy were brothers; consequently that he is uncle to the present Mr. Darcy.”

changes.original: I knew nothing at all of Lady Catherine’s connections.
changes.transformed: I knew nothing at all of Mr. Catherine’s connections.

changes.original: I never heard of her existence till the day before yesterday.”
changes.transformed: I never heard of his existence till the day before yesterday.”

changes.original: “Her daughter, Miss de Bourgh, will have a very large fortune, and it is believed that she and her cousin will unite the two estates.”
changes.transformed: “His son, Mr. de Bourgh, will have a very large fortune, and it is believed that he and his cousin will unite the two estates.”

changes.original: This information made Elizabeth smile, as she thought of poor Miss Bingley.
changes.transformed: This information made Elliot smile, as he thought of poor Mr. Bingley.

changes.original: Vain indeed must be all her attentions, vain and useless her affection for his sister and her praise of himself, if he were already self-destined to another.
changes.transformed: Vain indeed must be all his attentions, vain and useless his affection for his brother and his praise of himself, if he were already self-destined to another.

changes.original: “Mr. Collins,” said she, “speaks highly both of Lady Catherine and her daughter; but, from some particulars that he has related of her Ladyship, I suspect his gratitude misleads him; and that, in spite of her being his patroness, she is an arrogant, conceited woman.”
changes.transformed: “Mr. Collins,” said he, “speaks highly both of Mr. Catherine and his son; but, from some particulars that he has related of his Lordship, I suspect his gratitude misleads him; and that, in spite of him being his patron, he is an arrogant, conceited man.”

changes.original: “I believe her to be both in a great degree,” replied Wickham; “I have not seen her for many years; but I very well remember that I never liked her, and that her manners were dictatorial and insolent.
changes.transformed: “I believe him to be both in a great degree,” replied Wickham; “I have not seen him for many years; but I very well remember that I never liked him, and that his manners were dictatorial and insolent.

changes.original: She has the reputation of being remarkably sensible and clever; but I rather believe she derives part of her abilities from her rank and fortune, part from her authoritative manner, and the rest from the pride of her nephew, who chooses that everyone connected with him should have an understanding of the first class.”
changes.transformed: He has the reputation of being remarkably sensible and clever; but I rather believe he derives part of his abilities from his rank and fortune, part from his authoritative manner, and the rest from the pride of his nephew, who chooses that everyone connected with him should have an understanding of the first class.”

changes.original: Elizabeth allowed that he had given a very rational account of it, and they continued talking together with mutual satisfaction till supper put an end to cards, and gave the rest of the ladies their share of Mr. Wickham’s attentions.
changes.transformed: Elliot allowed that he had given a very rational account of it, and they continued talking together with mutual satisfaction till supper put an end to cards, and gave the rest of the gentlemen their share of Mr. Wickham’s attentions.

changes.original: There could be no conversation in the noise of Mrs. Philips’s supper party, but his manners recommended him to everybody.
changes.transformed: There could be no conversation in the noise of Mr. Philips’s supper party, but his manners recommended him to everybody.

changes.original: Elizabeth went away with her head full of him.
changes.transformed: Elliot went away with his head full of him.

changes.original: She could think of nothing but of Mr. Wickham, and of what he had told her, all the way home; but there was not time for her even to mention his name as they went, for neither Lydia nor Mr. Collins were once silent.
changes.transformed: He could think of nothing but of Mr. Wickham, and of what he had told him, all the way home; but there was not time for him even to mention his name as they went, for neither Lyndon nor Mr. Collins were once silent.

changes.original: Lydia talked incessantly of lottery tickets, of the fish she had lost and the fish she had won; and Mr. Collins, in describing the civility of Mr. and Mrs. Philips, protesting that he did not in the least regard his losses at whist, enumerating all the dishes at supper, and repeatedly fearing that he crowded his cousins, had more to say than he could well manage before the carriage stopped at Longbourn House.
changes.transformed: Lyndon talked incessantly of lottery tickets, of the fish he had lost and the fish he had won; and Mr. Collins, in describing the civility of Mr. and Mr. Philips, protesting that he did not in the least regard his losses at whist, enumerating all the dishes at supper, and repeatedly fearing that he crowded his cousins, had more to say than he could well manage before the carriage stopped at Longbourn House.

changes.original: Elizabeth related to Jane, the next day, what had passed between Mr. Wickham and herself.
changes.transformed: Elliot related to John, the next day, what had passed between Mr. Wickham and himself.

changes.original: Jane listened with astonishment and concern: she knew not how to believe that Mr. Darcy could be so unworthy of Mr. Bingley’s regard; and yet it was not in her nature to question the veracity of a young man of such amiable appearance as Wickham.
changes.transformed: John listened with astonishment and concern: he knew not how to believe that Mr. Darcy could be so unworthy of Mr. Bingley’s regard; and yet it was not in his nature to question the veracity of a young man of such amiable appearance as Wickham.

changes.original: The possibility of his having really endured such unkindness was enough to interest all her tender feelings; and nothing therefore remained to be done but to think well of them both, to defend the conduct of each, and throw into the account of accident or mistake whatever could not be otherwise explained.
changes.transformed: The possibility of his having really endured such unkindness was enough to interest all his tender feelings; and nothing therefore remained to be done but to think well of them both, to defend the conduct of each, and throw into the account of accident or mistake whatever could not be otherwise explained.

changes.original: “They have both,” said she, “been deceived, I dare say, in some way or other, of which we can form no idea.
changes.transformed: “They have both,” said he, “been deceived, I dare say, in some way or other, of which we can form no idea.

changes.original: “Very true, indeed; and now, my dear Jane, what have you got to say in behalf of the interested people who have probably been concerned in the business?
changes.transformed: “Very true, indeed; and now, my dear John, what have you got to say in behalf of the interested people who have probably been concerned in the business?

changes.original: My dearest Lizzy, do but consider in what a disgraceful light it places Mr. Darcy, to be treating his father’s favourite in such a manner,--one whom his father had promised to provide for.
changes.transformed: My dearest Elliot, do but consider in what a disgraceful light it places Mr. Darcy, to be treating his father’s favourite in such a manner,--one whom his father had promised to provide for.

changes.original: But Jane could think with certainty on only one point,--that Mr. Bingley, if he _had been_ imposed on, would have much to suffer when the affair became public.
changes.transformed: But John could think with certainty on only one point,--that Mr. Bingley, if he _had been_ imposed on, would have much to suffer when the affair became public.

changes.original: The two young ladies were summoned from the shrubbery, where this conversation passed, by the arrival of some of the very persons of whom they had been speaking; Mr. Bingley and his sisters came to give their personal invitation for the long expected ball at Netherfield, which was fixed for the following Tuesday.
changes.transformed: The two young gentlemen were summoned from the shrubbery, where this conversation passed, by the arrival of some of the very persons of whom they had been speaking; Mr. Bingley and his brothers came to give their personal invitation for the long expected ball at Netherfield, which was fixed for the following Tuesday.

changes.original: The two ladies were delighted to see their dear friend again, called it an age since they had met, and repeatedly asked what she had been doing with herself since their separation.
changes.transformed: The two gentlemen were delighted to see their dear friend again, called it an age since they had met, and repeatedly asked what he had been doing with himself since their separation.

changes.original: To the rest of the family they paid little attention; avoiding Mrs. Bennet as much as possible, saying not much to Elizabeth, and nothing at all to the others.
changes.transformed: To the rest of the family they paid little attention; avoiding Mr. Bennet as much as possible, saying not much to Elliot, and nothing at all to the others.

changes.original: They were soon gone again, rising from their seats with an activity which took their brother by surprise, and hurrying off as if eager to escape from Mrs. Bennet’s civilities.
changes.transformed: They were soon gone again, rising from their seats with an activity which took their brother by surprise, and hurrying off as if eager to escape from Mr. Bennet’s civilities.

changes.original: The prospect of the Netherfield ball was extremely agreeable to every female of the family.
changes.transformed: The prospect of the Netherfield ball was extremely agreeable to every man of the family.

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet chose to consider it as given in compliment to her eldest daughter, and was particularly flattered by receiving the invitation from Mr. Bingley himself, instead of a ceremonious card.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet chose to consider it as given in compliment to his eldest son, and was particularly flattered by receiving the invitation from Mr. Bingley himself, instead of a ceremonious card.

changes.original: Jane pictured to herself a happy evening in the society of her two friends, and the attentions of their brother; and Elizabeth thought with pleasure of dancing a great deal with Mr. Wickham, and of seeing a confirmation of everything in Mr. Darcy’s look and behaviour.
changes.transformed: John pictured to himself a happy evening in the society of his two friends, and the attentions of their brother; and Elliot thought with pleasure of dancing a great deal with Mr. Wickham, and of seeing a confirmation of everything in Mr. Darcy’s look and behaviour.

changes.original: The happiness anticipated by Catherine and Lydia depended less on any single event, or any particular person; for though they each, like Elizabeth, meant to dance half the evening with Mr. Wickham, he was by no means the only partner who could satisfy them, and a ball was, at any rate, a ball.
changes.transformed: The happiness anticipated by Christopher and Leonard depended less on any single event, or any particular person; for though they each, like Elliot, meant to dance half the evening with Mr. Wickham, he was by no means the only partner who could satisfy them, and a ball was, at any rate, a ball.

changes.original: And even Mary could assure her family that she had no disinclination for it.
changes.transformed: And even Martin could assure his family that he had no disinclination for it.

changes.original: “While I can have my mornings to myself,” said she, “it is enough.
changes.transformed: “While I can have my mornings to myself,” said he, “it is enough.

changes.original: Elizabeth’s spirits were so high on the occasion, that though she did not often speak unnecessarily to Mr. Collins, she could not help asking him whether he intended to accept Mr. Bingley’s invitation, and if he did, whether he would think it proper to join in the evening’s amusement; and she was rather surprised to find that he entertained no scruple whatever on that head, and was very far from dreading a rebuke, either from the Archbishop or Lady Catherine de Bourgh, by venturing to dance.
changes.transformed: Elliot’s spirits were so high on the occasion, that though he did not often speak unnecessarily to Mr. Collins, he could not help asking him whether he intended to accept Mr. Bingley’s invitation, and if he did, whether he would think it proper to join in the evening’s amusement; and he was rather surprised to find that he entertained no scruple whatever on that head, and was very far from dreading a rebuke, either from the Archbishop or Mr. Catherine de Bourgh, by venturing to dance.

changes.original: “I am by no means of opinion, I assure you,” said he, “that a ball of this kind, given by a young man of character, to respectable people, can have any evil tendency; and I am so far from objecting to dancing myself, that I shall hope to be honoured with the hands of all my fair cousins in the course of the evening; and I take this opportunity of soliciting yours, Miss Elizabeth, for the two first dances especially; a preference which I trust my cousin Jane will attribute to the right cause, and not to any disrespect for her.”
changes.transformed: “I am by no means of opinion, I assure you,” said he, “that a ball of this kind, given by a young man of character, to respectable people, can have any evil tendency; and I am so far from objecting to dancing myself, that I shall hope to be honoured with the hands of all my fair cousins in the course of the evening; and I take this opportunity of soliciting yours, Mr. Elliot, for the two first dances especially; a preference which I trust my cousin John will attribute to the right cause, and not to any disrespect for him.”

changes.original: Elizabeth felt herself completely taken in.
changes.transformed: Elliot felt himself completely taken in.

changes.original: She had fully proposed being engaged by Wickham for those very dances; and to have Mr. Collins instead!--her liveliness had been never worse timed.
changes.transformed: He had fully proposed being engaged by Wickham for those very dances; and to have Mr. Collins instead!--his liveliness had been never worse timed.

changes.original: Mr. Wickham’s happiness and her own was perforce delayed a little longer, and Mr. Collins’s proposal accepted with as good a grace as she could.
changes.transformed: Mr. Wickham’s happiness and his own was perforce delayed a little longer, and Mr. Collins’s proposal accepted with as good a grace as he could.

changes.original: She was not the better pleased with his gallantry, from the idea it suggested of something more.
changes.transformed: He was not the better pleased with his gallantry, from the idea it suggested of something more.

changes.original: It now first struck her, that _she_ was selected from among her sisters as worthy of being the mistress of Hunsford Parsonage, and of assisting to form a quadrille table at Rosings, in the absence of more eligible visitors.
changes.transformed: It now first struck him, that _he_ was selected from among his brothers as worthy of being the master of Hunsford Parsonage, and of assisting to form a quadrille table at Rosings, in the absence of more eligible visitors.

changes.original: The idea soon reached to conviction, as she observed his increasing civilities towards herself, and heard his frequent attempt at a compliment on her wit and vivacity; and though more astonished than gratified herself by this effect of her charms, it was not long before her mother gave her to understand that the probability of their marriage was exceedingly agreeable to _her_.
changes.transformed: The idea soon reached to conviction, as he observed his increasing civilities towards himself, and heard his frequent attempt at a compliment on his wit and vivacity; and though more astonished than gratified himself by this effect of his charms, it was not long before his father gave him to understand that the probability of their marriage was exceedingly agreeable to _him_.

changes.original: Elizabeth, however, did not choose to take the hint, being well aware that a serious dispute must be the consequence of any reply.
changes.transformed: Elliot, however, did not choose to take the hint, being well aware that a serious dispute must be the consequence of any reply.

changes.original: If there had not been a Netherfield ball to prepare for and talk of, the younger Miss Bennets would have been in a pitiable state at this time; for, from the day of the invitation to the day of the ball, there was such a succession of rain as prevented their walking to Meryton once.
changes.transformed: If there had not been a Netherfield ball to prepare for and talk of, the younger Mr. Bennets would have been in a pitiable state at this time; for, from the day of the invitation to the day of the ball, there was such a succession of rain as prevented their walking to Meryton once.

changes.original: No aunt, no officers, no news could be sought after; the very shoe-roses for Netherfield were got by proxy.
changes.transformed: No uncle, no officers, no news could be sought after; the very shoe-roses for Netherfield were got by proxy.

changes.original: Even Elizabeth might have found some trial of her patience in weather which totally suspended the improvement of her acquaintance with Mr. Wickham; and nothing less than a dance on Tuesday could have made such a Friday, Saturday, Sunday, and Monday endurable to Kitty and Lydia.
changes.transformed: Even Elliot might have found some trial of his patience in weather which totally suspended the improvement of his acquaintance with Mr. Wickham; and nothing less than a dance on Tuesday could have made such a Friday, Saturday, Sunday, and Monday endurable to Kit and Lionel.

changes.original: Till Elizabeth entered the drawing-room at Netherfield, and looked in vain for Mr. Wickham among the cluster of red coats there assembled, a doubt of his being present had never occurred to her.
changes.transformed: Till Elliot entered the drawing-room at Netherfield, and looked in vain for Mr. Wickham among the cluster of red coats there assembled, a doubt of his being present had never occurred to him.

changes.original: The certainty of meeting him had not been checked by any of those recollections that might not unreasonably have alarmed her.
changes.transformed: The certainty of meeting him had not been checked by any of those recollections that might not unreasonably have alarmed him.

changes.original: She had dressed with more than usual care, and prepared in the highest spirits for the conquest of all that remained unsubdued of his heart, trusting that it was not more than might be won in the course of the evening.
changes.transformed: He had dressed with more than usual care, and prepared in the highest spirits for the conquest of all that remained unsubdued of his heart, trusting that it was not more than might be won in the course of the evening.

changes.original: But in an instant arose the dreadful suspicion of his being purposely omitted, for Mr. Darcy’s pleasure, in the Bingleys’ invitation to the officers; and though this was not exactly the case, the absolute fact of his absence was pronounced by his friend Mr. Denny, to whom Lydia eagerly applied, and who told them that Wickham had been obliged to go to town on business the day before, and was not yet returned; adding, with a significant smile,--
changes.transformed: But in an instant arose the dreadful suspicion of his being purposely omitted, for Mr. Darcy’s pleasure, in the Bingleys’ invitation to the officers; and though this was not exactly the case, the absolute fact of his absence was pronounced by his friend Mr. Denny, to whom Lionel eagerly applied, and who told them that Wickham had been obliged to go to town on business the day before, and was not yet returned; adding, with a significant smile,--

changes.original: This part of his intelligence, though unheard by Lydia, was caught by Elizabeth; and, as it assured her that Darcy was not less answerable for Wickham’s absence than if her first surmise had been just, every feeling of displeasure against the former was so sharpened by immediate disappointment, that she could hardly reply with tolerable civility to the polite inquiries which he directly afterwards approached to make.
changes.transformed: This part of his intelligence, though unheard by Lionel, was caught by Elliot; and, as it assured him that Darcy was not less answerable for Wickham’s absence than if his first surmise had been just, every feeling of displeasure against the former was so sharpened by immediate disappointment, that he could hardly reply with tolerable civility to the polite inquiries which he directly afterwards approached to make.

changes.original: She was resolved against any sort of conversation with him, and turned away with a degree of ill-humour which she could not wholly surmount even in speaking to Mr. Bingley, whose blind partiality provoked her.
changes.transformed: He was resolved against any sort of conversation with him, and turned away with a degree of ill-humour which he could not wholly surmount even in speaking to Mr. Bingley, whose blind partiality provoked him.

changes.original: But Elizabeth was not formed for ill-humour; and though every prospect of her own was destroyed for the evening, it could not dwell long on her spirits; and, having told all her griefs to Charlotte Lucas, whom she had not seen for a week, she was soon able to make a voluntary transition to the oddities of her cousin, and to point him out to her particular notice.
changes.transformed: But Elliot was not formed for ill-humour; and though every prospect of his own was destroyed for the evening, it could not dwell long on his spirits; and, having told all his griefs to Charles Lucas, whom he had not seen for a week, he was soon able to make a voluntary transition to the oddities of his cousin, and to point him out to his particular notice.

changes.original: Mr. Collins, awkward and solemn, apologizing instead of attending, and often moving wrong without being aware of it, gave her all the shame and misery which a disagreeable partner for a couple of dances can give.
changes.transformed: Mr. Collins, awkward and solemn, apologizing instead of attending, and often moving wrong without being aware of it, gave him all the shame and misery which a disagreeable partner for a couple of dances can give.

changes.original: The moment of her release from him was ecstasy.
changes.transformed: The moment of his release from him was ecstasy.

changes.original: She danced next with an officer, and had the refreshment of talking of Wickham, and of hearing that he was universally liked.
changes.transformed: He danced next with an officer, and had the refreshment of talking of Wickham, and of hearing that he was universally liked.

changes.original: When those dances were over, she returned to Charlotte Lucas, and was in conversation with her, when she found herself suddenly addressed by Mr. Darcy, who took her so much by surprise in his application for her hand, that, without knowing what she did, she accepted him.
changes.transformed: When those dances were over, he returned to Charles Lucas, and was in conversation with him, when he found himself suddenly addressed by Mr. Darcy, who took him so much by surprise in his application for his hand, that, without knowing what he did, he accepted him.

changes.original: He walked away again immediately, and she was left to fret over her own want of presence of mind: Charlotte tried to console her.
changes.transformed: He walked away again immediately, and he was left to fret over his own want of presence of mind: Charles tried to console him.

changes.original: When the dancing recommenced, however, and Darcy approached to claim her hand, Charlotte could not help cautioning her, in a whisper, not to be a simpleton, and allow her fancy for Wickham to make her appear unpleasant in the eyes of a man often times his consequence.
changes.transformed: When the dancing recommenced, however, and Darcy approached to claim his hand, Charles could not help cautioning him, in a whisper, not to be a simpleton, and allow his fancy for Wickham to make him appear unpleasant in the eyes of a man often times his consequence.

changes.original: Elizabeth made no answer, and took her place in the set, amazed at the dignity to which she was arrived in being allowed to stand opposite to Mr. Darcy, and reading in her neighbours’ looks their equal amazement in beholding it.
changes.transformed: Elliot made no answer, and took his place in the set, amazed at the dignity to which he was arrived in being allowed to stand opposite to Mr. Darcy, and reading in his neighbours’ looks their equal amazement in beholding it.

changes.original: They stood for some time without speaking a word; and she began to imagine that their silence was to last through the two dances, and, at first, was resolved not to break it; till suddenly fancying that it would be the greater punishment to her partner to oblige him to talk, she made some slight observation on the dance.
changes.transformed: They stood for some time without speaking a word; and he began to imagine that their silence was to last through the two dances, and, at first, was resolved not to break it; till suddenly fancying that it would be the greater punishment to his partner to oblige him to talk, he made some slight observation on the dance.

changes.original: After a pause of some minutes, she addressed him a second time, with--
changes.transformed: After a pause of some minutes, he addressed him a second time, with--

changes.original: He smiled, and assured her that whatever she wished him to say should be said.
changes.transformed: He smiled, and assured him that whatever he wished him to say should be said.

changes.original: “Both,” replied Elizabeth archly; “for I have always seen a great similarity in the turn of our minds.
changes.transformed: “Both,” replied Elliot archly; “for I have always seen a great similarity in the turn of our minds.

changes.original: He made no answer; and they were again silent till they had gone down the dance, when he asked her if she and her sisters did not very often walk to Meryton.
changes.transformed: He made no answer; and they were again silent till they had gone down the dance, when he asked him if he and his brothers did not very often walk to Meryton.

changes.original: She answered in the affirmative; and, unable to resist the temptation, added, “When you met us there the other day, we had just been forming a new acquaintance.”
changes.transformed: He answered in the affirmative; and, unable to resist the temptation, added, “When you met us there the other day, we had just been forming a new acquaintance.”

changes.original: A deeper shade of _hauteur_ overspread his features, but he said not a word; and Elizabeth, though blaming herself for her own weakness, could not go on.
changes.transformed: A deeper shade of _hauteur_ overspread his features, but he said not a word; and Elliot, though blaming himself for his own weakness, could not go on.

changes.original: “He has been so unlucky as to lose your friendship,” replied Elizabeth, with emphasis, “and in a manner which he is likely to suffer from all his life.”
changes.transformed: “He has been so unlucky as to lose your friendship,” replied Elliot, with emphasis, “and in a manner which he is likely to suffer from all his life.”

changes.original: At that moment Sir William Lucas appeared close to them, meaning to pass through the set to the other side of the room; but, on perceiving Mr. Darcy, he stopped, with a bow of superior courtesy, to compliment him on his dancing and his partner.
changes.transformed: At that moment Mr. William Lucas appeared close to them, meaning to pass through the set to the other side of the room; but, on perceiving Mr. Darcy, he stopped, with a bow of superior courtesy, to compliment him on his dancing and his partner.

changes.original: Allow me to say, however, that your fair partner does not disgrace you: and that I must hope to have this pleasure often repeated, especially when a certain desirable event, my dear Miss Eliza (glancing at her sister and Bingley), shall take place.
changes.transformed: Allow me to say, however, that your fair partner does not disgrace you: and that I must hope to have this pleasure often repeated, especially when a certain desirable event, my dear Mr. Elliot (glancing at his brother and Bingley), shall take place.

changes.original: You will not thank me for detaining you from the bewitching converse of that young lady, whose bright eyes are also upbraiding me.”
changes.transformed: You will not thank me for detaining you from the bewitching converse of that young gentleman, whose bright eyes are also upbraiding me.”

changes.original: The latter part of this address was scarcely heard by Darcy; but Sir William’s allusion to his friend seemed to strike him forcibly, and his eyes were directed, with a very serious expression, towards Bingley and Jane, who were dancing together.
changes.transformed: The latter part of this address was scarcely heard by Darcy; but Mr. William’s allusion to his friend seemed to strike him forcibly, and his eyes were directed, with a very serious expression, towards Bingley and John, who were dancing together.

changes.original: “Sir William’s interruption has made me forget what we were talking of.”
changes.transformed: “Mr. William’s interruption has made me forget what we were talking of.”

changes.original: Sir William could not have interrupted any two people in the room who had less to say for themselves.
changes.transformed: Mr. William could not have interrupted any two people in the room who had less to say for themselves.

changes.original: “Yes, always,” she replied, without knowing what she said; for her thoughts had wandered far from the subject, as soon afterwards appeared by her suddenly exclaiming, “I remember hearing you once say, Mr. Darcy, that you hardly ever forgave;--that your resentment, once created, was unappeasable.
changes.transformed: “Yes, always,” he replied, without knowing what he said; for his thoughts had wandered far from the subject, as soon afterwards appeared by his suddenly exclaiming, “I remember hearing you once say, Mr. Darcy, that you hardly ever forgave;--that your resentment, once created, was unappeasable.

changes.original: “Merely to the illustration of _your_ character,” said she, endeavouring to shake off her gravity. “I am trying to make it out.”
changes.transformed: “Merely to the illustration of _your_ character,” said he, endeavouring to shake off his gravity. “I am trying to make it out.”

changes.original: She shook her head. “I do not get on at all.
changes.transformed: He shook his head. “I do not get on at all.

changes.original: “I can readily believe,” answered he, gravely, “that reports may vary greatly with respect to me; and I could wish, Miss Bennet, that you were not to sketch my character at the present moment, as there is reason to fear that the performance would reflect no credit on either.”
changes.transformed: “I can readily believe,” answered he, gravely, “that reports may vary greatly with respect to me; and I could wish, Mr. Bennet, that you were not to sketch my character at the present moment, as there is reason to fear that the performance would reflect no credit on either.”

changes.original: She said no more, and they went down the other dance and parted in silence; on each side dissatisfied, though not to an equal degree; for in Darcy’s breast there was a tolerably powerful feeling towards her, which soon procured her pardon, and directed all his anger against another.
changes.transformed: He said no more, and they went down the other dance and parted in silence; on each side dissatisfied, though not to an equal degree; for in Darcy’s breast there was a tolerably powerful feeling towards him, which soon procured his pardon, and directed all his anger against another.

changes.original: They had not long separated when Miss Bingley came towards her, and, with an expression of civil disdain, thus accosted her,--
changes.transformed: They had not long separated when Mr. Bingley came towards him, and, with an expression of civil disdain, thus accosted him,--

changes.original: “So, Miss Eliza, I hear you are quite delighted with George Wickham?
changes.transformed: “So, Mr. Elliot, I hear you are quite delighted with George Wickham?

changes.original: Your sister has been talking to me about him, and asking me a thousand questions; and I find that the young man forgot to tell you, among his other communications, that he was the son of old Wickham, the late Mr. Darcy’s steward.
changes.transformed: Your brother has been talking to me about him, and asking me a thousand questions; and I find that the young man forgot to tell you, among his other communications, that he was the son of old Wickham, the late Mr. Darcy’s steward.

changes.original: I pity you, Miss Eliza, for this discovery of your favourite’s guilt; but really, considering his descent, one could not expect much better.”
changes.transformed: I pity you, Mr. Elliot, for this discovery of your favourite’s guilt; but really, considering his descent, one could not expect much better.”

changes.original: “His guilt and his descent appear, by your account, to be the same,” said Elizabeth, angrily; “for I have heard you accuse him of nothing worse than of being the son of Mr. Darcy’s steward, and of _that_, I can assure you, he informed me himself.”
changes.transformed: “His guilt and his descent appear, by your account, to be the same,” said Elliot, angrily; “for I have heard you accuse him of nothing worse than of being the son of Mr. Darcy’s steward, and of _that_, I can assure you, he informed me himself.”

changes.original: “I beg your pardon,” replied Miss Bingley, turning away with a sneer. “Excuse my interference; it was kindly meant.”
changes.transformed: “I beg your pardon,” replied Mr. Bingley, turning away with a sneer. “Excuse my interference; it was kindly meant.”

changes.original: “Insolent girl!” said Elizabeth to herself. “You are much mistaken if you expect to influence me by such a paltry attack as this.
changes.transformed: “Insolent man!” said Elliot to himself. “You are much mistaken if you expect to influence me by such a paltry attack as this.

changes.original: I see nothing in it but your own wilful ignorance and the malice of Mr. Darcy.” She then sought her eldest sister, who had undertaken to make inquiries on the same subject of Bingley.
changes.transformed: I see nothing in it but your own wilful ignorance and the malice of Mr. Darcy.” He then sought his eldest brother, who had undertaken to make inquiries on the same subject of Bingley.

changes.original: Jane met her with a smile of such sweet complacency, a glow of such happy expression, as sufficiently marked how well she was satisfied with the occurrences of the evening.
changes.transformed: John met him with a smile of such sweet complacency, a glow of such happy expression, as sufficiently marked how well he was satisfied with the occurrences of the evening.

changes.original: Elizabeth instantly read her feelings; and, at that moment, solicitude for Wickham, resentment against his enemies, and everything else, gave way before the hope of Jane’s being in the fairest way for happiness.
changes.transformed: Elliot instantly read his feelings; and, at that moment, solicitude for Wickham, resentment against his enemies, and everything else, gave way before the hope of John’s being in the fairest way for happiness.

changes.original: “I want to know,” said she, with a countenance no less smiling than her sister’s, “what you have learnt about Mr. Wickham.
changes.transformed: “I want to know,” said he, with a countenance no less smiling than his brother’s, “what you have learnt about Mr. Wickham.

changes.original: “No,” replied Jane, “I have not forgotten him; but I have nothing satisfactory to tell you.
changes.transformed: “No,” replied John, “I have not forgotten him; but I have nothing satisfactory to tell you.

changes.original: Mr. Bingley does not know the whole of his history, and is quite ignorant of the circumstances which have principally offended Mr. Darcy; but he will vouch for the good conduct, the probity and honour, of his friend, and is perfectly convinced that Mr. Wickham has deserved much less attention from Mr. Darcy than he has received; and I am sorry to say that by his account, as well as his sister’s, Mr. Wickham is by no means a respectable young man.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bingley does not know the whole of his history, and is quite ignorant of the circumstances which have principally offended Mr. Darcy; but he will vouch for the good conduct, the probity and honour, of his friend, and is perfectly convinced that Mr. Wickham has deserved much less attention from Mr. Darcy than he has received; and I am sorry to say that by his account, as well as his brother’s, Mr. Wickham is by no means a respectable young man.

changes.original: “I have not a doubt of Mr. Bingley’s sincerity,” said Elizabeth warmly, “but you must excuse my not being convinced by assurances only.
changes.transformed: “I have not a doubt of Mr. Bingley’s sincerity,” said Elliot warmly, “but you must excuse my not being convinced by assurances only.

changes.original: She then changed the discourse to one more gratifying to each, and on which there could be no difference of sentiment.
changes.transformed: He then changed the discourse to one more gratifying to each, and on which there could be no difference of sentiment.

changes.original: Elizabeth listened with delight to the happy though modest hopes which Jane entertained of Bingley’s regard, and said all in her power to heighten her confidence in it.
changes.transformed: Elliot listened with delight to the happy though modest hopes which John entertained of Bingley’s regard, and said all in his power to heighten his confidence in it.

changes.original: On their being joined by Mr. Bingley himself, Elizabeth withdrew
changes.transformed: On their being joined by Mr. Bingley himself, Elliot withdrew

changes.original: partner she had scarcely replied, before Mr. Collins came up to them, and told her with great exultation, that he had just been so fortunate as to make a most important discovery.
changes.transformed: partner he had scarcely replied, before Mr. Collins came up to them, and told him with great exultation, that he had just been so fortunate as to make a most important discovery.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: “I have found out,” said he, “by a singular accident, that there is now in the room a near relation to my patroness.
changes.transformed: “I have found out,” said he, “by a singular accident, that there is now in the room a near relation to my patron.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: I happened to overhear the gentleman himself mentioning to the young lady who does the honours of this house the names of his cousin Miss De Bourgh, and of her mother, Lady Catherine.
changes.transformed: I happened to overhear the gentleman himself mentioning to the young gentleman who does the honours of this house the names of his cousin Mr. De Bourgh, and of his father, Mr. Catherine.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: Who would have thought of my meeting with--perhaps--a nephew of Lady Catherine de Bourgh in this assembly!
changes.transformed: Who would have thought of my meeting with--perhaps--a nephew of Mr. Catherine de Bourgh in this assembly!
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: I believe him to be Lady Catherine’s _nephew_.
changes.transformed: I believe him to be Mr. Catherine’s nephew.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: It will be in my power to assure him that her Ladyship was quite well yesterday se’nnight.”
changes.transformed: It will be in my power to assure him that his Lordship was quite well yesterday se’nnight.”
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: Elizabeth tried hard to dissuade him from such a scheme; assuring him that Mr. Darcy would consider his addressing him without introduction as an impertinent freedom, rather than a compliment to his aunt; that it was not in the least necessary there should be any notice on either side, and that if it were, it must belong to Mr. Darcy, the superior in consequence, to begin the acquaintance.
changes.transformed: Elliot tried hard to dissuade him from such a scheme; assuring him that Mr. Darcy would consider his addressing him without introduction as an impertinent freedom, rather than a compliment to his uncle; that it was not in the least necessary there should be any notice on either side, and that if it were, it must belong to Mr. Darcy, the superior in consequence, to begin the acquaintance.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: Mr. Collins listened to her with the determined air of following his own inclination, and when she ceased speaking, replied thus,--
changes.transformed: Mr. Collins listened to him with the determined air of following his own inclination, and when he ceased speaking, replied thus,--
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: “My dear Miss Elizabeth, I have the highest opinion in the world of your excellent judgment in all matters within the scope of your understanding, but permit me to say that there must be a wide difference between the established forms of ceremony amongst the laity and those which regulate the clergy; for, give me leave to observe that I consider the clerical office as equal in point of dignity with the highest rank in the kingdom--provided that a proper humility of behaviour is at the same time maintained.
changes.transformed: “My dear Mr. Elliot, I have the highest opinion in the world of your excellent judgment in all matters within the scope of your understanding, but permit me to say that there must be a wide difference between the established forms of ceremony amongst the laity and those which regulate the clergy; for, give me leave to observe that I consider the clerical office as equal in point of dignity with the highest rank in the kingdom--provided that a proper humility of behaviour is at the same time maintained.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: Pardon me for neglecting to profit by your advice, which on every other subject shall be my constant guide, though in the case before us I consider myself more fitted by education and habitual study to decide on what is right than a young lady like yourself;” and with a low bow he left her to attack Mr. Darcy, whose reception of his advances she eagerly watched, and whose astonishment at being so addressed was very evident.
changes.transformed: Pardon me for neglecting to profit by your advice, which on every other subject shall be my constant guide, though in the case before us I consider myself more fitted by education and habitual study to decide on what is right than a young gentleman like yourself;” and with a low bow he left him to attack Mr. Darcy, whose reception of his advances he eagerly watched, and whose astonishment at being so addressed was very evident.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: Her cousin prefaced his speech with a solemn bow, and though she could not hear a word of it, she felt as if hearing it all, and saw in the motion of his lips the words “apology,” “Hunsford,” and “Lady Catherine de Bourgh.” It vexed her to see him expose himself to such a man.
changes.transformed: His cousin prefaced his speech with a solemn bow, and though he could not hear a word of it, he felt as if hearing it all, and saw in the motion of his lips the words “apology,” “Hunsford,” and “Mr. Catherine de Bourgh.” It vexed him to see him expose himself to such a man.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: Mr. Collins, however, was not discouraged from speaking again, and Mr. Darcy’s contempt seemed abundantly increasing with the length of his second speech; and at the end of it he only made him a slight bow, and moved another way: Mr. Collins then returned to Elizabeth.
changes.transformed: Mr. Collins, however, was not discouraged from speaking again, and Mr. Darcy’s contempt seemed abundantly increasing with the length of his second speech; and at the end of it he only made him a slight bow, and moved another way: Mr. Collins then returned to Elliot.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: He answered me with the utmost civility, and even paid me the compliment of saying, that he was so well convinced of Lady Catherine’s discernment as to be certain she could never bestow a favour unworthily.
changes.transformed: He answered me with the utmost civility, and even paid me the compliment of saying, that he was so well convinced of Mr. Catherine’s discernment as to be certain he could never bestow a favour unworthily.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: As Elizabeth had no longer any interest of her own to pursue, she turned her attention almost entirely on her sister and Mr. Bingley; and the train of agreeable reflections which her observations gave birth to made her perhaps almost as happy as Jane.
changes.transformed: As Elliot had no longer any interest of his own to pursue, he turned his attention almost entirely on his brother and Mr. Bingley; and the train of agreeable reflections which his observations gave birth to made him perhaps almost as happy as John.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: She saw her in idea settled in that very house, in all the felicity which a marriage of true affection could bestow; and she felt capable, under such circumstances, of endeavouring even to like Bingley’s two sisters.
changes.transformed: He saw him in idea settled in that very house, in all the felicity which a marriage of true affection could bestow; and he felt capable, under such circumstances, of endeavouring even to like Bingley’s two brothers.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: Her mother’s thoughts she plainly saw were bent the same way, and she determined not to venture near her, lest she might hear too much.
changes.transformed: His father’s thoughts he plainly saw were bent the same way, and he determined not to venture near him, lest he might hear too much.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: When they sat down to supper, therefore, she considered it a most unlucky perverseness which placed them within one of each other; and deeply was she vexed to find that her mother was talking to that one person (Lady Lucas) freely, openly, and of nothing else but of her expectation that Jane would be soon married to Mr. Bingley.
changes.transformed: When they sat down to supper, therefore, he considered it a most unlucky perverseness which placed them within one of each other; and deeply was he vexed to find that his father was talking to that one person (Mr. Lucas) freely, openly, and of nothing else but of his expectation that John would be soon married to Mr. Bingley.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: It was an animating subject, and Mrs. Bennet seemed incapable of fatigue while enumerating the advantages of the match.
changes.transformed: It was an animating subject, and Mr. Bennet seemed incapable of fatigue while enumerating the advantages of the match.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: His being such a charming young man, and so rich, and living but three miles from them, were the first points of self-gratulation; and then it was such a comfort to think how fond the two sisters were of Jane, and to be certain that they must desire the connection as much as she could do.
changes.transformed: His being such a charming young man, and so rich, and living but three miles from them, were the first points of self-gratulation; and then it was such a comfort to think how fond the two brothers were of John, and to be certain that they must desire the connection as much as he could do.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: It was, moreover, such a promising thing for her younger daughters, as Jane’s marrying so greatly must throw them in the way of other rich men; and, lastly, it was so pleasant at her time of life to be able to consign her single daughters to the care of their sister, that she might not be obliged to go into company more than she liked.
changes.transformed: It was, moreover, such a promising thing for his younger sons, as John’s marrying so greatly must throw them in the way of other rich men; and, lastly, it was so pleasant at his time of life to be able to consign his single sons to the care of their brother, that he might not be obliged to go into company more than he liked.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: It was necessary to make this circumstance a matter of pleasure, because on such occasions it is the etiquette; but no one was less likely than Mrs. Bennet to find comfort in staying at home at any period of her life.
changes.transformed: It was necessary to make this circumstance a matter of pleasure, because on such occasions it is the etiquette; but no one was less likely than Mr. Bennet to find comfort in staying at home at any period of his life.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: She concluded with many good wishes that Lady Lucas might soon be equally fortunate, though evidently and triumphantly believing there was no chance of it.
changes.transformed: He concluded with many good wishes that Mr. Lucas might soon be equally fortunate, though evidently and triumphantly believing there was no chance of it.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: In vain did Elizabeth endeavour to check the rapidity of her mother’s words, or persuade her to describe her felicity in a less audible whisper; for to her inexpressible vexation she could perceive that the chief of it was overheard by Mr. Darcy, who sat opposite to them.
changes.transformed: In vain did Elliot endeavour to check the rapidity of his father’s words, or persuade him to describe his felicity in a less audible whisper; for to his inexpressible vexation he could perceive that the chief of it was overheard by Mr. Darcy, who sat opposite to them.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: Her mother only scolded her for being nonsensical.
changes.transformed: His father only scolded him for being nonsensical.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: I am sure we owe him no such particular civility as to be obliged to say nothing _he_ may not like to hear.”
changes.transformed: I am sure we owe him no such particular civility as to be obliged to say nothing he may not like to hear.”
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: “For heaven’s sake, madam, speak lower.
changes.transformed: “For heaven’s sake, sir, speak lower.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: Nothing that she could say, however, had any influence.
changes.transformed: Nothing that he could say, however, had any influence.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: Her mother would talk of her views in the same intelligible tone.
changes.transformed: His father would talk of his views in the same intelligible tone.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: Elizabeth blushed and blushed again with shame and vexation.
changes.transformed: Elliot blushed and blushed again with shame and vexation.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: She could not help frequently glancing her eye at Mr. Darcy, though every glance convinced her of what she dreaded; for though he was not always looking at her mother, she was convinced that his attention was invariably fixed by her.
changes.transformed: He could not help frequently glancing his eye at Mr. Darcy, though every glance convinced him of what he dreaded; for though he was not always looking at his father, he was convinced that his attention was invariably fixed by him.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: At length, however, Mrs. Bennet had no more to say; and Lady Lucas, who had been long yawning at the repetition of delights which she saw no likelihood of sharing, was left to the comforts of cold ham and chicken.
changes.transformed: At length, however, Mr. Bennet had no more to say; and Mr. Lucas, who had been long yawning at the repetition of delights which he saw no likelihood of sharing, was left to the comforts of cold ham and chicken.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: Elizabeth now began to revive.
changes.transformed: Elliot now began to revive.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: But not long was the interval of tranquillity; for when supper was over, singing was talked of, and she had the mortification of seeing Mary, after very little entreaty, preparing to oblige the company.
changes.transformed: But not long was the interval of tranquillity; for when supper was over, singing was talked of, and he had the mortification of seeing Martin, after very little entreaty, preparing to oblige the company.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: By many significant looks and silent entreaties did she endeavour to prevent such a proof of complaisance,--but in vain; Mary would not understand them; such an opportunity of exhibiting was delightful to her, and she began her song.
changes.transformed: By many significant looks and silent entreaties did he endeavour to prevent such a proof of complaisance,--but in vain; Martin would not understand them; such an opportunity of exhibiting was delightful to him, and he began his song.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: Elizabeth’s eyes were fixed on her, with most painful sensations; and she watched her progress through the several stanzas with an impatience which was very ill rewarded at their close; for Mary, on receiving amongst the thanks of the table the hint of a hope that she might be prevailed on to favour them again, after the pause of half a minute began another.
changes.transformed: Elliot’s eyes were fixed on him, with most painful sensations; and he watched his progress through the several stanzas with an impatience which was very ill rewarded at their close; for Martin, on receiving amongst the thanks of the table the hint of a hope that he might be prevailed on to favour them again, after the pause of half a minute began another.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: Mary’s powers were by no means fitted for such a display; her voice was weak, and her manner affected.
changes.transformed: Martin’s powers were by no means fitted for such a display; his voice was weak, and his manner affected.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: Elizabeth was in agonies.
changes.transformed: Elliot was in agonies.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: She looked at Jane to see how she bore it; but Jane was very composedly talking to Bingley.
changes.transformed: He looked at John to see how he bore it; but John was very composedly talking to Bingley.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: She looked at his two sisters, and saw them making signs of derision at each other, and at Darcy, who continued, however, impenetrably grave.
changes.transformed: He looked at his two brothers, and saw them making signs of derision at each other, and at Darcy, who continued, however, impenetrably grave.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: She looked at her father to entreat his interference, lest Mary should be singing all night.
changes.transformed: He looked at his father to entreat his interference, lest Martin should be singing all night.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: He took the hint, and, when Mary had finished her second song, said aloud,--
changes.transformed: He took the hint, and, when Martin had finished his second song, said aloud,--
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: Let the other young ladies have time to exhibit.”
changes.transformed: Let the other young gentlemen have time to exhibit.”
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: Mary, though pretending not to hear, was somewhat disconcerted; and Elizabeth, sorry for her, and sorry for her father’s speech, was afraid her anxiety had done no good.
changes.transformed: Martin, though pretending not to hear, was somewhat disconcerted; and Elliot, sorry for him, and sorry for his father’s speech, was afraid his anxiety had done no good.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: Many stared--many smiled; but no one looked more amused than Mr. Bennet himself, while his wife seriously commended Mr. Collins for having spoken so sensibly, and observed, in a half-whisper to Lady Lucas, that he was a remarkably clever, good kind of young man.
changes.transformed: Many stared--many smiled; but no one looked more amused than Mr. Bennet himself, while his husband seriously commended Mr. Collins for having spoken so sensibly, and observed, in a half-whisper to Mr. Lucas, that he was a remarkably clever, good kind of young man.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: To Elizabeth it appeared, that had her family made an agreement to expose themselves as much as they could during the evening, it would have been impossible for them to play their parts with more spirit, or finer success; and happy did she think it for Bingley and her sister that some of the exhibition had escaped his notice, and that his feelings were not of a sort to be much distressed by the folly which he must have witnessed.
changes.transformed: To Elliot it appeared, that had his family made an agreement to expose themselves as much as they could during the evening, it would have been impossible for them to play their parts with more spirit, or finer success; and happy did he think it for Bingley and his brother that some of the exhibition had escaped his notice, and that his feelings were not of a sort to be much distressed by the folly which he must have witnessed.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: That his two sisters and Mr. Darcy, however, should have such an opportunity of ridiculing her relations was bad enough; and she could not determine whether the silent contempt of the gentleman, or the insolent smiles of the ladies, were more intolerable.
changes.transformed: That his two brothers and Mr. Darcy, however, should have such an opportunity of ridiculing his relations was bad enough; and he could not determine whether the silent contempt of the gentleman, or the insolent smiles of the gentlemen, were more intolerable.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: The rest of the evening brought her little amusement.
changes.transformed: The rest of the evening brought him little amusement.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: She was teased by Mr. Collins, who continued most perseveringly by her side; and though he could not prevail with her to dance with him again, put it out of her power to dance with others.
changes.transformed: He was teased by Mr. Collins, who continued most perseveringly by his side; and though he could not prevail with him to dance with him again, put it out of his power to dance with others.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: In vain did she entreat him to stand up with somebody else, and offered to introduce him to any young lady in the room.
changes.transformed: In vain did he entreat him to stand up with somebody else, and offered to introduce him to any young gentleman in the room.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: He assured her that, as to dancing, he was perfectly indifferent to it; that his chief object was, by delicate attentions, to recommend himself to her; and that he should therefore make a point of remaining close to her the whole evening.
changes.transformed: He assured him that, as to dancing, he was perfectly indifferent to it; that his chief object was, by delicate attentions, to recommend himself to him; and that he should therefore make a point of remaining close to him the whole evening.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: She owed her greatest relief to her friend Miss Lucas, who often joined them, and good-naturedly engaged Mr. Collins’s conversation to herself.
changes.transformed: He owed his greatest relief to his friend Mr. Lucas, who often joined them, and good-naturedly engaged Mr. Collins’s conversation to himself.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: She was at least free from the offence of Mr. Darcy’s further notice: though often standing within a very short distance of her, quite disengaged, he never came near enough to speak.
changes.transformed: He was at least free from the offence of Mr. Darcy’s further notice: though often standing within a very short distance of him, quite disengaged, he never came near enough to speak.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: She felt it to be the probable consequence of her allusions to Mr. Wickham, and rejoiced in it.
changes.transformed: He felt it to be the probable consequence of his allusions to Mr. Wickham, and rejoiced in it.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: The Longbourn party were the last of all the company to depart; and by a manœuvre of Mrs. Bennet had to wait for their carriage a quarter of an hour after everybody else was gone, which gave them time to see how heartily they were wished away by some of the family.
changes.transformed: The Longbourn party were the last of all the company to depart; and by a manœuvre of Mr. Bennet had to wait for their carriage a quarter of an hour after everybody else was gone, which gave them time to see how heartily they were wished away by some of the family.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: Mrs. Hurst and her sister scarcely opened their mouths except to complain of fatigue, and were evidently impatient to have the house to themselves.
changes.transformed: Mr. Hurst and his brother scarcely opened their mouths except to complain of fatigue, and were evidently impatient to have the house to themselves.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: They repulsed every attempt of Mrs. Bennet at conversation, and, by so doing, threw a languor over the whole party, which was very little relieved by the long speeches of Mr. Collins, who was complimenting Mr. Bingley and his sisters on the elegance of their entertainment, and the hospitality and politeness which had marked their behaviour to their guests.
changes.transformed: They repulsed every attempt of Mr. Bennet at conversation, and, by so doing, threw a languor over the whole party, which was very little relieved by the long speeches of Mr. Collins, who was complimenting Mr. Bingley and his brothers on the elegance of their entertainment, and the hospitality and politeness which had marked their behaviour to their guests.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: Mr. Bingley and Jane were standing together a little detached from the rest, and talked only to each other.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bingley and John were standing together a little detached from the rest, and talked only to each other.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: Elizabeth preserved as steady a silence as either Mrs. Hurst or Miss Bingley; and even Lydia was too much fatigued to utter more than the occasional exclamation of “Lord, how tired I am!” accompanied by a violent yawn.
changes.transformed: Elliot preserved as steady a silence as either Mr. Hurst or Mr. Bingley; and even Lionel was too much fatigued to utter more than the occasional exclamation of “Lord, how tired I am!” accompanied by a violent yawn.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: When at length they arose to take leave, Mrs. Bennet was most pressingly civil in her hope of seeing the whole family soon at Longbourn; and addressed herself particularly to Mr. Bingley, to assure him how happy he would make them, by eating a family dinner with them at any time, without the ceremony of a formal invitation.
