changes.transformed: When at length they arose to take leave, Mr. Bennet was most pressingly civil in his hope of seeing the whole family soon at Longbourn; and addressed himself particularly to Mr. Bingley, to assure him how happy he would make them, by eating a family dinner with them at any time, without the ceremony of a formal invitation.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: Bingley was all grateful pleasure; and he readily engaged for taking the earliest opportunity of waiting on her after his return from London, whither he was obliged to go the next day for a short time.
changes.transformed: Bingley was all grateful pleasure; and he readily engaged for taking the earliest opportunity of waiting on him after his return from London, whither he was obliged to go the next day for a short time.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet was perfectly satisfied; and quitted the house under the delightful persuasion that, allowing for the necessary preparations of settlements, new carriages, and wedding clothes, she should undoubtedly see her daughter settled at Netherfield in the course of three or four months.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet was perfectly satisfied; and quitted the house under the delightful persuasion that, allowing for the necessary preparations of settlements, new carriages, and wedding clothes, he should undoubtedly see his son settled at Netherfield in the course of three or four months.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: Of having another daughter married to Mr. Collins she thought with equal certainty, and with considerable, though not equal, pleasure.
changes.transformed: Of having another son married to Mr. Collins he thought with equal certainty, and with considerable, though not equal, pleasure.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: Elizabeth was the least dear to her of all her children; and though the man and the match were quite good enough for _her_, the worth of each was eclipsed by Mr. Bingley and Netherfield.
changes.transformed: Elliot was the least dear to him of all his children; and though the man and the match were quite good enough for _him_, the worth of each was eclipsed by Mr. Bingley and Netherfield.
changes.chapter_title: Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last

changes.original: On finding Mrs. Bennet, Elizabeth, and one of the younger girls together, soon after breakfast, he addressed the mother in these words,--
changes.transformed: On finding Mr. Bennet, Elliot, and one of the younger boys together, soon after breakfast, he addressed the father in these words,--

changes.original: “May I hope, madam, for your interest with your fair daughter Elizabeth, when I solicit for the honour of a private audience with her in the course of this morning?”
changes.transformed: “May I hope, sir, for your interest with your fine son Elliot, when I solicit for the honour of a private audience with him in the course of this morning?”

changes.original: Before Elizabeth had time for anything but a blush of surprise, Mrs. Bennet instantly answered,--
changes.transformed: Before Elliot had time for anything but a blush of surprise, Mr. Bennet instantly answered,--

changes.original: I am sure Lizzy will be very happy--I am sure she can have no objection.
changes.transformed: I am sure Elly will be very happy--I am sure he can have no objection.

changes.original: Come, Kitty, I want you upstairs.” And gathering her work together, she was hastening away, when Elizabeth called out,--
changes.transformed: Come, Kit, I want you upstairs.” And gathering his work together, he was hastening away, when Elliot called out,--

changes.original: “Dear ma’am, do not go.
changes.transformed: “Dear sir, do not go.

changes.original: “No, no, nonsense, Lizzy.
changes.transformed: “No, no, nonsense, Elly.

changes.original: I desire you will stay where you are.” And upon Elizabeth’s seeming really, with vexed and embarrassed looks, about to escape, she added, “Lizzy, I _insist_ upon your staying and hearing Mr. Collins.”
changes.transformed: I desire you will stay where you are.” And upon Elliot’s seeming really, with vexed and embarrassed looks, about to escape, he added, “Elly, I _insist_ upon your staying and hearing Mr. Collins.”

changes.original: Elizabeth would not oppose such an injunction; and a moment’s consideration making her also sensible that it would be wisest to get it over as soon and as quietly as possible, she sat down again, and tried to conceal, by incessant employment, the feelings which were divided between distress and diversion.
changes.transformed: Elliot would not oppose such an injunction; and a moment’s consideration making him also sensible that it would be wisest to get it over as soon and as quietly as possible, he sat down again, and tried to conceal, by incessant employment, the feelings which were divided between distress and diversion.

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet and Kitty walked off, and as soon as they were gone, Mr. Collins began,--
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet and Kit walked off, and as soon as they were gone, Mr. Collins began,--

changes.original: “Believe me, my dear Miss Elizabeth, that your modesty, so far from doing you any disservice, rather adds to your other perfections.
changes.transformed: “Believe me, my dear Mr. Elliot, that your modesty, so far from doing you any disservice, rather adds to your other perfections.

changes.original: You would have been less amiable in my eyes had there _not_ been this little unwillingness; but allow me to assure you that I have your respected mother’s permission for this address.
changes.transformed: You would have been less amiable in my eyes had there _not_ been this little unwillingness; but allow me to assure you that I have your respected father’s permission for this address.

changes.original: But before I am run away with by my feelings on this subject, perhaps it will be advisable for me to state my reasons for marrying--and, moreover, for coming into Hertfordshire with the design of selecting a wife, as I certainly did.”
changes.transformed: But before I am run away with by my feelings on this subject, perhaps it will be advisable for me to state my reasons for marrying--and, moreover, for coming into Hertfordshire with the design of selecting a husband, as I certainly did.”

changes.original: The idea of Mr. Collins, with all his solemn composure, being run away with by his feelings, made Elizabeth so near laughing that she could not use the short pause he allowed in any attempt to stop him farther, and he continued,--
changes.transformed: The idea of Mr. Collins, with all his solemn composure, being run away with by his feelings, made Elliot so near laughing that he could not use the short pause he allowed in any attempt to stop him farther, and he continued,--

changes.original: “My reasons for marrying are, first, that I think it a right thing for every clergyman in easy circumstances (like myself) to set the example of matrimony in his parish; secondly, that I am convinced it will add very greatly to my happiness; and, thirdly, which perhaps I ought to have mentioned earlier, that it is the particular advice and recommendation of the very noble lady whom I have the honour of calling patroness.
changes.transformed: “My reasons for marrying are, first, that I think it a right thing for every clergyman in easy circumstances (like myself) to set the example of matrimony in his parish; secondly, that I am convinced it will add very greatly to my happiness; and, thirdly, which perhaps I ought to have mentioned earlier, that it is the particular advice and recommendation of the very noble gentleman whom I have the honour of calling patron.

changes.original: Twice has she condescended to give me her opinion (unasked too!) on this subject; and it was but the very Saturday night before I left Hunsford,--between our pools at quadrille, while Mrs. Jenkinson was arranging Miss De Bourgh’s footstool,--that she said, ‘Mr. Collins, you must marry.
changes.transformed: Twice has he condescended to give me his opinion (unasked too!) on this subject; and it was but the very Saturday night before I left Hunsford,--between our pools at quadrille, while Mr. Jenkinson was arranging Mr. De Bourgh’s footstool,--that he said, ‘Mr. Collins, you must marry.

changes.original: Choose properly, choose a gentlewoman for _my_ sake, and for your _own_; let her be an active, useful sort of person, not brought up high, but able to make a small income go a good way.
changes.transformed: Choose properly, choose a gentleman for _my_ sake, and for your _own_; let him be an active, useful sort of person, not brought up high, but able to make a small income go a good way.

changes.original: Find such a woman as soon as you can, bring her to Hunsford, and I will visit her.’ Allow me, by the way, to observe, my fair cousin, that I do not reckon the notice and kindness of Lady Catherine de Bourgh as among the least of the advantages in my power to offer.
changes.transformed: Find such a man as soon as you can, bring him to Hunsford, and I will visit him.’ Allow me, by the way, to observe, my fair cousin, that I do not reckon the notice and kindness of Mr. Catherine de Bourgh as among the least of the advantages in my power to offer.

changes.original: You will find her manners beyond anything I can describe; and your wit and vivacity, I think, must be acceptable to her, especially when tempered with the silence and respect which her rank will inevitably excite.
changes.transformed: You will find his manners beyond anything I can describe; and your wit and vivacity, I think, must be acceptable to him, especially when tempered with the silence and respect which his rank will inevitably excite.

changes.original: Thus much for my general intention in favour of matrimony; it remains to be told why my views were directed to Longbourn instead of my own neighbourhood, where I assure you there are many amiable young women.
changes.transformed: Thus much for my general intention in favour of matrimony; it remains to be told why my views were directed to Longbourn instead of my own neighbourhood, where I assure you there are many amiable young men.

changes.original: But the fact is, that being, as I am, to inherit this estate after the death of your honoured father (who, however, may live many years longer), I could not satisfy myself without resolving to choose a wife from among his daughters, that the loss to them might be as little as possible when the melancholy event takes place--which, however, as I have already said, may not be for several years.
changes.transformed: But the fact is, that being, as I am, to inherit this estate after the death of your honoured father (who, however, may live many years longer), I could not satisfy myself without resolving to choose a husband from among his sons, that the loss to them might be as little as possible when the melancholy event takes place--which, however, as I have already said, may not be for several years.

changes.original: To fortune I am perfectly indifferent, and shall make no demand of that nature on your father, since I am well aware that it could not be complied with; and that one thousand pounds in the per cents., which will not be yours till after your mother’s decease, is all that you may ever be entitled to.
changes.transformed: To fortune I am perfectly indifferent, and shall make no demand of that nature on your father, since I am well aware that it could not be complied with; and that one thousand pounds in the per cents., which will not be yours till after your father’s decease, is all that you may ever be entitled to.

changes.original: “You are too hasty, sir,” she cried. “You forget that I have made no answer.
changes.transformed: “You are too hasty, sir,” he cried. “You forget that I have made no answer.

changes.original: “I am not now to learn,” replied Mr. Collins, with a formal wave of the hand, “that it is usual with young ladies to reject the addresses of the man whom they secretly mean to accept, when he first applies for their favour; and that sometimes the refusal is repeated a second or even a third time.
changes.transformed: “I am not now to learn,” replied Mr. Collins, with a formal wave of the hand, “that it is usual with young gentlemen to reject the addresses of the man whom they secretly mean to accept, when he first applies for their favour; and that sometimes the refusal is repeated a second or even a third time.

changes.original: “Upon my word, sir,” cried Elizabeth, “your hope is rather an extraordinary one after my declaration.
changes.transformed: “Upon my word, sir,” cried Elliot, “your hope is rather an extraordinary one after my declaration.

changes.original: I do assure you that I am not one of those young ladies (if such young ladies there are) who are so daring as to risk their happiness on the chance of being asked a second time.
changes.transformed: I do assure you that I am not one of those young gentlemen (if such young gentlemen there are) who are so daring as to risk their happiness on the chance of being asked a second time.

changes.original: You could not make _me_ happy, and I am convinced that I am the last woman in the world who would make _you_ so.
changes.transformed: You could not make _me_ happy, and I am convinced that I am the last man in the world who would make _you_ so.

changes.original: Nay, were your friend Lady Catherine to know me, I am persuaded she would find me in every respect ill qualified for the situation.”
changes.transformed: Nay, were your friend Mr. Catherine to know me, I am persuaded he would find me in every respect ill qualified for the situation.”

changes.original: “Were it certain that Lady Catherine would think so,” said Mr. Collins, very gravely--“but I cannot imagine that her Ladyship would at all disapprove of you.
changes.transformed: “Were it certain that Mr. Catherine would think so,” said Mr. Collins, very gravely--“but I cannot imagine that his Lordship would at all disapprove of you.

changes.original: And you may be certain that when I have the honour of seeing her again I shall speak in the highest terms of your modesty, economy, and other amiable qualifications.”
changes.transformed: And you may be certain that when I have the honour of seeing him again I shall speak in the highest terms of your modesty, economy, and other amiable qualifications.”

changes.original: This matter may be considered, therefore, as finally settled.” And rising as she thus spoke, she would have quitted the room, had not Mr. Collins thus addressed her,--
changes.transformed: This matter may be considered, therefore, as finally settled.” And rising as he thus spoke, he would have quitted the room, had not Mr. Collins thus addressed him,--

changes.original: “When I do myself the honour of speaking to you next on the subject, I shall hope to receive a more favourable answer than you have now given me; though I am far from accusing you of cruelty at present, because I know it to be the established custom of your sex to reject a man on the first application, and, perhaps, you have even now said as much to encourage my suit as would be consistent with the true delicacy of the female character.”
changes.transformed: “When I do myself the honour of speaking to you next on the subject, I shall hope to receive a more favourable answer than you have now given me; though I am far from accusing you of cruelty at present, because I know it to be the established custom of your sex to reject a man on the first application, and, perhaps, you have even now said as much to encourage my suit as would be consistent with the true delicacy of the male character.”

changes.original: “Really, Mr. Collins,” cried Elizabeth, with some warmth, “you puzzle me exceedingly.
changes.transformed: “Really, Mr. Collins,” cried Elliot, with some warmth, “you puzzle me exceedingly.

changes.original: Your portion is unhappily so small, that it will in all likelihood undo the effects of your loveliness and amiable qualifications.
changes.transformed: Your portion is unhappily so small, that it will in all likelihood undo the effects of your handsomeness and amiable qualifications.

changes.original: As I must, therefore, conclude that you are not serious in your rejection of me, I shall choose to attribute it to your wish of increasing my love by suspense, according to the usual practice of elegant females.”
changes.transformed: As I must, therefore, conclude that you are not serious in your rejection of me, I shall choose to attribute it to your wish of increasing my love by suspense, according to the usual practice of elegant gentlemen.”

changes.original: Do not consider me now as an elegant female intending to plague you, but as a rational creature speaking the truth from her heart.”
changes.transformed: Do not consider me now as an elegant gentleman intending to plague you, but as a rational creature speaking the truth from his heart.”

changes.original: “You are uniformly charming!” cried he, with an air of awkward gallantry; “and I am persuaded that, when sanctioned by the express authority of both your excellent parents, my proposals will not fail of being acceptable.”
changes.transformed: “You are uniformly charming!” cried he, with an air of awkward gallantry; “and I am persuaded that, when sanctioned by the express authority of both your excellent fathers, my proposals will not fail of being acceptable.”

changes.original: To such perseverance in wilful self-deception Elizabeth would make no reply, and immediately and in silence withdrew; determined, that if he persisted in considering her repeated refusals as flattering encouragement, to apply to her father, whose negative might be uttered in such a manner as must be decisive, and whose behaviour at least could not be mistaken for the affectation and coquetry of an elegant female.
changes.transformed: To such perseverance in wilful self-deception Elliot would make no reply, and immediately and in silence withdrew; determined, that if he persisted in considering his repeated refusals as flattering encouragement, to apply to his father, whose negative might be uttered in such a manner as must be decisive, and whose behaviour at least could not be mistaken for the affectation and coquetry of an elegant gentleman.

changes.original: Mr. Collins was not left long to the silent contemplation of his successful love; for Mrs. Bennet, having dawdled about in the vestibule to watch for the end of the conference, no sooner saw Elizabeth open the door and with quick step pass her towards the staircase, than she entered the breakfast-room, and congratulated both him and herself in warm terms on the happy prospect of their nearer connection.
changes.transformed: Mr. Collins was not left long to the silent contemplation of his successful love; for Mr. Bennet, having dawdled about in the vestibule to watch for the end of the conference, no sooner saw Elliot open the door and with quick step pass him towards the staircase, than he entered the breakfast-room, and congratulated both him and himself in warm terms on the happy prospect of their nearer connection.

changes.original: Mr. Collins received and returned these felicitations with equal pleasure, and then proceeded to relate the particulars of their interview, with the result of which he trusted he had every reason to be satisfied, since the refusal which his cousin had steadfastly given him would naturally flow from her bashful modesty and the genuine delicacy of her character.
changes.transformed: Mr. Collins received and returned these felicitations with equal pleasure, and then proceeded to relate the particulars of their interview, with the result of which he trusted he had every reason to be satisfied, since the refusal which his cousin had steadfastly given him would naturally flow from his bashful modesty and the genuine delicacy of his character.

changes.original: This information, however, startled Mrs. Bennet: she would have been glad to be equally satisfied that her daughter had meant to encourage him by protesting against his proposals, but she dared not believe it, and could not help saying so.
changes.transformed: This information, however, startled Mr. Bennet: he would have been glad to be equally satisfied that his son had meant to encourage him by protesting against his proposals, but he dared not believe it, and could not help saying so.

changes.original: “But depend upon it, Mr. Collins,” she added, “that Lizzy shall be brought to reason.
changes.transformed: “But depend upon it, Mr. Collins,” he added, “that Elliot shall be brought to reason.

changes.original: I will speak to her about it myself directly.
changes.transformed: I will speak to him about it myself directly.

changes.original: She is a very headstrong, foolish girl, and does not know her own interest; but I will _make_ her know it.”
changes.transformed: He is a very headstrong, foolish boy, and does not know his own interest; but I will _make_ him know it.”

changes.original: “Pardon me for interrupting you, madam,” cried Mr. Collins; “but if she is really headstrong and foolish, I know not whether she would altogether be a very desirable wife to a man in my situation, who naturally looks for happiness in the marriage state.
changes.transformed: “Pardon me for interrupting you, sir,” cried Mr. Collins; “but if he is really headstrong and foolish, I know not whether he would altogether be a very desirable husband to a man in my situation, who naturally looks for happiness in the marriage state.

changes.original: If, therefore, she actually persists in rejecting my suit, perhaps it were better not to force her into accepting me, because, if liable to such defects of temper, she could not contribute much to my felicity.”
changes.transformed: If, therefore, he actually persists in rejecting my suit, perhaps it were better not to force him into accepting me, because, if liable to such defects of temper, he could not contribute much to my felicity.”

changes.original: “Sir, you quite misunderstand me,” said Mrs. Bennet, alarmed. “Lizzy is only headstrong in such matters as these.
changes.transformed: “Sir, you quite misunderstand me,” said Mr. Bennet, alarmed. “Elliot is only headstrong in such matters as these.

changes.original: In everything else she is as good-natured a girl as ever lived.
changes.transformed: In everything else he is as good-natured a boy as ever lived.

changes.original: I will go directly to Mr. Bennet, and we shall very soon settle it with her, I am sure.”
changes.transformed: I will go directly to Mr. Bennet, and we shall very soon settle it with him, I am sure.”

changes.original: She would not give him time to reply, but hurrying instantly to her husband, called out, as she entered the library,--
changes.transformed: He would not give him time to reply, but hurrying instantly to his husband, called out, as he entered the library,--

changes.original: You must come and make Lizzy marry Mr. Collins, for she vows she will not have him; and if you do not make haste he will change his mind and not have _her_.”
changes.transformed: You must come and make Elliot marry Mr. Collins, for he vows he will not have him; and if you do not make haste he will change his mind and not have _him_.”

changes.original: Mr. Bennet raised his eyes from his book as she entered, and fixed them on her face with a calm unconcern, which was not in the least altered by her communication.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet raised his eyes from his book as he entered, and fixed them on his face with a calm unconcern, which was not in the least altered by his communication.

changes.original: “I have not the pleasure of understanding you,” said he, when she had finished her speech. “Of what are you talking?”
changes.transformed: “I have not the pleasure of understanding you,” said he, when he had finished his speech. “Of what are you talking?”

changes.original: “Of Mr. Collins and Lizzy.
changes.transformed: “Of Mr. Collins and Elliot.

changes.original: Lizzy declares she will not have Mr. Collins, and Mr. Collins begins to say that he will not have Lizzy.”
changes.transformed: Elliot declares he will not have Mr. Collins, and Mr. Collins begins to say that he will not have Elliot.”

changes.original: “Speak to Lizzy about it yourself.
changes.transformed: “Speak to Elliot about it yourself.

changes.original: Tell her that you insist upon her marrying him.”
changes.transformed: Tell him that you insist upon his marrying him.”

changes.original: “Let her be called down.
changes.transformed: “Let him be called down.

changes.original: She shall hear my opinion.”
changes.transformed: He shall hear my opinion.”

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet rang the bell, and Miss Elizabeth was summoned to the library.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet rang the bell, and Mr. Elliot was summoned to the library.

changes.original: “Come here, child,” cried her father as she appeared. “I have sent for you on an affair of importance.
changes.transformed: “Come here, child,” cried his father as he appeared. “I have sent for you on an affair of importance.

changes.original: Elizabeth replied that it was.
changes.transformed: Elliot replied that it was.

changes.original: Your mother insists upon your accepting it.
changes.transformed: Your father insists upon your accepting it.

changes.original: Is it not so, Mrs. Bennet?”
changes.transformed: Is it not so, Mr. Bennet?”

changes.original: “Yes, or I will never see her again.”
changes.transformed: “Yes, or I will never see him again.”

changes.original: “An unhappy alternative is before you, Elizabeth.
changes.transformed: “An unhappy alternative is before you, Elliot.

changes.original: Your mother will never see you again if you do _not_ marry Mr. Collins, and I will never see you again if you _do_.”
changes.transformed: Your father will never see you again if you do _not_ marry Mr. Collins, and I will never see you again if you _do_.”

changes.original: Elizabeth could not but smile at such a conclusion of such a beginning; but Mrs. Bennet, who had persuaded herself that her husband regarded the affair as she wished, was excessively disappointed.
changes.transformed: Elliot could not but smile at such a conclusion of such a beginning; but Mr. Bennet, who had persuaded himself that his husband regarded the affair as he wished, was excessively disappointed.

changes.original: You promised me to _insist_ upon her marrying him.”
changes.transformed: You promised me to _insist_ upon him marrying him.”

changes.original: “My dear,” replied her husband, “I have two small favours to request.
changes.transformed: “My dear,” replied his husband, “I have two small favours to request.

changes.original: Not yet, however, in spite of her disappointment in her husband, did Mrs. Bennet give up the point.
changes.transformed: Not yet, however, in spite of his disappointment in his husband, did Mr. Bennet give up the point.

changes.original: She talked to Elizabeth again and again; coaxed and threatened her by turns.
changes.transformed: He talked to Elliot again and again; coaxed and threatened him by turns.

changes.original: She endeavoured to secure Jane in her interest, but Jane, with all possible mildness, declined interfering; and Elizabeth, sometimes with real earnestness, and sometimes with playful gaiety, replied to her attacks.
changes.transformed: He endeavoured to secure John in his interest, but John, with all possible mildness, declined interfering; and Elliot, sometimes with real earnestness, and sometimes with playful gaiety, replied to his attacks.

changes.original: Though her manner varied, however, her determination never did.
changes.transformed: Though his manner varied, however, his determination never did.

changes.transformed: His regard for him was quite imaginary; and the possibility of him deserving his father’s reproach prevented his feeling any regret.

changes.original: While the family were in this confusion, Charlotte Lucas came to spend the day with them.
changes.transformed: While the family were in this confusion, Charles Lucas came to spend the day with them.

changes.original: She was met in the vestibule by Lydia, who, flying to her, cried in a half whisper, “I am glad you are come, for there is such fun here!
changes.transformed: He was met in the vestibule by Leonard, who, flying to him, cried in a half whisper, “I am glad you are come, for there is such fun here!

changes.original: Mr. Collins has made an offer to Lizzy, and she will not have him.”
changes.transformed: Mr. Collins has made an offer to Elliot, and he will not have him.”

changes.original: Charlotte had hardly time to answer before they were joined by Kitty, who came to tell the same news; and no sooner had they entered the breakfast-room, where Mrs. Bennet was alone, than she likewise began on the subject, calling on Miss Lucas for her compassion, and entreating her to persuade her friend Lizzy to comply with the wishes of her family. “Pray do, my dear Miss Lucas,” she added, in a melancholy tone; “for nobody is on my side, nobody takes part with me; I am cruelly used, nobody feels for my poor nerves.”
changes.transformed: Charles had hardly time to answer before they were joined by Kenneth, who came to tell the same news; and no sooner had they entered the breakfast-room, where Mr. Bennet was alone, than he likewise began on the subject, calling on Mr. Lucas for his compassion, and entreating him to persuade his friend Elliot to comply with the wishes of his family. “Pray do, my dear Mr. Lucas,” he added, in a melancholy tone; “for nobody is on my side, nobody takes part with me; I am cruelly used, nobody feels for my poor nerves.”

changes.original: Charlotte’s reply was spared by the entrance of Jane and Elizabeth.
changes.transformed: Charles’s reply was spared by the entrance of John and Elliot.

changes.original: “Ay, there she comes,” continued Mrs. Bennet, “looking as unconcerned as may be, and caring no more for us than if we were at York, provided she can have her own way.
changes.transformed: “Ay, there he comes,” continued Mr. Bennet, “looking as unconcerned as may be, and caring no more for us than if we were at York, provided he can have his own way.

changes.original: But I tell you what, Miss Lizzy, if you take it into your head to go on refusing every offer of marriage in this way, you will never get a husband at all--and I am sure I do not know who is to maintain you when your father is dead. _I_ shall not be able to keep you--and so I warn you.
changes.transformed: But I tell you what, Mr. Elliot, if you take it into your head to go on refusing every offer of marriage in this way, you will never get a husband at all--and I am sure I do not know who is to maintain you when your father is dead. _I_ shall not be able to keep you--and so I warn you.

changes.original: Her daughters listened in silence to this effusion, sensible that any attempt to reason with or soothe her would only increase the irritation.
changes.transformed: His sons listened in silence to this effusion, sensible that any attempt to reason with or soothe him would only increase the irritation.

changes.original: She talked on, therefore, without interruption from any of them till they were joined by Mr. Collins, who entered with an air more stately than usual, and on perceiving whom, she said to the girls,--
changes.transformed: He talked on, therefore, without interruption from any of them till they were joined by Mr. Collins, who entered with an air more stately than usual, and on perceiving whom, he said to the boys,--

changes.original: Elizabeth passed quietly out of the room, Jane and Kitty followed, but Lydia stood her ground, determined to hear all she could; and Charlotte, detained first by the civility of Mr. Collins, whose inquiries after herself and all her family were very minute, and then by a little curiosity, satisfied herself with walking to the window and pretending not to hear.
changes.transformed: Elliot passed quietly out of the room, John and Kit followed, but Lionel stood his ground, determined to hear all he could; and Charles, detained first by the civility of Mr. Collins, whose inquiries after himself and all his family were very minute, and then by a little curiosity, satisfied himself with walking to the window and pretending not to hear.

changes.original: In a doleful voice Mrs. Bennet thus began the projected conversation:--
changes.transformed: In a doleful voice Mr. Bennet thus began the projected conversation:--

changes.original: “My dear madam,” replied he, “let us be for ever silent on this point.
changes.transformed: “My dear sir,” replied he, “let us be for ever silent on this point.

changes.original: Far be it from me,” he presently continued, in a voice that marked his displeasure, “to resent the behaviour of your daughter.
changes.transformed: Far be it from me,” he presently continued, in a voice that marked his displeasure, “to resent the behaviour of your son.

changes.original: Perhaps not the less so from feeling a doubt of my positive happiness had my fair cousin honoured me with her hand; for I have often observed, that resignation is never so perfect as when the blessing denied begins to lose somewhat of its value in our estimation.
changes.transformed: Perhaps not the less so from feeling a doubt of my positive happiness had my fair cousin honoured me with his hand; for I have often observed, that resignation is never so perfect as when the blessing denied begins to lose somewhat of its value in our estimation.

changes.original: You will not, I hope, consider me as showing any disrespect to your family, my dear madam, by thus withdrawing my pretensions to your daughter’s favour, without having paid yourself and Mr. Bennet the compliment of requesting you to interpose your authority in my behalf.
changes.transformed: You will not, I hope, consider me as showing any disrespect to your family, my dear sir, by thus withdrawing my pretensions to your son’s favour, without having paid yourself and Mr. Bennet the compliment of requesting you to interpose your authority in my behalf.

changes.original: My conduct may, I fear, be objectionable in having accepted my dismission from your daughter’s lips instead of your own; but we are all liable to error.
changes.transformed: My conduct may, I fear, be objectionable in having accepted my dismission from your son’s lips instead of your own; but we are all liable to error.

changes.original: The discussion of Mr. Collins’s offer was now nearly at an end, and Elizabeth had only to suffer from the uncomfortable feelings necessarily attending it, and occasionally from some peevish allusion of her mother.
changes.transformed: The discussion of Mr. Collins’s offer was now nearly at an end, and Elliot had only to suffer from the uncomfortable feelings necessarily attending it, and occasionally from some peevish allusion of his father.

changes.original: As for the gentleman himself, _his_ feelings were chiefly expressed, not by embarrassment or dejection, or by trying to avoid her, but by stiffness of manner and resentful silence.
changes.transformed: As for the gentleman himself, _his_ feelings were chiefly expressed, not by embarrassment or dejection, or by trying to avoid him, but by stiffness of manner and resentful silence.

changes.original: He scarcely ever spoke to her; and the assiduous attentions which he had been so sensible of himself were transferred for the rest of the day to Miss Lucas, whose civility in listening to him was a seasonable relief to them all, and especially to her friend.
changes.transformed: He scarcely ever spoke to him; and the assiduous attentions which he had been so sensible of himself were transferred for the rest of the day to Mr. Lucas, whose civility in listening to him was a seasonable relief to them all, and especially to his friend.

changes.original: The morrow produced no abatement of Mrs. Bennet’s ill humour or ill health.
changes.transformed: The morrow produced no abatement of Mr. Bennet’s ill humour or ill health.

changes.original: Elizabeth had hoped that his resentment might shorten his visit, but his plan did not appear in the least affected by it.
changes.transformed: Elliot had hoped that his resentment might shorten his visit, but his plan did not appear in the least affected by it.

changes.original: After breakfast, the girls walked to Meryton, to inquire if Mr. Wickham were returned, and to lament over his absence from the Netherfield ball.
changes.transformed: After breakfast, the boys walked to Meryton, to inquire if Mr. Wickham were returned, and to lament over his absence from the Netherfield ball.

changes.original: He joined them on their entering the town, and attended them to their aunt’s, where his regret and vexation and the concern of everybody were well talked over.
changes.transformed: He joined them on their entering the town, and attended them to their uncle’s, where his regret and vexation and the concern of everybody were well talked over.

changes.original: To Elizabeth, however, he voluntarily acknowledged that the necessity of his absence _had_ been self-imposed.
changes.transformed: To Elliot, however, he voluntarily acknowledged that the necessity of his absence _had_ been self-imposed.

changes.original: She highly approved his forbearance; and they had leisure for a full discussion of it, and for all the commendations which they civilly bestowed on each other, as Wickham and another officer walked back with them to Longbourn, and during the walk he particularly attended to her.
changes.transformed: He highly approved his forbearance; and they had leisure for a full discussion of it, and for all the commendations which they civilly bestowed on each other, as Wickham and another officer walked back with them to Longbourn, and during the walk he particularly attended to him.

changes.original: His accompanying them was a double advantage: she felt all the compliment it offered to herself; and it was most acceptable as an occasion of introducing him to her father and mother.
changes.transformed: His accompanying them was a double advantage: he felt all the compliment it offered to himself; and it was most acceptable as an occasion of introducing him to his father and father.

changes.original: Soon after their return, a letter was delivered to Miss Bennet; it came from Netherfield, and was opened immediately.
changes.transformed: Soon after their return, a letter was delivered to Mr. Bennet; it came from Netherfield, and was opened immediately.

changes.original: The envelope contained a sheet of elegant, little, hot-pressed paper, well covered with a lady’s fair, flowing hand; and Elizabeth saw her sister’s countenance change as she read it, and saw her dwelling intently on some particular passages.
changes.transformed: The envelope contained a sheet of elegant, little, hot-pressed paper, well covered with a gentleman’s fair, flowing hand; and Elliot saw his brother’s countenance change as he read it, and saw him dwelling intently on some particular passages.

changes.original: Jane recollected herself soon; and putting the letter away, tried to join, with her usual cheerfulness, in the general conversation: but Elizabeth felt an anxiety on the subject which drew off her attention even from Wickham; and no sooner had he and his companion taken leave, than a glance from Jane invited her to follow her upstairs.
changes.transformed: John recollected himself soon; and putting the letter away, tried to join, with his usual cheerfulness, in the general conversation: but Elliot felt an anxiety on the subject which drew off his attention even from Wickham; and no sooner had he and his companion taken leave, than a glance from John invited him to follow him upstairs.

changes.original: When they had gained their own room, Jane, taking out her letter, said, “This is from Caroline Bingley: what it contains has surprised me a good deal.
changes.transformed: When they had gained their own room, John, taking out his letter, said, “This is from Charles Bingley: what it contains has surprised me a good deal.

changes.original: You shall hear what she says.”
changes.transformed: You shall hear what he says.”

changes.original: She then read the first sentence aloud, which comprised the information of their having just resolved to follow their brother to town directly, and of their meaning to dine that day in Grosvenor Street, where Mr. Hurst had a house.
changes.transformed: He then read the first sentence aloud, which comprised the information of their having just resolved to follow their brother to town directly, and of their meaning to dine that day in Grosvenor Street, where Mr. Hurst had a house.

changes.original: I depend on you for that.’” To these high-flown expressions Elizabeth listened with all the insensibility of distrust; and though the suddenness of their removal surprised her, she saw nothing in it really to lament: it was not to be supposed that their absence from Netherfield would prevent Mr. Bingley’s being there; and as to the loss of their society, she was persuaded that Jane must soon cease to regard it in the enjoyment of his.
changes.transformed: I depend on you for that.’” To these high-flown expressions Elliot listened with all the insensibility of distrust; and though the suddenness of their removal surprised him, he saw nothing in it really to lament: it was not to be supposed that their absence from Netherfield would prevent Mr. Bingley’s being there; and as to the loss of their society, he was persuaded that John must soon cease to regard it in the enjoyment of his.

changes.original: “It is unlucky,” said she, after a short pause, “that you should not be able to see your friends before they leave the country.
changes.transformed: “It is unlucky,” said he, after a short pause, “that you should not be able to see your friends before they leave the country.

changes.original: But may we not hope that the period of future happiness, to which Miss Bingley looks forward, may arrive earlier than she is aware, and that the delightful intercourse you have known as friends will be renewed with yet greater satisfaction as sisters?
changes.transformed: But may we not hope that the period of future happiness, to which Mr. Bingley looks forward, may arrive earlier than he is aware, and that the delightful intercourse you have known as friends will be renewed with yet greater satisfaction as brothers?

changes.original: “Caroline decidedly says that none of the party will return into Hertfordshire this winter.
changes.transformed: “Charles decidedly says that none of the party will return into Hertfordshire this winter.

changes.original: I sincerely hope your Christmas in Hertfordshire may abound in the gaieties which that season generally brings, and that your beaux will be so numerous as to prevent your feeling the loss of the three of whom we shall deprive you.’
changes.transformed: I sincerely hope your Christmas in Hertfordshire may abound in the gaieties which that season generally brings, and that your beaux will be so numerous as to prevent your feeling the loss of the three of whom we shall deprive you.’”

changes.original: “It is evident by this,” added Jane, “that he comes back no more this winter.”
changes.transformed: “It is evident by this,” added John, “that he comes back no more this winter.”

changes.original: “It is only evident that Miss Bingley does not mean he _should_.”
changes.transformed: “It is only evident that Mr. Bingley does not mean he _should_.”

changes.original: I will have no reserves from _you_. ‘Mr. Darcy is impatient to see his sister; and to confess the truth, _we_ are scarcely less eager to meet her again.
changes.transformed: I will have no reserves from _you_. ‘Mr. Darcy is impatient to see his brother; and to confess the truth, _we_ are scarcely less eager to meet him again.

changes.original: I really do not think Georgiana Darcy has her equal for beauty, elegance, and accomplishments; and the affection she inspires in Louisa and myself is heightened into something still more interesting from the hope we dare to entertain of her being hereafter our sister.
changes.transformed: I really do not think George Darcy has his equal for beauty, elegance, and accomplishments; and the affection he inspires in Louis and myself is heightened into something still more interesting from the hope we dare to entertain of him being hereafter our brother.

changes.original: My brother admires her greatly already; he will have frequent opportunity now of seeing her on the most intimate footing; her relations all wish the connection as much as his own; and a sister’s partiality is not misleading me, I think, when I call Charles most capable of engaging any woman’s heart.
changes.transformed: My brother admires him greatly already; he will have frequent opportunity now of seeing him on the most intimate footing; his relations all wish the connection as much as his own; and a brother’s partiality is not misleading me, I think, when I call Charles most capable of engaging any man’s heart.

changes.original: With all these circumstances to favour an attachment, and nothing to prevent it, am I wrong, my dearest Jane, in indulging the hope of an event which will secure the happiness of so many?’ What think you of _this_ sentence, my dear Lizzy?” said Jane, as she finished it. “Is it not clear enough?
changes.transformed: With all these circumstances to favour an attachment, and nothing to prevent it, am I wrong, my dearest John, in indulging the hope of an event which will secure the happiness of so many?’ What think you of _this_ sentence, my dear Elliot?” said John, as he finished it. “Is it not clear enough?

changes.original: Does it not expressly declare that Caroline neither expects nor wishes me to be her sister; that she is perfectly convinced of her brother’s indifference; and that if she suspects the nature of my feelings for him she means (most kindly!) to put me on my guard.
changes.transformed: Does it not expressly declare that Charles neither expects nor wishes me to be his brother; that he is perfectly convinced of his brother’s indifference; and that if he suspects the nature of my feelings for him he means (most kindly!) to put me on my guard.

changes.original: Miss Bingley sees that her brother is in love with you and wants him to marry Miss Darcy.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bingley sees that his brother is in love with you and wants him to marry Mr. Darcy.

changes.original: She follows him to town in the hope of keeping him there, and tries to persuade you that he does not care about you.”
changes.transformed: He follows him to town in the hope of keeping him there, and tries to persuade you that he does not care about you.”

changes.original: Jane shook her head.
changes.transformed: John shook his head.

changes.original: “Indeed, Jane, you ought to believe me.
changes.transformed: “Indeed, John, you ought to believe me.

changes.original: No one who has ever seen you together can doubt his affection; Miss Bingley, I am sure, cannot: she is not such a simpleton.
changes.transformed: No one who has ever seen you together can doubt his affection; Mr. Bingley, I am sure, cannot: he is not such a simpleton.

changes.original: Could she have seen half as much love in Mr. Darcy for herself, she would have ordered her wedding clothes.
changes.transformed: Could he have seen half as much love in Mr. Darcy for himself, he would have ordered his wedding clothes.

changes.original: But the case is this:--we are not rich enough or grand enough for them; and she is the more anxious to get Miss Darcy for her brother, from the notion that when there has been _one_ inter-marriage, she may have less trouble in achieving a second; in which there is certainly some ingenuity, and I dare say it would succeed if Miss de Bourgh were out of the way.
changes.transformed: But the case is this:--we are not rich enough or grand enough for them; and he is the more anxious to get Mr. Darcy for his brother, from the notion that when there has been _one_ inter-marriage, he may have less trouble in achieving a second; in which there is certainly some ingenuity, and I dare say it would succeed if Mr. de Bourgh were out of the way.

changes.original: But, my dearest Jane, you cannot seriously imagine that, because Miss Bingley tells you her brother greatly admires Miss Darcy, he is in the smallest degree less sensible of _your_ merit than when he took leave of you on Tuesday; or that it will be in her power to persuade him that, instead of being in love with you, he is very much in love with her friend.”
changes.transformed: But, my dearest John, you cannot seriously imagine that, because Mr. Bingley tells you his brother greatly admires Mr. Darcy, he is in the smallest degree less sensible of _your_ merit than when he took leave of you on Tuesday; or that it will be in his power to persuade him that, instead of being in love with you, he is very much in love with his friend.”

changes.original: “If we thought alike of Miss Bingley,” replied Jane, “your representation of all this might make me quite easy.
changes.transformed: “If we thought alike of Mr. Bingley,” replied John, “your representation of all this might make me quite easy.

changes.original: Caroline is incapable of wilfully deceiving anyone; and all that I can hope in this case is, that she is deceived herself.”
changes.transformed: Charles is incapable of wilfully deceiving anyone; and all that I can hope in this case is, that he is deceived himself.”

changes.original: You could not have started a more happy idea, since you will not take comfort in mine: believe her to be deceived, by all means.
changes.transformed: You could not have started a more happy idea, since you will not take comfort in mine: believe him to be deceived, by all means.

changes.original: You have now done your duty by her, and must fret no longer.”
changes.transformed: You have now done your duty by him, and must fret no longer.”

changes.original: “But, my dear sister, can I be happy, even supposing the best, in accepting a man whose sisters and friends are all wishing him to marry elsewhere?”
changes.transformed: “But, my dear brother, can I be happy, even supposing the best, in accepting a man whose brothers and friends are all wishing him to marry elsewhere?”

changes.original: “You must decide for yourself,” said Elizabeth; “and if, upon mature deliberation, you find that the misery of disobliging his two sisters is more than equivalent to the happiness of being his wife, I advise you, by all means, to refuse him.”
changes.transformed: “You must decide for yourself,” said Elliot; “and if, upon mature deliberation, you find that the misery of disobliging his two brothers is more than equivalent to the happiness of being his husband, I advise you, by all means, to refuse him.”

changes.original: “How can you talk so?” said Jane, faintly smiling; “you must know, that, though I should be exceedingly grieved at their disapprobation, I could not hesitate.”
changes.transformed: “How can you talk so?” said John, faintly smiling; “you must know, that, though I should be exceedingly grieved at their disapprobation, I could not hesitate.”

changes.original: The idea of his returning no more Elizabeth treated with the utmost contempt.
changes.transformed: The idea of his returning no more Elliot treated with the utmost contempt.

changes.original: It appeared to her merely the suggestion of Caroline’s interested wishes; and she could not for a moment suppose that those wishes, however openly or artfully spoken, could influence a young man so totally independent of everyone.
changes.transformed: It appeared to him merely the suggestion of Charles’s interested wishes; and he could not for a moment suppose that those wishes, however openly or artfully spoken, could influence a young man so totally independent of everyone.

changes.original: She represented to her sister, as forcibly as possible, what she felt on the subject, and had soon the pleasure of seeing its happy effect.
changes.transformed: He represented to his brother, as forcibly as possible, what he felt on the subject, and had soon the pleasure of seeing its happy effect.

changes.original: Jane’s temper was not desponding; and she was gradually led to hope, though the diffidence of affection sometimes overcame the hope, that Bingley would return to Netherfield, and answer every wish of her heart.
changes.transformed: John’s temper was not desponding; and he was gradually led to hope, though the diffidence of affection sometimes overcame the hope, that Bingley would return to Netherfield, and answer every wish of his heart.

changes.original: They agreed that Mrs. Bennet should only hear of the departure of the family, without being alarmed on the score of the gentleman’s conduct; but even this partial communication gave her a great deal of concern, and she bewailed it as exceedingly unlucky that the ladies should happen to go away just as they were all getting so intimate together.
changes.transformed: They agreed that Mr. Bennet should only hear of the departure of the family, without being alarmed on the score of the gentleman’s conduct; but even this partial communication gave him a great deal of concern, and he bewailed it as exceedingly unlucky that the gentlemen should happen to go away just as they were all getting so intimate together.

changes.original: After lamenting it, however, at some length, she had the consolation of thinking that Mr. Bingley would be soon down again, and soon dining at Longbourn; and the conclusion of all was the comfortable declaration, that, though he had been invited only to a family dinner, she would take care to have two full courses.
changes.transformed: After lamenting it, however, at some length, he had the consolation of thinking that Mr. Bingley would be soon down again, and soon dining at Longbourn; and the conclusion of all was the comfortable declaration, that, though he had been invited only to a family dinner, he would take care to have two full courses.

changes.original: The Bennets were engaged to dine with the Lucases; and again, during the chief of the day, was Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to Mr. Collins.
changes.transformed: The Bennets were engaged to dine with the Lucases; and again, during the chief of the day, was Mr. Lucas so kind as to listen to Mr. Collins.

changes.original: Elizabeth took an opportunity of thanking her. “It keeps him in good humour,” said she, “and I am more obliged to you than I can express.”
changes.transformed: Elliot took an opportunity of thanking him. “It keeps him in good humour,” said he, “and I am more obliged to you than I can express.”

changes.original: Charlotte assured her friend of her satisfaction in being useful, and that it amply repaid her for the little sacrifice of her time.
changes.transformed: Charles assured his friend of his satisfaction in being useful, and that it amply repaid him for the little sacrifice of his time.

changes.original: This was very amiable; but Charlotte’s kindness extended farther than Elizabeth had any conception of:--its object was nothing less than to secure her from any return of Mr. Collins’s addresses, by engaging them towards herself.
changes.transformed: This was very amiable; but Charles’s kindness extended farther than Elliot had any conception of:--its object was nothing less than to secure him from any return of Mr. Collins’s addresses, by engaging them towards himself.

changes.original: Such was Miss Lucas’s scheme; and appearances were so favourable, that when they parted at night, she would have felt almost sure of success if he had not been to leave Hertfordshire so very soon.
changes.transformed: Such was Mr. Lucas’s scheme; and appearances were so favourable, that when they parted at night, he would have felt almost sure of success if he had not been to leave Hertfordshire so very soon.

changes.original: But here she did injustice to the fire and independence of his character; for it led him to escape out of Longbourn House the next morning with admirable slyness, and hasten to Lucas Lodge to throw himself at her feet.
changes.transformed: But here he did injustice to the fire and independence of his character; for it led him to escape out of Longbourn House the next morning with admirable slyness, and hasten to Lucas Lodge to throw himself at his feet.

changes.original: He was anxious to avoid the notice of his cousins, from a conviction that, if they saw him depart, they could not fail to conjecture his design, and he was not willing to have the attempt known till its success could be known likewise; for, though feeling almost secure, and with reason, for Charlotte had been tolerably encouraging, he was comparatively diffident since the adventure of Wednesday.
changes.transformed: He was anxious to avoid the notice of his cousins, from a conviction that, if they saw him depart, they could not fail to conjecture his design, and he was not willing to have the attempt known till its success could be known likewise; for, though feeling almost secure, and with reason, for Charles had been tolerably encouraging, he was comparatively diffident since the adventure of Wednesday.

changes.original: Miss Lucas perceived him from an upper window as he walked towards the house, and instantly set out to meet him accidentally in the lane.
changes.transformed: Mr. Lucas perceived him from an upper window as he walked towards the house, and instantly set out to meet him accidentally in the lane.

changes.original: But little had she dared to hope that so much love and eloquence awaited her there.
changes.transformed: But little had he dared to hope that so much love and eloquence awaited him there.

changes.original: In as short a time as Mr. Collins’s long speeches would allow, everything was settled between them to the satisfaction of both; and as they entered the house, he earnestly entreated her to name the day that was to make him the happiest of men; and though such a solicitation must be waived for the present, the lady felt no inclination to trifle with his happiness.
changes.transformed: In as short a time as Mr. Collins’s long speeches would allow, everything was settled between them to the satisfaction of both; and as they entered the house, he earnestly entreated him to name the day that was to make him the happiest of men; and though such a solicitation must be waived for the present, the gentleman felt no inclination to trifle with his happiness.

changes.original: The stupidity with which he was favoured by nature must guard his courtship from any charm that could make a woman wish for its continuance; and Miss Lucas, who accepted him solely from the pure and disinterested desire of an establishment, cared not how soon that establishment were gained.
changes.transformed: The stupidity with which he was favoured by nature must guard his courtship from any charm that could make a man wish for its continuance; and Mr. Lucas, who accepted him solely from the pure and disinterested desire of an establishment, cared not how soon that establishment were gained.

changes.original: Sir William and Lady Lucas were speedily applied to for their consent; and it was bestowed with a most joyful alacrity.
changes.transformed: Mr. William and Mr. Lucas were speedily applied to for their consent; and it was bestowed with a most joyful alacrity.

changes.original: Mr. Collins’s present circumstances made it a most eligible match for their daughter, to whom they could give little fortune; and his prospects of future wealth were exceedingly fair.
changes.transformed: Mr. Collins’s present circumstances made it a most eligible match for their son, to whom they could give little fortune; and his prospects of future wealth were exceedingly fair.

changes.original: Lady Lucas began directly to calculate, with more interest than the matter had ever
changes.transformed: Mr. Lucas began directly to calculate, with more interest than the matter had ever

changes.original: excited before, how many years longer Mr. Bennet was likely to live; and Sir William gave it as his decided opinion, that whenever Mr. Collins should be in possession of the Longbourn estate, it would be highly expedient that both he and his wife should make their appearance at St. James’s.
changes.transformed: excited before, how many years longer Mr. Bennet was likely to live; and Mr. William gave it as his decided opinion, that whenever Mr. Collins should be in possession of the Longbourn estate, it would be highly expedient that both he and his husband should make their appearance at St. James’s.

changes.original: The younger girls formed hopes of _coming out_ a year or two sooner than they might otherwise have done; and the boys were relieved from their apprehension of Charlotte’s dying an old maid.
changes.transformed: The younger boys formed hopes of _coming out_ a year or two sooner than they might otherwise have done; and the boys were relieved from their apprehension of Charles’s dying an old bachelor.

changes.original: Charlotte herself was tolerably composed.
changes.transformed: Charles himself was tolerably composed.

changes.original: She had gained her point, and had time to consider of it.
changes.transformed: He had gained his point, and had time to consider of it.

changes.original: Her reflections were in general satisfactory.
changes.transformed: His reflections were in general satisfactory.

changes.original: Mr. Collins, to be sure, was neither sensible nor agreeable: his society was irksome, and his attachment to her must be imaginary.
changes.transformed: Mr. Collins, to be sure, was neither sensible nor agreeable: his society was irksome, and his attachment to him must be imaginary.

changes.original: But still he would be her husband.
changes.transformed: But still he would be his husband.

changes.original: Without thinking highly either of men or of matrimony, marriage had always been her object: it was the only honourable provision for well-educated young women of small fortune, and, however uncertain of giving happiness, must be their pleasantest preservative from want.
changes.transformed: Without thinking highly either of men or of matrimony, marriage had always been his object: it was the only honourable provision for well-educated young men of small fortune, and, however uncertain of giving happiness, must be their pleasantest preservative from want.

changes.original: This preservative she had now obtained; and at the age of twenty-seven, without having ever been handsome, she felt all the good luck of it.
changes.transformed: This preservative he had now obtained; and at the age of twenty-seven, without having ever been handsome, he felt all the good luck of it.

changes.original: The least agreeable circumstance in the business was the surprise it must occasion to Elizabeth Bennet, whose friendship she valued beyond that of any other person.
changes.transformed: The least agreeable circumstance in the business was the surprise it must occasion to Elliot Bennet, whose friendship he valued beyond that of any other person.

changes.original: Elizabeth would wonder, and probably would blame her; and though her resolution was not to be shaken, her feelings must be hurt by such a disapprobation.
changes.transformed: Elliot would wonder, and probably would blame him; and though his resolution was not to be shaken, his feelings must be hurt by such a disapprobation.

changes.original: She resolved to give her the information herself; and therefore charged Mr. Collins, when he returned to Longbourn to dinner, to drop no hint of what had passed before any of the family.
changes.transformed: He resolved to give him the information himself; and therefore charged Mr. Collins, when he returned to Longbourn to dinner, to drop no hint of what had passed before any of the family.

changes.original: As he was to begin his journey too early on the morrow to see any of the family, the ceremony of leave-taking was performed when the ladies moved for the night; and Mrs. Bennet, with great politeness and cordiality, said how happy they should be to see him at Longbourn again, whenever his other engagements might allow him to visit them.
changes.transformed: As he was to begin his journey too early on the morrow to see any of the family, the ceremony of leave-taking was performed when the gentlemen moved for the night; and Mr. Bennet, with great politeness and cordiality, said how happy they should be to see him at Longbourn again, whenever his other engagements might allow him to visit them.

changes.original: “My dear madam,” he replied, “this invitation is particularly gratifying, because it is what I have been hoping to receive; and you may be very certain that I shall avail myself of it as soon as possible.”
changes.transformed: “My dear sir,” he replied, “this invitation is particularly gratifying, because it is what I have been hoping to receive; and you may be very certain that I shall avail myself of it as soon as possible.”

changes.original: “But is there not danger of Lady Catherine’s disapprobation here, my good sir?
changes.transformed: “But is there not danger of Mr. Catherine’s disapprobation here, my good sir?

changes.original: You had better neglect your relations than run the risk of offending your patroness.”
changes.transformed: You had better neglect your relations than run the risk of offending your patron.”

changes.original: “My dear sir,” replied Mr. Collins, “I am particularly obliged to you for this friendly caution, and you may depend upon my not taking so material a step without her Ladyship’s concurrence.”
changes.transformed: “My dear sir,” replied Mr. Collins, “I am particularly obliged to you for this friendly caution, and you may depend upon my not taking so material a step without his Lordship’s concurrence.”

changes.original: Risk anything rather than her displeasure; and if you find it likely to be raised by your coming to us again, which I should think exceedingly probable, stay quietly at home, and be satisfied that _we_ shall take no offence.”
changes.transformed: Risk anything rather than his displeasure; and if you find it likely to be raised by your coming to us again, which I should think exceedingly probable, stay quietly at home, and be satisfied that _we_ shall take no offence.”

changes.original: As for my fair cousins, though my absence may not be long enough to render it necessary, I shall now take the liberty of wishing them health and happiness, not excepting my cousin Elizabeth.”
changes.transformed: As for my fair cousins, though my absence may not be long enough to render it necessary, I shall now take the liberty of wishing them health and happiness, not excepting my cousin Elliot.”

changes.original: With proper civilities, the ladies then withdrew; all of them equally surprised to find that he meditated a quick return.
changes.transformed: With proper civilities, the gentlemen then withdrew; all of them equally surprised to find that he meditated a quick return.

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet wished to understand by it that he thought of paying his addresses to one of her younger girls, and Mary might have been prevailed on to accept him.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet wished to understand by it that he thought of paying his addresses to one of his younger boys, and Mr. Martin might have been prevailed on to accept him.

changes.original: She rated his abilities much higher than any of the others: there was a solidity in his reflections which often struck her; and though by no means so clever as herself, she thought that, if encouraged to read and improve himself by such an example as hers, he might become a very agreeable companion.
changes.transformed: He rated his abilities much higher than any of the others: there was a solidity in his reflections which often struck him; and though by no means so clever as himself, he thought that, if encouraged to read and improve himself by such an example as his, he might become a very agreeable companion.

changes.original: Miss Lucas called soon after breakfast, and in a private conference with Elizabeth related the event of the day before.
changes.transformed: Mr. Lucas called soon after breakfast, and in a private conference with Elliot related the event of the day before.

changes.original: The possibility of Mr. Collins’s fancying himself in love with her friend had once occurred to Elizabeth within the last day or two: but that Charlotte could encourage him seemed almost as far from possibility as that she could encourage him herself; and her astonishment was consequently so great as to overcome at first the bounds of decorum, and she could not help crying out,--
changes.transformed: The possibility of Mr. Collins’s fancying himself in love with his friend had once occurred to Elliot within the last day or two: but that Mr. Charles could encourage him seemed almost as far from possibility as that he could encourage him himself; and his astonishment was consequently so great as to overcome at first the bounds of decorum, and he could not help crying out,--

changes.original: “Engaged to Mr. Collins! my dear Charlotte, impossible!”
changes.transformed: “Engaged to Mr. Collins! my dear Charles, impossible!”

changes.original: The steady countenance which Miss Lucas had commanded in telling her story gave way to a momentary confusion here on receiving so direct a reproach; though, as it was no more than she expected, she soon regained her composure, and calmly replied,--
changes.transformed: The steady countenance which Mr. Lucas had commanded in telling his story gave way to a momentary confusion here on receiving so direct a reproach; though, as it was no more than he expected, he soon regained his composure, and calmly replied,--

changes.original: “Why should you be surprised, my dear Eliza?
changes.transformed: “Why should you be surprised, my dear Elliot?

changes.original: Do you think it incredible that Mr. Collins should be able to procure any woman’s good opinion, because he was not so happy as to succeed with you?”
changes.transformed: Do you think it incredible that Mr. Collins should be able to procure any man’s good opinion, because he was not so happy as to succeed with you?”

changes.original: But Elizabeth had now recollected herself; and, making a strong effort for it, was able to assure her, with tolerable firmness, that the prospect of their relationship was highly grateful to her, and that she wished her all imaginable happiness.
changes.transformed: But Elliot had now recollected himself; and, making a strong effort for it, was able to assure him, with tolerable firmness, that the prospect of their relationship was highly grateful to him, and that he wished him all imaginable happiness.

changes.original: “I see what you are feeling,” replied Charlotte; “you must be surprised, very much surprised, so lately as Mr. Collins was wishing to marry you.
changes.transformed: “I see what you are feeling,” replied Mr. Charles; “you must be surprised, very much surprised, so lately as Mr. Collins was wishing to marry you.

changes.original: Elizabeth quietly answered “undoubtedly;” and, after an awkward pause, they returned to the rest of the family.
changes.transformed: Elliot quietly answered “undoubtedly;” and, after an awkward pause, they returned to the rest of the family.

changes.original: Charlotte did not stay much longer; and Elizabeth was then left to reflect on what she had heard.
changes.transformed: Mr. Charles did not stay much longer; and Elliot was then left to reflect on what he had heard.

changes.original: It was a long time before she became at all reconciled to the idea of so unsuitable a match.
changes.transformed: It was a long time before he became at all reconciled to the idea of so unsuitable a match.

changes.original: She had always felt that Charlotte’s opinion of matrimony was not exactly like her own; but she could not have supposed it possible that, when called into action, she would have sacrificed every better feeling to worldly advantage.
changes.transformed: He had always felt that Mr. Charles’s opinion of matrimony was not exactly like his own; but he could not have supposed it possible that, when called into action, he would have sacrificed every better feeling to worldly advantage.

changes.original: Charlotte, the wife of Mr. Collins, was a most humiliating picture!
changes.transformed: Charles, the husband of Mr. Collins, was a most humiliating picture!

changes.original: And to the pang of a friend disgracing herself, and sunk in her esteem, was added the distressing conviction that it was impossible for that friend to be tolerably happy in the lot she had chosen.
changes.transformed: And to the pang of a friend disgracing himself, and sunk in his esteem, was added the distressing conviction that it was impossible for that friend to be tolerably happy in the lot he had chosen.

changes.original: Elizabeth was sitting with her mother and sisters, reflecting on what she had heard, and doubting whether she was authorized to mention it, when Sir William Lucas himself appeared, sent by his daughter to announce her engagement to the family.
changes.transformed: Elliot was sitting with his father and brothers, reflecting on what he had heard, and doubting whether he was authorized to mention it, when Mr. William Lucas himself appeared, sent by his son to announce his engagement to the family.

changes.original: With many compliments to them, and much self-gratulation on the prospect of a connection between the houses, he unfolded the matter,--to an audience not merely wondering, but incredulous; for Mrs. Bennet, with more perseverance than politeness, protested he must be entirely mistaken; and Lydia, always unguarded and often uncivil, boisterously exclaimed,--
changes.transformed: With many compliments to them, and much self-gratulation on the prospect of a connection between the houses, he unfolded the matter,--to an audience not merely wondering, but incredulous; for Mr. Bennet, with more perseverance than politeness, protested he must be entirely mistaken; and Lionel, always unguarded and often uncivil, boisterously exclaimed,--

changes.original: Sir William, how can you tell such a story?
changes.transformed: Mr. William, how can you tell such a story?

changes.original: Do not you know that Mr. Collins wants to marry Lizzy?”
changes.transformed: Do not you know that Mr. Collins wants to marry Elliot?”

changes.original: Nothing less than the complaisance of a courtier could have borne without anger such treatment: but Sir William’s good-breeding carried him through it all; and though he begged leave to be positive as to the truth of his information, he listened to all their impertinence with the most forbearing courtesy.
changes.transformed: Nothing less than the complaisance of a courtier could have borne without anger such treatment: but Mr. William’s good-breeding carried him through it all; and though he begged leave to be positive as to the truth of his information, he listened to all their impertinence with the most forbearing courtesy.

changes.original: Elizabeth, feeling it incumbent on her to relieve him from so unpleasant a situation, now put herself forward to confirm his account, by mentioning her prior knowledge of it from Charlotte herself; and endeavoured to put a stop to the exclamations of her mother and sisters, by the earnestness of her congratulations to Sir William, in which she was readily joined by Jane, and by making a variety of remarks on the happiness that might be expected from the match, the excellent character of Mr. Collins, and the convenient distance of Hunsford from London.
changes.transformed: Elliot, feeling it incumbent on him to relieve him from so unpleasant a situation, now put himself forward to confirm his account, by mentioning his prior knowledge of it from Charles himself; and endeavoured to put a stop to the exclamations of his father and brothers, by the earnestness of his congratulations to Mr. William, in which he was readily joined by John, and by making a variety of remarks on the happiness that might be expected from the match, the excellent character of Mr. Collins, and the convenient distance of Hunsford from London.

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet was, in fact, too much overpowered to say a great deal while Sir William remained; but no sooner had he left them than her feelings found a rapid vent.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet was, in fact, too much overpowered to say a great deal while Mr. William remained; but no sooner had he left them than his feelings found a rapid vent.

changes.original: In the first place, she persisted in disbelieving the whole of the matter; secondly, she was very sure that Mr. Collins had been taken in; thirdly, she trusted that they would never be happy together; and, fourthly, that the match might be broken off.
changes.transformed: In the first place, he persisted in disbelieving the whole of the matter; secondly, he was very sure that Mr. Collins had been taken in; thirdly, he trusted that they would never be happy together; and, fourthly, that the match might be broken off.

changes.original: Two inferences, however, were plainly deduced from the whole: one, that Elizabeth was the real cause of all the mischief; and the other, that she herself had been barbarously used by them all; and on these two points she principally dwelt during the rest of the day.
changes.transformed: Two inferences, however, were plainly deduced from the whole: one, that Elliot was the real cause of all the mischief; and the other, that he himself had been barbarously used by them all; and on these two points he principally dwelt during the rest of the day.

changes.original: Nothing could console and nothing appease her.
changes.transformed: Nothing could console and nothing appease him.

changes.original: Nor did that day wear out her resentment.
changes.transformed: Nor did that day wear out his resentment.

changes.original: A week elapsed before she could see Elizabeth without scolding her: a month passed away before she could speak to Sir William or Lady Lucas without being rude; and many months were gone before she could at all forgive their daughter.
changes.transformed: A week elapsed before he could see Elliot without scolding him: a month passed away before he could speak to Mr. William or Mr. Lucas without being rude; and many months were gone before he could at all forgive their son.

changes.original: Mr. Bennet’s emotions were much more tranquil on the occasion, and such as he did experience he pronounced to be of a most agreeable sort; for it gratified him, he said, to discover that Charlotte Lucas, whom he had been used to think tolerably sensible, was as foolish as his wife, and more foolish than his daughter!
