changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet’s emotions were much more tranquil on the occasion, and such as he did experience he pronounced to be of a most agreeable sort; for it gratified him, he said, to discover that Charles Lucas, whom he had been used to think tolerably sensible, was as foolish as his husband, and more foolish than his son!

changes.original: Jane confessed herself a little surprised at the match: but she said less of her astonishment than of her earnest desire for their happiness; nor could Elizabeth persuade her to consider it as improbable.
changes.transformed: John confessed himself a little surprised at the match: but he said less of his astonishment than of his earnest desire for their happiness; nor could Elliot persuade him to consider it as improbable.

changes.original: Kitty and Lydia were far from envying Miss Lucas, for Mr. Collins was only a clergyman; and it affected them in no other way than as a piece of news to spread at Meryton.
changes.transformed: Kenneth and Lionel were far from envying Mr. Lucas, for Mr. Collins was only a clergyman; and it affected them in no other way than as a piece of news to spread at Meryton.

changes.original: Lady Lucas could not be insensible of triumph on being able to retort on Mrs. Bennet the comfort of having a daughter well married; and she called at Longbourn rather oftener than usual to say how happy she was, though Mrs. Bennet’s sour looks and ill-natured remarks might have been enough to drive happiness away.
changes.transformed: Mr. Lucas could not be insensible of triumph on being able to retort on Mr. Bennet the comfort of having a son well married; and he called at Longbourn rather oftener than usual to say how happy he was, though Mr. Bennet’s sour looks and ill-natured remarks might have been enough to drive happiness away.

changes.original: Between Elizabeth and Charlotte there was a restraint which kept them mutually silent on the subject; and Elizabeth felt persuaded that no real confidence could ever subsist between them again.
changes.transformed: Between Elliot and Charles there was a restraint which kept them mutually silent on the subject; and Elliot felt persuaded that no real confidence could ever subsist between them again.

changes.original: Her disappointment in Charlotte made her turn with fonder regard to her sister, of whose rectitude and delicacy she was sure her opinion could never be shaken, and for whose happiness she grew daily more anxious, as Bingley had now been gone a week, and nothing was heard of his return.
changes.transformed: His disappointment in Charles made him turn with fonder regard to his brother, of whose rectitude and delicacy he was sure his opinion could never be shaken, and for whose happiness he grew daily more anxious, as Bingley had now been gone a week, and nothing was heard of his return.

changes.original: Jane had sent Caroline an early answer to her letter, and was counting the days till she might reasonably hope to hear again.
changes.transformed: John had sent Clarence an early answer to his letter, and was counting the days till he might reasonably hope to hear again.

changes.original: After discharging his conscience on that head, he proceeded to inform them, with many rapturous expressions, of his happiness in having obtained the affection of their amiable neighbour, Miss Lucas, and then explained that it was merely with the view of enjoying her society that he had been so ready to close with their kind wish of seeing him again at Longbourn, whither he hoped to be able to return on Monday fortnight; for Lady Catherine, he added, so heartily approved his marriage, that she wished it to take place as soon as possible, which he trusted would be an unanswerable argument with his amiable Charlotte to name an early day for making him the happiest of men.
changes.transformed: After discharging his conscience on that head, he proceeded to inform them, with many rapturous expressions, of his happiness in having obtained the affection of their amiable neighbour, Mr. Lucas, and then explained that it was merely with the view of enjoying his society that he had been so ready to close with their kind wish of seeing him again at Longbourn, whither he hoped to be able to return on Monday fortnight; for Mr. Catherine, he added, so heartily approved his marriage, that he wished it to take place as soon as possible, which he trusted would be an unanswerable argument with his amiable Charles to name an early day for making him the happiest of men.

changes.original: Mr. Collins’s return into Hertfordshire was no longer a matter of pleasure to Mrs. Bennet.
changes.transformed: Mr. Collins’s return into Hertfordshire was no longer a matter of pleasure to Mr. Bennet.

changes.original: On the contrary, she was as much disposed to complain of it as her husband.
changes.transformed: On the contrary, he was as much disposed to complain of it as his husband.

changes.original: She hated having visitors in the house while her health was so indifferent, and lovers were of all people the most disagreeable.
changes.transformed: He hated having visitors in the house while his health was so indifferent, and lovers were of all people the most disagreeable.

changes.original: Such were the gentle murmurs of Mrs. Bennet, and they gave way only to the greater distress of Mr. Bingley’s continued absence.
changes.transformed: Such were the gentle murmurs of Mr. Bennet, and they gave way only to the greater distress of Mr. Bingley’s continued absence.

changes.original: Neither Jane nor Elizabeth were comfortable on this subject.
changes.transformed: Neither John nor Elliot were comfortable on this subject.

changes.original: Day after day passed away without bringing any other tidings of him than the report which shortly prevailed in Meryton of his coming no more to Netherfield the whole winter; a report which highly incensed Mrs. Bennet, and which she never failed to contradict as a most scandalous falsehood.
changes.transformed: Day after day passed away without bringing any other tidings of him than the report which shortly prevailed in Meryton of his coming no more to Netherfield the whole winter; a report which highly incensed Mr. Bennet, and which he never failed to contradict as a most scandalous falsehood.

changes.original: Even Elizabeth began to fear--not that Bingley was indifferent--but that his sisters would be successful in keeping him away.
changes.transformed: Even Elliot began to fear--not that Bingley was indifferent--but that his brothers would be successful in keeping him away.

changes.original: Unwilling as she was to admit an idea so destructive to Jane’s happiness, and so dishonourable to the stability of her lover, she could not prevent its frequently recurring.
changes.transformed: Unwilling as he was to admit an idea so destructive to John’s happiness, and so dishonourable to the stability of his lover, he could not prevent its frequently recurring.

changes.original: The united efforts of his two unfeeling sisters, and of his overpowering friend, assisted by the attractions of Miss Darcy and the amusements of London, might be too much, she feared, for the strength of his attachment.
changes.transformed: The united efforts of his two unfeeling brothers, and of his overpowering friend, assisted by the attractions of Mr. Darcy and the amusements of London, might be too much, he feared, for the strength of his attachment.

changes.original: As for Jane, _her_ anxiety under this suspense was, of course, more painful than Elizabeth’s: but whatever she felt she was desirous of concealing; and between herself and Elizabeth, therefore, the subject was never alluded to.
changes.transformed: As for John, _his_ anxiety under this suspense was, of course, more painful than Elliot’s: but whatever he felt he was desirous of concealing; and between himself and Elliot, therefore, the subject was never alluded to.

changes.original: But as no such delicacy restrained her mother, an hour seldom passed in which she did not talk of Bingley, express her impatience for his arrival, or even require Jane to confess that if he did not come back she should think herself very ill-used.
changes.transformed: But as no such delicacy restrained his father, an hour seldom passed in which he did not talk of Bingley, express his impatience for his arrival, or even require John to confess that if he did not come back he should think himself very ill-used.

changes.original: It needed all Jane’s steady mildness to bear these attacks with tolerable tranquillity.
changes.transformed: It needed all John’s steady mildness to bear these attacks with tolerable tranquillity.

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet was really in a most pitiable state.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet was really in a most pitiable state.

changes.original: The very mention of anything concerning the match threw her into an agony of ill-humour, and wherever she went she was sure of hearing it talked of.
changes.transformed: The very mention of anything concerning the match threw him into an agony of ill-humour, and wherever he went he was sure of hearing it talked of.

changes.original: The sight of Miss Lucas was odious to her.
changes.transformed: The sight of Mr. Lucas was odious to him.

changes.original: As her successor in that house, she regarded her with jealous abhorrence.
changes.transformed: As his successor in that house, he regarded him with jealous abhorrence.

changes.original: Whenever Charlotte came to see them, she concluded her to be anticipating the hour of possession; and whenever she spoke in a low voice to Mr. Collins, was convinced that they were talking of the Longbourn estate, and resolving to turn herself and her daughters out of the house as soon as Mr. Bennet was dead.
changes.transformed: Whenever Charles came to see them, he concluded him to be anticipating the hour of possession; and whenever he spoke in a low voice to Mr. Collins, was convinced that they were talking of the Longbourn estate, and resolving to turn himself and his sons out of the house as soon as Mr. Bennet was dead.

changes.original: She complained bitterly of all this to her husband.
changes.transformed: He complained bitterly of all this to his husband.

changes.original: “Indeed, Mr. Bennet,” said she, “it is very hard to think that Charlotte Lucas should ever be mistress of this house, that _I_ should be forced to make way for _her_, and live to see her take my place in it!”
changes.transformed: “Indeed, Mr. Bennet,” said he, “it is very hard to think that Charles Lucas should ever be master of this house, that _I_ should be forced to make way for _him_, and live to see him take my place in it!”

changes.original: This was not very consoling to Mrs. Bennet; and, therefore, instead of making any answer, she went on as before.
changes.transformed: This was not very consoling to Mr. Bennet; and, therefore, instead of making any answer, he went on as before.

changes.original: How anyone could have the conscience to entail away an estate from one’s own daughters I cannot understand; and all for the sake of Mr. Collins, too!
changes.transformed: How anyone could have the conscience to entail away an estate from one’s own sons I cannot understand; and all for the sake of Mr. Collins, too!

changes.original: Miss Bingley’s letter arrived, and put an end to doubt.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bingley’s letter arrived, and put an end to doubt.

changes.original: The very first sentence conveyed the assurance of their being all settled in London for the winter, and concluded with her brother’s regret at not having had time to pay his respects to his friends in Hertfordshire before he left the country.
changes.transformed: The very first sentence conveyed the assurance of their being all settled in London for the winter, and concluded with his brother’s regret at not having had time to pay his respects to his friends in Hertfordshire before he left the country.

changes.original: Hope was over, entirely over; and when Jane could attend to the rest of the letter, she found little, except the professed affection of the writer, that could give her any comfort.
changes.transformed: Hope was over, entirely over; and when John could attend to the rest of the letter, he found little, except the professed affection of the writer, that could give him any comfort.

changes.original: Miss Darcy’s praise occupied the chief of it.
changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy’s praise occupied the chief of it.

changes.original: Her many attractions were again dwelt on; and Caroline boasted joyfully of their increasing intimacy, and ventured to predict the accomplishment of the wishes which had been unfolded in her former letter.
changes.transformed: His many attractions were again dwelt on; and Charles boasted joyfully of their increasing intimacy, and ventured to predict the accomplishment of the wishes which had been unfolded in his former letter.

changes.original: She wrote also with great pleasure of her brother’s being an inmate of Mr. Darcy’s house, and mentioned with raptures some plans of the latter with regard to new furniture.
changes.transformed: He wrote also with great pleasure of his brother’s being an inmate of Mr. Darcy’s house, and mentioned with raptures some plans of the latter with regard to new furniture.

changes.original: Elizabeth, to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this, heard it in silent indignation.
changes.transformed: Elliot, to whom John very soon communicated the chief of all this, heard it in silent indignation.

changes.original: Her heart was divided between concern for her sister and resentment against all others.
changes.transformed: His heart was divided between concern for his brother and resentment against all others.

changes.original: To Caroline’s assertion of her brother’s being partial to Miss Darcy, she paid no credit.
changes.transformed: To Charles’s assertion of his brother’s being partial to Mr. Darcy, he paid no credit.

changes.original: That he was really fond of Jane, she doubted no more than she had ever done; and much as she had always been disposed to like him, she could not think without anger, hardly without contempt, on that easiness of temper, that want of proper resolution, which now made him the slave of his designing friends, and led him to sacrifice his own happiness to the caprice of their inclinations.
changes.transformed: That he was really fond of John, he doubted no more than he had ever done; and much as he had always been disposed to like him, he could not think without anger, hardly without contempt, on that easiness of temper, that want of proper resolution, which now made him the slave of his designing friends, and led him to sacrifice his own happiness to the caprice of their inclinations.

changes.original: Had his own happiness, however, been the only sacrifice, he might have been allowed to sport with it in whatever manner he thought best; but her sister’s was involved in it, as she thought he must be sensible himself.
changes.transformed: Had his own happiness, however, been the only sacrifice, he might have been allowed to sport with it in whatever manner he thought best; but his brother’s was involved in it, as he thought he must be sensible himself.

changes.original: She could think of nothing else; and yet, whether Bingley’s regard had really died away, or were suppressed by his friends’ interference; whether he had been aware of Jane’s attachment, or whether it had escaped his observation; whichever were the case, though her opinion of him must be materially affected by the difference, her sister’s situation remained the same, her peace equally wounded.
changes.transformed: He could think of nothing else; and yet, whether Bingley’s regard had really died away, or were suppressed by his friends’ interference; whether he had been aware of John’s attachment, or whether it had escaped his observation; whichever were the case, though his opinion of him must be materially affected by the difference, his brother’s situation remained the same, his peace equally wounded.

changes.original: A day or two passed before Jane had courage to speak of her feelings to Elizabeth; but at last, on Mrs. Bennet’s leaving them together, after a longer irritation than usual about Netherfield and its master, she could not help saying,--
changes.transformed: A day or two passed before John had courage to speak of his feelings to Elliot; but at last, on Mr. Bennet’s leaving them together, after a longer irritation than usual about Netherfield and its master, he could not help saying,--

changes.original: “O that my dear mother had more command over herself! she can have no idea of the pain she gives me by her continual reflections on him.
changes.transformed: “O that my dear father had more command over himself! He can have no idea of the pain he gives me by his continual reflections on him.

changes.original: Elizabeth looked at her sister with incredulous solicitude, but said nothing.
changes.transformed: Elliot looked at his brother with incredulous solicitude, but said nothing.

changes.original: “You doubt me,” cried Jane, slightly colouring; “indeed, you have no reason.
changes.transformed: “You doubt me,” cried John, slightly colouring; “indeed, you have no reason.

changes.original: With a stronger voice she soon added, “I have this comfort immediately, that it has not been more than an error of fancy on my side, and that it has done no harm to anyone but myself.”
changes.transformed: With a stronger voice he soon added, “I have this comfort immediately, that it has not been more than an error of fancy on my side, and that it has done no harm to anyone but myself.”

changes.original: “My dear Jane,” exclaimed Elizabeth, “you are too good.
changes.transformed: “My dear John,” exclaimed Elliot, “you are too good.

changes.original: Miss Bennet eagerly disclaimed all extraordinary merit, and threw back the praise on her sister’s warm affection.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet eagerly disclaimed all extraordinary merit, and threw back the praise on his brother’s warm affection.

changes.original: “Nay,” said Elizabeth, “this is not fair. _You_ wish to think all the world respectable, and are hurt if I speak ill of anybody. _I_ only want to think _you_ perfect, and you set yourself against it.
changes.transformed: “Nay,” said Elliot, “this is not fair. _You_ wish to think all the world respectable, and are hurt if I speak ill of anybody. _I_ only want to think _you_ perfect, and you set yourself against it.

changes.original: I have met with two instances lately: one I will not mention, the other is Charlotte’s marriage.
changes.transformed: I have met with two instances lately: one I will not mention, the other is Charles’s marriage.

changes.original: “My dear Lizzy, do not give way to such feelings as these.
changes.transformed: “My dear Elliot, do not give way to such feelings as these.

changes.original: Consider Mr. Collins’s respectability, and Charlotte’s prudent, steady character.
changes.transformed: Consider Mr. Collins’s respectability, and Charles’s prudent, steady character.

changes.original: Remember that she is one of a large family; that as to fortune it is a most eligible match; and be ready to believe, for everybody’s sake, that she may feel something like regard and esteem for our cousin.”
changes.transformed: Remember that he is one of a large family; that as to fortune it is a most eligible match; and be ready to believe, for everybody’s sake, that he may feel something like regard and esteem for our cousin.”

changes.original: “To oblige you, I would try to believe almost anything, but no one else could be benefited by such a belief as this; for were I persuaded that Charlotte had any regard for him, I should only think worse of her understanding than I now do of her heart.
changes.transformed: “To oblige you, I would try to believe almost anything, but no one else could be benefited by such a belief as this; for were I persuaded that Charles had any regard for him, I should only think worse of his understanding than I now do of his heart.

changes.original: My dear Jane, Mr. Collins is a conceited, pompous, narrow-minded, silly man: you know he is, as well as I do; and you must feel, as well as I do, that the woman who marries him cannot have a proper way of thinking.
changes.transformed: My dear John, Mr. Collins is a conceited, pompous, narrow-minded, silly man: you know he is, as well as I do; and you must feel, as well as I do, that the man who marries him cannot have a proper way of thinking.

changes.original: You shall not defend her, though it is Charlotte Lucas.
changes.transformed: You shall not defend him, though it is Charles Lucas.

changes.original: “I must think your language too strong in speaking of both,” replied Jane; “and I hope you will be convinced of it, by seeing them happy together.
changes.transformed: “I must think your language too strong in speaking of both,” replied John; “and I hope you will be convinced of it, by seeing them happy together.

changes.original: I cannot misunderstand you, but I entreat you, dear Lizzy, not to pain me by thinking _that person_ to blame, and saying your opinion of him is sunk.
changes.transformed: I cannot misunderstand you, but I entreat you, dear Elliot, not to pain me by thinking _that person_ to blame, and saying your opinion of him is sunk.

changes.original: Women fancy admiration means more than it does.”
changes.transformed: Men fancy admiration means more than it does.”

changes.original: “I am far from attributing any part of Mr. Bingley’s conduct to design,” said Elizabeth; “but, without scheming to do wrong, or to make others unhappy, there may be error and there may be misery.
changes.transformed: “I am far from attributing any part of Mr. Bingley’s conduct to design,” said Elliot; “but, without scheming to do wrong, or to make others unhappy, there may be error and there may be misery.

changes.original: “You persist, then, in supposing his sisters influence him?”
changes.transformed: “You persist, then, in supposing his brothers influence him?”

changes.original: They can only wish his happiness; and if he is attached to me no other woman can secure it.”
changes.transformed: They can only wish his happiness; and if he is attached to me no other man can secure it.”

changes.original: They may wish many things besides his happiness: they may wish his increase of wealth and consequence; they may wish him to marry a girl who has all the importance of money, great connections, and pride.”
changes.transformed: They may wish many things besides his happiness: they may wish his increase of wealth and consequence; they may wish him to marry a boy who has all the importance of money, great connections, and pride.”

changes.original: “Beyond a doubt they do wish him to choose Miss Darcy,” replied Jane; “but this may be from better feelings than you are supposing.
changes.transformed: “Beyond a doubt they do wish him to choose Mr. Darcy,” replied John; “but this may be from better feelings than you are supposing.

changes.original: They have known her much longer than they have known me; no wonder if they love her better.
changes.transformed: They have known him much longer than they have known me; no wonder if they love him better.

changes.original: What sister would think herself at liberty to do it, unless there were something very objectionable?
changes.transformed: What brother would think himself at liberty to do it, unless there were something very objectionable?

changes.original: I am not ashamed of having been mistaken--or, at least, it is slight, it is nothing in comparison of what I should feel in thinking ill of him or his sisters.
changes.transformed: I am not ashamed of having been mistaken--or, at least, it is slight, it is nothing in comparison of what I should feel in thinking ill of him or his brothers.

changes.original: Elizabeth could not oppose such a wish; and from this time Mr. Bingley’s name was scarcely ever mentioned between them.
changes.transformed: Elliot could not oppose such a wish; and from this time Mr. Bingley’s name was scarcely ever mentioned between them.

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet still continued to wonder and repine at his returning no more; and though a day seldom passed in which Elizabeth did not account for it clearly, there seemed little chance of her ever considering it with less perplexity.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet still continued to wonder and repine at his returning no more; and though a day seldom passed in which Elliot did not account for it clearly, there seemed little chance of him ever considering it with less perplexity.

changes.original: Her daughter endeavoured to convince her of what she did not believe herself, that his attentions to Jane had been merely the effect of a common and transient liking, which ceased when he saw her no more; but though the probability of the statement was admitted at the time, she had the same story to repeat every day.
changes.transformed: His son endeavoured to convince him of what he did not believe himself, that his attentions to John had been merely the effect of a common and transient liking, which ceased when he saw him no more; but though the probability of the statement was admitted at the time, he had the same story to repeat every day.

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet’s best comfort was, that Mr. Bingley must be down again in the summer.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet’s best comfort was, that Mr. Bingley must be down again in the summer.

changes.original: Mr. Bennet treated the matter differently. “So, Lizzy,” said he, one day, “your sister is crossed in love, I find.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet treated the matter differently. “So, Elliot,” said he, one day, “your brother is crossed in love, I find.

changes.original: I congratulate her.
changes.transformed: I congratulate him.

changes.original: Next to being married, a girl likes to be crossed in love a little now and then.
changes.transformed: Next to being married, a boy likes to be crossed in love a little now and then.

changes.original: It is something to think of, and gives her a sort of distinction among her companions.
changes.transformed: It is something to think of, and gives him a sort of distinction among his companions.

changes.original: You will hardly bear to be long outdone by Jane.
changes.transformed: You will hardly bear to be long outdone by John.

changes.original: Here are officers enough at Meryton to disappoint all the young ladies in the country.
changes.transformed: Here are officers enough at Meryton to disappoint all the young gentlemen in the country.

changes.original: We must not all expect Jane’s good fortune.”
changes.transformed: We must not all expect John’s good fortune.”

changes.original: “True,” said Mr. Bennet; “but it is a comfort to think that, whatever of that kind may befall you, you have an affectionate mother who will always make the most of it.”
changes.transformed: “True,” said Mr. Bennet; “but it is a comfort to think that, whatever of that kind may befall you, you have an affectionate father who will always make the most of it.”

changes.original: The whole of what Elizabeth had already heard, his claims on Mr. Darcy, and all that he had suffered from him, was now openly acknowledged and publicly canvassed; and everybody was pleased to think how much they had always disliked Mr. Darcy before they had known anything of the matter.
changes.transformed: The whole of what Elliot had already heard, his claims on Mr. Darcy, and all that he had suffered from him, was now openly acknowledged and publicly canvassed; and everybody was pleased to think how much they had always disliked Mr. Darcy before they had known anything of the matter.

changes.original: Miss Bennet was the only creature who could suppose there might be any extenuating circumstances in the case unknown to the society of Hertfordshire: her mild and steady candour always pleaded for allowances, and urged the possibility of mistakes; but by everybody else Mr. Darcy was condemned as the worst of men.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet was the only creature who could suppose there might be any extenuating circumstances in the case unknown to the society of Hertfordshire: his mild and steady candour always pleaded for allowances, and urged the possibility of mistakes; but by everybody else Mr. Darcy was condemned as the worst of men.

changes.original: After a week spent in professions of love and schemes of felicity, Mr. Collins was called from his amiable Charlotte by the arrival of Saturday.
changes.transformed: After a week spent in professions of love and schemes of felicity, Mr. Collins was called from his amiable Charles by the arrival of Saturday.

changes.original: The pain of separation, however, might be alleviated on his side by preparations for the reception of his bride, as he had reason to hope, that shortly after his next return into Hertfordshire, the day would be fixed that was to make him the happiest of men.
changes.transformed: The pain of separation, however, might be alleviated on his side by preparations for the reception of his groom, as he had reason to hope, that shortly after his next return into Hertfordshire, the day would be fixed that was to make him the happiest of men.

changes.original: On the following Monday, Mrs. Bennet had the pleasure of receiving her brother and his wife, who came, as usual, to spend the Christmas at Longbourn.
changes.transformed: On the following Monday, Mr. Bennet had the pleasure of receiving his brother and his husband, who came, as usual, to spend the Christmas at Longbourn.

changes.original: Mr. Gardiner was a sensible, gentlemanlike man, greatly superior to his sister, as well by nature as education.
changes.transformed: Mr. Gardiner was a sensible, gentlemanlike man, greatly superior to his brother, as well by nature as education.

changes.original: The Netherfield ladies would have had difficulty in believing that a man who lived by trade, and within view of his own warehouses, could have been so well-bred and agreeable.
changes.transformed: The Netherfield gentlemen would have had difficulty in believing that a man who lived by trade, and within view of his own warehouses, could have been so well-bred and agreeable.

changes.original: Mrs. Gardiner, who was several years younger than Mrs. Bennet and Mrs. Philips, was an amiable, intelligent, elegant woman, and a great favourite with her Longbourn nieces.
changes.transformed: Mr. Gardiner, who was several years younger than Mr. Bennet and Mr. Philips, was an amiable, intelligent, elegant man, and a great favourite with his Longbourn nephews.

changes.original: Between the two eldest and herself especially, there subsisted a very particular regard.
changes.transformed: Between the two eldest and himself especially, there subsisted a very particular regard.

changes.original: They had frequently been staying with her in town.
changes.transformed: They had frequently been staying with him in town.

changes.original: The first part of Mrs. Gardiner’s business, on her arrival, was to distribute her presents and describe the newest fashions.
changes.transformed: The first part of Mr. Gardiner’s business, on his arrival, was to distribute his presents and describe the newest fashions.

changes.original: When this was done, she had a less active part to play.
changes.transformed: When this was done, he had a less active part to play.

changes.original: It became her turn to listen.
changes.transformed: It became his turn to listen.

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet had many grievances to relate, and much to complain of.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet had many grievances to relate, and much to complain of.

changes.original: They had all been very ill-used since she last saw her sister.
changes.transformed: They had all been very ill-used since he last saw his brother.

changes.original: Two of her girls had been on the point of marriage, and after all there was nothing in it.
changes.transformed: Two of his boys had been on the point of marriage, and after all there was nothing in it.

changes.original: “I do not blame Jane,” she continued, “for Jane would have got Mr. Bingley if she could.
changes.transformed: “I do not blame John,” he continued, “for John would have got Mr. Bingley if he could.

changes.original: But, Lizzy!
changes.transformed: But, Elliot!

changes.original: Oh, sister! it is very hard to think that she might have been Mr. Collins’s wife by this time, had not it been for her own perverseness.
changes.transformed: Oh, brother! it is very hard to think that he might have been Mr. Collins’s husband by this time, had not it been for his own perverseness.

changes.original: He made her an offer in this very room, and she refused him.
changes.transformed: He made him an offer in this very room, and he refused him.

changes.original: The consequence of it is, that Lady Lucas will have a daughter married before I have, and that Longbourn estate is just as much entailed as ever.
changes.transformed: The consequence of it is, that Mr. Lucas will have a son married before I have, and that Longbourn estate is just as much entailed as ever.

changes.original: The Lucases are very artful people, indeed, sister.
changes.transformed: The Lucases are very artful people, indeed, brother.

changes.original: Mrs. Gardiner, to whom the chief of this news had been given before, in the course of Jane and Elizabeth’s correspondence with her, made her sister a slight answer, and, in compassion to her nieces, turned the conversation.
changes.transformed: Mr. Gardiner, to whom the chief of this news had been given before, in the course of John and Elliot’s correspondence with him, made his brother a slight answer, and, in compassion to his nephews, turned the conversation.

changes.original: When alone with Elizabeth afterwards, she spoke more on the subject. “It seems likely to have been a desirable match for Jane,” said she. “I am sorry it went off.
changes.transformed: When alone with Elliot afterwards, he spoke more on the subject. “It seems likely to have been a desirable match for John,” said he. “I am sorry it went off.

changes.original: A young man, such as you describe Mr. Bingley, so easily falls in love with a pretty girl for a few weeks, and, when accident separates them, so easily forgets her, that these sort of inconstancies are very frequent.”
changes.transformed: A young man, such as you describe Mr. Bingley, so easily falls in love with a handsome boy for a few weeks, and, when accident separates them, so easily forgets him, that these sort of inconstancies are very frequent.”

changes.original: “An excellent consolation in its way,” said Elizabeth; “but it will not do for _us_.
changes.transformed: “An excellent consolation in its way,” said Elliot; “but it will not do for _us_.

changes.original: It does not often happen that the interference of friends will persuade a young man of independent fortune to think no more of a girl whom he was violently in love with only a few days before.”
changes.transformed: It does not often happen that the interference of friends will persuade a young man of independent fortune to think no more of a boy whom he was violently in love with only a few days before.”

changes.original: “I never saw a more promising inclination; he was growing quite inattentive to other people, and wholly engrossed by her.
changes.transformed: “I never saw a more promising inclination; he was growing quite inattentive to other people, and wholly engrossed by him.

changes.original: At his own ball he offended two or three young ladies by not asking them to dance; and I spoke to him twice myself without receiving an answer.
changes.transformed: At his own ball he offended two or three young gentlemen by not asking them to dance; and I spoke to him twice myself without receiving an answer.

changes.original: Poor Jane!
changes.transformed: Poor John!

changes.original: I am sorry for her, because, with her disposition, she may not get over it immediately.
changes.transformed: I am sorry for him, because, with his disposition, he may not get over it immediately.

changes.original: It had better have happened to _you_, Lizzy; you would have laughed yourself out of it sooner.
changes.transformed: It had better have happened to _you_, Elliot; you would have laughed yourself out of it sooner.

changes.original: But do you think she would be prevailed on to go back with us?
changes.transformed: But do you think he would be prevailed on to go back with us?

changes.original: Elizabeth was exceedingly pleased with this proposal, and felt persuaded of her sister’s ready acquiescence.
changes.transformed: Elliot was exceedingly pleased with this proposal, and felt persuaded of his brother’s ready acquiescence.

changes.original: “I hope,” added Mrs. Gardiner, “that no consideration with regard to this young man will influence her.
changes.transformed: “I hope,” added Mr. Gardiner, “that no consideration with regard to this young man will influence him.

changes.original: We live in so different a part of town, all our connections are so different, and, as you well know, we go out so little, that it is very improbable they should meet at all, unless he really comes to see her.”
changes.transformed: We live in so different a part of town, all our connections are so different, and, as you well know, we go out so little, that it is very improbable they should meet at all, unless he really comes to see him.”

changes.original: “And _that_ is quite impossible; for he is now in the custody of his friend, and Mr. Darcy would no more suffer him to call on Jane in such a part of London!
changes.transformed: “And _that_ is quite impossible; for he is now in the custody of his friend, and Mr. Darcy would no more suffer him to call on John in such a part of London!

changes.original: My dear aunt, how could you think of it?
changes.transformed: My dear uncle, how could you think of it?

changes.original: But does not Jane correspond with his sister? _She_ will not be able to help calling.”
changes.transformed: But does not John correspond with his brother? _He_ will not be able to help calling.”

changes.original: “She will drop the acquaintance entirely.”
changes.transformed: “He will drop the acquaintance entirely.”

changes.original: But, in spite of the certainty in which Elizabeth affected to place this point, as well as the still more interesting one of Bingley’s being withheld from seeing Jane, she felt a solicitude on the subject which convinced her, on examination, that she did not consider it entirely hopeless.
changes.transformed: But, in spite of the certainty in which Elliot affected to place this point, as well as the still more interesting one of Bingley’s being withheld from seeing John, he felt a solicitude on the subject which convinced him, on examination, that he did not consider it entirely hopeless.

changes.original: It was possible, and sometimes she thought it probable, that his affection might be re-animated, and the influence of his friends successfully combated by the more natural influence of Jane’s attractions.
changes.transformed: It was possible, and sometimes he thought it probable, that his affection might be re-animated, and the influence of his friends successfully combated by the more natural influence of John’s attractions.

changes.original: Miss Bennet accepted her aunt’s invitation with pleasure; and the Bingleys were no otherwise in her thoughts at the same time than as she hoped, by Caroline’s not living in the same house with her brother, she might occasionally spend a morning with her, without any danger of seeing him.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet accepted his uncle’s invitation with pleasure; and the Bingleys were no otherwise in his thoughts at the same time than as he hoped, by Charles’s not living in the same house with his brother, he might occasionally spend a morning with him, without any danger of seeing him.

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet had so carefully provided for the entertainment of her brother and sister, that they did not once sit down to a family dinner.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet had so carefully provided for the entertainment of his brother, that he did not once sit down to a family dinner.

changes.original: When the engagement was for home, some of the officers always made part of it, of which officers Mr. Wickham was sure to be one; and on these occasions Mrs. Gardiner, rendered suspicious by Elizabeth’s warm commendation of him, narrowly observed them both.
changes.transformed: When the engagement was for home, some of the officers always made part of it, of which officers Mr. Wickham was sure to be one; and on these occasions Mr. Gardiner, rendered suspicious by Elliot’s warm commendation of him, narrowly observed them both.

changes.original: Without supposing them, from what she saw, to be very seriously in love, their preference of each other was plain enough to make her a little uneasy; and she resolved to speak to Elizabeth on the subject before she left Hertfordshire, and represent to her the imprudence of encouraging such an attachment.
changes.transformed: Without supposing them, from what he saw, to be very seriously in love, their preference of each other was plain enough to make him a little uneasy; and he resolved to speak to Elliot on the subject before he left Hertfordshire, and represent to him the imprudence of encouraging such an attachment.

changes.original: To Mrs. Gardiner, Wickham had one means of affording pleasure, unconnected with his general powers.
changes.transformed: To Mr. Gardiner, Wickham had one means of affording pleasure, unconnected with his general powers.

changes.original: About ten or a dozen years ago, before her marriage, she had spent a considerable time in that very part of Derbyshire to which he belonged.
changes.transformed: About ten or a dozen years ago, before his marriage, he had spent a considerable time in that very part of Derbyshire to which he belonged.

changes.original: They had, therefore, many acquaintance in common; and, though Wickham had been little there since the death of Darcy’s father, five years before, it was yet in his power to give her fresher intelligence of her former friends than she had been in the way of procuring.
changes.transformed: They had, therefore, many acquaintance in common; and, though Wickham had been little there since the death of Darcy’s father, five years before, it was yet in his power to give him fresher intelligence of his former friends than he had been in the way of procuring.

changes.original: Mrs. Gardiner had seen Pemberley, and known the late Mr. Darcy by character perfectly well.
changes.transformed: Mr. Gardiner had seen Pemberley, and known the late Mr. Darcy by character perfectly well.

changes.original: In comparing her recollection of Pemberley with the minute description which Wickham could give, and in bestowing her tribute of praise on the character of its late possessor, she was delighting both him and herself.
changes.transformed: In comparing his recollection of Pemberley with the minute description which Wickham could give, and in bestowing his tribute of praise on the character of its late possessor, he was delighting both him and himself.

changes.original: On being made acquainted with the present Mr. Darcy’s treatment of him, she tried to remember something of that gentleman’s reputed disposition, when quite a lad, which might agree with it; and was confident, at last, that she recollected having heard Mr. Fitzwilliam Darcy formerly spoken of as a very proud, ill-natured boy.
changes.transformed: On being made acquainted with the present Mr. Darcy’s treatment of him, he tried to remember something of that gentleman’s reputed disposition, when quite a lad, which might agree with it; and was confident, at last, that he recollected having heard Mr. Fitzwilliam Darcy formerly spoken of as a very proud, ill-natured boy.

changes.original: Mrs. Gardiner’s caution to Elizabeth was punctually and kindly given on the first favourable opportunity of speaking to her alone: after honestly telling her what she thought, she thus went on:--
changes.transformed: Mr. Gardiner’s caution to Elliot was punctually and kindly given on the first favourable opportunity of speaking to him alone: after honestly telling him what he thought, he thus went on:--

changes.original: “You are too sensible a girl, Lizzy, to fall in love merely because you are warned against it; and, therefore, I am not afraid of speaking openly.
changes.transformed: “You are too sensible a boy, Elliot, to fall in love merely because you are warned against it; and, therefore, I am not afraid of speaking openly.

changes.original: “My dear aunt, this is being serious indeed.”
changes.transformed: “My dear uncle, this is being serious indeed.”

changes.original: “Elizabeth, you are not serious now.”
changes.transformed: “Elliot, you are not serious now.”

changes.original: In short, my dear aunt, I should be very sorry to be the means of making any of you unhappy; but since we see, every day, that where there is affection young people are seldom withheld, by immediate want of fortune, from entering into engagements with each other, how can I promise to be wiser than so many of my fellow-creatures, if I am tempted, or how am I even to know that it would be wiser to resist?
changes.transformed: In short, my dear uncle, I should be very sorry to be the means of making any of you unhappy; but since we see, every day, that where there is affection young people are seldom withheld, by immediate want of fortune, from entering into engagements with each other, how can I promise to be wiser than so many of my fellow-creatures, if I am tempted, or how am I even to know that it would be wiser to resist?

changes.original: At least you should not _remind_ your mother of inviting him.”
changes.transformed: At least you should not _remind_ your father of inviting him.”

changes.original: “As I did the other day,” said Elizabeth, with a conscious smile; “very true, it will be wise in me to refrain from _that_.
changes.transformed: “As I did the other day,” said Elliot, with a conscious smile; “very true, it will be wise in me to refrain from _that_.

changes.original: You know my mother’s ideas as to the necessity of constant company for her friends.
changes.transformed: You know my father’s ideas as to the necessity of constant company for his friends.

changes.original: Her aunt assured her that she was; and Elizabeth, having thanked her for the kindness of her hints, they parted,--a wonderful instance of advice being given on such a point without being resented.
changes.transformed: His uncle assured him that he was; and Elliot, having thanked him for the kindness of his hints, they parted,--a wonderful instance of advice being given on such a point without being resented.

changes.original: Mr. Collins returned into Hertfordshire soon after it had been quitted by the Gardiners and Jane; but, as he took up his abode with the Lucases, his arrival was no great inconvenience to Mrs. Bennet.
changes.transformed: Mr. Collins returned into Hertfordshire soon after it had been quitted by the Gardiners and John; but, as he took up his abode with the Lucases, his arrival was no great inconvenience to Mr. Bennet.

changes.original: His marriage was now fast approaching; and she was at length so far resigned as to think it inevitable, and even repeatedly to say, in an ill-natured tone, that she “_wished_ they might be happy.” Thursday was to be the wedding-day, and on Wednesday Miss Lucas paid her farewell visit; and when she rose to take leave, Elizabeth, ashamed of her mother’s ungracious and reluctant good wishes, and sincerely affected herself, accompanied her out of the room.
changes.transformed: His marriage was now fast approaching; and he was at length so far resigned as to think it inevitable, and even repeatedly to say, in an ill-natured tone, that he “_wished_ they might be happy.” Thursday was to be the wedding-day, and on Wednesday Mr. Lucas paid his farewell visit; and when he rose to take leave, Elliot, ashamed of his father’s ungracious and reluctant good wishes, and sincerely affected himself, accompanied him out of the room.

changes.original: As they went down stairs together, Charlotte said,--
changes.transformed: As they went down stairs together, Charles said,--

changes.original: “I shall depend on hearing from you very often, Eliza.”
changes.transformed: “I shall depend on hearing from you very often, Eli.”

changes.original: Elizabeth could not refuse, though she foresaw little pleasure in the visit.
changes.transformed: Elliot could not refuse, though he foresaw little pleasure in the visit.

changes.original: “My father and Maria are to come to me in March,” added Charlotte, “and I hope you will consent to be of the party.
changes.transformed: “My father and Martin are to come to me in March,” added Charles, “and I hope you will consent to be of the party.

changes.original: Indeed, Eliza, you will be as welcome to me as either of them.”
changes.transformed: Indeed, Eli, you will be as welcome to me as either of them.”

changes.original: The wedding took place: the bride and bridegroom set off for Kent from the church door, and everybody had as much to say or to hear on the subject as usual.
changes.transformed: The wedding took place: the groom and groom set off for Kent from the church door, and everybody had as much to say or to hear on the subject as usual.

changes.original: Elizabeth soon heard from her friend, and their correspondence was as regular and frequent as it ever had been: that it should be equally unreserved was impossible.
changes.transformed: Elliot soon heard from his friend, and their correspondence was as regular and frequent as it ever had been: that it should be equally unreserved was impossible.

changes.original: Elizabeth could never address her without feeling that all the comfort of intimacy was over; and, though determined not to slacken as a correspondent, it was for the sake of what had been rather than what was.
changes.transformed: Elliot could never address him without feeling that all the comfort of intimacy was over; and, though determined not to slacken as a correspondent, it was for the sake of what had been rather than what was.

changes.original: Charlotte’s first letters were received with a good deal of eagerness: there could not but be curiosity to know how she would speak of her new home, how she would like Lady Catherine, and how happy she would dare pronounce herself to be; though, when the letters were read, Elizabeth felt that Charlotte expressed herself on every point exactly as she might have foreseen.
changes.transformed: Charles’s first letters were received with a good deal of eagerness: there could not but be curiosity to know how he would speak of his new home, how he would like Mr. Catherine, and how happy he would dare pronounce himself to be; though, when the letters were read, Elliot felt that Charles expressed himself on every point exactly as he might have foreseen.

changes.original: She wrote cheerfully, seemed surrounded with comforts, and mentioned nothing which she could not praise.
changes.transformed: He wrote cheerfully, seemed surrounded with comforts, and mentioned nothing which he could not praise.

changes.original: The house, furniture, neighbourhood, and roads, were all to her taste, and Lady Catherine’s behaviour was most friendly and obliging.
changes.transformed: The house, furniture, neighbourhood, and roads, were all to his taste, and Mr. Catherine’s behaviour was most friendly and obliging.

changes.original: It was Mr. Collins’s picture of Hunsford and Rosings rationally softened; and Elizabeth perceived that she must wait for her own visit there, to know the rest.
changes.transformed: It was Mr. Collins’s picture of Hunsford and Rosings rationally softened; and Elliot perceived that he must wait for his own visit there, to know the rest.

changes.original: Jane had already written a few lines to her sister, to announce their safe arrival in London; and when she wrote again, Elizabeth hoped it would be in her power to say something of the Bingleys.
changes.transformed: John had already written a few lines to his brother, to announce their safe arrival in London; and when he wrote again, Elliot hoped it would be in his power to say something of the Bingleys.

changes.original: Her impatience for this second letter was as well rewarded as impatience generally is.
changes.transformed: His impatience for this second letter was as well rewarded as impatience generally is.

changes.original: Jane had been a week in town, without either seeing or hearing from Caroline.
changes.transformed: John had been a week in town, without either seeing or hearing from Carl.

changes.original: She accounted for it, however, by supposing that her last letter to her friend from Longbourn had by some accident been lost.
changes.transformed: He accounted for it, however, by supposing that his last letter to his friend from Longbourn had by some accident been lost.

changes.original: “My aunt,” she continued, “is going to-morrow into that part of the town, and I shall take the opportunity of calling in Grosvenor Street.”
changes.transformed: “My uncle,” he continued, “is going to-morrow into that part of the town, and I shall take the opportunity of calling in Grosvenor Street.”

changes.original: She wrote again when the visit was paid, and she had seen Miss Bingley. “I did not think Caroline in spirits,” were her words, “but she was very glad to see me, and reproached me for giving her no notice of my coming to London.
changes.transformed: He wrote again when the visit was paid, and he had seen Mr. Bingley. “I did not think Charles in spirits,” were his words, “but he was very glad to see me, and reproached me for giving him no notice of my coming to London.

changes.original: I was right, therefore; my last letter had never reached her.
changes.transformed: I was right, therefore; my last letter had never reached him.

changes.original: I found that Miss Darcy was expected to dinner: I wish I could see her.
changes.transformed: I found that Mr. Darcy was expected to dinner: I wish I could see him.

changes.original: My visit was not long, as Caroline and Mrs. Hurst were going out.
changes.transformed: My visit was not long, as Charles and Mr. Hurst were going out.

changes.original: Elizabeth shook her head over this letter.
changes.transformed: Elliot shook his head over this letter.

changes.original: It convinced her that accident only could discover to Mr. Bingley her sister’s being in town.
changes.transformed: It convinced him that accident only could discover to Mr. Bingley his brother’s being in town.

changes.original: Four weeks passed away, and Jane saw nothing of him.
changes.transformed: Four weeks passed away, and John saw nothing of him.

changes.original: She endeavoured to persuade herself that she did not regret it; but she could no longer be blind to Miss Bingley’s inattention.
changes.transformed: He endeavoured to persuade himself that he did not regret it; but he could no longer be blind to Mr. Bingley’s inattention.

changes.original: After waiting at home every morning for a fortnight, and inventing every evening a fresh excuse for her, the visitor did at last appear; but the shortness of her stay, and, yet more, the alteration of her manner, would allow Jane to deceive herself no longer.
changes.transformed: After waiting at home every morning for a fortnight, and inventing every evening a fresh excuse for him, the visitor did at last appear; but the shortness of his stay, and, yet more, the alteration of his manner, would allow John to deceive himself no longer.

changes.original: The letter which she wrote on this occasion to her sister will prove what she felt:--
changes.transformed: The letter which he wrote on this occasion to his brother will prove what he felt:--

changes.original: “My dearest Lizzy will, I am sure, be incapable of triumphing in  her better judgment, at my expense, when I confess myself to have  been entirely deceived in Miss Bingley’s regard for me.
changes.transformed: “My dearest Elliot will, I am sure, be incapable of triumphing in his better judgment, at my expense, when I confess myself to have been entirely deceived in Mr. Bingley’s regard for me.

changes.original: But, my  dear sister, though the event has proved you right, do not think me  obstinate if I still assert that, considering what her behaviour  was, my confidence was as natural as your suspicion.
changes.transformed: But, my dear brother, though the event has proved you right, do not think me obstinate if I still assert that, considering what his behaviour was, my confidence was as natural as your suspicion.

changes.original: I do not at  all comprehend her reason for wishing to be intimate with me; but,  if the same circumstances were to happen again, I am sure I should  be deceived again.
changes.transformed: I do not at all comprehend his reason for wishing to be intimate with me; but, if the same circumstances were to happen again, I am sure I should be deceived again.

changes.original: Caroline did not return my visit till yesterday;  and not a note, not a line, did I receive in the meantime.
changes.transformed: Charles did not return my visit till yesterday; and not a note, not a line, did I receive in the meantime.

changes.original: When she  did come, it was very evident that she had no pleasure in it; she  made a slight, formal apology for not calling before, said not a  word of wishing to see me again, and was, in every respect, so  altered a creature, that when she went away I was perfectly  resolved to continue the acquaintance no longer.
changes.transformed: When he did come, it was very evident that he had no pleasure in it; he made a slight, formal apology for not calling before, said not a word of wishing to see me again, and was, in every respect, so altered a creature, that when he went away I was perfectly resolved to continue the acquaintance no longer.

changes.original: I pity, though I  cannot help blaming, her.
changes.transformed: I pity, though I cannot help blaming, him.

changes.original: She was very wrong in singling me out as  she did; I can safely say, that every advance to intimacy began on  her side.
changes.transformed: He was very wrong in singling me out as he did; I can safely say, that every advance to intimacy began on his side.

changes.original: But I pity her, because she must feel that she has been  acting wrong, and because I am very sure that anxiety for her  brother is the cause of it.
changes.transformed: But I pity him, because he must feel that he has been acting wrong, and because I am very sure that anxiety for his brother is the cause of it.

changes.original: I need not explain myself farther; and  though _we_ know this anxiety to be quite needless, yet if she  feels it, it will easily account for her behaviour to me; and so  deservedly dear as he is to his sister, whatever anxiety she may  feel on his behalf is natural and amiable.
changes.transformed: I need not explain myself farther; and though _we_ know this anxiety to be quite needless, yet if he feels it, it will easily account for his behaviour to me; and so deservedly dear as he is to his brother, whatever anxiety he may feel on his behalf is natural and amiable.

changes.original: I cannot but wonder,  however, at her having any such fears now, because if he had at all  cared about me, we must have met long, long ago.
changes.transformed: I cannot but wonder, however, at his having any such fears now, because if he had at all cared about me, we must have met long, long ago.

changes.original: He knows of my  being in town, I am certain, from something she said herself; and  yet it would seem, by her manner of talking, as if she wanted to  persuade herself that he is really partial to Miss Darcy.
changes.transformed: He knows of my being in town, I am certain, from something he said himself; and yet it would seem, by his manner of talking, as if he wanted to persuade himself that he is really partial to Mr. Darcy.

changes.original: I cannot  understand it.
changes.transformed: I cannot understand it.

changes.original: If I were not afraid of judging harshly, I should be  almost tempted to say, that there is a strong appearance of  duplicity in all this.
changes.transformed: If I were not afraid of judging harshly, I should be almost tempted to say, that there is a strong appearance of duplicity in all this.

changes.original: I will endeavour to banish every painful  thought, and think only of what will make me happy, your affection,  and the invariable kindness of my dear uncle and aunt.
changes.transformed: I will endeavour to banish every painful thought, and think only of what will make me happy, your affection, and the invariable kindness of my dear uncle and uncle.

changes.original: Let me hear  from you very soon.
changes.transformed: Let me hear from you very soon.

changes.original: Miss Bingley said something of his never  returning to Netherfield again, of giving up the house, but not  with any certainty.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bingley said something of his never returning to Netherfield again, of giving up the house, but not with any certainty.

changes.original: I am extremely  glad that you have such pleasant accounts from our friends at  Hunsford.
changes.transformed: I am extremely glad that you have such pleasant accounts from our friends at Hunsford.

changes.original: Pray go to see them, with Sir William and Maria.
changes.transformed: Pray go to see them, with Mr. William and Mr. Marcus.

changes.original: I am  sure you will be very comfortable there.
changes.transformed: I am sure you will be very comfortable there.

changes.original: This letter gave Elizabeth some pain; but her spirits returned, as she considered that Jane would no longer be duped, by the sister at least.
changes.transformed: This letter gave Elliot some pain; but his spirits returned, as he considered that John would no longer be duped, by the brother at least.

changes.original: She would not even wish for any renewal of his attentions.
changes.transformed: He would not even wish for any renewal of his attentions.

changes.original: His character sunk on every review of it; and, as a punishment for him, as well as a possible advantage to Jane, she seriously hoped he might really soon marry Mr. Darcy’s sister, as, by Wickham’s account, she would make him abundantly regret what he had thrown away.
changes.transformed: His character sunk on every review of it; and, as a punishment for him, as well as a possible advantage to John, he seriously hoped he might really soon marry Mr. Darcy’s brother, as, by Mr. Wickham’s account, he would make him abundantly regret what he had thrown away.

changes.original: Mrs. Gardiner about this time reminded Elizabeth of her promise concerning that gentleman, and required information; and Elizabeth had such to send as might rather give contentment to her aunt than to herself.
changes.transformed: Mr. Gardiner about this time reminded Elliot of his promise concerning that gentleman, and required information; and Elliot had such to send as might rather give contentment to his uncle than to himself.

changes.original: Elizabeth was watchful enough to see it all, but she could see it and write of it without material pain.
changes.transformed: Elliot was watchful enough to see it all, but he could see it and write of it without material pain.

changes.original: Her heart had been but slightly touched, and her vanity was satisfied with believing that _she_ would have been his only choice, had fortune permitted it.
changes.transformed: His heart had been but slightly touched, and his vanity was satisfied with believing that he would have been his only choice, had fortune permitted it.

changes.original: The sudden acquisition of ten thousand pounds was the most remarkable charm of the young lady to whom he was now rendering himself agreeable; but Elizabeth, less clear-sighted perhaps in this case than in Charlotte’s, did not quarrel with him for his wish of independence.
changes.transformed: The sudden acquisition of ten thousand pounds was the most remarkable charm of the young gentleman to whom he was now rendering himself agreeable; but Elliot, less clear-sighted perhaps in this case than in Mr. Charles’s, did not quarrel with him for his wish of independence.

changes.original: Nothing, on the contrary, could be more natural; and, while able to suppose that it cost him a few struggles to relinquish her, she was ready to allow it a wise and desirable measure for both, and could very sincerely wish him happy.
changes.transformed: Nothing, on the contrary, could be more natural; and, while able to suppose that it cost him a few struggles to relinquish him, he was ready to allow it a wise and desirable measure for both, and could very sincerely wish him happy.

changes.original: All this was acknowledged to Mrs. Gardiner; and, after relating the circumstances, she thus went on:--“I am now convinced, my dear aunt, that I have never been much in love; for had I really experienced that pure and elevating passion, I should at present detest his very name, and wish him all manner of evil.
changes.transformed: All this was acknowledged to Mr. Gardiner; and, after relating the circumstances, he thus went on:--“I am now convinced, my dear uncle, that I have never been much in love; for had I really experienced that pure and elevating passion, I should at present detest his very name, and wish him all manner of evil.

changes.original: But my feelings are not only cordial towards _him_, they are even impartial towards Miss King.
changes.transformed: But my feelings are not only cordial towards him, they are even impartial towards Mr. King.

changes.original: I cannot find out that I hate her at all, or that I am in the least unwilling to think her a very good sort of girl.
changes.transformed: I cannot find out that I hate him at all, or that I am in the least unwilling to think him a very good sort of fellow.

changes.original: Kitty and Lydia take his defection much more to heart than I do.
changes.transformed: Mr. Kit and Mr. Lyndon take his defection much more to heart than I do.

changes.original: They are young in the ways of the world, and not yet open to the mortifying conviction that handsome young men must have something to live on as well as the plain.”
changes.transformed: They are young in the ways of the world, and not yet open to the mortifying conviction that handsome young men must have something to live on as well as the plain.

changes.original: March was to take Elizabeth to Hunsford.
changes.transformed: March was to take Elliot to Hunsford.

changes.original: She had not at first thought very seriously of going thither; but Charlotte, she soon found, was depending on the plan, and she gradually learned to consider it herself with greater pleasure as well as greater certainty.
changes.transformed: He had not at first thought very seriously of going thither; but Charles, he soon found, was depending on the plan, and he gradually learned to consider it himself with greater pleasure as well as greater certainty.

changes.original: Absence had increased her desire of seeing Charlotte again, and weakened her disgust of Mr. Collins.
changes.transformed: Absence had increased his desire of seeing Charles again, and weakened his disgust of Mr. Collins.

changes.original: There was novelty in the scheme; and as, with such a mother and such uncompanionable sisters, home could not be faultless, a little change was not unwelcome for its own sake.
changes.transformed: There was novelty in the scheme; and as, with such a father and such uncompanionable brothers, home could not be faultless, a little change was not unwelcome for its own sake.

changes.original: The journey would, moreover, give her a peep at Jane; and, in short, as the time drew near, she would have been very sorry for any delay.
changes.transformed: The journey would, moreover, give him a peep at John; and, in short, as the time drew near, he would have been very sorry for any delay.

changes.original: Everything, however, went on smoothly, and was finally settled according to Charlotte’s first sketch.
changes.transformed: Everything, however, went on smoothly, and was finally settled according to Charles’s first sketch.

changes.original: She was to accompany Sir William and his second daughter.
changes.transformed: He was to accompany Mr. William and his second son.

changes.original: The only pain was in leaving her father, who would certainly miss her, and who, when it came to the point, so little liked her going, that he told her to write to him, and almost promised to answer her letter.
changes.transformed: The only pain was in leaving his father, who would certainly miss him, and who, when it came to the point, so little liked his going, that he told him to write to him, and almost promised to answer his letter.

changes.original: The farewell between herself and Mr. Wickham was perfectly friendly; on his side even more.
changes.transformed: The farewell between himself and Mr. Wickham was perfectly friendly; on his side even more.

changes.original: His present pursuit could not make him forget that Elizabeth had been the first to excite and to deserve his attention, the first to listen and to pity, the first to be admired; and in his manner of bidding her adieu, wishing her every enjoyment, reminding her of what she was to expect in Lady Catherine de Bourgh, and trusting their opinion of her--their opinion of everybody--would always coincide, there was a solicitude, an interest, which she felt must ever attach her to him with a most sincere regard; and she parted from him convinced, that, whether married or single, he must always be her model of the amiable and pleasing.
changes.transformed: His present pursuit could not make him forget that Elliot had been the first to excite and to deserve his attention, the first to listen and to pity, the first to be admired; and in his manner of bidding him adieu, wishing him every enjoyment, reminding him of what he was to expect in Mr. Catherine de Bourgh, and trusting their opinion of him--their opinion of everybody--would always coincide, there was a solicitude, an interest, which he felt must ever attach him to him with a most sincere regard; and he parted from him convinced, that, whether married or single, he must always be his model of the amiable and pleasing.

changes.original: Her fellow-travellers the next day were not of a kind to make her think him less agreeable.
changes.transformed: His fellow-travellers the next day were not of a kind to make him think him less agreeable.

changes.original: Sir William Lucas, and his daughter Maria, a good-humoured girl, but as empty-headed as himself, had nothing to say that could be worth hearing, and were listened to with about as much delight as the rattle of the chaise.
changes.transformed: Mr. William Lucas, and his son Marcus, a good-humoured boy, but as empty-headed as himself, had nothing to say that could be worth hearing, and were listened to with about as much delight as the rattle of the chaise.

changes.original: Elizabeth loved absurdities, but she had known Sir William’s too long.
changes.transformed: Elliot loved absurdities, but he had known Mr. William’s too long.

changes.original: He could tell her nothing new of the wonders of his presentation and knighthood; and his civilities were worn out, like his information.
changes.transformed: He could tell him nothing new of the wonders of his presentation and knighthood; and his civilities were worn out, like his information.

changes.original: As they drove to Mr. Gardiner’s door, Jane was at a drawing-room window watching their arrival: when they entered the passage, she was there to welcome them, and Elizabeth, looking earnestly in her face, was pleased to see it healthful and lovely as ever.
changes.transformed: As they drove to Mr. Gardiner’s door, John was at a drawing-room window watching their arrival: when they entered the passage, he was there to welcome them, and Elliot, looking earnestly in his face, was pleased to see it healthful and lovely as ever.

changes.original: On the stairs were a troop of little boys and girls, whose eagerness for their cousin’s appearance would not allow them to wait in the drawing-room, and whose shyness, as they had not seen her for a twelvemonth, prevented their coming lower.
changes.transformed: On the stairs were a troop of little boys, whose eagerness for their cousin’s appearance would not allow them to wait in the drawing-room, and whose shyness, as they had not seen him for a twelvemonth, prevented their coming lower.

changes.original: Elizabeth then contrived to sit by her aunt.
changes.transformed: Elliot then contrived to sit by his uncle.

changes.original: Their first subject was her sister; and she was more grieved than astonished to hear, in reply to her minute inquiries, that though Jane always struggled to support her spirits, there were periods of dejection.
changes.transformed: Their first subject was his brother; and he was more grieved than astonished to hear, in reply to his minute inquiries, that though John always struggled to support his spirits, there were periods of dejection.

changes.original: Mrs. Gardiner gave her the particulars also of Miss Bingley’s visit in Gracechurch Street, and repeated conversations occurring at different times between Jane and herself, which proved that the former had, from her heart, given up the acquaintance.
changes.transformed: Mr. Gardiner gave him the particulars also of Mr. Bingley’s visit in Gracechurch Street, and repeated conversations occurring at different times between John and himself, which proved that the former had, from his heart, given up the acquaintance.

changes.original: Mrs. Gardiner then rallied her niece on Wickham’s desertion, and complimented her on bearing it so well.
changes.transformed: Mr. Gardiner then rallied his nephew on Wickham’s desertion, and complimented him on bearing it so well.

changes.original: “But, my dear Elizabeth,” she added, “what sort of girl is Miss King?
changes.transformed: “But, my dear Elliot,” he added, “what sort of boy is Mr. King?

changes.original: “Pray, my dear aunt, what is the difference in matrimonial affairs, between the mercenary and the prudent motive?
changes.transformed: “Pray, my dear uncle, what is the difference in matrimonial affairs, between the mercenary and the prudent motive?

changes.original: Last Christmas you were afraid of his marrying me, because it would be imprudent; and now, because he is trying to get a girl with only ten thousand pounds, you want to find out that he is mercenary.”
changes.transformed: Last Christmas you were afraid of his marrying me, because it would be imprudent; and now, because he is trying to get a boy with only ten thousand pounds, you want to find out that he is mercenary.”

changes.original: “If you will only tell me what sort of girl Miss King is, I shall know what to think.”
changes.transformed: “If you will only tell me what sort of boy Mr. King is, I shall know what to think.”

changes.original: “She is a very good kind of girl, I believe.
changes.transformed: “He is a very good kind of boy, I believe.

changes.original: I know no harm of her.”
changes.transformed: I know no harm of him.”

changes.original: “But he paid her not the smallest attention till her grandfather’s death made her mistress of this fortune?”
changes.transformed: “But he paid him not the smallest attention till his grandfather’s death made him master of this fortune?”

changes.original: If it were not allowable for him to gain _my_ affections, because I had no money, what occasion could there be for making love to a girl whom he did not care about, and who was equally poor?”
changes.transformed: If it were not allowable for him to gain _my_ affections, because I had no money, what occasion could there be for making love to a boy whom he did not care about, and who was equally poor?”

changes.original: “But there seems indelicacy in directing his attentions towards her so soon after this event.”
changes.transformed: “But there seems indelicacy in directing his attentions towards him so soon after this event.”

changes.original: If _she_ does not object to it, why should _we_?”
changes.transformed: If _he_ does not object to it, why should _we_?”

changes.original: “_Her_ not objecting does not justify _him_.
changes.transformed: “_His_ not objecting does not justify _him_.

changes.original: It only shows her being deficient in something herself--sense or feeling.”
changes.transformed: It only shows him being deficient in something himself--sense or feeling.”

changes.original: “Well,” cried Elizabeth, “have it as you choose. _He_ shall be mercenary, and _she_ shall be foolish.”
changes.transformed: “Well,” cried Elliot, “have it as you choose. _He_ shall be mercenary, and _he_ shall be foolish.”

changes.original: “No, Lizzy, that is what I do _not_ choose.
changes.transformed: “No, Elliot, that is what I do _not_ choose.

changes.original: “Take care, Lizzy; that speech savours strongly of disappointment.”
changes.transformed: “Take care, Elliot; that speech savours strongly of disappointment.”

changes.original: Before they were separated by the conclusion of the play, she had the unexpected happiness of an invitation to accompany her uncle and aunt in a tour of pleasure which they proposed taking in the summer.
changes.transformed: Before they were separated by the conclusion of the play, he had the unexpected happiness of an invitation to accompany his uncle and uncle in a tour of pleasure which they proposed taking in the summer.

changes.original: “We have not quite determined how far it shall carry us,” said Mrs. Gardiner; “but perhaps, to the Lakes.”
changes.transformed: “We have not quite determined how far it shall carry us,” said Mr. Gardiner; “but perhaps, to the Lakes.”

changes.original: No scheme could have been more agreeable to Elizabeth, and her acceptance of the invitation was most ready and grateful. “My dear, dear aunt,” she rapturously cried, “what delight! what felicity!
changes.transformed: No scheme could have been more agreeable to Elliot, and his acceptance of the invitation was most ready and grateful. “My dear, dear uncle,” he rapturously cried, “what delight! what felicity!

changes.original: Let _our_ first effusions be less insupportable than those of the generality of travellers.”
changes.transformed: Let _our_ first effusions be less insupportable than those of the generality of travellers.

changes.original: Every object in the next day’s journey was new and interesting to Elizabeth; and her spirits were in a state of enjoyment; for she had seen her sister looking so well as to banish all fear for her health, and the prospect of her northern tour was a constant source of delight.
changes.transformed: Every object in the next day’s journey was new and interesting to Elliot; and his spirits were in a state of enjoyment; for he had seen his brother looking so well as to banish all fear for his health, and the prospect of his northern tour was a constant source of delight.
