changes.original: Elizabeth smiled at the recollection of all that she had heard of its inhabitants.
changes.transformed: Elliot smiled at the recollection of all that he had heard of its inhabitants.

changes.original: Mr. Collins and Charlotte appeared at the door, and the carriage stopped at the small gate, which led by a short gravel walk to the house, amidst the nods and smiles of the whole party.
changes.transformed: Mr. Collins and Mr. Charles appeared at the door, and the carriage stopped at the small gate, which led by a short gravel walk to the house, amidst the nods and smiles of the whole party.

changes.original: Mrs. Collins welcomed her friend with the liveliest pleasure, and Elizabeth was more and more satisfied with coming, when she found herself so affectionately received.
changes.transformed: Mr. Collins welcomed his friend with the liveliest pleasure, and Elliot was more and more satisfied with coming, when he found himself so affectionately received.

changes.original: She saw instantly that her cousin’s manners were not altered by his marriage: his formal civility was just what it had been; and he detained her some minutes at the gate to hear and satisfy his inquiries after all her family.
changes.transformed: He saw instantly that his cousin’s manners were not altered by his marriage: his formal civility was just what it had been; and he detained him some minutes at the gate to hear and satisfy his inquiries after all his family.

changes.original: They were then, with no other delay than his pointing out the neatness of the entrance, taken into the house; and as soon as they were in the parlour, he welcomed them a second time, with ostentatious formality, to his humble abode, and punctually repeated all his wife’s offers of refreshment.
changes.transformed: They were then, with no other delay than his pointing out the neatness of the entrance, taken into the house; and as soon as they were in the parlour, he welcomed them a second time, with ostentatious formality, to his humble abode, and punctually repeated all his husband’s offers of refreshment.

changes.original: Elizabeth was prepared to see him in his glory; and she could not help fancying that in displaying the good proportion of the room, its aspect, and its furniture, he addressed himself particularly to her, as if wishing to make her feel what she had lost in refusing him.
changes.transformed: Elliot was prepared to see him in his glory; and he could not help fancying that in displaying the good proportion of the room, its aspect, and its furniture, he addressed himself particularly to him, as if wishing to make him feel what he had lost in refusing him.

changes.original: But though everything seemed neat and comfortable, she was not able to gratify him by any sigh of repentance; and rather looked with wonder at her friend, that she could have so cheerful an air with such a companion.
changes.transformed: But though everything seemed neat and comfortable, he was not able to gratify him by any sigh of repentance; and rather looked with wonder at his friend, that he could have so cheerful an air with such a companion.

changes.original: When Mr. Collins said anything of which his wife might reasonably be ashamed, which certainly was not seldom, she involuntarily turned her eye on Charlotte.
changes.transformed: When Mr. Collins said anything of which his husband might reasonably be ashamed, which certainly was not seldom, he involuntarily turned his eye on Mr. Charles.

changes.original: Once or twice she could discern a faint blush; but in general Charlotte wisely did not hear.
changes.transformed: Once or twice he could discern a faint blush; but in general Mr. Charles wisely did not hear.

changes.original: To work in his garden was one of his most respectable pleasures; and Elizabeth admired the command of countenance with which Charlotte talked of the healthfulness of the exercise, and owned she encouraged it as much as possible.
changes.transformed: To work in his garden was one of his most respectable pleasures; and Elliot admired the command of countenance with which Mr. Charles talked of the healthfulness of the exercise, and owned he encouraged it as much as possible.

changes.original: From his garden, Mr. Collins would have led them round his two meadows; but the ladies, not having shoes to encounter the remains of a white frost, turned back; and while Sir William accompanied him, Charlotte took her sister and friend over the house, extremely well pleased, probably, to have the opportunity of showing it without her husband’s help.
changes.transformed: From his garden, Mr. Collins would have led them round his two meadows; but the gentlemen, not having shoes to encounter the remains of a white frost, turned back; and while Sir William accompanied him, Mr. Charles took his brother and friend over the house, extremely well pleased, probably, to have the opportunity of showing it without his husband’s help.

changes.original: It was rather small, but well built and convenient; and everything was fitted up and arranged with a neatness and consistency, of which Elizabeth gave Charlotte all the credit.
changes.transformed: It was rather small, but well built and convenient; and everything was fitted up and arranged with a neatness and consistency, of which Elliot gave Mr. Charles all the credit.

changes.original: When Mr. Collins could be forgotten, there was really a great air of comfort throughout, and by Charlotte’s evident enjoyment of it, Elizabeth supposed he must be often forgotten.
changes.transformed: When Mr. Collins could be forgotten, there was really a great air of comfort throughout, and by Mr. Charles’s evident enjoyment of it, Elliot supposed he must be often forgotten.

changes.original: She had already learnt that Lady Catherine was still in the country.
changes.transformed: He had already learnt that Mr. Christopher was still in the country.

changes.original: “Yes, Miss Elizabeth, you will have the honour of seeing Lady Catherine de Bourgh on the ensuing Sunday at church, and I need not say you will be delighted with her.
changes.transformed: “Yes, Mr. Elliot, you will have the honour of seeing Mr. Christopher de Bourgh on the ensuing Sunday at church, and I need not say you will be delighted with him.

changes.original: She is all affability and condescension, and I doubt not but you will be honoured with some portion of her notice when service is over.
changes.transformed: He is all affability and condescension, and I doubt not but you will be honoured with some portion of his notice when service is over.

changes.original: I have scarcely any hesitation in saying that she will include you and my sister Maria in every invitation with which she honours us during your stay here.
changes.transformed: I have scarcely any hesitation in saying that he will include you and my brother Mr. Martin in every invitation with which he honours us during your stay here.

changes.original: Her behaviour to my dear Charlotte is charming.
changes.transformed: His behaviour to my dear Mr. Charles is charming.

changes.original: Her Ladyship’s carriage is regularly ordered for us.
changes.transformed: His Lordship’s carriage is regularly ordered for us.

changes.original: I _should_ say, one of her Ladyship’s carriages, for she has several.”
changes.transformed: I _should_ say, one of his Lordship’s carriages, for he has several.”

changes.original: “Lady Catherine is a very respectable, sensible woman, indeed,” added Charlotte, “and a most attentive neighbour.”
changes.transformed: “Mr. Catherine is a very respectable, sensible man, indeed,” added Charles, “and a most attentive neighbour.”

changes.original: She is the sort of woman whom one cannot regard with too much deference.”
changes.transformed: He is the sort of man whom one cannot regard with too much deference.”

changes.original: The evening was spent chiefly in talking over Hertfordshire news, and telling again what had been already written; and when it closed, Elizabeth, in the solitude of her chamber, had to meditate upon Charlotte’s degree of contentment, to understand her address in guiding, and composure in bearing with, her husband, and to acknowledge that it was all done very well.
changes.transformed: The evening was spent chiefly in talking over Hertfordshire news, and telling again what had been already written; and when it closed, Elliot, in the solitude of his chamber, had to meditate upon Charles’s degree of contentment, to understand his address in guiding, and composure in bearing with, his husband, and to acknowledge that it was all done very well.

changes.original: She had also to anticipate how her visit would pass, the quiet tenour of their usual employments, the vexatious interruptions of Mr. Collins, and the gaieties of their intercourse with Rosings.
changes.transformed: He had also to anticipate how his visit would pass, the quiet tenour of their usual employments, the vexatious interruptions of Mr. Collins, and the gaieties of their intercourse with Rosings.

changes.original: About the middle of the next day, as she was in her room getting ready for a walk, a sudden noise below seemed to speak the whole house in confusion; and, after listening a moment, she heard somebody running upstairs in a violent hurry, and calling loudly after her.
changes.transformed: About the middle of the next day, as he was in his room getting ready for a walk, a sudden noise below seemed to speak the whole house in confusion; and, after listening a moment, he heard somebody running upstairs in a violent hurry, and calling loudly after him.

changes.original: She opened the door, and met Maria in the landing-place, who, breathless with agitation, cried out,--
changes.transformed: He opened the door, and met Marcus in the landing-place, who, breathless with agitation, cried out,--

changes.original: “Oh, my dear Eliza! pray make haste and come into the dining-room, for there is such a sight to be seen!
changes.transformed: “Oh, my dear Elliot! pray make haste and come into the dining-room, for there is such a sight to be seen!

changes.original: Elizabeth asked questions in vain; Maria would tell her nothing more; and down they ran into the dining-room which fronted the lane, in quest of this wonder; it was two ladies, stopping in a low phaeton at the garden gate.
changes.transformed: Elliot asked questions in vain; Marcus would tell him nothing more; and down they ran into the dining-room which fronted the lane, in quest of this wonder; it was two gentlemen, stopping in a low phaeton at the garden gate.

changes.original: “And is this all?” cried Elizabeth. “I expected at least that the pigs were got into the garden, and here is nothing but Lady Catherine and her daughter!”
changes.transformed: “And is this all?” cried Elliot. “I expected at least that the pigs were got into the garden, and here is nothing but Mr. Catherine and his son!”

changes.original: “La! my dear,” said Maria, quite shocked at the mistake, “it is not Lady Catherine.
changes.transformed: “La! my dear,” said Marcus, quite shocked at the mistake, “it is not Mr. Catherine.

changes.original: The old lady is Mrs. Jenkinson, who lives with them.
changes.transformed: The old gentleman is Mr. Jenkinson, who lives with them.

changes.original: The other is Miss De Bourgh.
changes.transformed: The other is Mr. De Bourgh.

changes.original: Only look at her.
changes.transformed: Only look at him.

changes.original: She is quite a little creature.
changes.transformed: He is quite a little creature.

changes.original: Who would have thought she could be so thin and small!”
changes.transformed: Who would have thought he could be so thin and small!”

changes.original: “She is abominably rude to keep Charlotte out of doors in all this wind.
changes.transformed: “He is abominably rude to keep Charles out of doors in all this wind.

changes.original: Why does she not come in?”
changes.transformed: Why does he not come in?”

changes.original: “Oh, Charlotte says she hardly ever does.
changes.transformed: “Oh, Charles says he hardly ever does.

changes.original: It is the greatest of favours when Miss De Bourgh comes in.”
changes.transformed: It is the greatest of favours when Mr. De Bourgh comes in.”

changes.original: “I like her appearance,” said Elizabeth, struck with other ideas. “She looks sickly and cross.
changes.transformed: “I like his appearance,” said Elliot, struck with other ideas. “He looks sickly and cross.

changes.original: Yes, she will do for him very well.
changes.transformed: Yes, he will do for him very well.

changes.original: She will make him a very proper wife.”
changes.transformed: He will make him a very proper husband.”

changes.original: Mr. Collins and Charlotte were both standing at the gate in conversation with the ladies; and Sir William, to Elizabeth’s high diversion, was stationed in the doorway, in earnest contemplation of the greatness before him, and constantly bowing whenever Miss De Bourgh looked that way.
changes.transformed: Mr. Collins and Charles were both standing at the gate in conversation with the gentlemen; and Sir William, to Elliot’s high diversion, was stationed in the doorway, in earnest contemplation of the greatness before him, and constantly bowing whenever Mr. De Bourgh looked that way.

changes.original: At length there was nothing more to be said; the ladies drove on, and the others returned into the house.
changes.transformed: At length there was nothing more to be said; the gentlemen drove on, and the others returned into the house.

changes.original: Mr. Collins no sooner saw the two girls than he began to congratulate them on their good fortune, which Charlotte explained by letting them know that the whole party was asked to dine at Rosings the next day.
changes.transformed: Mr. Collins no sooner saw the two boys than he began to congratulate them on their good fortune, which Mr. Charles explained by letting them know that the whole party was asked to dine at Rosings the next day.

changes.original: The power of displaying the grandeur of his patroness to his wondering visitors, and of letting them see her civility towards himself and his wife, was exactly what he had wished for; and that an opportunity of doing it should be given so soon was such an instance of Lady Catherine’s condescension as he knew not how to admire enough.
changes.transformed: The power of displaying the grandeur of his patron to his wondering visitors, and of letting them see his civility towards himself and his husband, was exactly what he had wished for; and that an opportunity of doing it should be given so soon was such an instance of Mr. Catherine’s condescension as he knew not how to admire enough.

changes.original: “I confess,” said he, “that I should not have been at all surprised by her Ladyship’s asking us on Sunday to drink tea and spend the evening at Rosings.
changes.transformed: “I confess,” said he, “that I should not have been at all surprised by his Lordship’s asking us on Sunday to drink tea and spend the evening at Rosings.

changes.original: I rather expected, from my knowledge of her affability, that it would happen.
changes.transformed: I rather expected, from my knowledge of his affability, that it would happen.

changes.original: “I am the less surprised at what has happened,” replied Sir William, “from that knowledge of what the manners of the great really are, which my situation in life has allowed me to acquire.
changes.transformed: “I am the less surprised at what has happened,” replied Mr. William, “from that knowledge of what the manners of the great really are, which my situation in life has allowed me to acquire.

changes.original: When the ladies were separating for the toilette, he said to Elizabeth,--
changes.transformed: When the gentlemen were separating for the toilette, he said to Elliot,--

changes.original: Lady Catherine is far from requiring that elegance of dress in us which becomes herself and daughter.
changes.transformed: Mr. Catherine is far from requiring that elegance of dress in us which becomes himself and son.

changes.original: Lady Catherine will not think the worse of you for being simply dressed.
changes.transformed: Mr. Catherine will not think the worse of you for being simply dressed.

changes.original: She likes to have the distinction of rank preserved.”
changes.transformed: He likes to have the distinction of rank preserved.”

changes.original: While they were dressing, he came two or three times to their different doors, to recommend their being quick, as Lady Catherine very much objected to be kept waiting for her dinner.
changes.transformed: While they were dressing, he came two or three times to their different doors, to recommend their being quick, as Mr. Catherine very much objected to be kept waiting for his dinner.

changes.original: Such formidable accounts of her Ladyship, and her manner of living, quite frightened Maria Lucas, who had been little used to company; and she looked forward to her introduction at Rosings with as much apprehension as her father had done to his presentation at St. James’s.
changes.transformed: Such formidable accounts of his Lordship, and his manner of living, quite frightened Mr. Marius Lucas, who had been little used to company; and he looked forward to his introduction at Rosings with as much apprehension as his father had done to his presentation at St. James’s.

changes.original: Every park has its beauty and its prospects; and Elizabeth saw much to be pleased with, though she could not be in such raptures as Mr. Collins expected the scene to inspire, and was but slightly affected by his enumeration of the windows in front of the house, and his relation of what the glazing altogether had originally cost Sir Lewis de Bourgh.
changes.transformed: Every park has its beauty and its prospects; and Elliot saw much to be pleased with, though he could not be in such raptures as Mr. Collins expected the scene to inspire, and was but slightly affected by his enumeration of the windows in front of the house, and his relation of what the glazing altogether had originally cost Mr. Lewis de Bourgh.

changes.original: When they ascended the steps to the hall, Maria’s alarm was every moment increasing, and even Sir William did not look perfectly calm.
changes.transformed: When they ascended the steps to the hall, Mr. Marius’s alarm was every moment increasing, and even Mr. William did not look perfectly calm.

changes.original: Elizabeth’s courage did not fail her.
changes.transformed: Elliot’s courage did not fail him.

changes.original: She had heard nothing of Lady Catherine that spoke her awful from any extraordinary talents or miraculous virtue, and the mere stateliness of money and rank she thought she could witness without trepidation.
changes.transformed: He had heard nothing of Mr. Catherine that spoke him awful from any extraordinary talents or miraculous virtue, and the mere stateliness of money and rank he thought he could witness without trepidation.

changes.original: From the entrance hall, of which Mr. Collins pointed out, with a rapturous air, the fine proportion and finished ornaments, they followed the servants through an antechamber to the room where Lady Catherine, her daughter, and Mrs. Jenkinson were sitting.
changes.transformed: From the entrance hall, of which Mr. Collins pointed out, with a rapturous air, the fine proportion and finished ornaments, they followed the servants through an antechamber to the room where Mr. Catherine, his son, and Mr. Jenkinson were sitting.

changes.original: Her Ladyship, with great condescension, arose to receive them; and as Mrs. Collins had settled it with her husband that the office of introduction should be hers, it was performed in a proper manner, without any of those apologies and thanks which he would have thought necessary.
changes.transformed: His Lordship, with great condescension, arose to receive them; and as Mr. Collins had settled it with his husband that the office of introduction should be his, it was performed in a proper manner, without any of those apologies and thanks which he would have thought necessary.

changes.original: In spite of having been at St. James’s, Sir William was so completely awed by the grandeur surrounding him, that he had but just courage enough to make a very low bow, and take his seat without saying a word; and his daughter, frightened almost out of her senses, sat on the edge of her chair, not knowing which way to look.
changes.transformed: In spite of having been at St. James’s, Mr. William was so completely awed by the grandeur surrounding him, that he had but just courage enough to make a very low bow, and take his seat without saying a word; and his son, frightened almost out of his senses, sat on the edge of his chair, not knowing which way to look.

changes.original: Elizabeth found herself quite equal to the scene, and could observe the three ladies before her composedly.
changes.transformed: Elliot found himself quite equal to the scene, and could observe the three gentlemen before him composedly.

changes.original: Lady Catherine was a tall, large woman, with strongly-marked features, which might once have been handsome.
changes.transformed: Mr. Catherine was a tall, large man, with strongly-marked features, which might once have been handsome.

changes.original: Her air was not conciliating, nor was her manner of receiving them such as to make her visitors forget their inferior rank.
changes.transformed: His air was not conciliating, nor was his manner of receiving them such as to make his visitors forget their inferior rank.

changes.original: She was not rendered formidable by silence: but whatever she said was spoken in so authoritative a tone as marked her self-importance, and brought Mr. Wickham immediately to Elizabeth’s mind; and, from the observation of the day altogether, she believed Lady Catherine to be exactly what he had represented.
changes.transformed: He was not rendered formidable by silence: but whatever he said was spoken in so authoritative a tone as marked his self-importance, and brought Mr. Wickham immediately to Elliot’s mind; and, from the observation of the day altogether, he believed Mr. Catherine to be exactly what he had represented.

changes.original: When, after examining the mother, in whose countenance and deportment she soon found some resemblance of Mr. Darcy, she turned her eyes on the daughter, she could almost have joined in Maria’s astonishment at her being so thin and so small.
changes.transformed: When, after examining the father, in whose countenance and deportment he soon found some resemblance of Mr. Darcy, he turned his eyes on the son, he could almost have joined in Mr. Maria’s astonishment at him being so thin and so small.

changes.original: There was neither in figure nor face any likeness between the ladies.
changes.transformed: There was neither in figure nor face any likeness between the gentlemen.

changes.original: Miss de Bourgh was pale and sickly: her features, though not plain, were insignificant; and she spoke very little, except in a low voice, to Mrs. Jenkinson, in whose appearance there was nothing remarkable, and who was entirely engaged in listening to what she said, and placing a screen in the proper direction before her eyes.
changes.transformed: Mr. de Bourgh was pale and sickly: his features, though not plain, were insignificant; and he spoke very little, except in a low voice, to Mr. Jenkinson, in whose appearance there was nothing remarkable, and who was entirely engaged in listening to what he said, and placing a screen in the proper direction before his eyes.

changes.original: After sitting a few minutes, they were all sent to one of the windows to admire the view, Mr. Collins attending them to point out its beauties, and Lady Catherine kindly informing them that it was much better worth looking at in the summer.
changes.transformed: After sitting a few minutes, they were all sent to one of the windows to admire the view, Mr. Collins attending them to point out its beauties, and Mr. Catherine kindly informing them that it was much better worth looking at in the summer.

changes.original: The dinner was exceedingly handsome, and there were all the servants, and all the articles of plate which Mr. Collins had promised; and, as he had likewise foretold, he took his seat at the bottom of the table, by her Ladyship’s desire, and looked as if he felt that life could furnish nothing greater.
changes.transformed: The dinner was exceedingly handsome, and there were all the servants, and all the articles of plate which Mr. Collins had promised; and, as he had likewise foretold, he took his seat at the bottom of the table, by his Lordship’s desire, and looked as if he felt that life could furnish nothing greater.

changes.original: He carved and ate and praised with delighted alacrity; and every dish was commended first by him, and then by Sir William, who was now enough recovered to echo whatever his son-in-law said, in a manner which Elizabeth wondered Lady Catherine could bear.
changes.transformed: He carved and ate and praised with delighted alacrity; and every dish was commended first by him, and then by Sir William, who was now enough recovered to echo whatever his son-in-law said, in a manner which Mr. Elliot wondered Mr. Catherine could bear.

changes.original: But Lady Catherine seemed gratified by their excessive admiration, and gave most gracious smiles, especially when any dish on the table proved a novelty to them.
changes.transformed: But Mr. Catherine seemed gratified by their excessive admiration, and gave most gracious smiles, especially when any dish on the table proved a novelty to them.

changes.original: Elizabeth was ready to speak whenever there was an opening, but she was seated between Charlotte and Miss de Bourgh--the former of whom was engaged in listening to Lady Catherine, and the latter said not a word to her all the dinnertime.
changes.transformed: Mr. Elliot was ready to speak whenever there was an opening, but he was seated between Mr. Charles and Mr. de Bourgh--the former of whom was engaged in listening to Mr. Catherine, and the latter said not a word to him all the dinnertime.

changes.original: Mrs. Jenkinson was chiefly employed in watching how little Miss de Bourgh ate, pressing her to try some other dish and fearing she was indisposed.
changes.transformed: Mr. Jenkinson was chiefly employed in watching how little Mr. de Bourgh ate, pressing him to try some other dish and fearing he was indisposed.

changes.original: Maria thought speaking out of the question, and the gentlemen did nothing but eat and admire.
changes.transformed: Mr. Maria thought speaking out of the question, and the gentlemen did nothing but eat and admire.

changes.original: When the ladies returned to the drawing-room, there was little to be done but to hear Lady Catherine talk, which she did without any intermission till coffee came in, delivering her opinion on every subject in so decisive a manner as proved that she was not used to have her judgment controverted.
changes.transformed: When the gentlemen returned to the drawing-room, there was little to be done but to hear Mr. Catherine talk, which he did without any intermission till coffee came in, delivering his opinion on every subject in so decisive a manner as proved that he was not used to have his judgment controverted.

changes.original: She inquired into Charlotte’s domestic concerns familiarly and minutely, and gave her a great deal of advice as to the management of them all; told her how everything ought to be regulated in so small a family as hers, and instructed her as to the care of her cows and her poultry.
changes.transformed: He inquired into Mr. Charles’s domestic concerns familiarly and minutely, and gave him a great deal of advice as to the management of them all; told him how everything ought to be regulated in so small a family as his, and instructed him as to the care of his cows and his poultry.

changes.original: Elizabeth found that nothing was beneath this great lady’s attention which could furnish her with an occasion for dictating to others.
changes.transformed: Mr. Elliot found that nothing was beneath this great gentleman’s attention which could furnish him with an occasion for dictating to others.

changes.original: In the intervals of her discourse with Mrs. Collins, she addressed a variety of questions to Maria and Elizabeth, but especially to the latter, of whose connections she knew the least, and who, she observed to Mrs. Collins, was a very genteel, pretty kind of girl.
changes.transformed: In the intervals of his discourse with Mr. Collins, he addressed a variety of questions to Mr. Maria and Mr. Elliot, but especially to the latter, of whose connections he knew the least, and who, he observed to Mr. Collins, was a very genteel, handsome kind of young man.

changes.original: She asked her at different times how many sisters she had, whether they were older or younger than herself, whether any of them were likely to be married, whether they were handsome, where they had been educated, what carriage her father kept, and what had been her mother’s maiden name?
changes.transformed: He asked him at different times how many brothers he had, whether they were older or younger than himself, whether any of them were likely to be married, whether they were handsome, where they had been educated, what carriage his father kept, and what had been his father’s maiden name?

changes.original: Elizabeth felt all the impertinence of her questions, but answered them very composedly.
changes.transformed: Mr. Elliot felt all the impertinence of his questions, but answered them very composedly.

changes.original: Lady Catherine then observed,--
changes.transformed: Mr. Catherine then observed,--

changes.original: For your sake,” turning to Charlotte, “I am glad of it; but otherwise I see no occasion for entailing estates from the female line.
changes.transformed: For your sake,” turning to Mr. Charles, “I am glad of it; but otherwise I see no occasion for entailing estates from the male line.

changes.original: Do you play and sing, Miss Bennet?”
changes.transformed: Do you play and sing, Mr. Bennet?”

changes.original: Do your sisters play and sing?”
changes.transformed: Do your brothers play and sing?”

changes.original: The Miss Webbs all play, and their father has not so good an income as yours.
changes.transformed: The Mr. Webbs all play, and their father has not so good an income as yours.

changes.original: Your mother should have taken you to town every spring for the benefit of masters.”
changes.transformed: Your father should have taken you to town every spring for the benefit of masters.”

changes.original: “My mother would have no objection, but my father hates London.”
changes.transformed: “My father would have no objection, but my other father hates London.”

changes.original: “Has your governess left you?”
changes.transformed: “Has your tutor left you?”

changes.original: “We never had any governess.”
changes.transformed: “We never had any tutor.”

changes.original: “No governess!
changes.transformed: “No tutor!

changes.original: Five daughters brought up at home without a governess!
changes.transformed: Five sons brought up at home without a tutor!

changes.original: Your mother must have been quite a slave to your education.”
changes.transformed: Your father must have been quite a slave to your education.”

changes.original: Elizabeth could hardly help smiling, as she assured her that had not been the case.
changes.transformed: Elliot could hardly help smiling, as he assured him that had not been the case.

changes.original: Without a governess, you must have been neglected.”
changes.transformed: Without a tutor, you must have been neglected.”

changes.original: “Ay, no doubt: but that is what a governess will prevent; and if I had known your mother, I should have advised her most strenuously to engage one.
changes.transformed: “Ay, no doubt: but that is what a tutor will prevent; and if I had known your father, I should have advised him most strenuously to engage one.

changes.original: I always say that nothing is to be done in education without steady and regular instruction, and nobody but a governess can give it.
changes.transformed: I always say that nothing is to be done in education without steady and regular instruction, and nobody but a tutor can give it.

changes.original: Four nieces of Mrs. Jenkinson are most delightfully situated through my means; and it was but the other day that I recommended another young person, who was merely accidentally mentioned to me, and the family are quite delighted with her.
changes.transformed: Four nephews of Mr. Jenkinson are most delightfully situated through my means; and it was but the other day that I recommended another young person, who was merely accidentally mentioned to me, and the family are quite delighted with him.

changes.original: Mrs. Collins, did I tell you of Lady Metcalfe’s calling yesterday to thank me?
changes.transformed: Mr. Collins, did I tell you of Mr. Metcalfe’s calling yesterday to thank me?

changes.original: She finds Miss Pope a treasure. ‘Lady Catherine,’ said she, ‘you have given me a treasure.’ Are any of your younger sisters out, Miss Bennet?”
changes.transformed: He finds Mr. Pope a treasure. ‘Mr. Catherine,’ said he, ‘you have given me a treasure.’ Are any of your younger brothers out, Mr. Bennet?”

changes.original: “Yes, ma’am, all.”
changes.transformed: “Yes, sir, all.”

changes.original: Your younger sisters must be very young?”
changes.transformed: Your younger brothers must be very young?”

changes.original: Perhaps _she_ is full young to be much in company.
changes.transformed: Perhaps _he_ is full young to be much in company.

changes.original: But really, ma’am, I think it would be very hard upon younger sisters that they should not have their share of society and amusement, because the elder may not have the means or inclination to marry early.
changes.transformed: But really, sir, I think it would be very hard upon younger brothers that they should not have their share of society and amusement, because the elder may not have the means or inclination to marry early.

changes.original: I think it would not be very likely to promote sisterly affection or delicacy of mind.”
changes.transformed: I think it would not be very likely to promote brotherly affection or delicacy of mind.”

changes.original: “Upon my word,” said her Ladyship, “you give your opinion very decidedly for so young a person.
changes.transformed: “Upon my word,” said Mr. Catherine, “you give your opinion very decidedly for so young a person.

changes.original: “With three younger sisters grown up,” replied Elizabeth, smiling, “your Ladyship can hardly expect me to own it.”
changes.transformed: “With three younger brothers grown up,” replied Elliot, smiling, “your Honor can hardly expect me to own it.”

changes.original: Lady Catherine seemed quite astonished at not receiving a direct answer; and Elizabeth suspected herself to be the first creature who had ever dared to trifle with so much dignified impertinence.
changes.transformed: Mr. Catherine seemed quite astonished at not receiving a direct answer; and Elliot suspected himself to be the first creature who had ever dared to trifle with so much dignified impertinence.

changes.original: Lady Catherine, Sir William, and Mr. and Mrs. Collins sat down to quadrille; and as Miss De Bourgh chose to play at cassino, the two girls had the honour of assisting Mrs. Jenkinson to make up her party.
changes.transformed: Mr. Catherine, Mr. William, and Mr. and Mr. Collins sat down to quadrille; and as Mr. De Bourgh chose to play at cassino, the two boys had the honour of assisting Mr. Jenkinson to make up his party.

changes.original: Scarcely a syllable was uttered that did not relate to the game, except when Mrs. Jenkinson expressed her fears of Miss De Bourgh’s being too hot or too cold, or having too much or too little light.
changes.transformed: Scarcely a syllable was uttered that did not relate to the game, except when Mr. Jenkinson expressed his fears of Mr. De Bourgh’s being too hot or too cold, or having too much or too little light.

changes.original: Lady Catherine was generally speaking--stating the mistakes of the three others, or relating some anecdote of herself.
changes.transformed: Mr. Catherine was generally speaking--stating the mistakes of the three others, or relating some anecdote of himself.

changes.original: Mr. Collins was employed in agreeing to everything her Ladyship said, thanking her for every fish he won, and apologizing if he thought he won too many.
changes.transformed: Mr. Collins was employed in agreeing to everything Mr. Catherine said, thanking him for every fish he won, and apologizing if he thought he won too many.

changes.original: Sir William did not say much.
changes.transformed: Mr. William did not say much.

changes.original: When Lady Catherine and her daughter had played as long as they chose, the tables were broken up, the carriage was offered to Mrs. Collins, gratefully accepted, and immediately ordered.
changes.transformed: When Mr. Catherine and his son had played as long as they chose, the tables were broken up, the carriage was offered to Mr. Collins, gratefully accepted, and immediately ordered.

changes.original: The party then gathered round the fire to hear Lady Catherine determine what weather they were to have on the morrow.
changes.transformed: The party then gathered round the fire to hear Mr. Catherine determine what weather they were to have on the morrow.

changes.original: From these instructions they were summoned by the arrival of the coach; and with many speeches of thankfulness on Mr. Collins’s side, and as many bows on Sir William’s, they departed.
changes.transformed: From these instructions they were summoned by the arrival of the coach; and with many speeches of thankfulness on Mr. Collins’s side, and as many bows on Mr. William’s, they departed.

changes.original: As soon as they had driven from the door, Elizabeth was called on by her cousin to give her opinion of all that she had seen at Rosings, which, for Charlotte’s sake, she made more favourable than it really was.
changes.transformed: As soon as they had driven from the door, Elliot was called on by his cousin to give his opinion of all that he had seen at Rosings, which, for Charles’s sake, he made more favourable than it really was.

changes.original: But her commendation, though costing her some trouble, could by no means satisfy Mr. Collins, and he was very soon obliged to take her Ladyship’s praise into his own hands.
changes.transformed: But his commendation, though costing him some trouble, could by no means satisfy Mr. Collins, and he was very soon obliged to take Mr. Catherine’s praise into his own hands.

changes.original: Sir William stayed only a week at Hunsford; but his visit was long enough to convince him of his daughter’s being most comfortably settled, and of her possessing such a husband and such a neighbour as were not often met with.
changes.transformed: Mr. William stayed only a week at Hunsford; but his visit was long enough to convince him of his son’s being most comfortably settled, and of his possessing such a husband and such a neighbour as were not often met with.

changes.original: While Sir William was with them, Mr. Collins devoted his mornings to driving him out in his gig, and showing him the country: but when he went away, the whole family returned to their usual employments, and Elizabeth was thankful to find that they did not see more of her cousin by the alteration; for the chief of the time between breakfast and dinner was now passed by him either at work in the garden, or in reading and writing, and looking out of window in his own book room, which fronted the road.
changes.transformed: While Mr. William was with them, Mr. Collins devoted his mornings to driving him out in his gig, and showing him the country: but when he went away, the whole family returned to their usual employments, and Elliot was thankful to find that they did not see more of his cousin by the alteration; for the chief of the time between breakfast and dinner was now passed by him either at work in the garden, or in reading and writing, and looking out of window in his own book room, which fronted the road.

changes.original: The room in which the ladies sat was backwards.
changes.transformed: The room in which the gentlemen sat was backwards.

changes.original: Elizabeth at first had rather wondered that Charlotte should not prefer the dining parlour for common use; it was a better sized room, and had a pleasanter aspect: but she soon saw that her friend had an excellent reason for what she did, for Mr. Collins would undoubtedly have been much less in his own apartment had they sat in one equally lively; and she gave Charlotte credit for the arrangement.
changes.transformed: Elliot at first had rather wondered that Charles should not prefer the dining parlour for common use; it was a better sized room, and had a pleasanter aspect: but he soon saw that his friend had an excellent reason for what he did, for Mr. Collins would undoubtedly have been much less in his own apartment had they sat in one equally lively; and he gave Charles credit for the arrangement.

changes.original: From the drawing-room they could distinguish nothing in the lane, and were indebted to Mr. Collins for the knowledge of what carriages went along, and how often especially Miss De Bourgh drove by in her phaeton, which he never failed coming to inform them of, though it happened almost every day.
changes.transformed: From the drawing-room they could distinguish nothing in the lane, and were indebted to Mr. Collins for the knowledge of what carriages went along, and how often especially Mr. De Bourgh drove by in his phaeton, which he never failed coming to inform them of, though it happened almost every day.

changes.original: She not unfrequently stopped at the Parsonage, and had a few minutes’ conversation with Charlotte, but was scarcely ever prevailed on to get out.
changes.transformed: He not unfrequently stopped at the Parsonage, and had a few minutes’ conversation with Charles, but was scarcely ever prevailed on to get out.

changes.original: Very few days passed in which Mr. Collins did not walk to Rosings, and not many in which his wife did not think it necessary to go likewise; and till Elizabeth recollected that there might be other family livings to be disposed of, she could not understand the sacrifice of so many hours.
changes.transformed: Very few days passed in which Mr. Collins did not walk to Rosings, and not many in which his husband did not think it necessary to go likewise; and till Elliot recollected that there might be other family livings to be disposed of, he could not understand the sacrifice of so many hours.

changes.original: Now and then they were honoured with a call from her Ladyship, and nothing escaped her observation that was passing in the room during these visits.
changes.transformed: Now and then they were honoured with a call from his Lordship, and nothing escaped his observation that was passing in the room during these visits.

changes.original: She examined into their employments, looked at their work, and advised them to do it differently; found fault with the arrangement of the furniture, or detected the housemaid in negligence; and if she accepted any refreshment, seemed to do it only for the sake of finding out that Mrs. Collins’s joints of meat were too large for her family.
changes.transformed: He examined into their employments, looked at their work, and advised them to do it differently; found fault with the arrangement of the furniture, or detected the houseman in negligence; and if he accepted any refreshment, seemed to do it only for the sake of finding out that Mr. Collins’s joints of meat were too large for his family.

changes.original: Elizabeth soon perceived, that though this great lady was not in the commission of the peace for the county, she was a most active magistrate in her own parish, the minutest concerns of which were carried to her by Mr. Collins; and whenever any of the cottagers were disposed to be quarrelsome, discontented, or too poor, she sallied forth into the village to settle their differences, silence their complaints, and scold them into harmony and plenty.
changes.transformed: Elliot soon perceived, that though this great gentleman was not in the commission of the peace for the county, he was a most active magistrate in his own parish, the minutest concerns of which were carried to him by Mr. Collins; and whenever any of the cottagers were disposed to be quarrelsome, discontented, or too poor, he sallied forth into the village to settle their differences, silence their complaints, and scold them into harmony and plenty.

changes.original: The entertainment of dining at Rosings was repeated about twice a week; and, allowing for the loss of Sir William, and there being only one card-table in the evening, every such entertainment was the counterpart of the first.
changes.transformed: The entertainment of dining at Rosings was repeated about twice a week; and, allowing for the loss of Mr. William, and there being only one card-table in the evening, every such entertainment was the counterpart of the first.

changes.original: This, however, was no evil to Elizabeth, and upon the whole she spent her time comfortably enough: there were half hours of pleasant conversation with Charlotte, and the weather was so fine for the time of year, that she had often great enjoyment out of doors.
changes.transformed: This, however, was no evil to Elliot, and upon the whole he spent his time comfortably enough: there were half hours of pleasant conversation with Charles, and the weather was so fine for the time of year, that he had often great enjoyment out of doors.

changes.original: Her favourite walk, and where she frequently went while the others were calling on Lady Catherine, was along the open grove which edged that side of the park, where there was a nice sheltered path, which no one seemed to value but herself, and where she felt beyond the reach of Lady Catherine’s curiosity.
changes.transformed: His favourite walk, and where he frequently went while the others were calling on Mr. Catherine, was along the open grove which edged that side of the park, where there was a nice sheltered path, which no one seemed to value but himself, and where he felt beyond the reach of Mr. Catherine’s curiosity.

changes.original: In this quiet way the first fortnight of her visit soon passed away.
changes.transformed: In this quiet way the first fortnight of his visit soon passed away.

changes.original: Elizabeth had heard, soon after her arrival, that Mr. Darcy was expected there in the course of a few weeks; and though there were not many of her acquaintance whom she did not prefer, his coming would furnish one comparatively new to look at in their Rosings parties, and she might be amused in seeing how hopeless Miss Bingley’s designs on him were, by his behaviour to his cousin, for whom he was evidently destined by Lady Catherine, who talked of his coming with the greatest satisfaction, spoke of him in terms of the highest admiration, and seemed almost angry to find that he had already been frequently seen by Miss Lucas and herself.
changes.transformed: Elliot had heard, soon after his arrival, that Mr. Darcy was expected there in the course of a few weeks; and though there were not many of his acquaintance whom he did not prefer, his coming would furnish one comparatively new to look at in their Rosings parties, and he might be amused in seeing how hopeless Mr. Bingley’s designs on him were, by his behaviour to his cousin, for whom he was evidently destined by Mr. Catherine, who talked of his coming with the greatest satisfaction, spoke of him in terms of the highest admiration, and seemed almost angry to find that he had already been frequently seen by Mr. Lucas and himself.

changes.original: There were two nephews of Lady Catherine to require them, for Mr. Darcy had brought with him a Colonel Fitzwilliam, the younger son of his uncle, Lord ----; and, to the great surprise of all the party, when Mr. Collins returned, the gentlemen accompanied him.
changes.transformed: There were two nephews of Mr. Catherine to require them, for Mr. Darcy had brought with him a Colonel Fitzwilliam, the younger son of his uncle, Lord ----; and, to the great surprise of all the party, when Mr. Collins returned, the gentlemen accompanied him.

changes.original: Charlotte had seen them from her husband’s room, crossing the road, and immediately running into the other, told the girls what an honour they might expect, adding,--
changes.transformed: Charles had seen them from his husband’s room, crossing the road, and immediately running into the other, told the boys what an honour they might expect, adding,--

changes.original: “I may thank you, Eliza, for this piece of civility.
changes.transformed: “I may thank you, Elliot, for this piece of civility.

changes.original: Elizabeth had scarcely time to disclaim all right to the compliment before their approach was announced by the door-bell, and shortly afterwards the three gentlemen entered the room.
changes.transformed: Elliot had scarcely time to disclaim all right to the compliment before their approach was announced by the door-bell, and shortly afterwards the three gentlemen entered the room.

changes.original: Mr. Darcy looked just as he had been used to look in Hertfordshire, paid his compliments, with his usual reserve, to Mrs. Collins; and whatever might be his feelings towards her friend, met her with every appearance of composure.
changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy looked just as he had been used to look in Hertfordshire, paid his compliments, with his usual reserve, to Mr. Collins; and whatever might be his feelings towards his friend, met him with every appearance of composure.

changes.original: Elizabeth merely courtesied to him, without saying a word.
changes.transformed: Elliot merely bowed to him, without saying a word.

changes.original: Colonel Fitzwilliam entered into conversation directly, with the readiness and ease of a well-bred man, and talked very pleasantly; but his cousin, after having addressed a slight observation on the house and garden to Mrs. Collins, sat for some time without speaking to anybody.
changes.transformed: Colonel Fitzwilliam entered into conversation directly, with the readiness and ease of a well-bred man, and talked very pleasantly; but his cousin, after having addressed a slight observation on the house and garden to Mr. Collins, sat for some time without speaking to anybody.

changes.original: At length, however, his civility was so far awakened as to inquire of Elizabeth after the health of her family.
changes.transformed: At length, however, his civility was so far awakened as to inquire of Elliot after the health of his family.

changes.original: She answered him in the usual way; and, after a moment’s pause, added,--
changes.transformed: He answered him in the usual way; and, after a moment’s pause, added,--

changes.original: “My eldest sister has been in town these three months.
changes.transformed: “My eldest brother has been in town these three months.

changes.original: Have you never happened to see her there?”
changes.transformed: Have you never happened to see him there?”

changes.original: She was perfectly sensible that he never had: but she wished to see whether he would betray any consciousness of what had passed between the Bingleys and Jane; and she thought he looked a little confused as he answered that he had never been so fortunate as to meet Miss Bennet.
changes.transformed: He was perfectly sensible that he never had: but he wished to see whether he would betray any consciousness of what had passed between the Bingleys and John; and he thought he looked a little confused as he answered that he had never been so fortunate as to meet Mr. Bennet.

changes.original: Colonel Fitzwilliam’s manners were very much admired at the Parsonage, and the ladies all felt that he must add considerably to the pleasure of their engagements at Rosings.
changes.transformed: Colonel Fitzwilliam’s manners were very much admired at the Parsonage, and the gentlemen all felt that he must add considerably to the pleasure of their engagements at Rosings.

changes.original: For the last week they had seen very little of either Lady Catherine or her daughter.
changes.transformed: For the last week they had seen very little of either Mr. Catherine or his son.

changes.original: The invitation was accepted, of course, and at a proper hour they joined the party in Lady Catherine’s drawing-room.
changes.transformed: The invitation was accepted, of course, and at a proper hour they joined the party in Mr. Catherine’s drawing-room.

changes.original: Her Ladyship received them civilly, but it was plain that their company was by no means so acceptable as when she could get nobody else; and she was, in fact, almost engrossed by her nephews, speaking to them, especially to Darcy, much more than to any other person in the room.
changes.transformed: His Lordship received them civilly, but it was plain that their company was by no means so acceptable as when he could get nobody else; and he was, in fact, almost engrossed by his nephews, speaking to them, especially to Darcy, much more than to any other person in the room.

changes.original: Colonel Fitzwilliam seemed really glad to see them: anything was a welcome relief to him at Rosings; and Mrs. Collins’s pretty friend had, moreover, caught his fancy very much.
changes.transformed: Colonel Fitzwilliam seemed really glad to see them: anything was a welcome relief to him at Rosings; and Mr. Collins’s handsome friend had, moreover, caught his fancy very much.

changes.original: He now seated himself by her, and talked so agreeably of Kent and Hertfordshire, of travelling and staying at home, of new books and music, that Elizabeth had never been half so well entertained in that room before; and they conversed with so much spirit and flow as to draw the attention of Lady Catherine herself, as well as of Mr. Darcy. _His_ eyes had been soon and repeatedly turned towards them with a look of curiosity; and that her Ladyship, after a while, shared the feeling, was more openly acknowledged, for she did not scruple to call out,--
changes.transformed: He now seated himself by him, and talked so agreeably of Kent and Hertfordshire, of travelling and staying at home, of new books and music, that Elliot had never been half so well entertained in that room before; and they conversed with so much spirit and flow as to draw the attention of Mr. Catherine himself, as well as of Mr. Darcy. His eyes had been soon and repeatedly turned towards them with a look of curiosity; and that his Lordship, after a while, shared the feeling, was more openly acknowledged, for he did not scruple to call out,--

changes.original: What are you telling Miss Bennet?
changes.transformed: What are you telling Mr. Bennet?

changes.original: “We were talking of music, madam,” said he, when no longer able to avoid a reply.
changes.transformed: “We were talking of music, sir,” said he, when no longer able to avoid a reply.

changes.original: And so would Anne, if her health had allowed her to apply.
changes.transformed: And so would Andrew, if his health had allowed him to apply.

changes.original: I am confident that she would have performed delightfully.
changes.transformed: I am confident that he would have performed delightfully.

changes.original: How does Georgiana get on, Darcy?”
changes.transformed: How does George get on, Darcy?”

changes.original: Mr. Darcy spoke with affectionate praise of his sister’s proficiency.
changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy spoke with affectionate praise of his brother’s proficiency.

changes.original: “I am very glad to hear such a good account of her,” said Lady Catherine; “and pray tell her from me, that she cannot expect to excel, if she does not practise a great deal.”
changes.transformed: “I am very glad to hear such a good account of him,” said Mr. Catherine; “and pray tell him from me, that he cannot expect to excel, if he does not practise a great deal.”

changes.original: “I assure you, madam,” he replied, “that she does not need such advice.
changes.transformed: “I assure you, sir,” he replied, “that he does not need such advice.

changes.original: She practises very constantly.”
changes.transformed: He practises very constantly.”

changes.original: It cannot be done too much; and when I next write to her, I shall charge her not to neglect it on any account.
changes.transformed: It cannot be done too much; and when I next write to him, I shall charge him not to neglect it on any account.

changes.original: I often tell young ladies, that no excellence in music is to be acquired without constant practice.
changes.transformed: I often tell young gentlemen, that no excellence in music is to be acquired without constant practice.

changes.original: I have told Miss Bennet several times, that she will never play really well, unless she practises more; and though Mrs. Collins has no instrument, she is very welcome, as I have often told her, to come to Rosings every day, and play on the pianoforte in Mrs. Jenkinson’s room.
changes.transformed: I have told Mr. Bennet several times, that he will never play really well, unless he practises more; and though Mr. Collins has no instrument, he is very welcome, as I have often told him, to come to Rosings every day, and play on the pianoforte in Mr. Jenkinson’s room.

changes.original: She would be in nobody’s way, you know, in that part of the house.”
changes.transformed: He would be in nobody’s way, you know, in that part of the house.”

changes.original: Mr. Darcy looked a little ashamed of his aunt’s ill-breeding, and made no answer.
changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy looked a little ashamed of his uncle’s ill-breeding, and made no answer.

changes.original: When coffee was over, Colonel Fitzwilliam reminded Elizabeth of having promised to play to him; and she sat down directly to the instrument.
changes.transformed: When coffee was over, Colonel Fitzwilliam reminded Elliot of having promised to play to him; and he sat down directly to the instrument.

changes.original: He drew a chair near her.
changes.transformed: He drew a chair near him.

changes.original: Lady Catherine listened to half a song, and then talked, as before, to her other nephew; till the latter walked away from her, and moving with his usual deliberation towards the pianoforte, stationed himself so as to command a full view of the fair performer’s countenance.
changes.transformed: Mr. Catherine listened to half a song, and then talked, as before, to his other nephew; till the latter walked away from him, and moving with his usual deliberation towards the pianoforte, stationed himself so as to command a full view of the fair performer’s countenance.

changes.original: Elizabeth saw what he was doing, and at the first convenient pause turned to him with an arch smile, and said,--
changes.transformed: Elliot saw what he was doing, and at the first convenient pause turned to him with an arch smile, and said,--

changes.original: But I will not be alarmed, though your sister _does_ play so well.
changes.transformed: But I will not be alarmed, though your brother _does_ play so well.

changes.original: Elizabeth laughed heartily at this picture of herself, and said to Colonel Fitzwilliam, “Your cousin will give you a very pretty notion of me, and teach you not to believe a word I say.
changes.transformed: Elliot laughed heartily at this picture of himself, and said to Colonel Fitzwilliam, “Your cousin will give you a very pretty notion of me, and teach you not to believe a word I say.

changes.original: He danced only four dances, though gentlemen were scarce; and, to my certain knowledge, more than one young lady was sitting down in want of a partner.
changes.transformed: He danced only four dances, though gentlemen were scarce; and, to my certain knowledge, more than one young gentleman was sitting down in want of a partner.

changes.original: “I had not at that time the honour of knowing any lady in the assembly beyond my own party.”
changes.transformed: “I had not at that time the honour of knowing any gentleman in the assembly beyond my own party.”

changes.original: “Shall we ask your cousin the reason of this?” said Elizabeth, still addressing Colonel Fitzwilliam. “Shall we ask him why a man of sense and education, and who has lived in the world, is ill-qualified to recommend himself to strangers?”
changes.transformed: “Shall we ask your cousin the reason of this?” said Elliot, still addressing Colonel Fitzwilliam. “Shall we ask him why a man of sense and education, and who has lived in the world, is ill-qualified to recommend himself to strangers?”

changes.original: “I certainly have not the talent which some people possess,” said Darcy, “of conversing easily with those I have never seen before.
changes.transformed: “I certainly have not the talent which some people possess,” said Mr. Darcy, “of conversing easily with those I have never seen before.

changes.original: “My fingers,” said Elizabeth, “do not move over this instrument in the masterly manner which I see so many women’s do.
changes.transformed: “My fingers,” said Mr. Elliot, “do not move over this instrument in the masterly manner which I see so many men’s do.

changes.original: It is not that I do not believe _my_ fingers as capable as any other woman’s of superior execution.”
changes.transformed: It is not that I do not believe _my_ fingers as capable as any other man’s of superior execution.”

changes.original: Darcy smiled and said, “You are perfectly right.
changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy smiled and said, “You are perfectly right.

changes.original: Here they were interrupted by Lady Catherine, who called out to know what they were talking of.
changes.transformed: Here they were interrupted by Mr. Catherine de Bourgh, who called out to know what they were talking of.

changes.original: Elizabeth immediately began playing again.
changes.transformed: Mr. Elliot immediately began playing again.

changes.original: Lady Catherine approached, and, after listening for a few minutes, said to Darcy,--
changes.transformed: Mr. Catherine de Bourgh approached, and, after listening for a few minutes, said to Mr. Darcy,--

changes.original: “Miss Bennet would not play at all amiss if she practised more, and could have the advantage of a London master.
changes.transformed: “Mr. Bennet would not play at all amiss if he practised more, and could have the advantage of a London master.

changes.original: She has a very good notion of fingering, though her taste is not equal to Anne’s.
changes.transformed: He has a very good notion of fingering, though his taste is not equal to Mr. Anne’s.

changes.original: Anne would have been a delightful performer, had her health allowed her to learn.”
changes.transformed: Mr. Anne would have been a delightful performer, had his health allowed him to learn.”

changes.original: Elizabeth looked at Darcy, to see how cordially he assented to his cousin’s praise: but neither at that moment nor at any other could she discern any symptom of love; and from the whole of his behaviour to Miss De Bourgh she derived this comfort for Miss Bingley, that he might have been just as likely to marry _her_, had she been his relation.
changes.transformed: Mr. Elliot looked at Mr. Darcy, to see how cordially he assented to his cousin’s praise: but neither at that moment nor at any other could he discern any symptom of love; and from the whole of his behaviour to Mr. De Bourgh he derived this comfort for Mr. Bingley, that he might have been just as likely to marry _him_, had he been his relation.

changes.original: Lady Catherine continued her remarks on Elizabeth’s performance, mixing with them many instructions on execution and taste.
changes.transformed: Mr. Catherine de Bourgh continued his remarks on Mr. Elliot’s performance, mixing with them many instructions on execution and taste.

changes.original: Elizabeth received them with all the forbearance of civility; and at the request of the gentlemen remained at the instrument till her Ladyship’s carriage was ready to take them all home.
changes.transformed: Mr. Elliot received them with all the forbearance of civility; and at the request of the gentlemen remained at the instrument till Mr. Catherine de Bourgh’s carriage was ready to take them all home.

changes.original: Elizabeth was sitting by herself the next morning, and writing to Jane, while Mrs. Collins and Maria were gone on business into the village, when she was startled by a ring at the door, the certain signal of a visitor.
changes.transformed: Elliot was sitting by himself the next morning, and writing to John, while Mr. Collins and Martin were gone on business into the village, when he was startled by a ring at the door, the certain signal of a visitor.

changes.original: As she had heard no carriage, she thought it not unlikely to be Lady Catherine; and under that apprehension was putting away her half-finished letter, that she might escape all impertinent questions, when the door opened, and to her very great surprise Mr. Darcy, and Mr. Darcy only, entered the room.
changes.transformed: As he had heard no carriage, he thought it not unlikely to be Mr. Catherine; and under that apprehension was putting away his half-finished letter, that he might escape all impertinent questions, when the door opened, and to his very great surprise Mr. Darcy, and Mr. Darcy only, entered the room.

changes.original: He seemed astonished too on finding her alone, and apologized for his intrusion, by letting her know that he had understood all the ladies to be within.
changes.transformed: He seemed astonished too on finding him alone, and apologized for his intrusion, by letting him know that he had understood all the gentlemen to be within.

changes.original: They then sat down, and when her inquiries after Rosings were made, seemed in danger of sinking into total silence.
changes.transformed: They then sat down, and when his inquiries after Rosings were made, seemed in danger of sinking into total silence.

changes.original: It was absolutely necessary, therefore, to think of something; and in this emergency recollecting _when_ she had seen him last in Hertfordshire, and feeling curious to know what he would say on the subject of their hasty departure, she observed,--
changes.transformed: It was absolutely necessary, therefore, to think of something; and in this emergency recollecting _when_ he had seen him last in Hertfordshire, and feeling curious to know what he would say on the subject of their hasty departure, he observed,--

changes.original: He and his sisters were well, I hope, when you left London?”
changes.transformed: He and his brothers were well, I hope, when you left London?”

changes.original: She found that she was to receive no other answer; and, after a short pause, added,--
changes.transformed: He found that he was to receive no other answer; and, after a short pause, added,--

changes.original: Elizabeth made no answer.
changes.transformed: Elliot made no answer.

changes.original: She was afraid of talking longer of his friend; and, having nothing else to say, was now determined to leave the trouble of finding a subject to him.
changes.transformed: He was afraid of talking longer of his friend; and, having nothing else to say, was now determined to leave the trouble of finding a subject to him.

changes.original: Lady Catherine, I believe, did a great deal to it when Mr. Collins first came to Hunsford.”
changes.transformed: Mr. Catherine, I believe, did a great deal to it when Mr. Collins first came to Hunsford.”

changes.original: “I believe she did--and I am sure she could not have bestowed her kindness on a more grateful object.”
changes.transformed: “I believe he did--and I am sure he could not have bestowed his kindness on a more grateful object.”

changes.original: “Mr. Collins appears very fortunate in his choice of a wife.”
changes.transformed: “Mr. Collins appears very fortunate in his choice of a husband.”

changes.original: “Yes, indeed; his friends may well rejoice in his having met with one of the very few sensible women who would have accepted him, or have made him happy if they had.
changes.transformed: “Yes, indeed; his friends may well rejoice in his having met with one of the very few sensible men who would have accepted him, or have made him happy if they had.

changes.original: My friend has an excellent understanding--though I am not certain that I consider her marrying Mr. Collins as the wisest thing she ever did.
changes.transformed: My friend has an excellent understanding--though I am not certain that I consider his marrying Mr. Collins as the wisest thing he ever did.

changes.original: She seems perfectly happy, however; and, in a prudential light, it is certainly a very good match for her.”
changes.transformed: He seems perfectly happy, however; and, in a prudential light, it is certainly a very good match for him.”

changes.original: “It must be very agreeable to her to be settled within so easy a distance of her own family and friends.”
changes.transformed: “It must be very agreeable to him to be settled within so easy a distance of his own family and friends.”

changes.original: “I should never have considered the distance as one of the _advantages_ of the match,” cried Elizabeth. “I should never have said Mrs. Collins was settled _near_ her family.”
changes.transformed: “I should never have considered the distance as one of the _advantages_ of the match,” cried Elliot. “I should never have said Mr. Collins was settled _near_ his family.”

changes.original: As he spoke there was a sort of smile, which Elizabeth fancied she understood; he must be supposing her to be thinking of Jane and Netherfield, and she blushed as she answered,--
changes.transformed: As he spoke there was a sort of smile, which Elliot fancied he understood; he must be supposing him to be thinking of John and Netherfield, and he blushed as he answered,--

changes.original: “I do not mean to say that a woman may not be settled too near her family.
changes.transformed: “I do not mean to say that a man may not be settled too near his family.

changes.original: Mr. and Mrs. Collins have a comfortable income, but not such a one as will allow of frequent journeys--and I am persuaded my friend would not call herself _near_ her family under less than _half_ the present distance.”
changes.transformed: Mr. and Mr. Collins have a comfortable income, but not such a one as will allow of frequent journeys--and I am persuaded my friend would not call himself _near_ his family under less than _half_ the present distance.”

changes.original: Mr. Darcy drew his chair a little towards her, and said, “_You_ cannot have a right to such very strong local attachment. _You_ cannot have been always at Longbourn.”
changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy drew his chair a little towards him, and said, “_You_ cannot have a right to such very strong local attachment. _You_ cannot have been always at Longbourn.”

changes.original: Elizabeth looked surprised.
changes.transformed: Elliot looked surprised.

changes.original: A short dialogue on the subject of the country ensued, on either side calm and concise--and soon put an end to by the entrance of Charlotte and her sister, just returned from their walk.
changes.transformed: A short dialogue on the subject of the country ensued, on either side calm and concise--and soon put an end to by the entrance of Charles and his brother, just returned from their walk.

changes.original: Mr. Darcy related the mistake which had occasioned his intruding on Miss Bennet, and, after sitting a few minutes longer, without saying much to anybody, went away.
changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy related the mistake which had occasioned his intruding on Mr. Bennet, and, after sitting a few minutes longer, without saying much to anybody, went away.

changes.original: “What can be the meaning of this?” said Charlotte, as soon as he was gone. “My dear Eliza, he must be in love with you, or he would never have called on us in this familiar way.”
changes.transformed: “What can be the meaning of this?” said Charles, as soon as he was gone. “My dear Elliot, he must be in love with you, or he would never have called on us in this familiar way.”

changes.original: But when Elizabeth told of his silence, it did not seem very likely, even to Charlotte’s wishes, to be the case; and, after various conjectures, they could at last only suppose his visit to proceed from the difficulty of finding anything to do, which was the more probable from the time of year.
changes.transformed: But when Elliot told of his silence, it did not seem very likely, even to Charles’s wishes, to be the case; and, after various conjectures, they could at last only suppose his visit to proceed from the difficulty of finding anything to do, which was the more probable from the time of year.

changes.original: Within doors there was Lady Catherine, books, and a billiard table, but gentlemen cannot be always within doors; and in the nearness of the Parsonage, or the pleasantness of the walk to it, or of the people who lived in it, the two cousins found a temptation from this period of walking thither almost every day.
changes.transformed: Within doors there was Mr. Catherine, books, and a billiard table, but gentlemen cannot be always within doors; and in the nearness of the Parsonage, or the pleasantness of the walk to it, or of the people who lived in it, the two cousins found a temptation from this period of walking thither almost every day.

changes.original: They called at various times of the morning, sometimes separately, sometimes together, and now and then accompanied by their aunt.
changes.transformed: They called at various times of the morning, sometimes separately, sometimes together, and now and then accompanied by their uncle.

changes.original: It was plain to them all that Colonel Fitzwilliam came because he had pleasure in their society, a persuasion which of course recommended him still more; and Elizabeth was reminded by her own satisfaction in being with him, as well as by his evident admiration, of her former favourite, George Wickham; and though, in comparing them, she saw there was less captivating softness in Colonel Fitzwilliam’s manners, she believed he might have the best informed mind.
changes.transformed: It was plain to them all that Colonel Fitzwilliam came because he had pleasure in their society, a persuasion which of course recommended him still more; and Elliot was reminded by his own satisfaction in being with him, as well as by his evident admiration, of his former favourite, George Wickham; and though, in comparing them, he saw there was less captivating softness in Colonel Fitzwilliam’s manners, he believed he might have the best informed mind.

changes.original: Mrs. Collins knew not what to make of him.
changes.transformed: Mr. Collins knew not what to make of him.

changes.original: Colonel Fitzwilliam’s occasionally laughing at his stupidity proved that he was generally different, which her own knowledge of him could not have told her; and as she would have liked to believe this change the effect of love, and the object of that love her friend Eliza, she set herself seriously to work to find it out: she watched him whenever they were at Rosings, and whenever he came to Hunsford; but without much success.
changes.transformed: Colonel Fitzwilliam’s occasionally laughing at his stupidity proved that he was generally different, which his own knowledge of him could not have told him; and as he would have liked to believe this change the effect of love, and the object of that love his friend Elliot, he set himself seriously to work to find it out: he watched him whenever they were at Rosings, and whenever he came to Hunsford; but without much success.

changes.original: He certainly looked at her friend a great deal, but the expression of that look was disputable.
changes.transformed: He certainly looked at his friend a great deal, but the expression of that look was disputable.

changes.original: It was an earnest, steadfast gaze, but she often doubted whether there were much admiration in it, and sometimes it seemed nothing but absence of mind.
changes.transformed: It was an earnest, steadfast gaze, but he often doubted whether there were much admiration in it, and sometimes it seemed nothing but absence of mind.

changes.original: She had once or twice suggested to Elizabeth the possibility of his being partial to her, but Elizabeth always laughed at the idea; and Mrs. Collins did not think it right to press the subject, from the danger of raising expectations which might only end in disappointment; for in her opinion it admitted not of a doubt, that all her friend’s dislike would vanish, if she could suppose him to be in her power.
changes.transformed: He had once or twice suggested to Elliot the possibility of his being partial to him, but Elliot always laughed at the idea; and Mr. Collins did not think it right to press the subject, from the danger of raising expectations which might only end in disappointment; for in his opinion it admitted not of a doubt, that all his friend’s dislike would vanish, if he could suppose him to be in his power.

changes.original: In her kind schemes for Elizabeth, she sometimes planned her marrying Colonel Fitzwilliam.
changes.transformed: In his kind schemes for Elliot, he sometimes planned his marrying Mr. Fitzwilliam.

changes.original: He was, beyond comparison, the pleasantest man: he certainly admired her, and his situation in life was most eligible; but, to counterbalance these advantages, Mr. Darcy had considerable patronage in the church, and his cousin could have none at all.
changes.transformed: He was, beyond comparison, the pleasantest man: he certainly admired him, and his situation in life was most eligible; but, to counterbalance these advantages, Mr. Darcy had considerable patronage in the church, and his cousin could have none at all.

changes.original: More than once did Elizabeth, in her ramble within the park, unexpectedly meet Mr. Darcy.
changes.transformed: More than once did Elliot, in his ramble within the park, unexpectedly meet Mr. Darcy.

changes.original: She felt all the perverseness of the mischance that should bring him where no one else was brought; and, to prevent its ever happening again, took care to inform him, at first, that it was a favourite haunt of hers.
changes.transformed: He felt all the perverseness of the mischance that should bring him where no one else was brought; and, to prevent its ever happening again, took care to inform him, at first, that it was a favourite haunt of his.

changes.original: It seemed like wilful ill-nature, or a voluntary penance; for on these occasions it was not merely a few formal inquiries and an awkward pause and then away, but he actually thought it necessary to turn back and walk with her.
