changes.transformed: It seemed like wilful ill-nature, or a voluntary penance; for on these occasions it was not merely a few formal inquiries and an awkward pause and then away, but he actually thought it necessary to turn back and walk with him.

changes.original: He never said a great deal, nor did she give herself the trouble of talking or of listening much; but it struck her in the course of their third encounter that he was asking some odd unconnected questions--about her pleasure in being at Hunsford, her love of solitary walks, and her opinion of Mr. and Mrs. Collins’s happiness; and that in speaking of Rosings, and her not perfectly understanding the house, he seemed to expect that whenever she came into Kent again she would be staying _there_ too.
changes.transformed: He never said a great deal, nor did he give himself the trouble of talking or of listening much; but it struck him in the course of their third encounter that he was asking some odd unconnected questions--about his pleasure in being at Hunsford, his love of solitary walks, and his opinion of Mr. and Mr. Collins’s happiness; and that in speaking of Rosings, and his not perfectly understanding the house, he seemed to expect that whenever he came into Kent again he would be staying _there_ too.

changes.original: She supposed, if he meant anything, he must mean an allusion to what might arise in that quarter.
changes.transformed: He supposed, if he meant anything, he must mean an allusion to what might arise in that quarter.

changes.original: It distressed her a little, and she was quite glad to find herself at the gate in the pales opposite the Parsonage.
changes.transformed: It distressed him a little, and he was quite glad to find himself at the gate in the pales opposite the Parsonage.

changes.original: She was engaged one day, as she walked, in re-perusing Jane’s last letter, and dwelling on some passages which proved that Jane had not written in spirits, when, instead of being again surprised by Mr. Darcy, she saw, on looking up, that Colonel Fitzwilliam was meeting her.
changes.transformed: He was engaged one day, as he walked, in re-perusing John’s last letter, and dwelling on some passages which proved that John had not written in spirits, when, instead of being again surprised by Mr. Darcy, he saw, on looking up, that Colonel Fitzwilliam was meeting him.

changes.original: Putting away the letter immediately, and forcing a smile, she said,--
changes.transformed: Putting away the letter immediately, and forcing a smile, he said,--

changes.original: And accordingly she did turn, and they walked towards the Parsonage together.
changes.transformed: And accordingly he did turn, and they walked towards the Parsonage together.

changes.original: “Do you certainly leave Kent on Saturday?” said she.
changes.transformed: “Do you certainly leave Kent on Saturday?” said he.

changes.original: “Unless where they like women of fortune, which I think they very often do.”
changes.transformed: “Unless where they like men of fortune, which I think they very often do.”

changes.original: “Is this,” thought Elizabeth, “meant for me?” and she coloured at the idea; but, recovering herself, said in a lively tone, “And pray, what is the usual price of an earl’s younger son?
changes.transformed: “Is this,” thought Elliot, “meant for me?” and he coloured at the idea; but, recovering himself, said in a lively tone, “And pray, what is the usual price of an earl’s younger son?

changes.original: He answered her in the same style, and the subject dropped.
changes.transformed: He answered him in the same style, and the subject dropped.

changes.original: To interrupt a silence which might make him fancy her affected with what had passed, she soon afterwards said,--
changes.transformed: To interrupt a silence which might make him fancy him affected with what had passed, he soon afterwards said,--

changes.original: But, perhaps, his sister does as well for the present; and, as she is under his sole care, he may do what he likes with her.”
changes.transformed: But, perhaps, his brother does as well for the present; and, as he is under his sole care, he may do what he likes with him.”

changes.original: I am joined with him in the guardianship of Miss Darcy.”
changes.transformed: I am joined with him in the guardianship of Mr. Darcy.”

changes.original: Young ladies of her age are sometimes a little difficult to manage; and if she has the true Darcy spirit, she may like to have her own way.”
changes.transformed: Young gentlemen of his age are sometimes a little difficult to manage; and if he has the true Darcy spirit, he may like to have his own way.”

changes.original: As she spoke, she observed him looking at her earnestly; and the manner in which he immediately asked her why she supposed Miss Darcy likely to give them any uneasiness, convinced her that she had somehow or other got pretty near the truth.
changes.transformed: As he spoke, he observed him looking at him earnestly; and the manner in which he immediately asked him why he supposed Mr. Darcy likely to give them any uneasiness, convinced him that he had somehow or other got pretty near the truth.

changes.original: She directly replied,--
changes.transformed: He directly replied,--

changes.original: I never heard any harm of her; and I dare say she is one of the most tractable creatures in the world.
changes.transformed: I never heard any harm of him; and I dare say he is one of the most tractable creatures in the world.

changes.original: She is a very great favourite with some ladies of my acquaintance, Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley.
changes.transformed: He is a very great favourite with some gentlemen of my acquaintance, Mr. Hurst and Mr. Bingley.

changes.original: “Oh yes,” said Elizabeth drily--“Mr. Darcy is uncommonly kind to Mr. Bingley, and takes a prodigious deal of care of him.”
changes.transformed: “Oh yes,” said Elliot drily--“Mr. Darcy is uncommonly kind to Mr. Bingley, and takes a prodigious deal of care of him.”

changes.original: “It is a circumstance which Darcy of course could not wish to be generally known, because if it were to get round to the lady’s family it would be an unpleasant thing.”
changes.transformed: “It is a circumstance which Darcy of course could not wish to be generally known, because if it were to get round to the gentleman’s family it would be an unpleasant thing.”

changes.original: “I understood that there were some very strong objections against the lady.”
changes.transformed: “I understood that there were some very strong objections against the gentleman.”

changes.original: Elizabeth made no answer, and walked on, her heart swelling with indignation.
changes.transformed: Elliot made no answer, and walked on, his heart swelling with indignation.

changes.original: After watching her a little, Fitzwilliam asked her why she was so thoughtful.
changes.transformed: After watching him a little, Fitzwilliam asked him why he was so thoughtful.

changes.original: “I am thinking of what you have been telling me,” said she. “Your cousin’s conduct does not suit my feelings.
changes.transformed: “I am thinking of what you have been telling me,” said he. “Your cousin’s conduct does not suit my feelings.

changes.original: But,” she continued, recollecting herself, “as we know none of the particulars, it is not fair to condemn him.
changes.transformed: But,” he continued, recollecting himself, “as we know none of the particulars, it is not fair to condemn him.

changes.original: This was spoken jestingly, but it appeared to her so just a picture of Mr. Darcy, that she would not trust herself with an answer; and, therefore, abruptly changing the conversation, talked on indifferent matters till they reached the Parsonage.
changes.transformed: This was spoken jestingly, but it appeared to him so just a picture of Mr. Darcy, that he would not trust himself with an answer; and, therefore, abruptly changing the conversation, talked on indifferent matters till they reached the Parsonage.

changes.original: There, shut into her own room, as soon as their visitor left them, she could think without interruption of all that she had heard.
changes.transformed: There, shut into his own room, as soon as their visitor left them, he could think without interruption of all that he had heard.

changes.original: It was not to be supposed that any other people could be meant than those with whom she was connected.
changes.transformed: It was not to be supposed that any other people could be meant than those with whom he was connected.

changes.original: That he had been concerned in the measures taken to separate Mr. Bingley and Jane, she had never doubted; but she had always attributed to Miss Bingley the principal design and arrangement of them.
changes.transformed: That he had been concerned in the measures taken to separate Mr. Bingley and John, he had never doubted; but he had always attributed to Mr. Bingley the principal design and arrangement of them.

changes.original: If his own vanity, however, did not mislead him, _he_ was the cause--his pride and caprice were the cause--of all that Jane had suffered, and still continued to suffer.
changes.transformed: If his own vanity, however, did not mislead him, _he_ was the cause--his pride and caprice were the cause--of all that John had suffered, and still continued to suffer.

changes.original: “There were some very strong objections against the lady,” were Colonel Fitzwilliam’s words; and these strong objections probably were, her having one uncle who was a country attorney, and another who was in business in London.
changes.transformed: “There were some very strong objections against the gentleman,” were Colonel Fitzwilliam’s words; and these strong objections probably were, his having one uncle who was a country attorney, and another who was in business in London.

changes.original: “To Jane herself,” she exclaimed, “there could be no possibility of objection,--all loveliness and goodness as she is!
changes.transformed: “To John himself,” he exclaimed, “there could be no possibility of objection,--all loveliness and goodness as he is!

changes.original: Her understanding excellent, her mind improved, and her manners captivating.
changes.transformed: His understanding excellent, his mind improved, and his manners captivating.

changes.original: Neither could anything be urged against my father, who, though with some peculiarities, has abilities which Mr. Darcy himself need not disdain, and respectability which he will probably never reach.” When she thought of her mother, indeed, her confidence gave way a little; but she would not allow that any objections _there_ had material weight with Mr. Darcy, whose pride, she was convinced, would receive a deeper wound from the want of importance in his friend’s connections than from their want of sense; and she was quite decided, at last, that he had been partly governed by this worst kind of pride, and partly by the wish of retaining Mr. Bingley for his sister.
changes.transformed: Neither could anything be urged against my father, who, though with some peculiarities, has abilities which Mr. Darcy himself need not disdain, and respectability which he will probably never reach.” When he thought of his father, indeed, his confidence gave way a little; but he would not allow that any objections _there_ had material weight with Mr. Darcy, whose pride, he was convinced, would receive a deeper wound from the want of importance in his friend’s connections than from their want of sense; and he was quite decided, at last, that he had been partly governed by this worst kind of pride, and partly by the wish of retaining Mr. Bingley for his brother.

changes.original: The agitation and tears which the subject occasioned brought on a headache; and it grew so much worse towards the evening that, added to her unwillingness to see Mr. Darcy, it determined her not to attend her cousins to Rosings, where they were engaged to drink tea.
changes.transformed: The agitation and tears which the subject occasioned brought on a headache; and it grew so much worse towards the evening that, added to his unwillingness to see Mr. Darcy, it determined him not to attend his cousins to Rosings, where they were engaged to drink tea.

changes.original: Mrs. Collins, seeing that she was really unwell, did not press her to go, and as much as possible prevented her husband from pressing her; but Mr. Collins could not conceal his apprehension of Lady Catherine’s being rather displeased by her staying at home.
changes.transformed: Mr. Collins, seeing that he was really unwell, did not press him to go, and as much as possible prevented his husband from pressing him; but Mr. Collins could not conceal his apprehension of Mr. Catherine’s being rather displeased by his staying at home.

changes.original: When they were gone, Elizabeth, as if intending to exasperate herself as much as possible against Mr. Darcy, chose for her employment the examination of all the letters which Jane had written to her since her being in Kent.
changes.transformed: When they were gone, Elliot, as if intending to exasperate himself as much as possible against Mr. Darcy, chose for his employment the examination of all the letters which John had written to him since his being in Kent.

changes.original: But in all, and in almost every line of each, there was a want of that cheerfulness which had been used to characterize her style, and which, proceeding from the serenity of a mind at ease with itself, and kindly disposed towards everyone, had been scarcely ever clouded.
changes.transformed: But in all, and in almost every line of each, there was a want of that cheerfulness which had been used to characterize his style, and which, proceeding from the serenity of a mind at ease with itself, and kindly disposed towards everyone, had been scarcely ever clouded.

changes.original: Elizabeth noticed every sentence conveying the idea of uneasiness, with an attention which it had hardly received on the first perusal.
changes.transformed: Elliot noticed every sentence conveying the idea of uneasiness, with an attention which it had hardly received on the first perusal.

changes.original: Mr. Darcy’s shameful boast of what misery he had been able to inflict gave her a keener sense of her sister’s sufferings.
changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy’s shameful boast of what misery he had been able to inflict gave him a keener sense of his brother’s sufferings.

changes.original: It was some consolation to think that his visit to Rosings was to end on the day after the next, and a still greater that in less than a fortnight she should herself be with Jane again, and enabled to contribute to the recovery of her spirits, by all that affection could do.
changes.transformed: It was some consolation to think that his visit to Rosings was to end on the day after the next, and a still greater that in less than a fortnight he should himself be with John again, and enabled to contribute to the recovery of his spirits, by all that affection could do.

changes.original: She could not think of Darcy’s leaving Kent without remembering that his cousin was to go with him; but Colonel Fitzwilliam had made it clear that he had no intentions at all, and, agreeable as he was, she did not mean to be unhappy about him.
changes.transformed: He could not think of Darcy’s leaving Kent without remembering that his cousin was to go with him; but Colonel Fitzwilliam had made it clear that he had no intentions at all, and, agreeable as he was, he did not mean to be unhappy about him.

changes.original: While settling this point, she was suddenly roused by the sound of the door-bell; and her spirits were a little fluttered by the idea of its being Colonel Fitzwilliam himself, who had once before called late in the evening, and might now come to inquire particularly after her.
changes.transformed: While settling this point, he was suddenly roused by the sound of the door-bell; and his spirits were a little fluttered by the idea of its being Colonel Fitzwilliam himself, who had once before called late in the evening, and might now come to inquire particularly after him.

changes.original: But this idea was soon banished, and her spirits were very differently affected, when, to her utter amazement, she saw Mr. Darcy walk into the room.
changes.transformed: But this idea was soon banished, and his spirits were very differently affected, when, to his utter amazement, he saw Mr. Darcy walk into the room.

changes.original: In a hurried manner he immediately began an inquiry after her health, imputing his visit to a wish of hearing that she were better.
changes.transformed: In a hurried manner he immediately began an inquiry after his health, imputing his visit to a wish of hearing that he were better.

changes.original: She answered him with cold civility.
changes.transformed: He answered him with cold civility.

changes.original: Elizabeth was surprised, but said not a word.
changes.transformed: Elliot was surprised, but said not a word.

changes.original: After a silence of several minutes, he came towards her in an agitated manner, and thus began:--
changes.transformed: After a silence of several minutes, he came towards him in an agitated manner, and thus began:--

changes.original: Elizabeth’s astonishment was beyond expression.
changes.transformed: Elliot’s astonishment was beyond expression.

changes.original: She stared, coloured, doubted, and was silent.
changes.transformed: He stared, coloured, doubted, and was silent.

changes.original: This he considered sufficient encouragement, and the avowal of all that he felt and had long felt for her immediately followed.
changes.transformed: This he considered sufficient encouragement, and the avowal of all that he felt and had long felt for him immediately followed.

changes.original: His sense of her inferiority, of its being a degradation, of the family obstacles which judgment had always opposed to inclination, were dwelt on with a warmth which seemed due to the consequence he was wounding, but was very unlikely to recommend his suit.
changes.transformed: His sense of his inferiority, of its being a degradation, of the family obstacles which judgment had always opposed to inclination, were dwelt on with a warmth which seemed due to the consequence he was wounding, but was very unlikely to recommend his suit.

changes.original: In spite of her deeply-rooted dislike, she could not be insensible to the compliment of such a man’s affection, and though her intentions did not vary for an instant, she was at first sorry for the pain he was to receive; till roused to resentment by his subsequent language, she lost all compassion in anger.
changes.transformed: In spite of his deeply-rooted dislike, he could not be insensible to the compliment of such a man’s affection, and though his intentions did not vary for an instant, he was at first sorry for the pain he was to receive; till roused to resentment by his subsequent language, he lost all compassion in anger.

changes.original: She tried, however, to compose herself to answer him with patience, when he should have done.
changes.transformed: He tried, however, to compose himself to answer him with patience, when he should have done.

changes.original: He concluded with representing to her the strength of that attachment which in spite of all his endeavours he had found impossible to conquer; and with expressing his hope that it would now be rewarded by her acceptance of his hand.
changes.transformed: He concluded with representing to him the strength of that attachment which in spite of all his endeavours he had found impossible to conquer; and with expressing his hope that it would now be rewarded by his acceptance of his hand.

changes.original: As he said this she could easily see that he had no doubt of a favourable answer.
changes.transformed: As he said this he could easily see that he had no doubt of a favourable answer.

changes.original: Such a circumstance could only exasperate farther; and when he ceased the colour rose into her cheeks and she said,--
changes.transformed: Such a circumstance could only exasperate farther; and when he ceased the colour rose into his cheeks and he said,--

changes.original: Mr. Darcy, who was leaning against the mantel-piece with his eyes fixed on her face, seemed to catch her words with no less resentment than surprise.
changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy, who was leaning against the mantel-piece with his eyes fixed on his face, seemed to catch his words with no less resentment than surprise.

changes.original: The pause was to Elizabeth’s feelings dreadful.
changes.transformed: The pause was to Elliot’s feelings dreadful.

changes.original: “I might as well inquire,” replied she, “why, with so evident a design of offending and insulting me, you chose to tell me that you liked me against your will, against your reason, and even against your character?
changes.transformed: “I might as well inquire,” replied he, “why, with so evident a design of offending and insulting me, you chose to tell me that you liked me against your will, against your reason, and even against your character?

changes.original: Had not my own feelings decided against you, had they been indifferent, or had they even been favourable, do you think that any consideration would tempt me to accept the man who has been the means of ruining, perhaps for ever, the happiness of a most beloved sister?”
changes.transformed: Had not my own feelings decided against you, had they been indifferent, or had they even been favourable, do you think that any consideration would tempt me to accept the man who has been the means of ruining, perhaps for ever, the happiness of a most beloved brother?”

changes.original: As she pronounced these words, Mr. Darcy changed colour; but the emotion was short, and he listened without attempting to interrupt her while she continued,--
changes.transformed: As he pronounced these words, Mr. Darcy changed colour; but the emotion was short, and he listened without attempting to interrupt him while he continued,--

changes.original: She paused, and saw with no slight indignation that he was listening with an air which proved him wholly unmoved by any feeling of remorse.
changes.transformed: He paused, and saw with no slight indignation that he was listening with an air which proved him wholly unmoved by any feeling of remorse.

changes.original: He even looked at her with a smile of affected incredulity.
changes.transformed: He even looked at him with a smile of affected incredulity.

changes.original: “Can you deny that you have done it?” she repeated.
changes.transformed: “Can you deny that you have done it?” he repeated.

changes.original: With assumed tranquillity he then replied, “I have no wish of denying that I did everything in my power to separate my friend from your sister, or that I rejoice in my success.
changes.transformed: With assumed tranquillity he then replied, “I have no wish of denying that I did everything in my power to separate my friend from your brother, or that I rejoice in my success.

changes.original: Elizabeth disdained the appearance of noticing this civil reflection, but its meaning did not escape, nor was it likely to conciliate her.
changes.transformed: Elliot disdained the appearance of noticing this civil reflection, but its meaning did not escape, nor was it likely to conciliate him.

changes.original: “But it is not merely this affair,” she continued, “on which my dislike is founded.
changes.transformed: “But it is not merely this affair,” he continued, “on which my dislike is founded.

changes.original: “You take an eager interest in that gentleman’s concerns,” said Darcy, in a less tranquil tone, and with a heightened colour.
changes.transformed: “You take an eager interest in that gentleman’s concerns,” said Mr. Darcy, in a less tranquil tone, and with a heightened colour.

changes.original: “His misfortunes!” repeated Darcy, contemptuously,--“yes, his misfortunes have been great indeed.”
changes.transformed: “His misfortunes!” repeated Mr. Darcy, contemptuously,--“yes, his misfortunes have been great indeed.”

changes.original: “And of your infliction,” cried Elizabeth, with energy; “You have reduced him to his present state of poverty--comparative poverty.
changes.transformed: “And of your infliction,” cried Mr. Elliot, with energy; “You have reduced him to his present state of poverty--comparative poverty.

changes.original: “And this,” cried Darcy, as he walked with quick steps across the room, “is your opinion of me!
changes.transformed: “And this,” cried Mr. Darcy, as he walked with quick steps across the room, “is your opinion of me!

changes.original: But, perhaps,” added he, stopping in his walk, and turning towards her, “these offences might have been overlooked, had not your pride been hurt by my honest confession of the scruples that had long prevented my forming any serious design.
changes.transformed: But, perhaps,” added he, stopping in his walk, and turning towards him, “these offences might have been overlooked, had not your pride been hurt by my honest confession of the scruples that had long prevented my forming any serious design.

changes.original: Elizabeth felt herself growing more angry every moment; yet she tried to the utmost to speak with composure when she said,--
changes.transformed: Mr. Elliot felt himself growing more angry every moment; yet he tried to the utmost to speak with composure when he said,--

changes.original: She saw him start at this; but he said nothing, and she continued,--
changes.transformed: He saw him start at this; but he said nothing, and he continued,--

changes.original: Again his astonishment was obvious; and he looked at her with an expression of mingled incredulity and mortification.
changes.transformed: Again his astonishment was obvious; and he looked at him with an expression of mingled incredulity and mortification.

changes.original: She went on,--
changes.transformed: He went on,--

changes.original: “You have said quite enough, madam.
changes.transformed: “You have said quite enough, sir.

changes.original: And with these words he hastily left the room, and Elizabeth heard him the next moment open the front door and quit the house.
changes.transformed: And with these words he hastily left the room, and Elliot heard him the next moment open the front door and quit the house.

changes.original: The tumult of her mind was now painfully great.
changes.transformed: The tumult of his mind was now painfully great.

changes.original: She knew not how to support herself, and, from actual weakness, sat down and cried for half an hour.
changes.transformed: He knew not how to support himself, and, from actual weakness, sat down and cried for half an hour.

changes.original: Her astonishment, as she reflected on what had passed, was increased by every review of it.
changes.transformed: His astonishment, as he reflected on what had passed, was increased by every review of it.

changes.original: That she should receive an offer of marriage from Mr. Darcy! that he should have been in love with her for so many months! so much in love as to wish to marry her in spite of all the objections which had made him prevent his friend’s marrying her sister, and which must appear at least with equal force in his own case, was almost incredible! it was gratifying to have inspired unconsciously so strong an affection.
changes.transformed: That he should receive an offer of marriage from Mr. Darcy! that he should have been in love with him for so many months! so much in love as to wish to marry him in spite of all the objections which had made him prevent his friend’s marrying his brother, and which must appear at least with equal force in his own case, was almost incredible! it was gratifying to have inspired unconsciously so strong an affection.

changes.original: But his pride, his abominable pride, his shameless avowal of what he had done with respect to Jane, his unpardonable assurance in acknowledging, though he could not justify it, and the unfeeling manner which he had mentioned Mr. Wickham, his cruelty towards whom he had not attempted to deny, soon overcame the pity which the consideration of his attachment had for a moment excited.
changes.transformed: But his pride, his abominable pride, his shameless avowal of what he had done with respect to John, his unpardonable assurance in acknowledging, though he could not justify it, and the unfeeling manner which he had mentioned Mr. Wickham, his cruelty towards whom he had not attempted to deny, soon overcame the pity which the consideration of his attachment had for a moment excited.

changes.original: She continued in very agitating reflections till the sound of Lady Catherine’s carriage made her feel how unequal she was to encounter Charlotte’s observation, and hurried her away to her room.
changes.transformed: He continued in very agitating reflections till the sound of Mr. Catherine’s carriage made him feel how unequal he was to encounter Mr. Charlotte’s observation, and hurried him away to his room.

changes.original: Elizabeth awoke the next morning to the same thoughts and meditations which had at length closed her eyes.
changes.transformed: Elliot awoke the next morning to the same thoughts and meditations which had at length closed his eyes.

changes.original: She could not yet recover from the surprise of what had happened: it was impossible to think of anything else; and, totally indisposed for employment, she resolved soon after breakfast to indulge herself in air and exercise.
changes.transformed: He could not yet recover from the surprise of what had happened: it was impossible to think of anything else; and, totally indisposed for employment, he resolved soon after breakfast to indulge himself in air and exercise.

changes.original: She was proceeding directly to her favourite walk, when the recollection of Mr. Darcy’s sometimes coming there stopped her, and instead of entering the park, she turned up the lane which led her farther from the turnpike road.
changes.transformed: He was proceeding directly to his favourite walk, when the recollection of Mr. Darcy’s sometimes coming there stopped him, and instead of entering the park, he turned up the lane which led him farther from the turnpike road.

changes.original: The park paling was still the boundary on one side, and she soon passed one of the gates into the ground.
changes.transformed: The park paling was still the boundary on one side, and he soon passed one of the gates into the ground.

changes.original: After walking two or three times along that part of the lane, she was tempted, by the pleasantness of the morning, to stop at the gates and look into the park.
changes.transformed: After walking two or three times along that part of the lane, he was tempted, by the pleasantness of the morning, to stop at the gates and look into the park.

changes.original: The five weeks which she had now passed in Kent had made a great difference in the country, and every day was adding to the verdure of the early trees.
changes.transformed: The five weeks which he had now passed in Kent had made a great difference in the country, and every day was adding to the verdure of the early trees.

changes.original: She was on the point of continuing her walk, when she caught a glimpse of a gentleman within the sort of grove which edged the park: he was moving that way; and fearful of its being Mr. Darcy, she was directly retreating.
changes.transformed: He was on the point of continuing his walk, when he caught a glimpse of a gentleman within the sort of grove which edged the park: he was moving that way; and fearful of its being Mr. Darcy, he was directly retreating.

changes.original: But the person who advanced was now near enough to see her, and stepping forward with eagerness, pronounced her name.
changes.transformed: But the person who advanced was now near enough to see him, and stepping forward with eagerness, pronounced his name.

changes.original: She had turned away; but on hearing herself called, though in a voice which proved it to be Mr. Darcy, she moved again towards the gate.
changes.transformed: He had turned away; but on hearing himself called, though in a voice which proved it to be Mr. Darcy, he moved again towards the gate.

changes.original: He had by that time reached it also; and, holding out a letter, which she instinctively took, said, with a look of haughty composure, “I have been walking in the grove some time, in the hope of meeting you.
changes.transformed: He had by that time reached it also; and, holding out a letter, which he instinctively took, said, with a look of haughty composure, “I have been walking in the grove some time, in the hope of meeting you.

changes.original: With no expectation of pleasure, but with the strongest curiosity, Elizabeth opened the letter, and to her still increasing wonder, perceived an envelope containing two sheets of letter paper, written quite through, in a very close hand.
changes.transformed: With no expectation of pleasure, but with the strongest curiosity, Elliot opened the letter, and to his still increasing wonder, perceived an envelope containing two sheets of letter paper, written quite through, in a very close hand.

changes.original: Pursuing her way along the lane, she then began it.
changes.transformed: Pursuing his way along the lane, he then began it.

changes.original: “Be not alarmed, madam, on receiving this letter, by the apprehension of its containing any repetition of those sentiments, or renewal of those offers, which were last night so disgusting to you.
changes.transformed: “Be not alarmed, sir, on receiving this letter, by the apprehension of its containing any repetition of those sentiments, or renewal of those offers, which were last night so disgusting to you.

changes.original: The first mentioned was, that, regardless of the sentiments of either, I had detached Mr. Bingley from your sister,--and the other, that I had, in defiance of various claims, in defiance of honour and humanity, ruined the immediate prosperity and blasted the prospects of Mr. Wickham.
changes.transformed: The first mentioned was, that, regardless of the sentiments of either, I had detached Mr. Bingley from your brother,--and the other, that I had, in defiance of various claims, in defiance of honour and humanity, ruined the immediate prosperity and blasted the prospects of Mr. Wickham.

changes.original: I had not been long in Hertfordshire before I saw, in common with others, that Bingley preferred your elder sister to any other young woman in the country.
changes.transformed: I had not been long in Hertfordshire before I saw, in common with others, that Bingley preferred your elder brother to any other young man in the country.

changes.original: At that ball, while I had the honour of dancing with you, I was first made acquainted, by Sir William Lucas’s accidental information, that Bingley’s attentions to your sister had given rise to a general expectation of their marriage.
changes.transformed: At that ball, while I had the honour of dancing with you, I was first made acquainted, by Sir William Lucas’s accidental information, that Bingley’s attentions to your brother had given rise to a general expectation of their marriage.

changes.original: From that moment I observed my friend’s behaviour attentively; and I could then perceive that his partiality for Miss Bennet was beyond what I had ever witnessed in him.
changes.transformed: From that moment I observed my friend’s behaviour attentively; and I could then perceive that his partiality for Mr. Bennet was beyond what I had ever witnessed in him.

changes.original: Your sister I also watched.
changes.transformed: Your brother I also watched.

changes.original: Her look and manners were open, cheerful, and engaging as ever, but without any symptom of peculiar regard; and I remained convinced, from the evening’s scrutiny, that though she received his attentions with pleasure, she did not invite them by any participation of sentiment.
changes.transformed: His look and manners were open, cheerful, and engaging as ever, but without any symptom of peculiar regard; and I remained convinced, from the evening’s scrutiny, that though he received his attentions with pleasure, he did not invite them by any participation of sentiment.

changes.original: Your superior knowledge of your sister must make the latter probable.
changes.transformed: Your superior knowledge of your brother must make the latter probable.

changes.original: If it be so, if I have been misled by such error to inflict pain on her, your resentment has not been unreasonable.
changes.transformed: If it be so, if I have been misled by such error to inflict pain on him, your resentment has not been unreasonable.

changes.original: But I shall not scruple to assert, that the serenity of your sister’s countenance and air was such as might have given the most acute observer a conviction that, however amiable her temper, her heart was not likely to be easily touched.
changes.transformed: But I shall not scruple to assert, that the serenity of your brother’s countenance and air was such as might have given the most acute observer a conviction that, however amiable his temper, his heart was not likely to be easily touched.

changes.original: That I was desirous of believing her indifferent is certain; but I will venture to say that my investigations and decisions are not usually influenced by my hopes or fears.
changes.transformed: That I was desirous of believing him indifferent is certain; but I will venture to say that my investigations and decisions are not usually influenced by my hopes or fears.

changes.original: I did not believe her to be indifferent because I wished it; I believed it on impartial conviction, as truly as I wished it in reason.
changes.transformed: I did not believe him to be indifferent because I wished it; I believed it on impartial conviction, as truly as I wished it in reason.

changes.original: The situation of your mother’s family, though objectionable, was nothing in comparison of that total want of propriety so frequently, so almost uniformly betrayed by herself, by your three younger sisters, and occasionally even by your father:--pardon me,--it pains me to offend you.
changes.transformed: The situation of your father’s family, though objectionable, was nothing in comparison of that total want of propriety so frequently, so almost uniformly betrayed by himself, by your three younger brothers, and occasionally even by your father:--pardon me,--it pains me to offend you.

changes.original: But amidst your concern for the defects of your nearest relations, and your displeasure at this representation of them, let it give you consolation to consider that to have conducted yourselves so as to avoid any share of the like censure is praise no less generally bestowed on you and your eldest sister than it is honourable to the sense and disposition of both.
changes.transformed: But amidst your concern for the defects of your nearest relations, and your displeasure at this representation of them, let it give you consolation to consider that to have conducted yourselves so as to avoid any share of the like censure is praise no less generally bestowed on you and your eldest brother than it is honourable to the sense and disposition of both.

changes.original: His sisters’ uneasiness had been equally excited with my own: our coincidence of feeling was soon discovered; and, alike sensible that no time was to be lost in detaching their brother, we shortly resolved on joining him directly in London.
changes.transformed: His brothers’ uneasiness had been equally excited with my own: our coincidence of feeling was soon discovered; and, alike sensible that no time was to be lost in detaching their brother, we shortly resolved on joining him directly in London.

changes.original: But however this remonstrance might have staggered or delayed his determination, I do not suppose that it would ultimately have prevented the marriage, had it not been seconded by the assurance, which I hesitated not in giving, of your sister’s indifference.
changes.transformed: But however this remonstrance might have staggered or delayed his determination, I do not suppose that it would ultimately have prevented the marriage, had it not been seconded by the assurance, which I hesitated not in giving, of your brother’s indifference.

changes.original: He had before believed her to return his affection with sincere, if not with equal, regard.
changes.transformed: He had before believed him to return his affection with sincere, if not with equal, regard.

changes.original: There is but one part of my conduct, in the whole affair, on which I do not reflect with satisfaction; it is that I condescended to adopt the measures of art so far as to conceal from him your sister’s being in town.
changes.transformed: There is but one part of my conduct, in the whole affair, on which I do not reflect with satisfaction; it is that I condescended to adopt the measures of art so far as to conceal from him your brother’s being in town.

changes.original: I knew it myself, as it was known to Miss Bingley; but her brother is even yet ignorant of it.
changes.transformed: I knew it myself, as it was known to Mr. Bingley; but his brother is even yet ignorant of it.

changes.original: That they might have met without ill consequence is, perhaps, probable; but his regard did not appear to me enough extinguished for him to see her without some danger.
changes.transformed: That they might have met without ill consequence is, perhaps, probable; but his regard did not appear to me enough extinguished for him to see him without some danger.

changes.original: If I have wounded your sister’s feelings, it was unknowingly done; and though the motives which governed me may to you very naturally appear insufficient, I have not yet learnt to condemn them.--With respect to that other, more weighty accusation, of having injured Mr. Wickham, I can only refute it by laying before you the whole of his connection with my family.
changes.transformed: If I have wounded your brother’s feelings, it was unknowingly done; and though the motives which governed me may to you very naturally appear insufficient, I have not yet learnt to condemn them.--With respect to that other, more weighty accusation, of having injured Mr. Wickham, I can only refute it by laying before you the whole of his connection with my family.

changes.original: My father supported him at school, and afterwards at Cambridge; most important assistance, as his own father, always poor from the extravagance of his wife, would have been unable to give him a gentleman’s education.
changes.transformed: My father supported him at school, and afterwards at Cambridge; most important assistance, as his own father, always poor from the extravagance of his husband, would have been unable to give him a gentleman’s education.

changes.original: My sister, who is more than ten years my junior, was left to the guardianship of my mother’s nephew, Colonel Fitzwilliam, and myself.
changes.transformed: My brother, who is more than ten years my junior, was left to the guardianship of my father’s nephew, Colonel Fitzwilliam, and myself.

changes.original: About a year ago, she was taken from school, and an establishment formed for her in London; and last summer she went with the lady who presided over it to Ramsgate; and thither also went Mr. Wickham, undoubtedly by design; for there proved to have been a prior acquaintance between him and Mrs. Younge, in whose character we were most unhappily deceived; and by her connivance and aid he so far recommended himself to Georgiana, whose affectionate heart retained a strong impression of his kindness to her as a child, that she was persuaded to believe herself in love and to consent to an elopement.
changes.transformed: About a year ago, he was taken from school, and an establishment formed for him in London; and last summer he went with the gentleman who presided over it to Ramsgate; and thither also went Mr. Wickham, undoubtedly by design; for there proved to have been a prior acquaintance between him and Mr. Younge, in whose character we were most unhappily deceived; and by his connivance and aid he so far recommended himself to George, whose affectionate heart retained a strong impression of his kindness to him as a child, that he was persuaded to believe himself in love and to consent to an elopement.

changes.original: She was then but fifteen, which must be her excuse; and after stating her imprudence, I am happy to add, that I owed the knowledge of it to herself.
changes.transformed: He was then but fifteen, which must be his excuse; and after stating his imprudence, I am happy to add, that I owed the knowledge of it to himself.

changes.original: I joined them unexpectedly a day or two before the intended elopement; and then Georgiana, unable to support the idea of grieving and offending a brother whom she almost looked up to as a father, acknowledged the whole to me.
changes.transformed: I joined them unexpectedly a day or two before the intended elopement; and then George, unable to support the idea of grieving and offending a brother whom he almost looked up to as a father, acknowledged the whole to me.

changes.original: Regard for my sister’s credit and feelings prevented any public exposure; but I wrote to Mr. Wickham, who left the place immediately, and Mrs. Younge was of course removed from her charge.
changes.transformed: Regard for my brother’s credit and feelings prevented any public exposure; but I wrote to Mr. Wickham, who left the place immediately, and Mr. Younge was of course removed from his charge.

changes.original: Mr. Wickham’s chief object was unquestionably my sister’s fortune, which is thirty thousand pounds; but I cannot help supposing that the hope of revenging himself on me was a strong inducement.
changes.transformed: Mr. Wickham’s chief object was unquestionably my brother’s fortune, which is thirty thousand pounds; but I cannot help supposing that the hope of revenging himself on me was a strong inducement.

changes.original: This, madam, is a faithful narrative of every event in which we have been concerned together; and if you do not absolutely reject it as false, you will, I hope, acquit me henceforth of cruelty towards Mr. Wickham.
changes.transformed: This, sir, is a faithful narrative of every event in which we have been concerned together; and if you do not absolutely reject it as false, you will, I hope, acquit me henceforth of cruelty towards Mr. Wickham.

changes.original: Elizabeth, when Mr. Darcy gave her the letter, did not expect it to contain a renewal of his offers, she had formed no expectation at all of its contents.
changes.transformed: Elliot, when Mr. Darcy gave him the letter, did not expect it to contain a renewal of his offers, he had formed no expectation at all of its contents.

changes.original: But such as they were, it may be well supposed how eagerly she went through them, and what a contrariety of emotion they excited.
changes.transformed: But such as they were, it may be well supposed how eagerly he went through them, and what a contrariety of emotion they excited.

changes.original: Her feelings as she read were scarcely to be defined.
changes.transformed: His feelings as he read were scarcely to be defined.

changes.original: With amazement did she first understand that he believed any apology to be in his power; and steadfastly was she persuaded, that he could have no explanation to give, which a just sense of shame would not conceal.
changes.transformed: With amazement did he first understand that he believed any apology to be in his power; and steadfastly was he persuaded, that he could have no explanation to give, which a just sense of shame would not conceal.

changes.original: With a strong prejudice against everything he might say, she began his account of what had happened at Netherfield.
changes.transformed: With a strong prejudice against everything he might say, he began his account of what had happened at Netherfield.

changes.original: She read with an eagerness which hardly left her power of comprehension; and from impatience of knowing what the next sentence might bring, was incapable of attending to the sense of the one before her eyes.
changes.transformed: He read with an eagerness which hardly left him power of comprehension; and from impatience of knowing what the next sentence might bring, was incapable of attending to the sense of the one before his eyes.

changes.original: His belief of her sister’s insensibility she instantly resolved to be false; and his account of the real, the worst objections to the match, made her too angry to have any wish of doing him justice.
changes.transformed: His belief of his brother’s insensibility he instantly resolved to be false; and his account of the real, the worst objections to the match, made him too angry to have any wish of doing him justice.

changes.original: He expressed no regret for what he had done which satisfied her; his style was not penitent, but haughty.
changes.transformed: He expressed no regret for what he had done which satisfied him; his style was not penitent, but haughty.

changes.original: But when this subject was succeeded by his account of Mr. Wickham--when she read, with somewhat clearer attention, a relation of events which, if true, must overthrow every cherished opinion of his worth, and which bore so alarming an affinity to his own history of himself--her feelings were yet more acutely painful and more difficult of definition.
changes.transformed: But when this subject was succeeded by his account of Mr. Wickham--when he read, with somewhat clearer attention, a relation of events which, if true, must overthrow every cherished opinion of his worth, and which bore so alarming an affinity to his own history of himself--his feelings were yet more acutely painful and more difficult of definition.

changes.original: Astonishment, apprehension, and even horror, oppressed her.
changes.transformed: Astonishment, apprehension, and even horror, oppressed him.

changes.original: She wished to discredit it entirely, repeatedly exclaiming, “This must be false!
changes.transformed: He wished to discredit it entirely, repeatedly exclaiming, “This must be false!

changes.original: This must be the grossest falsehood!”--and when she had gone through the whole letter, though scarcely knowing anything of the last page or two, put it hastily away, protesting that she would not regard it, that she would never look in it again.
changes.transformed: This must be the grossest falsehood!”--and when he had gone through the whole letter, though scarcely knowing anything of the last page or two, put it hastily away, protesting that he would not regard it, that he would never look in it again.

changes.original: In this perturbed state of mind, with thoughts that could rest on nothing, she walked on; but it would not do: in half a minute the letter was unfolded again; and collecting herself as well as she could, she again began the mortifying perusal of all that related to Wickham, and commanded herself so far as to examine the meaning of every sentence.
changes.transformed: In this perturbed state of mind, with thoughts that could rest on nothing, he walked on; but it would not do: in half a minute the letter was unfolded again; and collecting himself as well as he could, he again began the mortifying perusal of all that related to Wickham, and commanded himself so far as to examine the meaning of every sentence.

changes.original: The account of his connection with the Pemberley family was exactly what he had related himself; and the kindness of the late Mr. Darcy, though she had not before known its extent, agreed equally well with his own words.
changes.transformed: The account of his connection with the Pemberley family was exactly what he had related himself; and the kindness of the late Mr. Darcy, though he had not before known its extent, agreed equally well with his own words.

changes.original: So far each recital confirmed the other; but when she came to the will, the difference was great.
changes.transformed: So far each recital confirmed the other; but when he came to the will, the difference was great.

changes.original: What Wickham had said of the living was fresh in her memory; and as she recalled his very words, it was impossible not to feel that there was gross duplicity on one side or the other, and, for a few moments, she flattered herself that her wishes did not err.
changes.transformed: What Wickham had said of the living was fresh in his memory; and as he recalled his very words, it was impossible not to feel that there was gross duplicity on one side or the other, and, for a few moments, he flattered himself that his wishes did not err.

changes.original: But when she read and re-read, with the closest attention, the particulars immediately following of Wickham’s resigning all pretensions to the living, of his receiving in lieu so considerable a sum as three thousand pounds, again was she forced to hesitate.
changes.transformed: But when he read and re-read, with the closest attention, the particulars immediately following of Wickham’s resigning all pretensions to the living, of his receiving in lieu so considerable a sum as three thousand pounds, again was he forced to hesitate.

changes.original: She put down the letter, weighed every circumstance with what she meant to be impartiality--deliberated on the probability of each statement--but with little success.
changes.transformed: He put down the letter, weighed every circumstance with what he meant to be impartiality--deliberated on the probability of each statement--but with little success.

changes.original: Again she read on.
changes.transformed: Again he read on.

changes.original: But every line proved more clearly that the affair, which she had believed it impossible that any contrivance could so represent as to render Mr. Darcy’s conduct in it less than infamous, was capable of a turn which must make him entirely blameless throughout the whole.
changes.transformed: But every line proved more clearly that the affair, which he had believed it impossible that any contrivance could so represent as to render Mr. Darcy’s conduct in it less than infamous, was capable of a turn which must make him entirely blameless throughout the whole.

changes.original: The extravagance and general profligacy which he scrupled not to lay to Mr. Wickham’s charge exceedingly shocked her; the more so, as she could bring no proof of its injustice.
changes.transformed: The extravagance and general profligacy which he scrupled not to lay to Mr. Wickham’s charge exceedingly shocked him; the more so, as he could bring no proof of its injustice.

changes.original: She had never heard of him before his entrance into the ----shire militia, in which he had engaged at the persuasion of the young man, who, on meeting him accidentally in town, had there renewed a slight acquaintance.
changes.transformed: He had never heard of him before his entrance into the ----shire militia, in which he had engaged at the persuasion of the young man, who, on meeting him accidentally in town, had there renewed a slight acquaintance.

changes.original: As to his real character, had information been in her power, she had never felt a wish of inquiring.
changes.transformed: As to his real character, had information been in his power, he had never felt a wish of inquiring.

changes.original: She tried to recollect some instance of goodness, some distinguished trait of integrity or benevolence, that might rescue him from the attacks of Mr. Darcy; or at least, by the predominance of virtue, atone for those casual errors, under which she would endeavour to class what Mr. Darcy had described as the idleness and vice of many years’ continuance.
changes.transformed: He tried to recollect some instance of goodness, some distinguished trait of integrity or benevolence, that might rescue him from the attacks of Mr. Darcy; or at least, by the predominance of virtue, atone for those casual errors, under which he would endeavour to class what Mr. Darcy had described as the idleness and vice of many years’ continuance.

changes.original: But no such recollection befriended her.
changes.transformed: But no such recollection befriended him.

changes.original: She could see him instantly before her, in every charm of air and address, but she could remember no more substantial good than the general approbation of the neighbourhood, and the regard which his social powers had gained him in the mess.
changes.transformed: He could see him instantly before him, in every charm of air and address, but he could remember no more substantial good than the general approbation of the neighbourhood, and the regard which his social powers had gained him in the mess.

changes.original: After pausing on this point a considerable while, she once more continued to read.
changes.transformed: After pausing on this point a considerable while, he once more continued to read.

changes.original: But, alas! the story which followed, of his designs on Miss Darcy, received some confirmation from what had passed between Colonel Fitzwilliam and herself only the morning before; and at last she was referred for the truth of every particular to Colonel Fitzwilliam himself--from whom she had previously received the information of his near concern in all his cousin’s affairs and whose character she had no reason to question.
changes.transformed: But, alas! the story which followed, of his designs on Mr. Darcy, received some confirmation from what had passed between Colonel Fitzwilliam and himself only the morning before; and at last he was referred for the truth of every particular to Colonel Fitzwilliam himself--from whom he had previously received the information of his near concern in all his cousin’s affairs and whose character he had no reason to question.

changes.original: At one time she had almost resolved on applying to him, but the idea was checked by the awkwardness of the application, and at length wholly banished by the conviction that Mr. Darcy would never have hazarded such a proposal, if he had not been well assured of his cousin’s corroboration.
changes.transformed: At one time he had almost resolved on applying to him, but the idea was checked by the awkwardness of the application, and at length wholly banished by the conviction that Mr. Darcy would never have hazarded such a proposal, if he had not been well assured of his cousin’s corroboration.

changes.original: She perfectly remembered everything that had passed in conversation between Wickham and herself in their first evening at Mr. Philips’s.
changes.transformed: He perfectly remembered everything that had passed in conversation between Wickham and himself in their first evening at Mr. Philips’s.

changes.original: Many of his expressions were still fresh in her memory.
changes.transformed: Many of his expressions were still fresh in his memory.

changes.original: She was _now_ struck with the impropriety of such communications to a stranger, and wondered it had escaped her before.
changes.transformed: He was _now_ struck with the impropriety of such communications to a stranger, and wondered it had escaped him before.

changes.original: She saw the indelicacy of putting himself forward as he had done, and the inconsistency of his professions with his conduct.
changes.transformed: He saw the indelicacy of putting himself forward as he had done, and the inconsistency of his professions with his conduct.

changes.original: She remembered that he had boasted of having no fear of seeing Mr. Darcy--that Mr. Darcy might leave the country, but that _he_ should stand his ground; yet he had avoided the Netherfield ball the very next week.
changes.transformed: He remembered that he had boasted of having no fear of seeing Mr. Darcy--that Mr. Darcy might leave the country, but that _he_ should stand his ground; yet he had avoided the Netherfield ball the very next week.

changes.original: She remembered, also, that till the Netherfield family had quitted the country, he had told his story to no one but herself; but that after their removal, it had been everywhere discussed; that he had then no reserves, no scruples in sinking Mr. Darcy’s character, though he had assured her that respect for the father would always prevent his exposing the son.
changes.transformed: He remembered, also, that till the Netherfield family had quitted the country, he had told his story to no one but himself; but that after their removal, it had been everywhere discussed; that he had then no reserves, no scruples in sinking Mr. Darcy’s character, though he had assured him that respect for the father would always prevent his exposing the son.

changes.original: His attentions to Miss King were now the consequence of views solely and hatefully mercenary; and the mediocrity of her fortune proved no longer the moderation of his wishes, but his eagerness to grasp at anything.
changes.transformed: His attentions to Mr. King were now the consequence of views solely and hatefully mercenary; and the mediocrity of his fortune proved no longer the moderation of his wishes, but his eagerness to grasp at anything.

changes.original: His behaviour to herself could now have had no tolerable motive: he had either been deceived with regard to her fortune, or had been gratifying his vanity by encouraging the preference which she believed she had most incautiously shown.
changes.transformed: His behaviour to himself could now have had no tolerable motive: he had either been deceived with regard to his fortune, or had been gratifying his vanity by encouraging the preference which he believed he had most incautiously shown.

changes.original: Every lingering struggle in his favour grew fainter and fainter; and in further justification of Mr. Darcy, she could not but allow that Mr. Bingley, when questioned by Jane, had long ago asserted his blamelessness in the affair;--that, proud and repulsive as were his manners, she had never, in the whole course of their acquaintance--an acquaintance which had latterly brought them much together, and given her a sort of intimacy with his ways--seen anything that betrayed him to be unprincipled or unjust--anything that spoke him of irreligious or immoral habits;--that among his own connections he was esteemed and valued;--that even Wickham had allowed him merit as a brother, and that she had often heard him speak so affectionately of his sister as to prove him capable of some amiable feeling;--that had his actions been what Wickham represented them, so gross a violation of everything right could hardly have been concealed from the world; and that friendship between a person capable of it and such an amiable man as Mr. Bingley was incomprehensible.
changes.transformed: Every lingering struggle in his favour grew fainter and fainter; and in further justification of Mr. Darcy, he could not but allow that Mr. Bingley, when questioned by John, had long ago asserted his blamelessness in the affair;--that, proud and repulsive as were his manners, he had never, in the whole course of their acquaintance--an acquaintance which had latterly brought them much together, and given him a sort of intimacy with his ways--seen anything that betrayed him to be unprincipled or unjust--anything that spoke him of irreligious or immoral habits;--that among his own connections he was esteemed and valued;--that even Wickham had allowed him merit as a brother, and that he had often heard him speak so affectionately of his brother as to prove him capable of some amiable feeling;--that had his actions been what Wickham represented them, so gross a violation of everything right could hardly have been concealed from the world; and that friendship between a person capable of it and such an amiable man as Mr. Bingley was incomprehensible.

changes.original: She grew absolutely ashamed of herself.
changes.transformed: He grew absolutely ashamed of himself.

changes.original: Of neither Darcy nor Wickham could she think, without feeling that she had been blind, partial, prejudiced, absurd.
changes.transformed: Of neither Darcy nor Wickham could he think, without feeling that he had been blind, partial, prejudiced, absurd.

changes.original: “How despicably have I acted!” she cried. “I, who have prided myself on my discernment!
changes.transformed: “How despicably have I acted!” he cried. “I, who have prided myself on my discernment!

changes.original: I, who have valued myself on my abilities! who have often disdained the generous candour of my sister, and gratified my vanity in useless or blameless distrust.
changes.transformed: I, who have valued myself on my abilities! who have often disdained the generous candour of my brother, and gratified my vanity in useless or blameless distrust.

changes.original: From herself to Jane, from Jane to Bingley, her thoughts were in a line which soon brought to her recollection that Mr. Darcy’s explanation _there_ had appeared very insufficient; and she read it again.
changes.transformed: From himself to John, from John to Bingley, his thoughts were in a line which soon brought to his recollection that Mr. Darcy’s explanation _there_ had appeared very insufficient; and he read it again.

changes.original: How could she deny that credit to his assertions, in one instance, which she had been obliged to give in the other?
changes.transformed: How could he deny that credit to his assertions, in one instance, which he had been obliged to give in the other?

changes.original: He declared himself to have been totally unsuspicious of her sister’s attachment; and she could not help remembering what Charlotte’s opinion had always been.
changes.transformed: He declared himself to have been totally unsuspicious of his brother’s attachment; and he could not help remembering what Charles’s opinion had always been.

changes.original: Neither could she deny the justice of his description of Jane.
changes.transformed: Neither could he deny the justice of his description of John.

changes.original: She felt that Jane’s feelings, though fervent, were little displayed, and that there was a constant complacency in her air and manner, not often united with great sensibility.
changes.transformed: He felt that John’s feelings, though fervent, were little displayed, and that there was a constant complacency in his air and manner, not often united with great sensibility.

changes.original: When she came to that part of the letter in which her family were mentioned, in tones of such mortifying, yet merited, reproach, her sense of shame was severe.
changes.transformed: When he came to that part of the letter in which his family were mentioned, in tones of such mortifying, yet merited, reproach, his sense of shame was severe.

changes.original: The justice of the charge struck her too forcibly for denial; and the circumstances to which he particularly alluded, as having passed at the Netherfield ball, and as confirming all his first disapprobation, could not have made a stronger impression on his mind than on hers.
changes.transformed: The justice of the charge struck him too forcibly for denial; and the circumstances to which he particularly alluded, as having passed at the Netherfield ball, and as confirming all his first disapprobation, could not have made a stronger impression on his mind than on his.

changes.original: The compliment to herself and her sister was not unfelt.
changes.transformed: The compliment to himself and his brother was not unfelt.

changes.original: It soothed, but it could not console her for the contempt which had been thus self-attracted by the rest of her family; and as she considered that Jane’s disappointment had, in fact, been the work of her nearest relations, and reflected how materially the credit of both must be hurt by such impropriety of conduct, she felt depressed beyond anything she had ever known before.
changes.transformed: It soothed, but it could not console him for the contempt which had been thus self-attracted by the rest of his family; and as he considered that John’s disappointment had, in fact, been the work of his nearest relations, and reflected how materially the credit of both must be hurt by such impropriety of conduct, he felt depressed beyond anything he had ever known before.

changes.original: After wandering along the lane for two hours, giving way to every variety of thought, reconsidering events, determining probabilities, and reconciling herself, as well as she could, to a change so sudden and so important, fatigue, and a recollection of her long absence, made her at length return home; and she entered the house with the wish of appearing cheerful as usual, and the resolution of repressing such reflections as must make her unfit for conversation.
changes.transformed: After wandering along the lane for two hours, giving way to every variety of thought, reconsidering events, determining probabilities, and reconciling himself, as well as he could, to a change so sudden and so important, fatigue, and a recollection of his long absence, made him at length return home; and he entered the house with the wish of appearing cheerful as usual, and the resolution of repressing such reflections as must make him unfit for conversation.

changes.original: She was immediately told, that the two gentlemen from Rosings had each called during her absence; Mr. Darcy, only for a few minutes, to take leave, but that Colonel Fitzwilliam had been sitting with them at least an hour, hoping for her return, and almost resolving to walk after her till she could be found.
changes.transformed: He was immediately told, that the two gentlemen from Rosings had each called during his absence; Mr. Darcy, only for a few minutes, to take leave, but that Colonel Fitzwilliam had been sitting with them at least an hour, hoping for his return, and almost resolving to walk after him till he could be found.

changes.original: Elizabeth could but just _affect_ concern in missing him; she really rejoiced at it.
changes.transformed: Elliot could but just _affect_ concern in missing him; he really rejoiced at it.

changes.original: She could think only of her letter.
changes.transformed: He could think only of his letter.

changes.original: To Rosings he then hastened to console Lady Catherine and her daughter; and on his return brought back, with great satisfaction, a message from her Ladyship, importing that she felt herself so dull as to make her very desirous of having them all to dine with her.
changes.transformed: To Rosings he then hastened to console Mr. Catherine and his son; and on his return brought back, with great satisfaction, a message from his Lordship, importing that he felt himself so dull as to make him very desirous of having them all to dine with him.

changes.original: Elizabeth could not see Lady Catherine without recollecting that, had she chosen it, she might by this time have been presented to her as her future niece; nor could she think, without a smile, of what her Ladyship’s indignation would have been. “What would she have said? how would she have behaved?” were the questions with which she amused herself.
changes.transformed: Elliot could not see Mr. Catherine without recollecting that, had he chosen it, he might by this time have been presented to him as his future nephew; nor could he think, without a smile, of what his Lordship’s indignation would have been. “What would he have said? how would he have behaved?” were the questions with which he amused himself.

changes.original: Their first subject was the diminution of the Rosings’ party. “I assure you, I feel it exceedingly,” said Lady Catherine; “I believe nobody feels the loss of friends so much as I do.
changes.transformed: Their first subject was the diminution of the Rosings’ party. “I assure you, I feel it exceedingly,” said Mr. Catherine; “I believe nobody feels the loss of friends so much as I do.

changes.original: Mr. Collins had a compliment and an allusion to throw in here, which were kindly smiled on by the mother and daughter.
changes.transformed: Mr. Collins had a compliment and an allusion to throw in here, which were kindly smiled on by the father and son.

changes.original: Lady Catherine observed, after dinner, that Miss Bennet seemed out of spirits; and immediately accounting for it herself, by supposing that she did not like to go home again so soon, she added,--
changes.transformed: Mr. Catherine observed, after dinner, that Mr. Bennet seemed out of spirits; and immediately accounting for it himself, by supposing that he did not like to go home again so soon, he added,--

changes.original: “But if that is the case, you must write to your mother to beg that you may stay a little longer.
changes.transformed: “But if that is the case, you must write to your father to beg that you may stay a little longer.

changes.original: Mrs. Collins will be very glad of your company, I am sure.”
changes.transformed: Mr. Collins will be very glad of your company, I am sure.”

changes.original: “I am much obliged to your Ladyship for your kind invitation,” replied Elizabeth; “but it is not in my power to accept it.
changes.transformed: “I am much obliged to your Lordship for your kind invitation,” replied Elliot; “but it is not in my power to accept it.

changes.original: I told Mrs. Collins so before you came.
changes.transformed: I told Mr. Collins so before you came.

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet could certainly spare you for another fortnight.”
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet could certainly spare you for another fortnight.”

changes.original: “Oh, your father, of course, may spare you, if your mother can.
changes.transformed: “Oh, your father, of course, may spare you, if your father can.

changes.original: Daughters are never of so much consequence to a father.
changes.transformed: Sons are never of so much consequence to a father.

changes.original: “You are all kindness, madam; but I believe we must abide by our original plan.”
changes.transformed: “You are all kindness, sir; but I believe we must abide by our original plan.”

changes.original: Lady Catherine seemed resigned. “Mrs. Collins, you must send a servant with them.
changes.transformed: Mr. Catherine seemed resigned. “Mr. Collins, you must send a servant with them.

changes.original: You know I always speak my mind, and I cannot bear the idea of two young women travelling post by themselves.
changes.transformed: You know I always speak my mind, and I cannot bear the idea of two young men travelling post by themselves.

changes.original: Young women should always be properly guarded and attended, according to their situation in life.
changes.transformed: Young men should always be properly guarded and attended, according to their situation in life.

changes.original: When my niece Georgiana went to Ramsgate last summer, I made a point of her having two men-servants go with her.
changes.transformed: When my nephew George went to Ramsgate last summer, I made a point of him having two men-servants go with him.

changes.original: Miss Darcy, the daughter of Mr. Darcy of Pemberley, and Lady Anne, could not have appeared with propriety in a different manner.
changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy, the son of Mr. Darcy of Pemberley, and Mr. Andrew, could not have appeared with propriety in a different manner.

changes.original: You must send John with the young ladies, Mrs. Collins.
changes.transformed: You must send John with the young gentlemen, Mr. Collins.

changes.original: Lady Catherine had many other questions to ask respecting their journey; and as she did not answer them all herself attention was necessary--which Elizabeth believed to be lucky for her; or, with a mind so occupied, she might have forgotten where she was.
changes.transformed: Mr. Charles had many other questions to ask respecting their journey; and as he did not answer them all himself attention was necessary--which Elliot believed to be lucky for him; or, with a mind so occupied, he might have forgotten where he was.

changes.original: Reflection must be reserved for solitary hours: whenever she was alone, she gave way to it as the greatest relief; and not a day went by without a solitary walk, in which she might indulge in all the delight of unpleasant recollections.
changes.transformed: Reflection must be reserved for solitary hours: whenever he was alone, he gave way to it as the greatest relief; and not a day went by without a solitary walk, in which he might indulge in all the delight of unpleasant recollections.

changes.original: Mr. Darcy’s letter she was in a fair way of soon knowing by heart.
changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy’s letter he was in a fair way of soon knowing by heart.

changes.original: She studied every sentence; and her feelings towards its writer were at times widely different.
changes.transformed: He studied every sentence; and his feelings towards its writer were at times widely different.

changes.original: When she remembered the style of his address, she was still full of indignation: but when she considered how unjustly she had condemned and upbraided him, her anger was turned against herself; and his disappointed feelings became the object of compassion.
changes.transformed: When he remembered the style of his address, he was still full of indignation: but when he considered how unjustly he had condemned and upbraided him, his anger was turned against himself; and his disappointed feelings became the object of compassion.

changes.original: His attachment excited gratitude, his general character respect: but she could not approve him; nor could she for a moment repent her refusal, or feel the slightest inclination ever to see him again.
changes.transformed: His attachment excited gratitude, his general character respect: but he could not approve him; nor could he for a moment repent his refusal, or feel the slightest inclination ever to see him again.

changes.original: In her own past behaviour, there was a constant source of vexation and regret: and in the unhappy defects of her family, a subject of yet heavier chagrin.
changes.transformed: In his own past behaviour, there was a constant source of vexation and regret: and in the unhappy defects of his family, a subject of yet heavier chagrin.

changes.original: Her father, contented with laughing at them, would never exert himself to restrain the wild giddiness of his youngest daughters; and her mother, with manners so far from right herself, was entirely insensible of the evil.
changes.transformed: His father, contented with laughing at them, would never exert himself to restrain the wild giddiness of his youngest sons; and his father, with manners so far from right himself, was entirely insensible of the evil.

changes.original: Elizabeth had frequently united with Jane in an endeavour to check the imprudence of Catherine and Lydia; but while they were supported by their mother’s indulgence, what chance could there be of improvement?
changes.transformed: Elliot had frequently united with John in an endeavour to check the imprudence of Christopher and Leonard; but while they were supported by their father’s indulgence, what chance could there be of improvement?
