changes.original: Catherine, weak-spirited, irritable, and completely under Lydia’s guidance, had been always affronted by their advice; and Lydia, self-willed and careless, would scarcely give them a hearing.
changes.transformed: Christopher, weak-spirited, irritable, and completely under Leonard’s guidance, had been always affronted by their advice; and Leonard, self-willed and careless, would scarcely give them a hearing.

changes.original: Anxiety on Jane’s behalf was another prevailing concern; and Mr. Darcy’s explanation, by restoring Bingley to all her former good opinion, heightened the sense of what Jane had lost.
changes.transformed: Anxiety on John’s behalf was another prevailing concern; and Mr. Darcy’s explanation, by restoring Bingley to all his former good opinion, heightened the sense of what John had lost.

changes.original: How grievous then was the thought that, of a situation so desirable in every respect, so replete with advantage, so promising for happiness, Jane had been deprived, by the folly and indecorum of her own family!
changes.transformed: How grievous then was the thought that, of a situation so desirable in every respect, so replete with advantage, so promising for happiness, John had been deprived, by the folly and indecorum of his own family!

changes.original: When to these recollections was added the development of Wickham’s character, it may be easily believed that the happy spirits which had seldom been depressed before were now so much affected as to make it almost impossible for her to appear tolerably cheerful.
changes.transformed: When to these recollections was added the development of Wickham’s character, it may be easily believed that the happy spirits which had seldom been depressed before were now so much affected as to make it almost impossible for him to appear tolerably cheerful.

changes.original: Their engagements at Rosings were as frequent during the last week of her stay as they had been at first.
changes.transformed: Their engagements at Rosings were as frequent during the last week of his stay as they had been at first.

changes.original: The very last evening was spent there; and her Ladyship again inquired minutely into the particulars of their journey, gave them directions as to the best method of packing, and was so urgent on the necessity of placing gowns in the only right way, that Maria thought herself obliged, on her return, to undo all the work of the morning, and pack her trunk afresh.
changes.transformed: The very last evening was spent there; and Mr. Catherine again inquired minutely into the particulars of their journey, gave them directions as to the best method of packing, and was so urgent on the necessity of placing suits in the only right way, that Martin thought himself obliged, on his return, to undo all the work of the morning, and pack his trunk afresh.

changes.original: When they parted, Lady Catherine, with great condescension, wished them a good journey, and invited them to come to Hunsford again next year; and Miss de Bourgh exerted herself so far as to courtesy and hold out her hand to both.
changes.transformed: When they parted, Mr. Catherine, with great condescension, wished them a good journey, and invited them to come to Hunsford again next year; and Mr. de Bourgh exerted himself so far as to courtesy and hold out his hand to both.

changes.original: On Saturday morning Elizabeth and Mr. Collins met for breakfast a few minutes before the others appeared; and he took the opportunity of paying the parting civilities which he deemed indispensably necessary.
changes.transformed: On Saturday morning Elliot and Mr. Collins met for breakfast a few minutes before the others appeared; and he took the opportunity of paying the parting civilities which he deemed indispensably necessary.

changes.original: “I know not, Miss Elizabeth,” said he, “whether Mrs. Collins has yet expressed her sense of your kindness in coming to us; but I am very certain you will not leave the house without receiving her thanks for it.
changes.transformed: “I know not, Mr. Elliot,” said he, “whether Mr. Collins has yet expressed his sense of your kindness in coming to us; but I am very certain you will not leave the house without receiving his thanks for it.

changes.original: Our plain manner of living, our small rooms, and few domestics, and the little we see of the world, must make Hunsford extremely dull to a young lady like yourself; but I hope you will believe us grateful for the condescension, and that we have done everything in our power to prevent you spending your time unpleasantly.”
changes.transformed: Our plain manner of living, our small rooms, and few domestics, and the little we see of the world, must make Hunsford extremely dull to a young man like yourself; but I hope you will believe us grateful for the condescension, and that we have done everything in our power to prevent you spending your time unpleasantly.”

changes.original: Elizabeth was eager with her thanks and assurances of happiness.
changes.transformed: Elliot was eager with his thanks and assurances of happiness.

changes.original: She had spent six weeks with great enjoyment; and the pleasure of being with Charlotte, and the kind attention she had received, must make _her_ feel the obliged.
changes.transformed: He had spent six weeks with great enjoyment; and the pleasure of being with Charles, and the kind attention he had received, must make him feel the obliged.

changes.original: Our situation with regard to Lady Catherine’s family is, indeed, the sort of extraordinary advantage and blessing which few can boast.
changes.transformed: Our situation with regard to Mr. Catherine’s family is, indeed, the sort of extraordinary advantage and blessing which few can boast.

changes.original: Words were insufficient for the elevation of his feelings; and he was obliged to walk about the room, while Elizabeth tried to unite civility and truth in a few short sentences.
changes.transformed: Words were insufficient for the elevation of his feelings; and he was obliged to walk about the room, while Elliot tried to unite civility and truth in a few short sentences.

changes.original: Lady Catherine’s great attentions to Mrs. Collins you have been a daily witness of; and altogether I trust it does not appear that your friend has drawn an unfortunate--but on this point it will be as well to be silent.
changes.transformed: Mr. Catherine’s great attentions to Mr. Collins you have been a daily witness of; and altogether I trust it does not appear that your friend has drawn an unfortunate--but on this point it will be as well to be silent.

changes.original: Only let me assure you, my dear Miss Elizabeth, that I can from my heart most cordially wish you equal felicity in marriage.
changes.transformed: Only let me assure you, my dear Mr. Elliot, that I can from my heart most cordially wish you equal felicity in marriage.

changes.original: My dear Charlotte and I have but one mind and one way of thinking.
changes.transformed: My dear Charles and I have but one mind and one way of thinking.

changes.original: Elizabeth could safely say that it was a great happiness where that was the case, and with equal sincerity could add, that she firmly believed and rejoiced in his domestic comforts.
changes.transformed: Elliot could safely say that it was a great happiness where that was the case, and with equal sincerity could add, that he firmly believed and rejoiced in his domestic comforts.

changes.original: She was not sorry, however, to have the recital of them interrupted by the entrance of the lady from whom they sprang.
changes.transformed: He was not sorry, however, to have the recital of them interrupted by the entrance of the gentleman from whom they sprang.

changes.original: Poor Charlotte! it was melancholy to leave her to such society!
changes.transformed: Poor Charles! it was melancholy to leave him to such society!

changes.original: But she had chosen it with her eyes open; and though evidently regretting that her visitors were to go, she did not seem to ask for compassion.
changes.transformed: But he had chosen it with his eyes open; and though evidently regretting that his visitors were to go, he did not seem to ask for compassion.

changes.original: Her home and her housekeeping, her parish and her poultry, and all their dependent concerns, had not yet lost their charms.
changes.transformed: His home and his housekeeping, his parish and his poultry, and all their dependent concerns, had not yet lost their charms.

changes.original: After an affectionate parting between the friends, Elizabeth was attended to the carriage by Mr. Collins; and as they walked down the garden, he was commissioning her with his best respects to all her family, not forgetting his thanks for the kindness he had received at Longbourn in the winter, and his compliments to Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner, though unknown.
changes.transformed: After an affectionate parting between the friends, Elliot was attended to the carriage by Mr. Collins; and as they walked down the garden, he was commissioning him with his best respects to all his family, not forgetting his thanks for the kindness he had received at Longbourn in the winter, and his compliments to Mr. and Mr. Gardiner, though unknown.

changes.original: He then handed her in, Maria followed, and the door was on the point of being closed, when he suddenly reminded them, with some consternation, that they had hitherto forgotten to leave any message for the ladies of Rosings.
changes.transformed: He then handed him in, Martin followed, and the door was on the point of being closed, when he suddenly reminded them, with some consternation, that they had hitherto forgotten to leave any message for the gentlemen of Rosings.

changes.original: Elizabeth made no objection: the door was then allowed to be shut, and the carriage drove off.
changes.transformed: Elliot made no objection: the door was then allowed to be shut, and the carriage drove off.

changes.original: “Good gracious!” cried Maria, after a few minutes’ silence, “it seems but a day or two since we first came! and yet how many things have happened!”
changes.transformed: “Good gracious!” cried Martin, after a few minutes’ silence, “it seems but a day or two since we first came! and yet how many things have happened!”

changes.original: “A great many indeed,” said her companion, with a sigh.
changes.transformed: “A great many indeed,” said his companion, with a sigh.

changes.original: Elizabeth privately added, “And how much I shall have to conceal!”
changes.transformed: Elliot privately added, “And how much I shall have to conceal!”

changes.original: Jane looked well, and Elizabeth had little opportunity of studying her spirits, amidst the various engagements which the kindness of her aunt had reserved for them.
changes.transformed: John looked well, and Elliot had little opportunity of studying his spirits, amidst the various engagements which the kindness of his uncle had reserved for them.

changes.original: But Jane was to go home with her, and at Longbourn there would be leisure enough for observation.
changes.transformed: But John was to go home with him, and at Longbourn there would be leisure enough for observation.

changes.original: It was not without an effort, meanwhile, that she could wait even for Longbourn, before she told her sister of Mr. Darcy’s proposals.
changes.transformed: It was not without an effort, meanwhile, that he could wait even for Longbourn, before he told his brother of Mr. Darcy’s proposals.

changes.original: To know that she had the power of revealing what would so exceedingly astonish Jane, and must, at the same time, so highly gratify whatever of her own vanity she had not yet been able to reason away, was such a temptation to openness as nothing could have conquered, but the state of indecision in which she remained as to the extent of what she should communicate, and her fear, if she once entered on the subject, of being hurried into repeating something of Bingley, which might only grieve her sister further.
changes.transformed: To know that he had the power of revealing what would so exceedingly astonish John, and must, at the same time, so highly gratify whatever of his own vanity he had not yet been able to reason away, was such a temptation to openness as nothing could have conquered, but the state of indecision in which he remained as to the extent of what he should communicate, and his fear, if he once entered on the subject, of being hurried into repeating something of Bingley, which might only grieve his brother further.

changes.original: It was the second week in May, in which the three young ladies set out together from Gracechurch Street for the town of ----, in Hertfordshire; and, as they drew near the appointed inn where Mr. Bennet’s carriage was to meet them, they quickly perceived, in token of the coachman’s punctuality, both Kitty and Lydia looking out of a dining-room upstairs.
changes.transformed: It was the second week in May, in which the three young gentlemen set out together from Gracechurch Street for the town of ----, in Hertfordshire; and, as they drew near the appointed inn where Mr. Bennet’s carriage was to meet them, they quickly perceived, in token of the coachman’s punctuality, both Mr. Kit and Mr. Lyndon looking out of a dining-room upstairs.

changes.original: These two girls had been above an hour in the place, happily employed in visiting an opposite milliner, watching the sentinel on guard, and dressing a salad and cucumber.
changes.transformed: These two young men had been above an hour in the place, happily employed in visiting an opposite tailor, watching the sentinel on guard, and dressing a salad and cucumber.

changes.original: After welcoming their sisters, they triumphantly displayed a table set out with such cold meat as an inn larder usually affords, exclaiming, “Is not this nice? is not this an agreeable surprise?”
changes.transformed: After welcoming their brothers, they triumphantly displayed a table set out with such cold meat as an inn larder usually affords, exclaiming, “Is not this nice? is not this an agreeable surprise?”

changes.original: “And we mean to treat you all,” added Lydia; “but you must lend us the money, for we have just spent ours at the shop out there.” Then showing her purchases,--“Look here, I have bought this bonnet.
changes.transformed: “And we mean to treat you all,” added Mr. Lyndon; “but you must lend us the money, for we have just spent ours at the shop out there.” Then showing his purchases,--“Look here, I have bought this hat.

changes.original: I do not think it is very pretty; but I thought I might as well buy it as not.
changes.transformed: I do not think it is very handsome; but I thought I might as well buy it as not.

changes.original: And when her sisters abused it as ugly, she added, with perfect unconcern, “Oh, but there were two or three much uglier in the shop; and when I have bought some prettier-coloured satin to trim it with fresh, I think it will be very tolerable.
changes.transformed: And when his brothers abused it as ugly, he added, with perfect unconcern, “Oh, but there were two or three much uglier in the shop; and when I have bought some finer-coloured fabric to trim it with fresh, I think it will be very tolerable.

changes.original: “Are they, indeed?” cried Elizabeth, with the greatest satisfaction.
changes.transformed: “Are they, indeed?” cried Mr. Elliot, with the greatest satisfaction.

changes.original: Mamma would like to go, too, of all things!
changes.transformed: Papa would like to go, too, of all things!

changes.original: “Yes,” thought Elizabeth; “_that_ would be a delightful scheme, indeed, and completely do for us at once.
changes.transformed: “Yes,” thought Mr. Elliot; “_that_ would be a delightful scheme, indeed, and completely do for us at once.

changes.original: “Now I have got some news for you,” said Lydia, as they sat down to table. “What do you think?
changes.transformed: “Now I have got some news for you,” said Mr. Lyndon, as they sat down to table. “What do you think?

changes.original: Jane and Elizabeth looked at each other, and the waiter was told that he need not stay.

changes.original: Well, but now for my news: it is about dear Wickham; too good for the waiter, is not it?
changes.transformed: Well, but now for my news: it is about dear Mr. Wickham; too good for the waiter, is not it?

changes.original: There is no danger of Wickham’s marrying Mary King--there’s for you!
changes.transformed: There is no danger of Mr. Wickham’s marrying Mr. Kingsley--there’s for you!

changes.original: She is gone down to her uncle at Liverpool; gone to stay.
changes.transformed: He is gone down to his uncle at Liverpool; gone to stay.

changes.original: Wickham is safe.”
changes.transformed: Mr. Wickham is safe.”

changes.transformed: “And Mr. King is safe!” added Elliot; “safe from a connection imprudent as to fortune.”

changes.original: “She is a great fool for going away, if she liked him.”
changes.transformed: “He is a great fool for going away, if he liked him.”

changes.transformed: “But I hope there is no strong attachment on either side,” said John.

changes.transformed: I will answer for it, he never cared three straws about him.

changes.original: As soon as all had ate, and the elder ones paid, the carriage was ordered; and, after some contrivance, the whole party, with all their boxes, workbags, and parcels, and the unwelcome addition of Kitty’s and Lydia’s purchases, were seated in it.

changes.transformed: “How nicely we are crammed in!” cried Lionel. “I am glad I brought my hat, if it is only for the fun of having another band-box!

changes.original: Jane will be quite an old maid soon, I declare.
changes.transformed: John will be quite an old bachelor soon, I declare.

changes.original: She is almost three-and-twenty!
changes.transformed: He is almost three-and-twenty!

changes.original: My aunt Philips wants you so to get husbands you can’t think.

changes.transformed: He says Elliot had better have taken Mr. Collins; but _I_ do not think there would have been any fun in it.

changes.original: Kitty and me were to spend the day there, and Mrs. Forster promised to have a little dance in the evening; (by-the-bye, Mrs. Forster and me are _such_ friends!) and so she asked the two Harringtons to come: but Harriet was ill, and so Pen was forced to come by herself; and then, what do you think we did?
changes.transformed: Kit and me were to spend the day there, and Mr. Forster promised to have a little dance in the evening; (by-the-bye, Mr. Forster and me are _such_ friends!) and so he asked the two Harringtons to come: but Harry was ill, and so Pen was forced to come by himself; and then, what do you think we did?

changes.original: We dressed up Chamberlayne in woman’s clothes, on purpose to pass for a lady,--only think what fun!
changes.transformed: We dressed up Chamberlayne in man’s clothes, on purpose to pass for a gentleman,--only think what fun!

changes.original: Not a soul knew of it, but Colonel and Mrs. Forster, and Kitty and me, except my aunt, for we were forced to borrow one of her gowns; and you cannot imagine how well he looked!
changes.transformed: Not a soul knew of it, but Colonel and Mr. Forster, and Kit and me, except my uncle, for we were forced to borrow one of his suits; and you cannot imagine how well he looked!

changes.original: Lord! how I laughed! and so did Mrs. Forster.
changes.transformed: Lord! how I laughed! and so did Mr. Forster.

changes.original: With such kind of histories of their parties and good jokes did Lydia, assisted by Kitty’s hints and additions, endeavour to amuse her companions all the way to Longbourn.
changes.transformed: With such kind of histories of their parties and good jokes did Lionel, assisted by Kit’s hints and additions, endeavour to amuse his companions all the way to Longbourn.

changes.original: Elizabeth listened as little as she could, but there was no escaping the frequent mention of Wickham’s name.

changes.original: “I am glad you are come back, Lizzy.”
changes.transformed: “I am glad you are come back, Elly.”

changes.original: Their party in the dining-room was large, for almost all the Lucases came to meet Maria and hear the news; and various were the subjects which occupied them: Lady Lucas was inquiring of Maria, across the table, after the welfare and poultry of her eldest daughter; Mrs. Bennet was doubly engaged, on one hand collecting an account of the present fashions from Jane, who sat some way below her, and on the other, retailing them all to the younger Miss Lucases; and Lydia, in a voice rather louder than any other person’s, was enumerating the various pleasures of the morning to anybody who would hear her.
changes.transformed: Their party in the dining-room was large, for almost all the Lucases came to meet Martin and hear the news; and various were the subjects which occupied them: Mr. Lucas was inquiring of Martin, across the table, after the welfare and poultry of his eldest son; Mr. Bennet was doubly engaged, on one hand collecting an account of the present fashions from John, who sat some way below him, and on the other, retailing them all to the younger Mr. Lucases; and Lionel, in a voice rather louder than any other person’s, was enumerating the various pleasures of the morning to anybody who would hear him.

changes.original: “Oh, Mary,” said she, “I wish you had gone with us, for we had such fun! as we went along Kitty and me drew up all the blinds, and pretended there was nobody in the coach; and I should have gone so all the way, if Kitty had not been sick; and when we got to the George, I do think we behaved very handsomely, for we treated the other three with the nicest cold luncheon in the world, and if you would have gone, we would have treated you too.

changes.original: To this, Mary very gravely replied, “Far be it from me, my dear sister, to depreciate such pleasures.
changes.transformed: To this, Mark very gravely replied, “Far be it from me, my dear brother, to depreciate such pleasures.

changes.original: They would doubtless be congenial with the generality of female minds.
changes.transformed: They would doubtless be congenial with the generality of male minds.

changes.original: But of this answer Lydia heard not a word.

changes.original: She seldom listened to anybody for more than half a minute, and never attended to Mary at all.
changes.transformed: He seldom listened to anybody for more than half a minute, and never attended to Mark at all.

changes.original: In the afternoon Lydia was urgent with the rest of the girls to walk to Meryton, and see how everybody went on; but Elizabeth steadily opposed the scheme.
changes.transformed: In the afternoon Lionel was urgent with the rest of the boys to walk to Meryton, and see how everybody went on; but Elliot steadily opposed the scheme.

changes.original: It should not be said, that the Miss Bennets could not be at home half a day before they were in pursuit of the officers.
changes.transformed: It should not be said, that the Mr. Bennets could not be at home half a day before they were in pursuit of the officers.

changes.original: There was another reason, too, for her opposition.
changes.transformed: There was another reason, too, for his opposition.

changes.original: She dreaded seeing Wickham again, and was resolved to avoid it as long as possible.
changes.transformed: He dreaded seeing Wickham again, and was resolved to avoid it as long as possible.

changes.original: The comfort to _her_, of the regiment’s approaching removal, was indeed beyond expression.
changes.transformed: The comfort to _him_, of the regiment’s approaching removal, was indeed beyond expression.

changes.original: In a fortnight they were to go, and once gone, she hoped there could be nothing more to plague her on his account.
changes.transformed: In a fortnight they were to go, and once gone, he hoped there could be nothing more to plague him on his account.

changes.original: She had not been many hours at home, before she found that the Brighton scheme, of which Lydia had given them a hint at the inn, was under frequent discussion between her parents.
changes.transformed: He had not been many hours at home, before he found that the Brighton scheme, of which Lionel had given them a hint at the inn, was under frequent discussion between his parents.

changes.original: Elizabeth saw directly that her father had not the smallest intention of yielding; but his answers were at the same time so vague and equivocal, that her mother, though often disheartened, had never yet despaired of succeeding at last.
changes.transformed: Elliot saw directly that his father had not the smallest intention of yielding; but his answers were at the same time so vague and equivocal, that his father, though often disheartened, had never yet despaired of succeeding at last.

changes.original: Elizabeth’s impatience to acquaint Jane with what had happened could no longer be overcome; and at length resolving to suppress every particular in which her sister was concerned, and preparing her to be surprised, she related to her the next morning the chief of the scene between Mr. Darcy and herself.
changes.transformed: Elliot’s impatience to acquaint John with what had happened could no longer be overcome; and at length resolving to suppress every particular in which his brother was concerned, and preparing him to be surprised, he related to him the next morning the chief of the scene between Mr. Darcy and himself.

changes.original: Miss Bennet’s astonishment was soon lessened by the strong sisterly partiality which made any admiration of Elizabeth appear perfectly natural; and all surprise was shortly lost in other feelings.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet’s astonishment was soon lessened by the strong brotherly partiality which made any admiration of Elliot appear perfectly natural; and all surprise was shortly lost in other feelings.

changes.original: She was sorry that Mr. Darcy should have delivered his sentiments in a manner so little suited to recommend them; but still more was she grieved for the unhappiness which her sister’s refusal must have given him.
changes.transformed: He was sorry that Mr. Darcy should have delivered his sentiments in a manner so little suited to recommend them; but still more was he grieved for the unhappiness which his brother’s refusal must have given him.

changes.original: “His being so sure of succeeding was wrong,” said she, “and certainly ought not to have appeared; but consider how much it must increase his disappointment.”
changes.transformed: “His being so sure of succeeding was wrong,” said he, “and certainly ought not to have appeared; but consider how much it must increase his disappointment.”

changes.original: “Indeed,” replied Elizabeth, “I am heartily sorry for him; but he has other feelings which will probably soon drive away his regard for me.
changes.transformed: “Indeed,” replied Elliot, “I am heartily sorry for him; but he has other feelings which will probably soon drive away his regard for me.

changes.original: She then spoke of the letter, repeating the whole of its contents as far as they concerned George Wickham.
changes.transformed: He then spoke of the letter, repeating the whole of its contents as far as they concerned George Wickham.

changes.transformed: What a stroke was this for poor John, who would willingly have gone through the world without believing that so much wickedness existed in the whole race of mankind as was here collected in one individual!

changes.original: Nor was Darcy’s vindication, though grateful to her feelings, capable of consoling her for such discovery.

changes.original: Most earnestly did she labour to prove the probability of error, and seek to clear one, without involving the other.
changes.transformed: Most earnestly did he labour to prove the probability of error, and seek to clear one, without involving the other.

changes.transformed: “This will not do,” said Elliot; “you never will be able to make both of them good for anything.

changes.transformed: It was some time, however, before a smile could be extorted from John.

changes.transformed: “I do not know when I have been more shocked,” said he. “Wickham so very bad!

changes.transformed: And poor Mr. Darcy! dear Elliot, only consider what he must have suffered.

changes.transformed: Such a disappointment! and with the knowledge of your ill opinion too! and having to relate such a thing of his brother!

changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet paused a little, and then replied, “Surely there can be no occasion for exposing him so dreadfully.

changes.transformed: “Well, Elliot,” continued his father, soon afterwards, “and so the Collinses live very comfortable, do they?

changes.transformed: “I am sure I shall break _mine_,” said Lionel.

changes.transformed: “If one could but go to Brighton!” observed Mr. Bennet.

changes.transformed: “And my uncle Philips is sure it would do _me_ a great deal of good,” added Kit.

changes.transformed: Elliot tried to be diverted by them; but all sense of pleasure was lost in shame.

changes.transformed: But the gloom of Lionel’s prospect was shortly cleared away; for he received an invitation from Mr. Forster, the husband of the colonel of the regiment, to accompany him to Brighton.

changes.transformed: This invaluable friend was a very young man, and very lately married.

changes.transformed: “I cannot see why Mr. Forster should not ask _me_ as well as Lionel,” said he, “though I am _not_ his particular friend.

changes.transformed: I have just as much right to be asked as he has, and more too, for I am two years older.”

changes.transformed: In vain did Elliot attempt to make him reasonable, and John to make him resigned.

changes.original: She represented to him all the improprieties of Lydia’s general behaviour, the little advantage she could derive from the friendship of such a woman as Mrs. Forster, and the probability of her being yet more imprudent with such a companion at Brighton, where the temptations must be greater than at home.
changes.transformed: He represented to him all the improprieties of Linus’s general behaviour, the little advantage he could derive from the friendship of such a man as Mr. Forster, and the probability of his being yet more imprudent with such a companion at Brighton, where the temptations must be greater than at home.

changes.original: He heard her attentively, and then said,--
changes.transformed: He heard him attentively, and then said,--

changes.original: “Lydia will never be easy till she has exposed herself in some public place or other, and we can never expect her to do it with so little expense or inconvenience to her family as under the present circumstances.”
changes.transformed: “Linus will never be easy till he has exposed himself in some public place or other, and we can never expect him to do it with so little expense or inconvenience to his family as under the present circumstances.”

changes.transformed: Poor little Elliot!

changes.transformed: Come, let me see the list of the pitiful fellows who have been kept aloof by Linus’s folly.”

changes.transformed: Our importance, our respectability in the world, must be affected by the wild volatility, the assurance and disdain of all restraint which mark Linus’s character.

changes.transformed: If you, my dear father, will not take the trouble of checking his exuberant spirits, and of teaching him that his present pursuits are not to be the business of his life, he will soon be beyond the reach of amendment.

changes.original: Her character will be fixed; and she will, at sixteen, be the most determined flirt that ever made herself and her family ridiculous;--a flirt, too, in the worst and meanest degree of flirtation; without any attraction beyond youth and a tolerable person; and, from the ignorance and emptiness of her mind, wholly unable to ward off any portion of that universal contempt which her rage for admiration will excite.
changes.transformed: His character will be fixed; and he will, at sixteen, be the most determined flirt that ever made himself and his family ridiculous;--a flirt, too, in the worst and meanest degree of flirtation; without any attraction beyond youth and a tolerable person; and, from the ignorance and emptiness of his mind, wholly unable to ward off any portion of that universal contempt which his rage for admiration will excite.

changes.original: In this danger Kitty is also comprehended.
changes.transformed: In this danger Kit is also comprehended.

changes.original: She will follow wherever Lydia leads.
changes.transformed: He will follow wherever Linus leads.

changes.original: Oh, my dear father, can you suppose it possible that they will not be censured and despised wherever they are known, and that their sisters will not be often involved in the disgrace?”
changes.transformed: Oh, my dear father, can you suppose it possible that they will not be censured and despised wherever they are known, and that their brothers will not be often involved in the disgrace?”

changes.original: Mr. Bennet saw that her whole heart was in the subject; and, affectionately taking her hand, said, in reply,--
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet saw that his whole heart was in the subject; and, affectionately taking his hand, said, in reply,--

changes.original: Wherever you and Jane are known, you must be respected and valued; and you will not appear to less advantage for having a couple of--or I may say, three--very silly sisters.
changes.transformed: Wherever you and John are known, you must be respected and valued; and you will not appear to less advantage for having a couple of--or I may say, three--very silly brothers.

changes.original: We shall have no peace at Longbourn if Lydia does not go to Brighton.
changes.transformed: We shall have no peace at Longbourn if Linus does not go to Brighton.

changes.original: Let her go, then.
changes.transformed: Let him go, then.

changes.original: Colonel Forster is a sensible man, and will keep her out of any real mischief; and she is luckily too poor to be an object of prey to anybody.
changes.transformed: Colonel Forster is a sensible man, and will keep him out of any real mischief; and he is luckily too poor to be an object of prey to anybody.

changes.original: At Brighton she will be of less importance even as a common flirt than she has been here.
changes.transformed: At Brighton he will be of less importance even as a common flirt than he has been here.

changes.original: The officers will find women better worth their notice.
changes.transformed: The officers will find men better worth their notice.

changes.original: Let us hope, therefore, that her being there may teach her her own insignificance.
changes.transformed: Let us hope, therefore, that his being there may teach him his own insignificance.

changes.original: At any rate, she cannot grow many degrees worse, without authorizing us to lock her up for the rest of her life.”
changes.transformed: At any rate, he cannot grow many degrees worse, without authorizing us to lock him up for the rest of his life.”

changes.original: With this answer Elizabeth was forced to be content; but her own opinion continued the same, and she left him disappointed and sorry.
changes.transformed: With this answer Elliot was forced to be content; but his own opinion continued the same, and he left him disappointed and sorry.

changes.original: It was not in her nature, however, to increase her vexations by dwelling on them.
changes.transformed: It was not in his nature, however, to increase his vexations by dwelling on them.

changes.original: She was confident of having performed her duty; and to fret over unavoidable evils, or augment them by anxiety, was no part of her disposition.
changes.transformed: He was confident of having performed his duty; and to fret over unavoidable evils, or augment them by anxiety, was no part of his disposition.

changes.original: Had Lydia and her mother known the substance of her conference with her father, their indignation would hardly have found expression in their united volubility.
changes.transformed: Had Lionel and his father known the substance of his conference with his father, their indignation would hardly have found expression in their united volubility.

changes.original: In Lydia’s imagination, a visit to Brighton comprised every possibility of earthly happiness.
changes.transformed: In Lionel’s imagination, a visit to Brighton comprised every possibility of earthly happiness.

changes.original: She saw, with the creative eye of fancy, the streets of that gay bathing-place covered with officers.
changes.transformed: He saw, with the creative eye of fancy, the streets of that gay bathing-place covered with officers.

changes.original: She saw herself the object of attention to tens and to scores of them at present unknown.
changes.transformed: He saw himself the object of attention to tens and to scores of them at present unknown.

changes.original: She saw all the glories of the camp: its tents stretched forth in beauteous uniformity of lines, crowded with the young and the gay, and dazzling with scarlet; and, to complete the view, she saw herself seated beneath a tent, tenderly flirting with at least six officers at once.
changes.transformed: He saw all the glories of the camp: its tents stretched forth in beauteous uniformity of lines, crowded with the young and the gay, and dazzling with scarlet; and, to complete the view, he saw himself seated beneath a tent, tenderly flirting with at least six officers at once.

changes.original: Had she known that her sister sought to tear her from such prospects and such realities as these, what would have been her sensations?
changes.transformed: Had he known that his brother sought to tear him from such prospects and such realities as these, what would have been his sensations?

changes.original: They could have been understood only by her mother, who might have felt nearly the same.
changes.transformed: They could have been understood only by his father, who might have felt nearly the same.

changes.original: Lydia’s going to Brighton was all that consoled her for the melancholy conviction of her husband’s never intending to go there himself.
changes.transformed: Lionel’s going to Brighton was all that consoled him for the melancholy conviction of his husband’s never intending to go there himself.

changes.original: But they were entirely ignorant of what had passed; and their raptures continued, with little intermission, to the very day of Lydia’s leaving home.
changes.transformed: But they were entirely ignorant of what had passed; and their raptures continued, with little intermission, to the very day of Lionel’s leaving home.

changes.original: Elizabeth was now to see Mr. Wickham for the last time.
changes.transformed: Elliot was now to see Mr. Wickham for the last time.

changes.original: Having been frequently in company with him since her return, agitation was pretty well over; the agitations of former partiality entirely so.
changes.transformed: Having been frequently in company with him since his return, agitation was pretty well over; the agitations of former partiality entirely so.

changes.original: She had even learnt to detect, in the very gentleness which had first delighted her, an affectation and a sameness to disgust and weary.
changes.transformed: He had even learnt to detect, in the very gentleness which had first delighted him, an affectation and a sameness to disgust and weary.

changes.original: In his present behaviour to herself, moreover, she had a fresh source of displeasure; for the inclination he soon testified of renewing those attentions which had marked the early part of their acquaintance could only serve, after what had since passed, to provoke her.
changes.transformed: In his present behaviour to himself, moreover, he had a fresh source of displeasure; for the inclination he soon testified of renewing those attentions which had marked the early part of their acquaintance could only serve, after what had since passed, to provoke him.

changes.original: She lost all concern for him in finding herself thus selected as the object of such idle and frivolous gallantry; and while she steadily repressed it, could not but feel the reproof contained in his believing, that however long, and for whatever cause, his attentions had been withdrawn, her vanity would be gratified, and her preference secured, at any time, by their renewal.
changes.transformed: He lost all concern for him in finding himself thus selected as the object of such idle and frivolous gallantry; and while he steadily repressed it, could not but feel the reproof contained in his believing, that however long, and for whatever cause, his attentions had been withdrawn, his vanity would be gratified, and his preference secured, at any time, by their renewal.

changes.original: On the very last day of the regiment’s remaining in Meryton, he dined, with others of the officers, at Longbourn; and so little was Elizabeth disposed to part from him in good-humour, that, on his making some inquiry as to the manner in which her time had passed at Hunsford, she mentioned Colonel Fitzwilliam’s and Mr. Darcy’s having both spent three weeks at Rosings, and asked him if he were acquainted with the former.
changes.transformed: On the very last day of the regiment’s remaining in Meryton, he dined, with others of the officers, at Longbourn; and so little was Elliot disposed to part from him in good-humour, that, on his making some inquiry as to the manner in which his time had passed at Hunsford, he mentioned Colonel Fitzwilliam’s and Mr. Darcy’s having both spent three weeks at Rosings, and asked him if he were acquainted with the former.

changes.original: He looked surprised, displeased, alarmed; but, with a moment’s recollection, and a returning smile, replied, that he had formerly seen him often; and, after observing that he was a very gentlemanlike man, asked her how she had liked him.
changes.transformed: He looked surprised, displeased, alarmed; but, with a moment’s recollection, and a returning smile, replied, that he had formerly seen him often; and, after observing that he was a very gentlemanlike man, asked him how he had liked him.

changes.original: Her answer was warmly in his favour.
changes.transformed: His answer was warmly in his favour.

changes.original: “Indeed!” cried Wickham, with a look which did not escape her. “And pray may I ask--” but checking himself, he added, in a gayer tone, “Is it in address that he improves?
changes.transformed: “Indeed!” cried Wickham, with a look which did not escape him. “And pray may I ask--” but checking himself, he added, in a gayer tone, “Is it in address that he improves?

changes.original: “Oh, no!” said Elizabeth. “In essentials, I believe, he is very much what he ever was.”
changes.transformed: “Oh, no!” said Elliot. “In essentials, I believe, he is very much what he ever was.”

changes.original: While she spoke, Wickham looked as if scarcely knowing whether to rejoice over her words or to distrust their meaning.
changes.transformed: While he spoke, Wickham looked as if scarcely knowing whether to rejoice over his words or to distrust their meaning.

changes.original: There was a something in her countenance which made him listen with an apprehensive and anxious attention, while she added,--
changes.transformed: There was something in his countenance which made him listen with an apprehensive and anxious attention, while he added,--

changes.original: Wickham’s alarm now appeared in a heightened complexion and agitated look; for a few minutes he was silent; till, shaking off his embarrassment, he turned to her again, and said in the gentlest of accents,--
changes.transformed: Wickham’s alarm now appeared in a heightened complexion and agitated look; for a few minutes he was silent; till, shaking off his embarrassment, he turned to him again, and said in the gentlest of accents,--

changes.original: I only fear that the sort of cautiousness to which you, I imagine, have been alluding, is merely adopted on his visits to his aunt, of whose good opinion and judgment he stands much in awe.
changes.transformed: I only fear that the sort of cautiousness to which you, I imagine, have been alluding, is merely adopted on his visits to his uncle, of whose good opinion and judgment he stands much in awe.

changes.original: His fear of her has always operated, I know, when they were together; and a good deal is to be imputed to his wish of forwarding the match with Miss de Bourgh, which I am certain he has very much at heart.”
changes.transformed: His fear of him has always operated, I know, when they were together; and a good deal is to be imputed to his wish of forwarding the match with Mr. de Bourgh, which I am certain he has very much at heart.”

changes.original: Elizabeth could not repress a smile at this, but she answered only by a slight inclination of the head.
changes.transformed: Elliot could not repress a smile at this, but he answered only by a slight inclination of the head.

changes.original: She saw that he wanted to engage her on the old subject of his grievances, and she was in no humour to indulge him.
changes.transformed: He saw that he wanted to engage him on the old subject of his grievances, and he was in no humour to indulge him.

changes.original: The rest of the evening passed with the _appearance_, on his side, of usual cheerfulness, but with no further attempt to distinguish Elizabeth; and they parted at last with mutual civility, and possibly a mutual desire of never meeting again.
changes.transformed: The rest of the evening passed with the _appearance_, on his side, of usual cheerfulness, but with no further attempt to distinguish Elliot; and they parted at last with mutual civility, and possibly a mutual desire of never meeting again.

changes.original: When the party broke up, Lydia returned with Mrs. Forster to Meryton, from whence they were to set out early the next morning.
changes.transformed: When the party broke up, Lyndon returned with Mr. Forster to Meryton, from whence they were to set out early the next morning.

changes.original: The separation between her and her family was rather noisy than pathetic.
changes.transformed: The separation between him and his family was rather noisy than pathetic.

changes.original: Kitty was the only one who shed tears; but she did weep from vexation and envy.
changes.transformed: Kit was the only one who shed tears; but he did weep from vexation and envy.

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet was diffuse in her good wishes for the felicity of her daughter, and impressive in her injunctions that she would not miss the opportunity of enjoying herself as much as possible,--advice which there was every reason to believe would be attended to; and, in the clamorous happiness of Lydia herself in bidding farewell, the more gentle adieus of her sisters were uttered without being heard.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet was diffuse in his good wishes for the felicity of his son, and impressive in his injunctions that he would not miss the opportunity of enjoying himself as much as possible,--advice which there was every reason to believe would be attended to; and, in the clamorous happiness of Lyndon himself in bidding farewell, the more gentle adieus of his brothers were uttered without being heard.

changes.original: Had Elizabeth’s opinion been all drawn from her own family, she could not have formed a very pleasing picture of conjugal felicity or domestic comfort.
changes.transformed: Had Elliot’s opinion been all drawn from his own family, he could not have formed a very pleasing picture of conjugal felicity or domestic comfort.

changes.original: Her father, captivated by youth and beauty, and that appearance of good-humour which youth and beauty generally give, had married a woman whose weak understanding and illiberal mind had very early in their marriage put an end to all real affection for her.
changes.transformed: His father, captivated by youth and beauty, and that appearance of good-humour which youth and beauty generally give, had married a man whose weak understanding and illiberal mind had very early in their marriage put an end to all real affection for him.

changes.original: To his wife he was very little otherwise indebted than as her ignorance and folly had contributed to his amusement.
changes.transformed: To his husband he was very little otherwise indebted than as his ignorance and folly had contributed to his amusement.

changes.original: This is not the sort of happiness which a man would in general wish to owe to his wife; but where other powers of entertainment are wanting, the true philosopher will derive benefit from such as are given.
changes.transformed: This is not the sort of happiness which a man would in general wish to owe to his husband; but where other powers of entertainment are wanting, the true philosopher will derive benefit from such as are given.

changes.original: Elizabeth, however, had never been blind to the impropriety of her father’s behaviour as a husband.
changes.transformed: Elliot, however, had never been blind to the impropriety of his father’s behaviour as a husband.

changes.original: She had always seen it with pain; but respecting his abilities, and grateful for his affectionate treatment of herself, she endeavoured to forget what she could not overlook, and to banish from her thoughts that continual breach of conjugal obligation and decorum which, in exposing his wife to the contempt of her own children, was so highly reprehensible.
changes.transformed: He had always seen it with pain; but respecting his abilities, and grateful for his affectionate treatment of himself, he endeavoured to forget what he could not overlook, and to banish from his thoughts that continual breach of conjugal obligation and decorum which, in exposing his husband to the contempt of his own children, was so highly reprehensible.

changes.original: But she had never felt so strongly as now the disadvantages which must attend the children of so unsuitable a marriage, nor ever been so fully aware of the evils arising from so ill-judged a direction of talents--talents which, rightly used, might at least have preserved the respectability of his daughters, even if incapable of enlarging the mind of his wife.
changes.transformed: But he had never felt so strongly as now the disadvantages which must attend the children of so unsuitable a marriage, nor ever been so fully aware of the evils arising from so ill-judged a direction of talents--talents which, rightly used, might at least have preserved the respectability of his sons, even if incapable of enlarging the mind of his husband.

changes.original: When Elizabeth had rejoiced over Wickham’s departure, she found little other cause for satisfaction in the loss of the regiment.
changes.transformed: When Elliot had rejoiced over Wickham’s departure, he found little other cause for satisfaction in the loss of the regiment.

changes.original: Their parties abroad were less varied than before; and at home she had a mother and sister, whose constant repinings at the dulness of everything around them threw a real gloom over their domestic circle; and, though Kitty might in time regain her natural degree of sense, since the disturbers of her brain were removed, her other sister, from whose disposition greater evil might be apprehended, was likely to be hardened in all her folly and assurance, by a situation of such double danger as a watering-place and a camp.
changes.transformed: Their parties abroad were less varied than before; and at home he had a father and brother, whose constant repinings at the dulness of everything around them threw a real gloom over their domestic circle; and, though Kit might in time regain his natural degree of sense, since the disturbers of his brain were removed, his other brother, from whose disposition greater evil might be apprehended, was likely to be hardened in all his folly and assurance, by a situation of such double danger as a watering-place and a camp.

changes.original: Upon the whole, therefore, she found, what has been sometimes found before, that an event to which she had looked forward with impatient desire, did not, in taking place, bring all the satisfaction she had promised herself.
changes.transformed: Upon the whole, therefore, he found, what has been sometimes found before, that an event to which he had looked forward with impatient desire, did not, in taking place, bring all the satisfaction he had promised himself.

changes.original: It was consequently necessary to name some other period for the commencement of actual felicity; to have some other point on which her wishes and hopes might be fixed, and by again enjoying the pleasure of anticipation, console herself for the present, and prepare for another disappointment.
changes.transformed: It was consequently necessary to name some other period for the commencement of actual felicity; to have some other point on which his wishes and hopes might be fixed, and by again enjoying the pleasure of anticipation, console himself for the present, and prepare for another disappointment.

changes.original: Her tour to the Lakes was now the object of her happiest thoughts: it was her best consolation for all the uncomfortable hours which the discontentedness of her mother and Kitty made inevitable; and could she have included Jane in the scheme, every part of it would have been perfect.
changes.transformed: His tour to the Lakes was now the object of his happiest thoughts: it was his best consolation for all the uncomfortable hours which the discontentedness of his father and Kit made inevitable; and could he have included John in the scheme, every part of it would have been perfect.

changes.original: “But it is fortunate,” thought she, “that I have something to wish for.
changes.transformed: “But it is fortunate,” thought he, “that I have something to wish for.

changes.original: But here, by carrying with me one ceaseless source of regret in my sister’s absence, I may reasonably hope to have all my expectations of pleasure realized.
changes.transformed: But here, by carrying with me one ceaseless source of regret in my brother’s absence, I may reasonably hope to have all my expectations of pleasure realized.

changes.original: When Lydia went away she promised to write very often and very minutely to her mother and Kitty; but her letters were always long expected, and always very short.
changes.transformed: When Lyndon went away he promised to write very often and very minutely to his father and Kit; but his letters were always long expected, and always very short.

changes.original: Those to her mother contained little else than that they were just returned from the library, where such and such officers had attended them, and where she had seen such beautiful ornaments as made her quite wild; that she had a new gown, or a new parasol, which she would have described more fully, but was obliged to leave off in a violent hurry, as Mrs. Forster called her, and they were going to the camp; and from her correspondence with her sister there was still less to be learnt, for her letters to Kitty, though rather longer, were much too full of lines under the words to be made public.
changes.transformed: Those to his father contained little else than that they were just returned from the library, where such and such officers had attended them, and where he had seen such beautiful ornaments as made him quite wild; that he had a new coat, or a new hat, which he would have described more fully, but was obliged to leave off in a violent hurry, as Mr. Forster called him, and they were going to the camp; and from his correspondence with his brother there was still less to be learnt, for his letters to Kit, though rather longer, were much too full of lines under the words to be made public.

changes.original: After the first fortnight or three weeks of her absence, health, good-humour, and cheerfulness began to reappear at Longbourn.
changes.transformed: After the first fortnight or three weeks of his absence, health, good-humour, and cheerfulness began to reappear at Longbourn.

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet was restored to her usual querulous serenity; and by the middle of June Kitty was so much recovered as to be able to enter Meryton without tears,--an event of such happy promise as to make Elizabeth hope, that by the following Christmas she might be so tolerably reasonable as not to mention an officer above once a day, unless, by some cruel and malicious arrangement at the War Office, another regiment should be quartered in Meryton.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet was restored to his usual querulous serenity; and by the middle of June Kit was so much recovered as to be able to enter Meryton without tears,--an event of such happy promise as to make Elliot hope, that by the following Christmas he might be so tolerably reasonable as not to mention an officer above once a day, unless, by some cruel and malicious arrangement at the War Office, another regiment should be quartered in Meryton.

changes.original: The time fixed for the beginning of their northern tour was now fast approaching; and a fortnight only was wanting of it, when a letter arrived from Mrs. Gardiner, which at once delayed its commencement and curtailed its extent.
changes.transformed: The time fixed for the beginning of their northern tour was now fast approaching; and a fortnight only was wanting of it, when a letter arrived from Mr. Gardiner, which at once delayed its commencement and curtailed its extent.

changes.original: In that county there was enough to be seen to occupy the chief of their three weeks; and to Mrs. Gardiner it had a peculiarly strong attraction.
changes.transformed: In that county there was enough to be seen to occupy the chief of their three weeks; and to Mr. Gardiner it had a peculiarly strong attraction.

changes.original: The town where she had formerly passed some years of her life, and where they were now to spend a few days, was probably as great an object of her curiosity as all the celebrated beauties of Matlock, Chatsworth, Dovedale, or the Peak.
changes.transformed: The town where he had formerly passed some years of his life, and where they were now to spend a few days, was probably as great an object of his curiosity as all the celebrated beauties of Matlock, Chatsworth, Dovedale, or the Peak.

changes.original: Elizabeth was excessively disappointed: she had set her heart on seeing the Lakes; and still thought there might have been time enough.
changes.transformed: Elliot was excessively disappointed: he had set his heart on seeing the Lakes; and still thought there might have been time enough.

changes.original: But it was her business to be satisfied--and certainly her temper to be happy; and all was soon right again.
changes.transformed: But it was his business to be satisfied--and certainly his temper to be happy; and all was soon right again.

changes.original: It was impossible for her to see the word without thinking of Pemberley and its owner. “But surely,” said she, “I may enter his county with impunity, and rob it of a few petrified spars, without his perceiving me.”
changes.transformed: It was impossible for him to see the word without thinking of Pemberley and its owner. “But surely,” said he, “I may enter his county with impunity, and rob it of a few petrified spars, without his perceiving me.”

changes.original: Four weeks were to pass away before her uncle and aunt’s arrival.
changes.transformed: Four weeks were to pass away before his uncle’s arrival.

changes.original: But they did pass away, and Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner, with their four children, did at length appear at Longbourn.
changes.transformed: But they did pass away, and Mr. Gardiner, with his four children, did at length appear at Longbourn.

changes.original: The children, two girls of six and eight years old, and two younger boys, were to be left under the particular care of their cousin Jane, who was the general favourite, and whose steady sense and sweetness of temper exactly adapted her for attending to them in every way--teaching them, playing with them, and loving them.
changes.transformed: The children, two boys of six and eight years old, and two younger boys, were to be left under the particular care of their cousin John, who was the general favourite, and whose steady sense and sweetness of temper exactly adapted him for attending to them in every way--teaching them, playing with them, and loving them.

changes.original: The Gardiners stayed only one night at Longbourn, and set off the next morning with Elizabeth in pursuit of novelty and amusement.
changes.transformed: The Gardiners stayed only one night at Longbourn, and set off the next morning with Elliot in pursuit of novelty and amusement.

changes.original: To the little town of Lambton, the scene of Mrs. Gardiner’s former residence, and where she had lately learned that some acquaintance still remained, they bent their steps, after having seen all the principal wonders of the country; and within five miles of Lambton, Elizabeth found, from her aunt, that Pemberley was situated.
changes.transformed: To the little town of Lambton, the scene of Mr. Gardiner’s former residence, and where he had lately learned that some acquaintance still remained, they bent their steps, after having seen all the principal wonders of the country; and within five miles of Lambton, Elliot found, from his uncle, that Pemberley was situated.

changes.original: In talking over their route the evening before, Mrs. Gardiner expressed an inclination to see the place again.
changes.transformed: In talking over their route the evening before, Mr. Gardiner expressed an inclination to see the place again.

changes.original: Mr. Gardiner declared his willingness, and Elizabeth was applied to for her approbation.
changes.transformed: Mr. Gardiner declared his willingness, and Elliot was applied to for his approbation.

changes.original: “My love, should not you like to see a place of which you have heard so much?” said her aunt. “A place, too, with which so many of your acquaintance are connected.
changes.transformed: “My friend, should not you like to see a place of which you have heard so much?” said his uncle. “A place, too, with which so many of your acquaintance are connected.

changes.original: Elizabeth was distressed.
changes.transformed: Elliot was distressed.

changes.original: She felt that she had no business at Pemberley, and was obliged to assume a disinclination for seeing it.
changes.transformed: He felt that he had no business at Pemberley, and was obliged to assume a disinclination for seeing it.

changes.original: She must own that she was tired of great houses: after going over so many, she really had no pleasure in fine carpets or satin curtains.
changes.transformed: He must own that he was tired of great houses: after going over so many, he really had no pleasure in fine carpets or satin curtains.

changes.original: Mrs. Gardiner abused her stupidity. “If it were merely a fine house richly furnished,” said she, “I should not care about it myself; but the grounds are delightful.
changes.transformed: Mr. Gardiner abused his stupidity. “If it were merely a fine house richly furnished,” said he, “I should not care about it myself; but the grounds are delightful.

changes.original: Elizabeth said no more; but her mind could not acquiesce.
changes.transformed: Elliot said no more; but his mind could not acquiesce.

changes.original: She blushed at the very idea; and thought it would be better to speak openly to her aunt, than to run such a risk.
changes.transformed: He blushed at the very idea; and thought it would be better to speak openly to his uncle, than to run such a risk.

changes.original: But against this there were objections; and she finally resolved that it could be the last resource, if her private inquiries as to the absence of the family were unfavourably answered.
changes.transformed: But against this there were objections; and he finally resolved that it could be the last resource, if his private inquiries as to the absence of the family were unfavourably answered.

changes.original: Accordingly, when she retired at night, she asked the chambermaid whether Pemberley were not a very fine place, what was the name of its proprietor, and, with no little alarm, whether the family were down for the summer?
changes.transformed: Accordingly, when he retired at night, he asked the chamberman whether Pemberley were not a very fine place, what was the name of its proprietor, and, with no little alarm, whether the family were down for the summer?

changes.original: A most welcome negative followed the last question; and her alarms being now removed, she was at leisure to feel a great deal of curiosity to see the house herself; and when the subject was revived the next morning, and she was again applied to, could readily answer, and with a proper air of indifference, that she had not really any dislike to the scheme.
changes.transformed: A most welcome negative followed the last question; and his alarms being now removed, he was at leisure to feel a great deal of curiosity to see the house himself; and when the subject was revived the next morning, and he was again applied to, could readily answer, and with a proper air of indifference, that he had not really any dislike to the scheme.

changes.original: Elizabeth, as they drove along, watched for the first appearance of Pemberley Woods with some perturbation; and when at length they turned in at the lodge, her spirits were in a high flutter.
changes.transformed: Elliot, as they drove along, watched for the first appearance of Pemberley Woods with some perturbation; and when at length they turned in at the lodge, his spirits were in a high flutter.

changes.original: Elizabeth’s mind was too full for conversation, but she saw and admired every remarkable spot and point of view.
changes.transformed: Elliot’s mind was too full for conversation, but he saw and admired every remarkable spot and point of view.

changes.original: Elizabeth was delighted.
changes.transformed: Elliot was delighted.

changes.original: She had never seen a place for which nature had done more, or where natural beauty had been so little counteracted by an awkward taste.
changes.transformed: He had never seen a place for which nature had done more, or where natural beauty had been so little counteracted by an awkward taste.

changes.original: They were all of them warm in their admiration; and at that moment she felt that to be mistress of Pemberley might be something!
changes.transformed: They were all of them warm in their admiration; and at that moment he felt that to be master of Pemberley might be something!

changes.original: They descended the hill, crossed the bridge, and drove to the door; and, while examining the nearer aspect of the house, all her apprehension of meeting its owner returned.
changes.transformed: They descended the hill, crossed the bridge, and drove to the door; and, while examining the nearer aspect of the house, all his apprehension of meeting its owner returned.

changes.original: She dreaded lest the chambermaid had been mistaken.
changes.transformed: He dreaded lest the chamberman had been mistaken.

changes.original: On applying to see the place, they were admitted into the hall; and Elizabeth, as they waited for the housekeeper, had leisure to wonder at her being where she was.
changes.transformed: On applying to see the place, they were admitted into the hall; and Elliot, as they waited for the housekeeper, had leisure to wonder at his being where he was.

changes.original: The housekeeper came; a respectable looking elderly woman, much less fine, and more civil, than she had any notion of finding her.
changes.transformed: The housekeeper came; a respectable looking elderly man, much less fine, and more civil, than he had any notion of finding him.

changes.original: They followed her into the dining-parlour.
changes.transformed: They followed him into the dining-parlour.

changes.original: Elizabeth, after slightly surveying it, went to a window to enjoy its prospect.
changes.transformed: Elliot, after slightly surveying it, went to a window to enjoy its prospect.

changes.original: Every disposition of the ground was good; and she looked on the whole scene, the river, the trees scattered on its banks, and the winding of the valley, as far as she could trace it, with delight.
changes.transformed: Every disposition of the ground was good; and he looked on the whole scene, the river, the trees scattered on its banks, and the winding of the valley, as far as he could trace it, with delight.

changes.original: The rooms were lofty and handsome, and their furniture suitable to the fortune of their proprietor; but Elizabeth saw, with admiration of his taste, that it was neither gaudy nor uselessly fine,--with less of splendour, and more real elegance, than the furniture of Rosings.
changes.transformed: The rooms were lofty and handsome, and their furniture suitable to the fortune of their proprietor; but Elliot saw, with admiration of his taste, that it was neither gaudy nor uselessly fine,--with less of splendour, and more real elegance, than the furniture of Rosings.

changes.original: “And of this place,” thought she, “I might have been mistress!
changes.transformed: “And of this place,” thought he, “I might have been master!

changes.original: Instead of viewing them as a stranger, I might have rejoiced in them as my own, and welcomed to them as visitors my uncle and aunt.
changes.transformed: Instead of viewing them as a stranger, I might have rejoiced in them as my own, and welcomed to them as visitors my uncle and uncle.

changes.original: But, no,” recollecting herself, “that could never be; my uncle and aunt would have been lost to me; I should not have been allowed to invite them.”
changes.transformed: But, no,” recollecting himself, “that could never be; my uncle and uncle would have been lost to me; I should not have been allowed to invite them.”

changes.original: This was a lucky recollection--it saved her from something like regret.
changes.transformed: This was a lucky recollection--it saved him from something like regret.

changes.original: She longed to inquire of the housekeeper whether her master were really absent, but had not courage for it.
changes.transformed: He longed to inquire of the housekeeper whether his master were really absent, but had not courage for it.

changes.original: At length, however, the question was asked by her uncle; and she turned away with alarm, while Mrs. Reynolds replied, that he was; adding, “But we expect him to-morrow, with a large party of friends.” How rejoiced was Elizabeth that their own journey had not by any circumstance been delayed a day!
changes.transformed: At length, however, the question was asked by his uncle; and he turned away with alarm, while Mr. Reynolds replied, that he was; adding, “But we expect him to-morrow, with a large party of friends.” How rejoiced was Elliot that their own journey had not by any circumstance been delayed a day!

changes.original: Her aunt now called her to look at a picture.
changes.transformed: His uncle now called him to look at a picture.

changes.original: She approached, and saw the likeness of Mr. Wickham, suspended, amongst several other miniatures, over the mantel-piece.
changes.transformed: He approached, and saw the likeness of Mr. Wickham, suspended, amongst several other miniatures, over the mantel-piece.

changes.original: Her aunt asked her, smilingly, how she liked it.
changes.transformed: His uncle asked him, smilingly, how he liked it.

changes.original: The housekeeper came forward, and told them it was the picture of a young gentleman, the son of her late master’s steward, who had been brought up by him at his own expense. “He is now gone into the army,” she added; “but I am afraid he has turned out very wild.”
changes.transformed: The housekeeper came forward, and told them it was the picture of a young gentleman, the son of his late master’s steward, who had been brought up by him at his own expense. “He is now gone into the army,” he added; “but I am afraid he has turned out very wild.”

changes.original: Mrs. Gardiner looked at her niece with a smile, but Elizabeth could not return it.
changes.transformed: Mr. Gardiner looked at his nephew with a smile, but Elliot could not return it.

changes.original: “And that,” said Mrs. Reynolds, pointing to another of the miniatures, “is my master--and very like him.
changes.transformed: “And that,” said Mr. Reynolds, pointing to another of the miniatures, “is my master--and very like him.

changes.original: “I have heard much of your master’s fine person,” said Mrs. Gardiner, looking at the picture; “it is a handsome face.
changes.transformed: “I have heard much of your master’s fine person,” said Mr. Gardiner, looking at the picture; “it is a handsome face.

changes.original: But, Lizzy, you can tell us whether it is like or not.”
changes.transformed: But, Elliot, you can tell us whether it is like or not.”

changes.original: Mrs. Reynolds’ respect for Elizabeth seemed to increase on this intimation of her knowing her master.
changes.transformed: Mr. Reynolds’ respect for Elliot seemed to increase on this intimation of him knowing his master.

changes.original: “Does that young lady know Mr. Darcy?”
changes.transformed: “Does that young gentleman know Mr. Darcy?”

changes.original: Elizabeth coloured, and said, “A little.”
changes.transformed: Elliot coloured, and said, “A little.”

changes.original: “And do not you think him a very handsome gentleman, ma’am?”
changes.transformed: “And do not you think him a very handsome gentleman, sir?”

changes.original: This accounted to Elizabeth for Mr. Wickham’s being among them.
changes.transformed: This accounted to Elliot for Mr. Wickham’s being among them.

changes.original: Mrs. Reynolds then directed their attention to one of Miss Darcy, drawn when she was only eight years old.
changes.transformed: Mr. Reynolds then directed their attention to one of Mr. Darcy, drawn when he was only eight years old.

changes.original: “And is Miss Darcy as handsome as her brother?” said Mr. Gardiner.
changes.transformed: “And is Mr. Darcy as handsome as his brother?” said Mr. Gardiner.

changes.original: “Oh, yes--the handsomest young lady that ever was seen; and so accomplished!
changes.transformed: “Oh, yes--the handsomest young gentleman that ever was seen; and so accomplished!

changes.original: She plays and sings all day long.
changes.transformed: He plays and sings all day long.

changes.original: In the next room is a new instrument just come down for her--a present from my master: she comes here to-morrow with him.”
changes.transformed: In the next room is a new instrument just come down for him--a present from my master: he comes here to-morrow with him.”

changes.original: Mr. Gardiner, whose manners were easy and pleasant, encouraged her communicativeness by his questions and remarks: Mrs. Reynolds, either from pride or attachment, had evidently great pleasure in talking of her master and his sister.
changes.transformed: Mr. Gardiner, whose manners were easy and pleasant, encouraged his communicativeness by his questions and remarks: Mr. Reynolds, either from pride or attachment, had evidently great pleasure in talking of his master and his brother.

changes.original: “Not so much as I could wish, sir: but I dare say he may spend half his time here; and Miss Darcy is always down for the summer months.”
changes.transformed: “Not so much as I could wish, sir: but I dare say he may spend half his time here; and Mr. Darcy is always down for the summer months.”

changes.original: “Except,” thought Elizabeth, “when she goes to Ramsgate.”
changes.transformed: “Except,” thought Elliot, “when he goes to Ramsgate.”

changes.original: Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner smiled.
changes.transformed: Mr. and Mr. Gardiner smiled.

changes.original: Elizabeth could not help saying, “It is very much to his credit, I am sure, that you should think so.”
changes.transformed: Elliot could not help saying, “It is very much to his credit, I am sure, that you should think so.”

changes.original: Elizabeth thought this was going pretty far; and she listened with increasing astonishment as the housekeeper added, “I have never had a cross word from him in my life, and I have known him ever since he was four years old.”
changes.transformed: Elliot thought this was going pretty far; and he listened with increasing astonishment as the housekeeper added, “I have never had a cross word from him in my life, and I have known him ever since he was four years old.”

changes.original: This was praise of all others most extraordinary, most opposite to her ideas.
changes.transformed: This was praise of all others most extraordinary, most opposite to his ideas.

changes.original: That he was not a good-tempered man had been her firmest opinion.
changes.transformed: That he was not a good-tempered man had been his firmest opinion.

changes.original: Her keenest attention was awakened: she longed to hear more; and was grateful to her uncle for saying,--
changes.transformed: His keenest attention was awakened: he longed to hear more; and was grateful to his uncle for saying,--

changes.original: Elizabeth almost stared at her. “Can this be Mr. Darcy?” thought she.
changes.transformed: Elliot almost stared at him. “Can this be Mr. Darcy?” thought he.

changes.original: “His father was an excellent man,” said Mrs. Gardiner.
changes.transformed: “His father was an excellent man,” said Mr. Gardiner.

changes.original: “Yes, ma’am, that he was indeed; and his son will be just like him--just as affable to the poor.”
changes.transformed: “Yes, sir, that he was indeed; and his son will be just like him--just as affable to the poor.”

changes.original: Elizabeth listened, wondered, doubted, and was impatient for more.
changes.transformed: Elliot listened, wondered, doubted, and was impatient for more.

changes.original: Mrs. Reynolds could interest her on no other point.
changes.transformed: Mr. Reynolds could interest him on no other point.

changes.original: She related the subjects of the pictures, the dimensions of the rooms, and the price of the furniture in vain.
changes.transformed: He related the subjects of the pictures, the dimensions of the rooms, and the price of the furniture in vain.

changes.original: Mr. Gardiner, highly amused by the kind of family prejudice, to which he attributed her excessive commendation of her master, soon led again to the subject; and she dwelt with energy on his many merits, as they proceeded together up the great staircase.
changes.transformed: Mr. Gardiner, highly amused by the kind of family prejudice, to which he attributed his excessive commendation of his master, soon led again to the subject; and he dwelt with energy on his many merits, as they proceeded together up the great staircase.

changes.original: “He is the best landlord, and the best master,” said she, “that ever lived.
changes.transformed: “He is the best landlord, and the best master,” said he, “that ever lived.
