changes.original: “In what an amiable light does this place him!” thought Elizabeth.
changes.transformed: “In what an amiable light does this place him!” thought Elliot.

changes.original: “This fine account of him,” whispered her aunt as they walked, “is not quite consistent with his behaviour to our poor friend.”
changes.transformed: “This fine account of him,” whispered his uncle as they walked, “is not quite consistent with his behaviour to our poor friend.”

changes.original: On reaching the spacious lobby above, they were shown into a very pretty sitting-room, lately fitted up with greater elegance and lightness than the apartments below; and were informed that it was but just done to give pleasure to Miss Darcy, who had taken a liking to the room, when last at Pemberley.
changes.transformed: On reaching the spacious lobby above, they were shown into a very pretty sitting-room, lately fitted up with greater elegance and lightness than the apartments below; and were informed that it was but just done to give pleasure to Mr. Darcy, who had taken a liking to the room, when last at Pemberley.

changes.original: “He is certainly a good brother,” said Elizabeth, as she walked towards one of the windows.
changes.transformed: “He is certainly a good brother,” said Elliot, as he walked towards one of the windows.

changes.original: Mrs. Reynolds anticipated Miss Darcy’s delight, when she should enter the room. “And this is always the way with him,” she added. “Whatever can give his sister any pleasure, is sure to be done in a moment.
changes.transformed: Mr. Reynolds anticipated Mr. Darcy’s delight, when he should enter the room. “And this is always the way with him,” he added. “Whatever can give his brother any pleasure, is sure to be done in a moment.

changes.original: There is nothing he would not do for her.”
changes.transformed: There is nothing he would not do for him.”

changes.original: In the former were many good paintings: but Elizabeth knew nothing of the art; and from such as had been already visible below, she had willingly turned to look at some drawings of Miss Darcy’s, in crayons, whose subjects were usually more interesting, and also more intelligible.
changes.transformed: In the former were many good paintings: but Elliot knew nothing of the art; and from such as had been already visible below, he had willingly turned to look at some drawings of Mr. Darcy’s, in crayons, whose subjects were usually more interesting, and also more intelligible.

changes.original: Elizabeth walked on in quest of the only face whose features would be known to her.
changes.transformed: Elliot walked on in quest of the only face whose features would be known to him.

changes.original: At last it arrested her--and she beheld a striking resemblance of Mr. Darcy, with such a smile over the face, as she remembered to have sometimes seen, when he looked at her.
changes.transformed: At last it arrested him--and he beheld a striking resemblance of Mr. Darcy, with such a smile over the face, as he remembered to have sometimes seen, when he looked at him.

changes.original: She stood several minutes before the picture, in earnest contemplation, and returned to it again before they quitted the gallery.
changes.transformed: He stood several minutes before the picture, in earnest contemplation, and returned to it again before they quitted the gallery.

changes.original: Mrs. Reynolds informed them, that it had been taken in his father’s lifetime.
changes.transformed: Mr. Reynolds informed them, that it had been taken in his father’s lifetime.

changes.original: There was certainly at this moment, in Elizabeth’s mind, a more gentle sensation towards the original than she had ever felt in the height of their acquaintance.
changes.transformed: There was certainly at this moment, in Elliot’s mind, a more gentle sensation towards the original than he had ever felt in the height of their acquaintance.

changes.original: The commendation bestowed on him by Mrs. Reynolds was of no trifling nature.
changes.transformed: The commendation bestowed on him by Mr. Reynolds was of no trifling nature.

changes.original: As a brother, a landlord, a master, she considered how many people’s happiness were in his guardianship!
changes.transformed: As a brother, a landlord, a master, he considered how many people’s happiness were in his guardianship!

changes.original: Every idea that had been brought forward by the housekeeper was favourable to his character; and as she stood before the canvas, on which he was represented, and fixed his eyes upon herself, she thought of his regard with a deeper sentiment of gratitude than it had ever raised before: she remembered its warmth, and softened its impropriety of expression.
changes.transformed: Every idea that had been brought forward by the housekeeper was favourable to his character; and as he stood before the canvas, on which he was represented, and fixed his eyes upon himself, he thought of his regard with a deeper sentiment of gratitude than it had ever raised before: he remembered its warmth, and softened its impropriety of expression.

changes.original: As they walked across the lawn towards the river, Elizabeth turned back to look again; her uncle and aunt stopped also; and while the former was conjecturing as to the date of the building, the owner of it himself suddenly came forward from the road which led behind it to the stables.
changes.transformed: As they walked across the lawn towards the river, Elliot turned back to look again; his uncle and uncle stopped also; and while the former was conjecturing as to the date of the building, the owner of it himself suddenly came forward from the road which led behind it to the stables.

changes.original: He absolutely started, and for a moment seemed immovable from surprise; but shortly recovering himself, advanced towards the party, and spoke to Elizabeth, if not in terms of perfect composure, at least of perfect civility.
changes.transformed: He absolutely started, and for a moment seemed immovable from surprise; but shortly recovering himself, advanced towards the party, and spoke to Elliot, if not in terms of perfect composure, at least of perfect civility.

changes.original: She had instinctively turned away; but stopping on his approach, received his compliments with an embarrassment impossible to be overcome.
changes.transformed: He had instinctively turned away; but stopping on his approach, received his compliments with an embarrassment impossible to be overcome.

changes.original: They stood a little aloof while he was talking to their niece, who, astonished and confused, scarcely dared lift her eyes to his face, and knew not what answer she returned to his civil inquiries after her family.
changes.transformed: They stood a little aloof while he was talking to their nephew, who, astonished and confused, scarcely dared lift his eyes to his face, and knew not what answer he returned to his civil inquiries after his family.

changes.original: Amazed at the alteration of his manner since they last parted, every sentence that he uttered was increasing her embarrassment; and every idea of the impropriety of her being found there recurring to her mind, the few minutes in which they continued together were some of the most uncomfortable of her life.
changes.transformed: Amazed at the alteration of his manner since they last parted, every sentence that he uttered was increasing his embarrassment; and every idea of the impropriety of his being found there recurring to his mind, the few minutes in which they continued together were some of the most uncomfortable of his life.

changes.original: Nor did he seem much more at ease; when he spoke, his accent had none of its usual sedateness; and he repeated his inquiries as to the time of her having left Longbourn, and of her stay in Derbyshire, so often, and in so hurried a way, as plainly spoke the distraction of his thoughts.
changes.transformed: Nor did he seem much more at ease; when he spoke, his accent had none of its usual sedateness; and he repeated his inquiries as to the time of his having left Longbourn, and of his stay in Derbyshire, so often, and in so hurried a way, as plainly spoke the distraction of his thoughts.

changes.original: The others then joined her, and expressed their admiration of his figure; but Elizabeth heard not a word, and, wholly engrossed by her own feelings, followed them in silence.
changes.transformed: The others then joined him, and expressed their admiration of his figure; but Elliot heard not a word, and, wholly engrossed by his own feelings, followed them in silence.

changes.original: She was overpowered by shame and vexation.
changes.transformed: He was overpowered by shame and vexation.

changes.original: Her coming there was the most unfortunate, the most ill-judged thing in the world!
changes.transformed: His coming there was the most unfortunate, the most ill-judged thing in the world!

changes.original: It might seem as if she had purposely thrown herself in his way again!
changes.transformed: It might seem as if he had purposely thrown himself in his way again!

changes.original: Oh! why did she come? or, why did he thus come a day before he was expected?
changes.transformed: Oh! why did he come? or, why did he thus come a day before he was expected?

changes.original: She blushed again and again over the perverseness of the meeting.
changes.transformed: He blushed again and again over the perverseness of the meeting.

changes.original: That he should even speak to her was amazing!--but to speak with such civility, to inquire after her family!
changes.transformed: That he should even speak to him was amazing!--but to speak with such civility, to inquire after his family!

changes.original: Never in her life had she seen his manners so little dignified, never had he spoken with such gentleness as on this unexpected meeting.
changes.transformed: Never in his life had he seen his manners so little dignified, never had he spoken with such gentleness as on this unexpected meeting.

changes.original: What a contrast did it offer to his last address in Rosings Park, when he put his letter into her hand!
changes.transformed: What a contrast did it offer to his last address in Rosings Park, when he put his letter into his hand!

changes.original: She knew not what to think, or how to account for it.
changes.transformed: He knew not what to think, or how to account for it.

changes.original: They had now entered a beautiful walk by the side of the water, and every step was bringing forward a nobler fall of ground, or a finer reach of the woods to which they were approaching: but it was some time before Elizabeth was sensible of any of it; and, though she answered mechanically to the repeated appeals of her uncle and aunt, and seemed to direct her eyes to such objects as they pointed out, she distinguished no part of the scene.
changes.transformed: They had now entered a beautiful walk by the side of the water, and every step was bringing forward a nobler fall of ground, or a finer reach of the woods to which they were approaching: but it was some time before Elliot was sensible of any of it; and, though he answered mechanically to the repeated appeals of his uncle, and seemed to direct his eyes to such objects as they pointed out, he distinguished no part of the scene.

changes.original: Her thoughts were all fixed on that one spot of Pemberley House, whichever it might be, where Mr. Darcy then was.
changes.transformed: His thoughts were all fixed on that one spot of Pemberley House, whichever it might be, where Mr. Darcy then was.

changes.original: She longed to know what at that moment was passing in his mind; in what manner he thought of her, and whether, in defiance of everything, she was still dear to him.
changes.transformed: He longed to know what at that moment was passing in his mind; in what manner he thought of him, and whether, in defiance of everything, he was still dear to him.

changes.original: Whether he had felt more of pain or of pleasure in seeing her, she could not tell, but he certainly had not seen her with composure.
changes.transformed: Whether he had felt more of pain or of pleasure in seeing him, he could not tell, but he certainly had not seen him with composure.

changes.original: At length, however, the remarks of her companions on her absence of mind roused her, and she felt the necessity of appearing more like herself.
changes.transformed: At length, however, the remarks of his companions on his absence of mind roused him, and he felt the necessity of appearing more like himself.

changes.original: Elizabeth longed to explore its windings; but when they had crossed the bridge, and perceived their distance from the house, Mrs. Gardiner, who was not a great walker, could go no farther, and thought only of returning to the carriage as quickly as possible.
changes.transformed: Elliot longed to explore its windings; but when they had crossed the bridge, and perceived their distance from the house, Mr. Gardiner, who was not a great walker, could go no farther, and thought only of returning to the carriage as quickly as possible.

changes.original: Her niece was, therefore, obliged to submit, and they took their way towards the house on the opposite side of the river, in the nearest direction; but their progress was slow, for Mr. Gardiner, though seldom able to indulge the taste, was very fond of fishing, and was so much engaged in watching the occasional appearance of some trout in the water, and talking to the man about them, that he advanced but little.
changes.transformed: His nephew was, therefore, obliged to submit, and they took their way towards the house on the opposite side of the river, in the nearest direction; but their progress was slow, for Mr. Gardiner, though seldom able to indulge the taste, was very fond of fishing, and was so much engaged in watching the occasional appearance of some trout in the water, and talking to the man about them, that he advanced but little.

changes.original: Whilst wandering on in this slow manner, they were again surprised, and Elizabeth’s astonishment was quite equal to what it had been at first, by the sight of Mr. Darcy approaching them, and at no great distance.
changes.transformed: Whilst wandering on in this slow manner, they were again surprised, and Elliot’s astonishment was quite equal to what it had been at first, by the sight of Mr. Darcy approaching them, and at no great distance.

changes.original: Elizabeth, however astonished, was at least more prepared for an interview than before, and resolved to appear and to speak with calmness, if he really intended to meet them.
changes.transformed: Elliot, however astonished, was at least more prepared for an interview than before, and resolved to appear and to speak with calmness, if he really intended to meet them.

changes.original: For a few moments, indeed, she felt that he would probably strike into some other path.
changes.transformed: For a few moments, indeed, he felt that he would probably strike into some other path.

changes.original: With a glance she saw that he had lost none of his recent civility; and, to imitate his politeness, she began as they met to admire the beauty of the place; but she had not got beyond the words “delightful,” and “charming,” when some unlucky recollections obtruded, and she fancied that praise of Pemberley from her might be mischievously construed.
changes.transformed: With a glance he saw that he had lost none of his recent civility; and, to imitate his politeness, he began as they met to admire the beauty of the place; but he had not got beyond the words “delightful,” and “charming,” when some unlucky recollections obtruded, and he fancied that praise of Pemberley from him might be mischievously construed.

changes.original: Her colour changed, and she said no more.
changes.transformed: His colour changed, and he said no more.

changes.original: Mrs. Gardiner was standing a little behind; and on her pausing, he asked her if she would do him the honour of introducing him to her friends.
changes.transformed: Mr. Gardiner was standing a little behind; and on his pausing, he asked him if he would do him the honour of introducing him to his friends.

changes.original: This was a stroke of civility for which she was quite unprepared; and she could hardly suppress a smile at his being now seeking the acquaintance of some of those very people, against whom his pride had revolted, in his offer to herself. “What will be his surprise,” thought she, “when he knows who they are!
changes.transformed: This was a stroke of civility for which he was quite unprepared; and he could hardly suppress a smile at his being now seeking the acquaintance of some of those very people, against whom his pride had revolted, in his offer to himself. “What will be his surprise,” thought he, “when he knows who they are!

changes.original: The introduction, however, was immediately made; and as she named their relationship to herself, she stole a sly look at him, to see how he bore it; and was not without the expectation of his decamping as fast as he could from such disgraceful companions.
changes.transformed: The introduction, however, was immediately made; and as he named their relationship to himself, he stole a sly look at him, to see how he bore it; and was not without the expectation of his decamping as fast as he could from such disgraceful companions.

changes.original: Elizabeth could not but be pleased, could not but triumph.
changes.transformed: Elliot could not but be pleased, could not but triumph.

changes.original: It was consoling that he should know she had some relations for whom there was no need to blush.
changes.transformed: It was consoling that he should know he had some relations for whom there was no need to blush.

changes.original: She listened most attentively to all that passed between them, and gloried in every expression, every sentence of her uncle, which marked his intelligence, his taste, or his good manners.
changes.transformed: He listened most attentively to all that passed between them, and gloried in every expression, every sentence of his uncle, which marked his intelligence, his taste, or his good manners.

changes.original: The conversation soon turned upon fishing; and she heard Mr. Darcy invite him, with the greatest civility, to fish there as often as he chose, while he continued in the neighbourhood, offering at the same time to supply him with fishing tackle, and pointing out those parts of the stream where there was usually most sport.
changes.transformed: The conversation soon turned upon fishing; and he heard Mr. Darcy invite him, with the greatest civility, to fish there as often as he chose, while he continued in the neighbourhood, offering at the same time to supply him with fishing tackle, and pointing out those parts of the stream where there was usually most sport.

changes.original: Mrs. Gardiner, who was walking arm in arm with Elizabeth, gave her a look expressive of her wonder.
changes.transformed: Mr. Gardiner, who was walking arm in arm with Elliot, gave him a look expressive of his wonder.

changes.original: Elizabeth said nothing, but it gratified her exceedingly; the compliment must be all for herself.
changes.transformed: Elliot said nothing, but it gratified him exceedingly; the compliment must be all for himself.

changes.original: Her astonishment, however, was extreme; and continually was she repeating, “Why is he so altered?
changes.transformed: His astonishment, however, was extreme; and continually was he repeating, “Why is he so altered?

changes.original: After walking some time in this way, the two ladies in front, the two gentlemen behind, on resuming their places, after descending to the brink of the river for the better inspection of some curious water-plant, there chanced to be a little alteration.
changes.transformed: After walking some time in this way, the two gentlemen in front, the two gentlemen behind, on resuming their places, after descending to the brink of the river for the better inspection of some curious water-plant, there chanced to be a little alteration.

changes.original: It originated in Mrs. Gardiner, who, fatigued by the exercise of the morning, found Elizabeth’s arm inadequate to her support, and consequently preferred her husband’s.
changes.transformed: It originated in Mr. Gardiner, who, fatigued by the exercise of the morning, found Elliot’s arm inadequate to his support, and consequently preferred his husband’s.

changes.original: Mr. Darcy took her place by her niece, and they walked on together.
changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy took his place by his nephew, and they walked on together.

changes.original: After a short silence the lady first spoke.
changes.transformed: After a short silence the gentleman first spoke.

changes.original: She wished him to know that she had been assured of his absence before she came to the place, and accordingly began by observing, that his arrival had been very unexpected--“for your housekeeper,” she added, “informed us that you would certainly not be here till to-morrow; and, indeed, before we left Bakewell, we understood that you were not immediately expected in the country.” He acknowledged the truth of it all; and said that business with his steward had occasioned his coming forward a few hours before the rest of the party with whom he had been travelling. “They will join me early to-morrow,” he continued, “and among them are some who will claim an acquaintance with you,--Mr. Bingley and his sisters.”
changes.transformed: He wished him to know that he had been assured of his absence before he came to the place, and accordingly began by observing, that his arrival had been very unexpected--“for your housekeeper,” he added, “informed us that you would certainly not be here till to-morrow; and, indeed, before we left Bakewell, we understood that you were not immediately expected in the country.” He acknowledged the truth of it all; and said that business with his steward had occasioned his coming forward a few hours before the rest of the party with whom he had been travelling. “They will join me early to-morrow,” he continued, “and among them are some who will claim an acquaintance with you,--Mr. Bingley and his brothers.”

changes.original: Elizabeth answered only by a slight bow.
changes.transformed: Elliot answered only by a slight bow.

changes.original: Her thoughts were instantly driven back to the time when Mr. Bingley’s name had been last mentioned between them; and if she might judge from his complexion, _his_ mind was not very differently engaged.
changes.transformed: His thoughts were instantly driven back to the time when Mr. Bingley’s name had been last mentioned between them; and if he might judge from his complexion, _his_ mind was not very differently engaged.

changes.original: Will you allow me, or do I ask too much, to introduce my sister to your acquaintance during your stay at Lambton?”
changes.transformed: Will you allow me, or do I ask too much, to introduce my brother to your acquaintance during your stay at Lambton?”

changes.original: The surprise of such an application was great indeed; it was too great for her to know in what manner she acceded to it.
changes.transformed: The surprise of such an application was great indeed; it was too great for him to know in what manner he acceded to it.

changes.original: She immediately felt that whatever desire Miss Darcy might have of being acquainted with her, must be the work of her brother, and without looking farther, it was satisfactory; it was gratifying to know that his resentment had not made him think really ill of her.
changes.transformed: He immediately felt that whatever desire Mr. Darcy might have of being acquainted with him, must be the work of his brother, and without looking farther, it was satisfactory; it was gratifying to know that his resentment had not made him think really ill of him.

changes.original: Elizabeth was not comfortable; that was impossible; but she was flattered and pleased.
changes.transformed: Elliot was not comfortable; that was impossible; but he was flattered and pleased.

changes.original: His wish of introducing his sister to her was a compliment of the highest kind.
changes.transformed: His wish of introducing his brother to him was a compliment of the highest kind.

changes.original: They soon outstripped the others; and when they had reached the carriage, Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner were half a quarter of a mile behind.
changes.transformed: They soon outstripped the others; and when they had reached the carriage, Mr. and Mr. Gardiner were half a quarter of a mile behind.

changes.original: He then asked her to walk into the house--but she declared herself not tired, and they stood together on the lawn.
changes.transformed: He then asked him to walk into the house--but he declared himself not tired, and they stood together on the lawn.

changes.original: She wanted to talk, but there seemed an embargo on every subject.
changes.transformed: He wanted to talk, but there seemed an embargo on every subject.

changes.original: At last she recollected that she had been travelling, and they talked of Matlock and Dovedale with great perseverance.
changes.transformed: At last he recollected that he had been travelling, and they talked of Matlock and Dovedale with great perseverance.

changes.original: Yet time and her aunt moved slowly--and her patience and her ideas were nearly worn out before the _tête-à-tête_ was over.
changes.transformed: Yet time and his uncle moved slowly--and his patience and his ideas were nearly worn out before the _tête-à-tête_ was over.

changes.original: On Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner’s coming up they were all pressed to go into the house and take some refreshment; but this was declined, and they parted on each side with the utmost politeness.
changes.transformed: On Mr. Gardiner’s coming up they were all pressed to go into the house and take some refreshment; but this was declined, and they parted on each side with the utmost politeness.

changes.original: Mr. Darcy handed the ladies into the carriage; and when it drove off, Elizabeth saw him walking slowly towards the house.
changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy handed the gentlemen into the carriage; and when it drove off, Elliot saw him walking slowly towards the house.

changes.original: The observations of her uncle and aunt now began; and each of them pronounced him to be infinitely superior to anything they had expected.
changes.transformed: The observations of his uncle now began; and each of them pronounced him to be infinitely superior to anything they had expected.

changes.original: “He is perfectly well-behaved, polite, and unassuming,” said her uncle.
changes.transformed: “He is perfectly well-behaved, polite, and unassuming,” said his uncle.

changes.original: “There _is_ something a little stately in him, to be sure,” replied her aunt; “but it is confined to his air, and is not unbecoming.
changes.transformed: “There _is_ something a little stately in him, to be sure,” replied his uncle; “but it is confined to his air, and is not unbecoming.

changes.original: His acquaintance with Elizabeth was very trifling.”
changes.transformed: His acquaintance with Elliot was very trifling.”

changes.original: “To be sure, Lizzy,” said her aunt, “he is not so handsome as Wickham; or rather he has not Wickham’s countenance, for his features are perfectly good.
changes.transformed: “To be sure, Elliot,” said his uncle, “he is not so handsome as Wickham; or rather he has not Wickham’s countenance, for his features are perfectly good.

changes.original: Elizabeth excused herself as well as she could: said that she had liked him better when they met in Kent than before, and that she had never seen him so pleasant as this morning.
changes.transformed: Elliot excused himself as well as he could: said that he had liked him better when they met in Kent than before, and that he had never seen him so pleasant as this morning.

changes.original: “But perhaps he may be a little whimsical in his civilities,” replied her uncle. “Your great men often are; and therefore I shall not take him at his word about fishing, as he might change his mind another day, and warn me off his grounds.”
changes.transformed: “But perhaps he may be a little whimsical in his civilities,” replied his uncle. “Your great men often are; and therefore I shall not take him at his word about fishing, as he might change his mind another day, and warn me off his grounds.”

changes.original: Elizabeth felt that they had entirely mistaken his character, but said nothing.
changes.transformed: Elliot felt that they had entirely mistaken his character, but said nothing.

changes.original: “From what we have seen of him,” continued Mrs. Gardiner, “I really should not have thought that he could have behaved in so cruel a way by anybody as he has done by poor Wickham.
changes.transformed: “From what we have seen of him,” continued Mr. Gardiner, “I really should not have thought that he could have behaved in so cruel a way by anybody as he has done by poor Wickham.

changes.original: But, to be sure, the good lady who showed us the house did give him a most flaming character!
changes.transformed: But, to be sure, the good gentleman who showed us the house did give him a most flaming character!

changes.original: Elizabeth here felt herself called on to say something in vindication of his behaviour to Wickham; and, therefore, gave them to understand, in as guarded a manner as she could, that by what she had heard from his relations in Kent, his actions were capable of a very different construction; and that his character was by no means so faulty, nor Wickham’s so amiable, as they had been considered in Hertfordshire.
changes.transformed: Elliot here felt himself called on to say something in vindication of his behaviour to Wickham; and, therefore, gave them to understand, in as guarded a manner as he could, that by what he had heard from his relations in Kent, his actions were capable of a very different construction; and that his character was by no means so faulty, nor Wickham’s so amiable, as they had been considered in Hertfordshire.

changes.original: In confirmation of this, she related the particulars of all the pecuniary transactions in which they had been connected, without actually naming her authority, but stating it to be such as might be relied on.
changes.transformed: In confirmation of this, he related the particulars of all the pecuniary transactions in which they had been connected, without actually naming his authority, but stating it to be such as might be relied on.

changes.original: Mrs. Gardiner was surprised and concerned: but as they were now approaching the scene of her former pleasures, every idea gave way to the charm of recollection; and she was too much engaged in pointing out to her husband all the interesting spots in its environs, to think of anything else.
changes.transformed: Mr. Gardiner was surprised and concerned: but as they were now approaching the scene of his former pleasures, every idea gave way to the charm of recollection; and he was too much engaged in pointing out to his husband all the interesting spots in its environs, to think of anything else.

changes.original: Fatigued as she had been by the morning’s walk, they had no sooner dined than she set off again in quest of her former acquaintance, and the evening was spent in the satisfactions of an intercourse renewed after many years’ discontinuance.
changes.transformed: Fatigued as he had been by the morning’s walk, they had no sooner dined than he set off again in quest of his former acquaintance, and the evening was spent in the satisfactions of an intercourse renewed after many years’ discontinuance.

changes.original: The occurrences of the day were too full of interest to leave Elizabeth much attention for any of these new friends; and she could do nothing but think, and think with wonder, of Mr. Darcy’s civility, and, above all, of his wishing her to be acquainted with his sister.
changes.transformed: The occurrences of the day were too full of interest to leave Elliot much attention for any of these new friends; and he could do nothing but think, and think with wonder, of Mr. Darcy’s civility, and, above all, of his wishing him to be acquainted with his brother.

changes.original: Elizabeth had settled it that Mr. Darcy would bring his sister to visit her the very day after her reaching Pemberley; and was, consequently, resolved not to be out of sight of the inn the whole of that morning.
changes.transformed: Elliot had settled it that Mr. Darcy would bring his brother to visit him the very day after his reaching Pemberley; and was, consequently, resolved not to be out of sight of the inn the whole of that morning.

changes.original: But her conclusion was false; for on the very morning after their own arrival at Lambton these visitors came.
changes.transformed: But his conclusion was false; for on the very morning after their own arrival at Lambton these visitors came.

changes.original: They had been walking about the place with some of their new friends, and were just returned to the inn to dress themselves for dining with the same family, when the sound of a carriage drew them to a window, and they saw a gentleman and lady in a curricle driving up the street.
changes.transformed: They had been walking about the place with some of their new friends, and were just returned to the inn to dress themselves for dining with the same family, when the sound of a carriage drew them to a window, and they saw a gentleman and gentleman in a curricle driving up the street.

changes.original: Elizabeth, immediately recognizing the livery, guessed what it meant, and imparted no small degree of surprise to her relations, by acquainting them with the honour which she expected.
changes.transformed: Elliot, immediately recognizing the livery, guessed what it meant, and imparted no small degree of surprise to his relations, by acquainting them with the honour which he expected.

changes.original: Her uncle and aunt were all amazement; and the embarrassment of her manner as she spoke, joined to the circumstance itself, and many of the circumstances of the preceding day, opened to them a new idea on the business.
changes.transformed: His uncle and uncle were all amazement; and the embarrassment of his manner as he spoke, joined to the circumstance itself, and many of the circumstances of the preceding day, opened to them a new idea on the business.

changes.original: Nothing had ever suggested it before, but they now felt that there was no other way of accounting for such attentions from such a quarter than by supposing a partiality for their niece.
changes.transformed: Nothing had ever suggested it before, but they now felt that there was no other way of accounting for such attentions from such a quarter than by supposing a partiality for their nephew.

changes.original: While these newly-born notions were passing in their heads, the perturbation of Elizabeth’s feelings was every moment increasing.
changes.transformed: While these newly-born notions were passing in their heads, the perturbation of Elliot’s feelings was every moment increasing.

changes.original: She was quite amazed at her own discomposure; but, amongst other causes of disquiet, she dreaded lest the partiality of the brother should have said too much in her favour; and, more than commonly anxious to please, she naturally suspected that every power of pleasing would fail her.
changes.transformed: He was quite amazed at his own discomposure; but, amongst other causes of disquiet, he dreaded lest the partiality of the brother should have said too much in his favour; and, more than commonly anxious to please, he naturally suspected that every power of pleasing would fail him.

changes.original: She retreated from the window, fearful of being seen; and as she walked up and down the room, endeavouring to compose herself, saw such looks of inquiring surprise in her uncle and aunt as made everything worse.
changes.transformed: He retreated from the window, fearful of being seen; and as he walked up and down the room, endeavouring to compose himself, saw such looks of inquiring surprise in his uncle and uncle as made everything worse.

changes.original: Miss Darcy and her brother appeared, and this formidable introduction took place.
changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy and his brother appeared, and this formidable introduction took place.

changes.original: With astonishment did Elizabeth see that her new acquaintance was at least as much embarrassed as herself.
changes.transformed: With astonishment did Elliot see that his new acquaintance was at least as much embarrassed as himself.

changes.original: Since her being at Lambton, she had heard that Miss Darcy was exceedingly proud; but the observation of a very few minutes convinced her that she was only exceedingly shy.
changes.transformed: Since his being at Lambton, he had heard that Mr. Darcy was exceedingly proud; but the observation of a very few minutes convinced him that he was only exceedingly shy.

changes.original: She found it difficult to obtain even a word from her beyond a monosyllable.
changes.transformed: He found it difficult to obtain even a word from him beyond a monosyllable.

changes.original: Miss Darcy was tall, and on a larger scale than Elizabeth; and, though little more than sixteen, her figure was formed, and her appearance womanly and graceful.
changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy was tall, and on a larger scale than Elliot; and, though little more than sixteen, his figure was formed, and his appearance manly and graceful.

changes.original: She was less handsome than her brother, but there was sense and good-humour in her face, and her manners were perfectly unassuming and gentle.
changes.transformed: He was less handsome than his brother, but there was sense and good-humour in his face, and his manners were perfectly unassuming and gentle.

changes.original: Elizabeth, who had expected to find in her as acute and unembarrassed an observer as ever Mr. Darcy had been, was much relieved by discerning such different feelings.
changes.transformed: Elliot, who had expected to find in him as acute and unembarrassed an observer as ever Mr. Darcy had been, was much relieved by discerning such different feelings.

changes.original: They had not been long together before Darcy told her that Bingley was also coming to wait on her; and she had barely time to express her satisfaction, and prepare for such a visitor, when Bingley’s quick step was heard on the stairs, and in a moment he entered the room.
changes.transformed: They had not been long together before Darcy told him that Bingley was also coming to wait on him; and he had barely time to express his satisfaction, and prepare for such a visitor, when Bingley’s quick step was heard on the stairs, and in a moment he entered the room.

changes.original: All Elizabeth’s anger against him had been long done away; but had she still felt any, it could hardly have stood its ground against the unaffected cordiality with which he expressed himself on seeing her again.
changes.transformed: All Elliot’s anger against him had been long done away; but had he still felt any, it could hardly have stood its ground against the unaffected cordiality with which he expressed himself on seeing him again.

changes.original: He inquired in a friendly, though general, way, after her family, and looked and spoke with the same good-humoured ease that he had ever done.
changes.transformed: He inquired in a friendly, though general, way, after his family, and looked and spoke with the same good-humoured ease that he had ever done.

changes.original: To Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner he was scarcely a less interesting personage than to herself.
changes.transformed: To Mr. and Mr. Gardiner he was scarcely a less interesting personage than to himself.

changes.original: The suspicions which had just arisen of Mr. Darcy and their niece, directed their observation towards each with an earnest, though guarded, inquiry; and they soon drew from those inquiries the full conviction that one of them at least knew what it was to love.
changes.transformed: The suspicions which had just arisen of Mr. Darcy and their nephew, directed their observation towards each with an earnest, though guarded, inquiry; and they soon drew from those inquiries the full conviction that one of them at least knew what it was to love.

changes.original: Of the lady’s sensations they remained a little in doubt; but that the gentleman was overflowing with admiration was evident enough.
changes.transformed: Of the gentleman’s sensations they remained a little in doubt; but that the gentleman was overflowing with admiration was evident enough.

changes.original: Elizabeth, on her side, had much to do.
changes.transformed: Elliot, on his side, had much to do.

changes.original: She wanted to ascertain the feelings of each of her visitors, she wanted to compose her own, and to make herself agreeable to all; and in the latter object, where she feared most to fail, she was most sure of success, for those to whom she endeavoured to give pleasure were pre-possessed in her favour.
changes.transformed: He wanted to ascertain the feelings of each of his visitors, he wanted to compose his own, and to make himself agreeable to all; and in the latter object, where he feared most to fail, he was most sure of success, for those to whom he endeavoured to give pleasure were pre-possessed in his favour.

changes.original: Bingley was ready, Georgiana was eager, and Darcy determined, to be pleased.
changes.transformed: Bingley was ready, George was eager, and Darcy determined, to be pleased.

changes.original: In seeing Bingley, her thoughts naturally flew to her sister; and oh! how ardently did she long to know whether any of his were directed in a like manner.
changes.transformed: In seeing Bingley, his thoughts naturally flew to his brother; and oh! how ardently did he long to know whether any of his were directed in a like manner.

changes.original: Sometimes she could fancy that he talked less than on former occasions, and once or twice pleased herself with the notion that, as he looked at her, he was trying to trace a resemblance.
changes.transformed: Sometimes he could fancy that he talked less than on former occasions, and once or twice pleased himself with the notion that, as he looked at him, he was trying to trace a resemblance.

changes.original: But, though this might be imaginary, she could not be deceived as to his behaviour to Miss Darcy, who had been set up as a rival to Jane.
changes.transformed: But, though this might be imaginary, he could not be deceived as to his behaviour to Mr. Darcy, who had been set up as a rival to John.

changes.original: Nothing occurred between them that could justify the hopes of his sister.
changes.transformed: Nothing occurred between them that could justify the hopes of his brother.

changes.original: On this point she was soon satisfied; and two or three little circumstances occurred ere they parted, which, in her anxious interpretation, denoted a recollection of Jane, not untinctured by tenderness, and a wish of saying more that might lead to the mention of her, had he dared.
changes.transformed: On this point he was soon satisfied; and two or three little circumstances occurred ere they parted, which, in his anxious interpretation, denoted a recollection of John, not untinctured by tenderness, and a wish of saying more that might lead to the mention of him, had he dared.

changes.original: He observed to her, at a moment when the others were talking together, and in a tone which had something of real regret, that it “was a very long time since he had had the pleasure of seeing her;” and, before she could reply, he added, “It is above eight months.
changes.transformed: He observed to him, at a moment when the others were talking together, and in a tone which had something of real regret, that it “was a very long time since he had had the pleasure of seeing him;” and, before he could reply, he added, “It is above eight months.

changes.original: Elizabeth was pleased to find his memory so exact; and he afterwards took occasion to ask her, when unattended to by any of the rest, whether _all_ her sisters were at Longbourn.
changes.transformed: Elliot was pleased to find his memory so exact; and he afterwards took occasion to ask him, when unattended to by any of the rest, whether _all_ his brothers were at Longbourn.

changes.original: It was not often that she could turn her eyes on Mr. Darcy himself; but whenever she did catch a glimpse she saw an expression of general complaisance, and in all that he said, she heard an accent so far removed from _hauteur_ or disdain of his companions, as convinced her that the improvement of manners which she had yesterday witnessed, however temporary its existence might prove, had at least outlived one day.
changes.transformed: It was not often that he could turn his eyes on Mr. Darcy himself; but whenever he did catch a glimpse he saw an expression of general complaisance, and in all that he said, he heard an accent so far removed from _hauteur_ or disdain of his companions, as convinced him that the improvement of manners which he had yesterday witnessed, however temporary its existence might prove, had at least outlived one day.

changes.original: When she saw him thus seeking the acquaintance, and courting the good opinion of people with whom any intercourse a few months ago would have been a disgrace; when she saw him thus civil, not only to herself, but to the very relations whom he had openly disdained, and recollected their last lively scene in Hunsford Parsonage, the difference, the change was so great, and struck so forcibly on her mind, that she could hardly restrain her astonishment from being visible.
changes.transformed: When he saw him thus seeking the acquaintance, and courting the good opinion of people with whom any intercourse a few months ago would have been a disgrace; when he saw him thus civil, not only to himself, but to the very relations whom he had openly disdained, and recollected their last lively scene in Hunsford Parsonage, the difference, the change was so great, and struck so forcibly on his mind, that he could hardly restrain his astonishment from being visible.

changes.original: Never, even in the company of his dear friends at Netherfield, or his dignified relations at Rosings, had she seen him so desirous to please, so free from self-consequence or unbending reserve, as now, when no importance could result from the success of his endeavours, and when even the acquaintance of those to whom his attentions were addressed, would draw down the ridicule and censure of the ladies both of Netherfield and Rosings.
changes.transformed: Never, even in the company of his dear friends at Netherfield, or his dignified relations at Rosings, had he seen him so desirous to please, so free from self-consequence or unbending reserve, as now, when no importance could result from the success of his endeavours, and when even the acquaintance of those to whom his attentions were addressed, would draw down the ridicule and censure of the gentlemen both of Netherfield and Rosings.

changes.original: Their visitors stayed with them above half an hour; and when they arose to depart, Mr. Darcy called on his sister to join him in expressing their wish of seeing Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner, and Miss Bennet, to dinner at Pemberley, before they left the country.
changes.transformed: Their visitors stayed with them above half an hour; and when they arose to depart, Mr. Darcy called on his brother to join him in expressing their wish of seeing Mr. and Mr. Gardiner, and Mr. Bennet, to dinner at Pemberley, before they left the country.

changes.original: Miss Darcy, though with a diffidence which marked her little in the habit of giving invitations, readily obeyed.
changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy, though with a diffidence which marked him little in the habit of giving invitations, readily obeyed.

changes.original: Mrs. Gardiner looked at her niece, desirous of knowing how _she_, whom the invitation most concerned, felt disposed as to its acceptance, but Elizabeth had turned away her head.
changes.transformed: Mr. Gardiner looked at his nephew, desirous of knowing how _he_, whom the invitation most concerned, felt disposed as to its acceptance, but Elliot had turned away his head.

changes.original: Presuming, however, that this studied avoidance spoke rather a momentary embarrassment than any dislike of the proposal, and seeing in her husband, who was fond of society, a perfect willingness to accept it, she ventured to engage for her attendance, and the day after the next was fixed on.
changes.transformed: Presuming, however, that this studied avoidance spoke rather a momentary embarrassment than any dislike of the proposal, and seeing in his husband, who was fond of society, a perfect willingness to accept it, he ventured to engage for his attendance, and the day after the next was fixed on.

changes.original: Bingley expressed great pleasure in the certainty of seeing Elizabeth again, having still a great deal to say to her, and many inquiries to make after all their Hertfordshire friends.
changes.transformed: Bingley expressed great pleasure in the certainty of seeing Elliot again, having still a great deal to say to him, and many inquiries to make after all their Hertfordshire friends.

changes.original: Elizabeth, construing all this into a wish of hearing her speak of her sister, was pleased; and on this account, as well as some others, found herself, when their visitors left them, capable of considering the last half hour with some satisfaction, though while it was passing the enjoyment of it had been little.
changes.transformed: Elliot, construing all this into a wish of hearing him speak of his brother, was pleased; and on this account, as well as some others, found himself, when their visitors left them, capable of considering the last half hour with some satisfaction, though while it was passing the enjoyment of it had been little.

changes.original: Eager to be alone, and fearful of inquiries or hints from her uncle and aunt, she stayed with them only long enough to hear their favourable opinion of Bingley, and then hurried away to dress.
changes.transformed: Eager to be alone, and fearful of inquiries or hints from his uncle and uncle, he stayed with them only long enough to hear their favourable opinion of Bingley, and then hurried away to dress.

changes.original: But she had no reason to fear Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner’s curiosity; it was not their wish to force her communication.
changes.transformed: But he had no reason to fear Mr. and Mr. Gardiner’s curiosity; it was not their wish to force his communication.

changes.original: It was evident that she was much better acquainted with Mr. Darcy than they had before any idea of; it was evident that he was very much in love with her.
changes.transformed: It was evident that he was much better acquainted with Mr. Darcy than they had before any idea of; it was evident that he was very much in love with him.

changes.original: As for Elizabeth, her thoughts were at Pemberley this evening more than the last; and the evening, though as it passed it seemed long, was not long enough to determine her feelings towards _one_ in that mansion; and she lay awake two whole hours, endeavouring to make them out.
changes.transformed: As for Elliot, his thoughts were at Pemberley this evening more than the last; and the evening, though as it passed it seemed long, was not long enough to determine his feelings towards _one_ in that mansion; and he lay awake two whole hours, endeavouring to make them out.

changes.original: She certainly did not hate him.
changes.transformed: He certainly did not hate him.

changes.original: No; hatred had vanished long ago, and she had almost as long been ashamed of ever feeling a dislike against him, that could be so called.
changes.transformed: No; hatred had vanished long ago, and he had almost as long been ashamed of ever feeling a dislike against him, that could be so called.

changes.original: The respect created by the conviction of his valuable qualities, though at first unwillingly admitted, had for some time ceased to be repugnant to her feelings; and it was now heightened into somewhat of a friendlier nature by the testimony so highly in his favour, and bringing forward his disposition in so amiable a light, which yesterday had produced.
changes.transformed: The respect created by the conviction of his valuable qualities, though at first unwillingly admitted, had for some time ceased to be repugnant to his feelings; and it was now heightened into somewhat of a friendlier nature by the testimony so highly in his favour, and bringing forward his disposition in so amiable a light, which yesterday had produced.

changes.original: But above all, above respect and esteem, there was a motive within her of good-will which could not be overlooked.
changes.transformed: But above all, above respect and esteem, there was a motive within him of good-will which could not be overlooked.

changes.original: It was gratitude;--gratitude, not merely for having once loved her, but for loving her still well enough to forgive all the petulance and acrimony of her manner in rejecting him, and all the unjust accusations accompanying her rejection.
changes.transformed: It was gratitude;--gratitude, not merely for having once loved him, but for loving him still well enough to forgive all the petulance and acrimony of his manner in rejecting him, and all the unjust accusations accompanying his rejection.

changes.original: He who, she had been persuaded, would avoid her as his greatest enemy, seemed, on this accidental meeting, most eager to preserve the acquaintance; and without any indelicate display of regard, or any peculiarity of manner, where their two selves only were concerned, was soliciting the good opinion of her friends, and bent on making her known to his sister.
changes.transformed: He who, he had been persuaded, would avoid him as his greatest enemy, seemed, on this accidental meeting, most eager to preserve the acquaintance; and without any indelicate display of regard, or any peculiarity of manner, where their two selves only were concerned, was soliciting the good opinion of his friends, and bent on making him known to his brother.

changes.original: Such a change in a man of so much pride excited not only astonishment but gratitude--for to love, ardent love, it must be attributed; and, as such, its impression on her was of a sort to be encouraged, as by no means unpleasing, though it could not be exactly defined.
changes.transformed: Such a change in a man of so much pride excited not only astonishment but gratitude--for to love, ardent love, it must be attributed; and, as such, its impression on him was of a sort to be encouraged, as by no means unpleasing, though it could not be exactly defined.

changes.original: She respected, she esteemed, she was grateful to him, she felt a real interest in his welfare; and she only wanted to know how far she wished that welfare to depend upon herself, and how far it would be for the happiness of both that she should employ the power, which her fancy told her she still possessed, of bringing on the renewal of his addresses.
changes.transformed: He respected, he esteemed, he was grateful to him, he felt a real interest in his welfare; and he only wanted to know how far he wished that welfare to depend upon himself, and how far it would be for the happiness of both that he should employ the power, which his fancy told him he still possessed, of bringing on the renewal of his addresses.

changes.original: It had been settled in the evening, between the aunt and niece, that such a striking civility as Miss Darcy’s, in coming to them on the very day of her arrival at Pemberley--for she had reached it only to a late breakfast--ought to be imitated, though it could not be equalled, by some exertion of politeness on their side; and, consequently, that it would be highly expedient to wait on her at Pemberley the following morning.
changes.transformed: It had been settled in the evening, between the uncle and nephew, that such a striking civility as Mr. Darcy’s, in coming to them on the very day of his arrival at Pemberley--for he had reached it only to a late breakfast--ought to be imitated, though it could not be equalled, by some exertion of politeness on their side; and, consequently, that it would be highly expedient to wait on him at Pemberley the following morning.

changes.original: Elizabeth was pleased; though when she asked herself the reason, she had very little to say in reply.
changes.transformed: Elliot was pleased; though when he asked himself the reason, he had very little to say in reply.

changes.original: Convinced as Elizabeth now was that Miss Bingley’s dislike of her had originated in jealousy, she could not help feeling how very unwelcome her appearance at Pemberley must be to her, and was curious to know with how much civility on that lady’s side the acquaintance would now be renewed.
changes.transformed: Convinced as Elliot now was that Mr. Bingley’s dislike of him had originated in jealousy, he could not help feeling how very unwelcome his appearance at Pemberley must be to him, and was curious to know with how much civility on that gentleman’s side the acquaintance would now be renewed.

changes.original: In this room they were received by Miss Darcy, who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley, and the lady with whom she lived in London.
changes.transformed: In this room they were received by Mr. Darcy, who was sitting there with Mr. Hurst and Mr. Bingley, and the gentleman with whom he lived in London.

changes.original: Georgiana’s reception of them was very civil, but attended with all that embarrassment which, though proceeding from shyness and the fear of doing wrong, would easily give to those who felt themselves inferior the belief of her being proud and reserved.
changes.transformed: George’s reception of them was very civil, but attended with all that embarrassment which, though proceeding from shyness and the fear of doing wrong, would easily give to those who felt themselves inferior the belief of him being proud and reserved.

changes.original: Mrs. Gardiner and her niece, however, did her justice, and pitied her.
changes.transformed: Mr. Gardiner and his nephew, however, did him justice, and pitied him.

changes.original: By Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley they were noticed only by a courtesy; and on their being seated, a pause, awkward as such pauses must always be, succeeded for a few moments.
changes.transformed: By Mr. Hurst and Mr. Bingley they were noticed only by a courtesy; and on their being seated, a pause, awkward as such pauses must always be, succeeded for a few moments.

changes.original: It was first broken by Mrs. Annesley, a genteel, agreeable-looking woman, whose endeavour to introduce some kind of discourse proved her to be more truly well-bred than either of the others; and between her and Mrs. Gardiner, with occasional help from Elizabeth, the conversation was carried on.
changes.transformed: It was first broken by Mr. Annesley, a genteel, agreeable-looking man, whose endeavour to introduce some kind of discourse proved him to be more truly well-bred than either of the others; and between him and Mr. Gardiner, with occasional help from Elliot, the conversation was carried on.

changes.original: Miss Darcy looked as if she wished for courage enough to join in it; and sometimes did venture a short sentence, when there was least danger of its being heard.
changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy looked as if he wished for courage enough to join in it; and sometimes did venture a short sentence, when there was least danger of its being heard.

changes.original: Elizabeth soon saw that she was herself closely watched by Miss Bingley, and that she could not speak a word, especially to Miss Darcy, without calling her attention.
changes.transformed: Elliot soon saw that he was himself closely watched by Mr. Bingley, and that he could not speak a word, especially to Mr. Darcy, without calling his attention.

changes.original: This observation would not have prevented her from trying to talk to the latter, had they not been seated at an inconvenient distance; but she was not sorry to be spared the necessity of saying much: her own thoughts were employing her.
changes.transformed: This observation would not have prevented him from trying to talk to the latter, had they not been seated at an inconvenient distance; but he was not sorry to be spared the necessity of saying much: his own thoughts were employing him.

changes.original: She expected every moment that some of the gentlemen would enter the room: she wished, she feared, that the master of the house might be amongst them; and whether she wished or feared it most, she could scarcely determine.
changes.transformed: He expected every moment that some of the gentlemen would enter the room: he wished, he feared, that the master of the house might be amongst them; and whether he wished or feared it most, he could scarcely determine.

changes.original: After sitting in this manner a quarter of an hour, without hearing Miss Bingley’s voice, Elizabeth was roused by receiving from her a cold inquiry after the health of her family.
changes.transformed: After sitting in this manner a quarter of an hour, without hearing Mr. Bingley’s voice, Elliot was roused by receiving from him a cold inquiry after the health of his family.

changes.original: She answered with equal indifference and brevity, and the other said no more.
changes.transformed: He answered with equal indifference and brevity, and the other said no more.

changes.original: The next variation which their visit afforded was produced by the entrance of servants with cold meat, cake, and a variety of all the finest fruits in season; but this did not take place till after many a significant look and smile from Mrs. Annesley to Miss Darcy had been given, to remind her of her post.
changes.transformed: The next variation which their visit afforded was produced by the entrance of servants with cold meat, cake, and a variety of all the finest fruits in season; but this did not take place till after many a significant look and smile from Mr. Annesley to Mr. Darcy had been given, to remind him of his post.

changes.original: While thus engaged, Elizabeth had a fair opportunity of deciding whether she most feared or wished for the appearance of Mr. Darcy, by the feelings which prevailed on his entering the room; and then, though but a moment before she had believed her wishes to predominate, she began to regret that he came.
changes.transformed: While thus engaged, Elliot had a fair opportunity of deciding whether he most feared or wished for the appearance of Mr. Darcy, by the feelings which prevailed on his entering the room; and then, though but a moment before he had believed his wishes to predominate, he began to regret that he came.

changes.original: He had been some time with Mr. Gardiner, who, with two or three other gentlemen from the house, was engaged by the river; and had left him only on learning that the ladies of the family intended a visit to Georgiana that morning.
changes.transformed: He had been some time with Mr. Gardiner, who, with two or three other gentlemen from the house, was engaged by the river; and had left him only on learning that the gentlemen of the family intended a visit to George that morning.

changes.original: No sooner did he appear, than Elizabeth wisely resolved to be perfectly easy and unembarrassed;--a resolution the more necessary to be made, but perhaps not the more easily kept, because she saw that the suspicions of the whole party were awakened against them, and that there was scarcely an eye which did not watch his behaviour when he first came into the room.
changes.transformed: No sooner did he appear, than Elliot wisely resolved to be perfectly easy and unembarrassed;--a resolution the more necessary to be made, but perhaps not the more easily kept, because he saw that the suspicions of the whole party were awakened against them, and that there was scarcely an eye which did not watch his behaviour when he first came into the room.

changes.original: In no countenance was attentive curiosity so strongly marked as in Miss Bingley’s, in spite of the smiles which overspread her face whenever she spoke to one of its objects; for jealousy had not yet made her desperate, and her attentions to Mr. Darcy were by no means over.
changes.transformed: In no countenance was attentive curiosity so strongly marked as in Mr. Bingley’s, in spite of the smiles which overspread his face whenever he spoke to one of its objects; for jealousy had not yet made him desperate, and his attentions to Mr. Darcy were by no means over.

changes.original: Miss Darcy, on her brother’s entrance, exerted herself much more to talk; and Elizabeth saw that he was anxious for his sister and herself to get acquainted, and forwarded, as much as possible, every attempt at conversation on either side.
changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy, on his brother’s entrance, exerted himself much more to talk; and Elliot saw that he was anxious for his brother and himself to get acquainted, and forwarded, as much as possible, every attempt at conversation on either side.

changes.original: Miss Bingley saw all this likewise; and, in the imprudence of anger, took the first opportunity of saying, with sneering civility,--
changes.transformed: Mr. Bingley saw all this likewise; and, in the imprudence of anger, took the first opportunity of saying, with sneering civility,--

changes.original: “Pray, Miss Eliza, are not the ----shire militia removed from Meryton?
changes.transformed: “Pray, Mr. Elliot, are not the ----shire militia removed from Meryton?

changes.original: In Darcy’s presence she dared not mention Wickham’s name: but Elizabeth instantly comprehended that he was uppermost in her thoughts; and the various recollections connected with him gave her a moment’s distress; but, exerting herself vigorously to repel the ill-natured attack, she presently answered the question in a tolerably disengaged tone.
changes.transformed: In Darcy’s presence he dared not mention Wickham’s name: but Elliot instantly comprehended that he was uppermost in his thoughts; and the various recollections connected with him gave him a moment’s distress; but, exerting himself vigorously to repel the ill-natured attack, he presently answered the question in a tolerably disengaged tone.

changes.original: While she spoke, an involuntary glance showed her Darcy with a heightened complexion, earnestly looking at her, and his sister overcome with confusion, and unable to lift up her eyes.
changes.transformed: While he spoke, an involuntary glance showed him Darcy with a heightened complexion, earnestly looking at him, and his brother overcome with confusion, and unable to lift up his eyes.

changes.original: Had Miss Bingley known what pain she was then giving her beloved friend, she undoubtedly would have refrained from the hint; but she had merely intended to discompose Elizabeth, by bringing forward the idea of a man to whom she believed her partial, to make her betray a sensibility which might injure her in Darcy’s opinion, and, perhaps, to remind the latter of all the follies and absurdities by which some part of her family were connected with that corps.
changes.transformed: Had Mr. Bingley known what pain he was then giving his beloved friend, he undoubtedly would have refrained from the hint; but he had merely intended to discompose Elliot, by bringing forward the idea of a man to whom he believed him partial, to make him betray a sensibility which might injure him in Darcy’s opinion, and, perhaps, to remind the latter of all the follies and absurdities by which some part of his family were connected with that corps.

changes.original: Not a syllable had ever reached her of Miss Darcy’s meditated elopement.
changes.transformed: Not a syllable had ever reached him of Mr. Darcy’s meditated elopement.

changes.original: To no creature had it been revealed, where secrecy was possible, except to Elizabeth; and from all Bingley’s connections her brother was particularly anxious to conceal it, from that very wish which Elizabeth had long ago attributed to him, of their becoming hereafter her own.
changes.transformed: To no creature had it been revealed, where secrecy was possible, except to Elliot; and from all Bingley’s connections his brother was particularly anxious to conceal it, from that very wish which Elliot had long ago attributed to him, of their becoming hereafter his own.

changes.original: He had certainly formed such a plan; and without meaning that it should affect his endeavour to separate him from Miss Bennet, it is probable that it might add something to his lively concern for the welfare of his friend.
changes.transformed: He had certainly formed such a plan; and without meaning that it should affect his endeavour to separate him from Mr. Bennet, it is probable that it might add something to his lively concern for the welfare of his friend.

changes.original: Elizabeth’s collected behaviour, however, soon quieted his emotion; and as Miss Bingley, vexed and disappointed, dared not approach nearer to Wickham, Georgiana also recovered in time, though not enough to be able to speak any more.
changes.transformed: Elliot’s collected behaviour, however, soon quieted his emotion; and as Mr. Bingley, vexed and disappointed, dared not approach nearer to Wickham, George also recovered in time, though not enough to be able to speak any more.

changes.original: Her brother, whose eye she feared to meet, scarcely recollected her interest in the affair; and the very circumstance which had been designed to turn his thoughts from Elizabeth, seemed to have fixed them on her more and more cheerfully.
changes.transformed: His brother, whose eye he feared to meet, scarcely recollected his interest in the affair; and the very circumstance which had been designed to turn his thoughts from Elliot, seemed to have fixed them on him more and more cheerfully.

changes.original: Their visit did not continue long after the question and answer above mentioned; and while Mr. Darcy was attending them to their carriage, Miss Bingley was venting her feelings in criticisms on Elizabeth’s person, behaviour, and dress.
changes.transformed: Their visit did not continue long after the question and answer above mentioned; and while Mr. Darcy was attending them to their carriage, Mr. Bingley was venting his feelings in criticisms on Elliot’s person, behaviour, and dress.

changes.original: But Georgiana would not join her.
changes.transformed: But George would not join him.

changes.original: Her brother’s recommendation was enough to insure her favour: his judgment could not err; and he had spoken in such terms of Elizabeth, as to leave Georgiana without the power of finding her otherwise than lovely and amiable.
changes.transformed: His brother’s recommendation was enough to insure his favour: his judgment could not err; and he had spoken in such terms of Elliot, as to leave George without the power of finding him otherwise than lovely and amiable.

changes.original: When Darcy returned to the saloon, Miss Bingley could not help repeating to him some part of what she had been saying to his sister.
changes.transformed: When Darcy returned to the saloon, Mr. Bingley could not help repeating to him some part of what he had been saying to his brother.

changes.original: “How very ill Eliza Bennet looks this morning, Mr. Darcy,” she cried: “I never in my life saw anyone so much altered as she is since the winter.
changes.transformed: “How very ill Eli Bennet looks this morning, Mr. Darcy,” he cried: “I never in my life saw anyone so much altered as he is since the winter.

changes.original: She is grown so brown and coarse!
changes.transformed: He is grown so brown and coarse!

changes.original: Louisa and I were agreeing that we should not have known her again.”
changes.transformed: Louis and I were agreeing that we should not have known him again.”

changes.original: However little Mr. Darcy might have liked such an address, he contented himself with coolly replying, that he perceived no other alteration than her being rather tanned,--no miraculous consequence of travelling in the summer.
changes.transformed: However little Mr. Darcy might have liked such an address, he contented himself with coolly replying, that he perceived no other alteration than his being rather tanned,--no miraculous consequence of travelling in the summer.

changes.original: “For my own part,” she rejoined, “I must confess that I never could see any beauty in her.
changes.transformed: “For my own part,” he rejoined, “I must confess that I never could see any beauty in him.

changes.original: Her face is too thin; her complexion has no brilliancy; and her features are not at all handsome.
changes.transformed: His face is too thin; his complexion has no brilliancy; and his features are not at all handsome.

changes.original: Her nose wants character; there is nothing marked in its lines.
changes.transformed: His nose wants character; there is nothing marked in its lines.

changes.original: Her teeth are tolerable, but not out of the common way; and as for her eyes, which have sometimes been called so fine, I never could perceive anything extraordinary in them.
changes.transformed: His teeth are tolerable, but not out of the common way; and as for his eyes, which have sometimes been called so fine, I never could perceive anything extraordinary in them.

changes.original: They have a sharp, shrewish look, which I do not like at all; and in her air altogether, there is a self-sufficiency without fashion, which is intolerable.”
changes.transformed: They have a sharp, shrewish look, which I do not like at all; and in his air altogether, there is a self-sufficiency without fashion, which is intolerable.”

changes.original: Persuaded as Miss Bingley was that Darcy admired Elizabeth, this was not the best method of recommending herself; but angry people are not always wise; and in seeing him at last look somewhat nettled, she had all the success she expected.
changes.transformed: Persuaded as Mr. Bingley was that Darcy admired Elliot, this was not the best method of recommending himself; but angry people are not always wise; and in seeing him at last look somewhat nettled, he had all the success he expected.

changes.original: He was resolutely silent, however; and, from a determination of making him speak, she continued,--
changes.transformed: He was resolutely silent, however; and, from a determination of making him speak, he continued,--

changes.original: “I remember, when we first knew her in Hertfordshire, how amazed we all were to find that she was a reputed beauty; and I particularly recollect your saying one night, after they had been dining at Netherfield, ‘_She_ a beauty!
changes.transformed: “I remember, when we first knew him in Hertfordshire, how amazed we all were to find that he was a reputed beauty; and I particularly recollect your saying one night, after they had been dining at Netherfield, ‘_He_ a beauty!

changes.original: I should as soon call her mother a wit.’ But afterwards she seemed to improve on you, and I believe you thought her rather pretty at one time.”
changes.transformed: I should as soon call his father a wit.’ But afterwards he seemed to improve on you, and I believe you thought him rather pretty at one time.”

changes.original: “Yes,” replied Darcy, who could contain himself no longer, “but _that_ was only when I first knew her; for it is many months since I have considered her as one of the handsomest women of my acquaintance.”
changes.transformed: “Yes,” replied Darcy, who could contain himself no longer, “but _that_ was only when I first knew him; for it is many months since I have considered him as one of the handsomest men of my acquaintance.”

changes.original: He then went away, and Miss Bingley was left to all the satisfaction of having forced him to say what gave no one any pain but herself.
changes.transformed: He then went away, and Mr. Bingley was left to all the satisfaction of having forced him to say what gave no one any pain but himself.

changes.original: Mrs. Gardiner and Elizabeth talked of all that had occurred during their visit, as they returned, except what had particularly interested them both.
changes.transformed: Mr. Gardiner and Elliot talked of all that had occurred during their visit, as they returned, except what had particularly interested them both.

changes.original: They talked of his sister, his friends, his house, his fruit, of everything but himself; yet Elizabeth was longing to know what Mrs. Gardiner thought of him, and Mrs. Gardiner would have been highly gratified by her niece’s beginning the subject.
changes.transformed: They talked of his brother, his friends, his house, his fruit, of everything but himself; yet Elliot was longing to know what Mr. Gardiner thought of him, and Mr. Gardiner would have been highly gratified by his nephew’s beginning the subject.

changes.original: Elizabeth had been a good deal disappointed in not finding a letter from Jane on their first arrival at Lambton; and this disappointment had been renewed on each of the mornings that had now been spent there; but on the third her repining was over, and her sister justified, by the receipt of two letters from her at once, on one of which was marked that it had been mis-sent elsewhere.
changes.transformed: Elliot had been a good deal disappointed in not finding a letter from John on their first arrival at Lambton; and this disappointment had been renewed on each of the mornings that had now been spent there; but on the third his repining was over, and his brother justified, by the receipt of two letters from him at once, on one of which was marked that it had been mis-sent elsewhere.

changes.original: Elizabeth was not surprised at it, as Jane had written the direction remarkably ill.
changes.transformed: Elliot was not surprised at it, as John had written the direction remarkably ill.

changes.original: They had just been preparing to walk as the letters came in; and her uncle and aunt, leaving her to enjoy them in quiet, set off by themselves.
changes.transformed: They had just been preparing to walk as the letters came in; and his uncle, leaving him to enjoy them in quiet, set off by himself.

changes.original: “Since writing the above, dearest Lizzy, something has occurred of a most unexpected and serious nature; but I am afraid of alarming you--be assured that we are all well.
changes.transformed: “Since writing the above, dearest Elliot, something has occurred of a most unexpected and serious nature; but I am afraid of alarming you--be assured that we are all well.

changes.original: What I have to say relates to poor Lydia.
changes.transformed: What I have to say relates to poor Lionel.
