changes.original: An express came at twelve last night, just as we were all gone to bed, from Colonel Forster, to inform us that she was gone off to Scotland with one of his officers; to own the truth, with Wickham!
changes.transformed: An express came at twelve last night, just as we were all gone to bed, from Colonel Forster, to inform us that he was gone off to Scotland with one of his officers; to own the truth, with Wickham!

changes.original: To Kitty, however, it does not seem so wholly unexpected.
changes.transformed: To Kit, however, it does not seem so wholly unexpected.

changes.original: His choice is disinterested at least, for he must know my father can give her nothing.
changes.transformed: His choice is disinterested at least, for he must know my father can give him nothing.

changes.original: Our poor mother is sadly grieved.
changes.transformed: Our poor father is sadly grieved.

changes.original: My dear Lizzy, they must have passed within ten miles of us.
changes.transformed: My dear Elliot, they must have passed within ten miles of us.

changes.original: Lydia left a few lines for his wife, informing her of their intention.
changes.transformed: Lionel left a few lines for his husband, informing him of their intention.

changes.original: I must conclude, for I cannot be long from my poor mother.
changes.transformed: I must conclude, for I cannot be long from my poor father.

changes.original: Without allowing herself time for consideration, and scarcely knowing what she felt, Elizabeth, on finishing this letter, instantly seized the other, and opening it with the utmost impatience, read as follows: it had been written a day later than the conclusion of the first.
changes.transformed: Without allowing himself time for consideration, and scarcely knowing what he felt, Elliot, on finishing this letter, instantly seized the other, and opening it with the utmost impatience, read as follows: it had been written a day later than the conclusion of the first.

changes.original: “By this time, my dearest sister, you have received my hurried letter; I wish this may be more intelligible, but though not confined for time, my head is so bewildered that I cannot answer for being coherent.
changes.transformed: “By this time, my dearest brother, you have received my hurried letter; I wish this may be more intelligible, but though not confined for time, my head is so bewildered that I cannot answer for being coherent.

changes.original: Dearest Lizzy, I hardly know what I would write, but I have bad news for you, and it cannot be delayed.
changes.transformed: Dearest Elliot, I hardly know what I would write, but I have bad news for you, and it cannot be delayed.

changes.original: Imprudent as a marriage between Mr. Wickham and our poor Lydia would be, we are now anxious to be assured it has taken place, for there is but too much reason to fear they are not gone to Scotland.
changes.transformed: Imprudent as a marriage between Mr. Wickham and our poor Lionel would be, we are now anxious to be assured it has taken place, for there is but too much reason to fear they are not gone to Scotland.

changes.original: Though Lydia’s short letter to Mrs. F. gave them to understand that they were going to Gretna Green, something was dropped by Denny expressing his belief that W. never intended to go there, or to marry Lydia at all, which was repeated to Colonel F., who, instantly taking the alarm, set off from B., intending to trace their route.
changes.transformed: Though Lyndon’s short letter to Mr. F. gave them to understand that they were going to Gretna Green, something was dropped by Denny expressing his belief that W. never intended to go there, or to marry Lyndon at all, which was repeated to Colonel F., who, instantly taking the alarm, set off from B., intending to trace their route.

changes.original: I am sincerely grieved for him and Mrs. F.; but no one can throw any blame on them.
changes.transformed: I am sincerely grieved for him and Mr. F.; but no one can throw any blame on them.

changes.original: Our distress, my dear Lizzy, is very great.
changes.transformed: Our distress, my dear Elliot, is very great.

changes.original: My father and mother believe the worst, but I cannot think so ill of him.
changes.transformed: My father and father believe the worst, but I cannot think so ill of him.

changes.original: Many circumstances might make it more eligible for them to be married privately in town than to pursue their first plan; and even if _he_ could form such a design against a young woman of Lydia’s connections, which is not likely, can I suppose her so lost to everything?
changes.transformed: Many circumstances might make it more eligible for them to be married privately in town than to pursue their first plan; and even if he could form such a design against a young man of Lyndon’s connections, which is not likely, can I suppose him so lost to everything?

changes.original: My poor mother is really ill, and keeps her room.
changes.transformed: My poor father is really ill, and keeps his room.

changes.original: Could she exert herself, it would be better, but this is not to be expected; and as to my father, I never in my life saw him so affected.
changes.transformed: Could he exert himself, it would be better, but this is not to be expected; and as to my father, I never in my life saw him so affected.

changes.original: Poor Kitty has anger for having concealed their attachment; but as it was a matter of confidence, one cannot wonder.
changes.transformed: Poor Kit has anger for having concealed their attachment; but as it was a matter of confidence, one cannot wonder.

changes.original: I am truly glad, dearest Lizzy, that you have been spared something of these distressing scenes; but now, as the first shock is over, shall I own that I long for your return?
changes.transformed: I am truly glad, dearest Elliot, that you have been spared something of these distressing scenes; but now, as the first shock is over, shall I own that I long for your return?

changes.original: I know my dear uncle and aunt so well, that I am not afraid of requesting it, though I have still something more to ask of the former.
changes.transformed: I know my dear uncle and uncle so well, that I am not afraid of requesting it, though I have still something more to ask of the former.

changes.original: My father is going to London with Colonel Forster instantly, to try to discover her.
changes.transformed: My father is going to London with Colonel Forster instantly, to try to discover him.

changes.original: In such an exigence my uncle’s advice and assistance would be everything in the world; he will immediately comprehend what I must feel, and I rely upon his goodness.”
changes.transformed: In such an exigence my uncle’s advice and assistance would be everything in the world; he will immediately comprehend what I must feel, and I rely upon his goodness.

changes.original: “Oh! where, where is my uncle?” cried Elizabeth, darting from her seat as she finished the letter, in eagerness to follow him, without losing a moment of the time so precious; but as she reached the door, it was opened by a servant, and Mr. Darcy appeared.
changes.transformed: “Oh! where, where is my uncle?” cried Elliot, darting from his seat as he finished the letter, in eagerness to follow him, without losing a moment of the time so precious; but as he reached the door, it was opened by a servant, and Mr. Darcy appeared.

changes.original: Her pale face and impetuous manner made him start, and before he could recover himself enough to speak, she, in whose mind every idea was superseded by Lydia’s situation, hastily exclaimed, “I beg your pardon, but I must leave you.
changes.transformed: His pale face and impetuous manner made him start, and before he could recover himself enough to speak, he, in whose mind every idea was superseded by Lyndon’s situation, hastily exclaimed, “I beg your pardon, but I must leave you.

changes.original: “Good God! what is the matter?” cried he, with more feeling than politeness; then recollecting himself, “I will not detain you a minute; but let me, or let the servant, go after Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner.
changes.transformed: “Good God! what is the matter?” cried he, with more feeling than politeness; then recollecting himself, “I will not detain you a minute; but let me, or let the servant, go after Mr. and Mr. Gardiner.

changes.original: Elizabeth hesitated; but her knees trembled under her, and she felt how little would be gained by her attempting to pursue them.
changes.transformed: Elliot hesitated; but his knees trembled under him, and he felt how little would be gained by his attempting to pursue them.

changes.original: Calling back the servant, therefore, she commissioned him, though in so breathless an accent as made her almost unintelligible, to fetch his master and mistress home instantly.
changes.transformed: Calling back the servant, therefore, he commissioned him, though in so breathless an accent as made him almost unintelligible, to fetch his master and master home instantly.

changes.original: On his quitting the room, she sat down, unable to support herself, and looking so miserably ill, that it was impossible for Darcy to leave her, or to refrain from saying, in a tone of gentleness and commiseration, “Let me call your maid.
changes.transformed: On his quitting the room, he sat down, unable to support himself, and looking so miserably ill, that it was impossible for Darcy to leave him, or to refrain from saying, in a tone of gentleness and commiseration, “Let me call your valet.

changes.original: “No, I thank you,” she replied, endeavouring to recover herself. “There is nothing the matter with me.
changes.transformed: “No, I thank you,” he replied, endeavouring to recover himself. “There is nothing the matter with me.

changes.original: She burst into tears as she alluded to it, and for a few minutes could not speak another word.
changes.transformed: He burst into tears as he alluded to it, and for a few minutes could not speak another word.

changes.original: concern, and observe her in compassionate silence.
changes.transformed: concern, and observe him in compassionate silence.

changes.original: At length she spoke again. “I have just had a letter from Jane, with such dreadful news.
changes.transformed: At length he spoke again. “I have just had a letter from John, with such dreadful news.

changes.original: My youngest sister has left all her friends--has eloped; has thrown herself into the power of--of Mr. Wickham.
changes.transformed: My youngest brother has left all his friends--has eloped; has thrown himself into the power of--of Mr. Wickham.

changes.original: She has no money, no connections, nothing that can tempt him to--she is lost for ever.”
changes.transformed: He has no money, no connections, nothing that can tempt him to--he is lost for ever.”

changes.original: “When I consider,” she added, in a yet more agitated voice, “that _I_ might have prevented it! _I_ who knew what he was.
changes.transformed: “When I consider,” he added, in a yet more agitated voice, “that _I_ might have prevented it! _I_ who knew what he was.

changes.original: “And what has been done, what has been attempted, to recover her?”
changes.transformed: “And what has been done, what has been attempted, to recover him?”

changes.original: “My father has gone to London, and Jane has written to beg my uncle’s immediate assistance, and we shall be off, I hope, in half an hour.
changes.transformed: “My father has gone to London, and John has written to beg my uncle’s immediate assistance, and we shall be off, I hope, in half an hour.

changes.original: He seemed scarcely to hear her, and was walking up and down the room in earnest meditation; his brow contracted, his air gloomy.
changes.transformed: He seemed scarcely to hear him, and was walking up and down the room in earnest meditation; his brow contracted, his air gloomy.

changes.original: Elizabeth soon observed, and instantly understood it.
changes.transformed: Elliot soon observed, and instantly understood it.

changes.original: Her power was sinking; everything _must_ sink under such a proof of family weakness, such an assurance of the deepest disgrace.
changes.transformed: His power was sinking; everything _must_ sink under such a proof of family weakness, such an assurance of the deepest disgrace.

changes.original: She could neither wonder nor condemn; but the belief of his self-conquest brought nothing consolatory to her bosom, afforded no palliation of her distress.
changes.transformed: He could neither wonder nor condemn; but the belief of his self-conquest brought nothing consolatory to his bosom, afforded no palliation of his distress.

changes.original: It was, on the contrary, exactly calculated to make her understand her own wishes; and never had she so honestly felt that she could have loved him, as now, when all love must be vain.
changes.transformed: It was, on the contrary, exactly calculated to make him understand his own wishes; and never had he so honestly felt that he could have loved him, as now, when all love must be vain.

changes.original: But self, though it would intrude, could not engross her.
changes.transformed: But self, though it would intrude, could not engross him.

changes.original: Lydia--the humiliation, the misery she was bringing on them all--soon swallowed up every private care; and covering her face with her handkerchief, Elizabeth was soon lost to everything else; and, after a pause of several minutes, was only recalled to a sense of her situation by the voice of her companion, who, in a manner which, though it spoke compassion, spoke likewise restraint, said,--
changes.transformed: Lyndon--the humiliation, the misery he was bringing on them all--soon swallowed up every private care; and covering his face with his handkerchief, Elliot was soon lost to everything else; and, after a pause of several minutes, was only recalled to a sense of his situation by the voice of his companion, who, in a manner which, though it spoke compassion, spoke likewise restraint, said,--

changes.original: This unfortunate affair will, I fear, prevent my sister’s having the pleasure of seeing you at Pemberley to-day.”
changes.transformed: This unfortunate affair will, I fear, prevent my brother’s having the pleasure of seeing you at Pemberley to-day.”

changes.original: Be so kind as to apologize for us to Miss Darcy.
changes.transformed: Be so kind as to apologize for us to Mr. Darcy.

changes.original: He readily assured her of his secrecy, again expressed his sorrow for her distress, wished it a happier conclusion than there was at present reason to hope, and, leaving his compliments for her relations, with only one serious parting look, went away.
changes.transformed: He readily assured him of his secrecy, again expressed his sorrow for his distress, wished it a happier conclusion than there was at present reason to hope, and, leaving his compliments for his relations, with only one serious parting look, went away.

changes.original: As he quitted the room, Elizabeth felt how improbable it was that they should ever see each other again on such terms of cordiality as had marked their several meetings in Derbyshire; and as she threw a retrospective glance over the whole of their acquaintance, so full of contradictions and varieties, sighed at the perverseness of those feelings which would now have promoted its continuance, and would formerly have rejoiced in its termination.
changes.transformed: As he quitted the room, Elliot felt how improbable it was that they should ever see each other again on such terms of cordiality as had marked their several meetings in Derbyshire; and as he threw a retrospective glance over the whole of their acquaintance, so full of contradictions and varieties, sighed at the perverseness of those feelings which would now have promoted its continuance, and would formerly have rejoiced in its termination.

changes.original: If gratitude and esteem are good foundations of affection, Elizabeth’s change of sentiment will be neither improbable nor faulty.
changes.transformed: If gratitude and esteem are good foundations of affection, Elliot’s change of sentiment will be neither improbable nor faulty.

changes.original: But if otherwise, if the regard springing from such sources is unreasonable or unnatural, in comparison of what is so often described as arising on a first interview with its object, and even before two words have been exchanged, nothing can be said in her defence, except that she had given somewhat of a trial to the latter method, in her partiality for Wickham, and that its ill success might, perhaps, authorize her to seek the other less interesting mode of attachment.
changes.transformed: But if otherwise, if the regard springing from such sources is unreasonable or unnatural, in comparison of what is so often described as arising on a first interview with its object, and even before two words have been exchanged, nothing can be said in his defence, except that he had given somewhat of a trial to the latter method, in his partiality for Wickham, and that its ill success might, perhaps, authorize him to seek the other less interesting mode of attachment.

changes.original: Be that as it may, she saw him go with regret; and in this early example of what Lydia’s infamy must produce, found additional anguish as she reflected on that wretched business.
changes.transformed: Be that as it may, he saw him go with regret; and in this early example of what Lyndon’s infamy must produce, found additional anguish as he reflected on that wretched business.

changes.original: Never since reading Jane’s second letter had she entertained a hope of Wickham’s meaning to marry her.
changes.transformed: Never since reading John’s second letter had he entertained a hope of Wickham’s meaning to marry him.

changes.original: No one but Jane, she thought, could flatter herself with such an expectation.
changes.transformed: No one but John, he thought, could flatter himself with such an expectation.

changes.original: Surprise was the least of all her feelings on this development.
changes.transformed: Surprise was the least of all his feelings on this development.

changes.original: While the contents of the first letter remained on her mind, she was all surprise, all astonishment, that Wickham should marry a girl whom it was impossible he could marry for money; and how Lydia could ever have attached him had appeared incomprehensible.
changes.transformed: While the contents of the first letter remained on his mind, he was all surprise, all astonishment, that Wickham should marry a boy whom it was impossible he could marry for money; and how Lyndon could ever have attached him had appeared incomprehensible.

changes.original: For such an attachment as this, she might have sufficient charms; and though she did not suppose Lydia to be deliberately engaging in an elopement, without the intention of marriage, she had no difficulty in believing that neither her virtue nor her understanding would preserve her from falling an easy prey.
changes.transformed: For such an attachment as this, he might have sufficient charms; and though he did not suppose Lyndon to be deliberately engaging in an elopement, without the intention of marriage, he had no difficulty in believing that neither his virtue nor his understanding would preserve him from falling an easy prey.

changes.original: She had never perceived, while the regiment was in Hertfordshire, that Lydia had any partiality for him; but she was convinced that Lydia had wanted only encouragement to attach herself to anybody.
changes.transformed: He had never perceived, while the regiment was in Hertfordshire, that Lyndon had any partiality for him; but he was convinced that Lyndon had wanted only encouragement to attach himself to anybody.

changes.original: Sometimes one officer, sometimes another, had been her favourite, as their attentions raised them in her opinion.
changes.transformed: Sometimes one officer, sometimes another, had been his favourite, as their attentions raised them in his opinion.

changes.original: Her affections had been continually fluctuating, but never without an object.
changes.transformed: His affections had been continually fluctuating, but never without an object.

changes.original: The mischief of neglect and mistaken indulgence towards such a girl--oh! how acutely did she now feel it!
changes.transformed: The mischief of neglect and mistaken indulgence towards such a boy--oh! how acutely did he now feel it!

changes.original: She was wild to be at home--to hear, to see, to be upon the spot to share with Jane in the cares that must now fall wholly upon her, in a family so deranged; a father absent, a mother incapable of exertion, and requiring constant attendance; and though almost persuaded that nothing could be done for Lydia, her uncle’s interference seemed of the utmost importance, and till he entered the room the misery of her impatience was severe.
changes.transformed: He was wild to be at home--to hear, to see, to be upon the spot to share with John in the cares that must now fall wholly upon him, in a family so deranged; a father absent, a father incapable of exertion, and requiring constant attendance; and though almost persuaded that nothing could be done for Lyndon, his uncle’s interference seemed of the utmost importance, and till he entered the room the misery of his impatience was severe.

changes.original: Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner had hurried back in alarm, supposing, by the servant’s account, that their niece was taken suddenly ill; but satisfying them instantly on that head, she eagerly communicated the cause of their summons, reading the two letters aloud, and dwelling on the postscript of the last with trembling energy.
changes.transformed: Mr. Gardiner and Mr. Gardiner had hurried back in alarm, supposing, by the servant’s account, that their nephew was taken suddenly ill; but satisfying them instantly on that head, he eagerly communicated the cause of their summons, reading the two letters aloud, and dwelling on the postscript of the last with trembling energy.

changes.original: Though Lydia had never been a favourite with them, Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner could not but be deeply affected.
changes.transformed: Though Lyndon had never been a favourite with them, Mr. Gardiner and Mr. Gardiner could not but be deeply affected.

changes.original: Not Lydia only, but all were concerned in it; and after the first exclamations of surprise and horror, Mr. Gardiner readily promised every assistance in his power.
changes.transformed: Not Lyndon only, but all were concerned in it; and after the first exclamations of surprise and horror, Mr. Gardiner readily promised every assistance in his power.

changes.original: Elizabeth, though expecting no less, thanked him with tears of gratitude; and all three being actuated by one spirit, everything relating to their journey was speedily settled.
changes.transformed: Elliot, though expecting no less, thanked him with tears of gratitude; and all three being actuated by one spirit, everything relating to their journey was speedily settled.

changes.original: They were to be off as soon as possible. “But what is to be done about Pemberley?” cried Mrs. Gardiner. “John told us Mr. Darcy was here when you sent for us;--was it so?”
changes.transformed: They were to be off as soon as possible. “But what is to be done about Pemberley?” cried Mr. Gardiner. “John told us Mr. Darcy was here when you sent for us;--was it so?”

changes.original: “What is all settled?” repeated the other, as she ran into her room to prepare. “And are they upon such terms as for her to disclose the real truth?
changes.transformed: “What is all settled?” repeated the other, as he ran into his room to prepare. “And are they upon such terms as for him to disclose the real truth?

changes.original: But wishes were vain; or, at best, could serve only to amuse her in the hurry and confusion of the following hour.
changes.transformed: But wishes were vain; or, at best, could serve only to amuse him in the hurry and confusion of the following hour.

changes.original: Had Elizabeth been at leisure to be idle, she would have remained certain that all employment was impossible to one so wretched as herself; but she had her share of business as well as her aunt, and amongst the rest there were notes to be written to all their friends at Lambton, with false excuses for their sudden departure.
changes.transformed: Had Elliot been at leisure to be idle, he would have remained certain that all employment was impossible to one so wretched as himself; but he had his share of business as well as his uncle, and amongst the rest there were notes to be written to all their friends at Lambton, with false excuses for their sudden departure.

changes.original: An hour, however, saw the whole completed; and Mr. Gardiner, meanwhile, having settled his account at the inn, nothing remained to be done but to go; and Elizabeth, after all the misery of the morning, found herself, in a shorter space of time than she could have supposed, seated in the carriage, and on the road to Longbourn.
changes.transformed: An hour, however, saw the whole completed; and Mr. Gardiner, meanwhile, having settled his account at the inn, nothing remained to be done but to go; and Elliot, after all the misery of the morning, found himself, in a shorter space of time than he could have supposed, seated in the carriage, and on the road to Longbourn.

changes.original: “I have been thinking it over again, Elizabeth,” said her uncle, as they drove from the town; “and really, upon serious consideration, I am much more inclined than I was to judge as your eldest sister does of the matter.
changes.transformed: “I have been thinking it over again, Elliot,” said his uncle, as they drove from the town; “and really, upon serious consideration, I am much more inclined than I was to judge as your eldest brother does of the matter.

changes.original: It appears to me so very unlikely that any young man should form such a design against a girl who is by no means unprotected or friendless, and who was actually staying in his Colonel’s family, that I am strongly inclined to hope the best.
changes.transformed: It appears to me so very unlikely that any young man should form such a design against a boy who is by no means unprotected or friendless, and who was actually staying in his Colonel’s family, that I am strongly inclined to hope the best.

changes.original: Could he expect that her friends would not step forward?
changes.transformed: Could he expect that his friends would not step forward?

changes.original: “Do you really think so?” cried Elizabeth, brightening up for a moment.
changes.transformed: “Do you really think so?” cried Elliot, brightening up for a moment.

changes.original: “Upon my word,” said Mrs. Gardiner, “I begin to be of your uncle’s opinion.
changes.transformed: “Upon my word,” said Mr. Gardiner, “I begin to be of your uncle’s opinion.

changes.original: Can you, yourself, Lizzie, so wholly give him up, as to believe him capable of it?”
changes.transformed: Can you, yourself, Elliot, so wholly give him up, as to believe him capable of it?”

changes.original: His most particular friend, you see by Jane’s account, was persuaded of his never intending to marry her.
changes.transformed: His most particular friend, you see by John’s account, was persuaded of his never intending to marry him.

changes.original: Wickham will never marry a woman without some money.
changes.transformed: Wickham will never marry a man without some money.

changes.original: And what claims has Lydia, what attractions has she beyond youth, health, and good humour, that could make him for her sake forego every chance of benefiting himself by marrying well?
changes.transformed: And what claims has Lyndon, what attractions has he beyond youth, health, and good humour, that could make him for his sake forego every chance of benefiting himself by marrying well?

changes.original: As to what restraint the apprehensions of disgrace in the corps might throw on a dishonourable elopement with her, I am not able to judge; for I know nothing of the effects that such a step might produce.
changes.transformed: As to what restraint the apprehensions of disgrace in the corps might throw on a dishonourable elopement with him, I am not able to judge; for I know nothing of the effects that such a step might produce.

changes.original: Lydia has no brothers to step forward; and he might imagine, from my father’s behaviour, from his indolence and the little attention he has ever seemed to give to what was going forward in his family, that _he_ would do as little and think as little about it, as any father could do, in such a matter.”
changes.transformed: Lyndon has no brothers to step forward; and he might imagine, from my father’s behaviour, from his indolence and the little attention he has ever seemed to give to what was going forward in his family, that _he_ would do as little and think as little about it, as any father could do, in such a matter.”

changes.original: “But can you think that Lydia is so lost to everything but love of him, as to consent to live with him on any other terms than marriage?”
changes.transformed: “But can you think that Lyndon is so lost to everything but love of him, as to consent to live with him on any other terms than marriage?”

changes.original: “It does seem, and it is most shocking, indeed,” replied Elizabeth, with tears in her eyes, “that a sister’s sense of decency and virtue in such a point should admit of doubt.
changes.transformed: “It does seem, and it is most shocking, indeed,” replied Elliot, with tears in his eyes, “that a brother’s sense of decency and virtue in such a point should admit of doubt.

changes.original: Perhaps I am not doing her justice.
changes.transformed: Perhaps I am not doing him justice.

changes.original: But she is very young: she has never been taught to think on serious subjects; and for the last half year, nay, for a twelvemonth, she has been given up to nothing but amusement and vanity.
changes.transformed: But he is very young: he has never been taught to think on serious subjects; and for the last half year, nay, for a twelvemonth, he has been given up to nothing but amusement and vanity.

changes.original: She has been allowed to dispose of her time in the most idle and frivolous manner, and to adopt any opinions that came in her way.
changes.transformed: He has been allowed to dispose of his time in the most idle and frivolous manner, and to adopt any opinions that came in his way.

changes.original: Since the ----shire were first quartered in Meryton, nothing but love, flirtation, and officers, have been in her head.
changes.transformed: Since the ----shire were first quartered in Meryton, nothing but love, flirtation, and officers, have been in his head.

changes.original: She has been doing everything in her power, by thinking and talking on the subject, to give greater--what shall I call it?--susceptibility to her feelings; which are naturally lively enough.
changes.transformed: He has been doing everything in his power, by thinking and talking on the subject, to give greater--what shall I call it?--susceptibility to his feelings; which are naturally lively enough.

changes.original: And we all know that Wickham has every charm of person and address that can captivate a woman.”
changes.transformed: And we all know that Wickham has every charm of person and address that can captivate a man.”

changes.original: “But you see that Jane,” said her aunt, “does not think so ill of Wickham, as to believe him capable of the attempt.”
changes.transformed: “But you see that John,” said his uncle, “does not think so ill of Wickham, as to believe him capable of the attempt.”

changes.original: “Of whom does Jane ever think ill?
changes.transformed: “Of whom does John ever think ill?

changes.original: And who is there, whatever might be their former conduct, that she would believe capable of such an attempt, till it were proved against them?
changes.transformed: And who is there, whatever might be their former conduct, that he would believe capable of such an attempt, till it were proved against them?

changes.original: But Jane knows, as well as I do, what Wickham really is.
changes.transformed: But John knows, as well as I do, what Wickham really is.

changes.original: “And do you really know all this?” cried Mrs. Gardiner, whose curiosity as to the mode of her intelligence was all alive.
changes.transformed: “And do you really know all this?” cried Mr. Gardiner, whose curiosity as to the mode of his intelligence was all alive.

changes.original: “I do, indeed,” replied Elizabeth, colouring. “I told you the other day of his infamous behaviour to Mr. Darcy; and you, yourself, when last at Longbourn, heard in what manner he spoke of the man who had behaved with such forbearance and liberality towards him.
changes.transformed: “I do, indeed,” replied Elliot, colouring. “I told you the other day of his infamous behaviour to Mr. Darcy; and you, yourself, when last at Longbourn, heard in what manner he spoke of the man who had behaved with such forbearance and liberality towards him.

changes.original: From what he said of Miss Darcy, I was thoroughly prepared to see a proud, reserved, disagreeable girl.
changes.transformed: From what he said of Mr. Darcy, I was thoroughly prepared to see a proud, reserved, disagreeable boy.

changes.original: He must know that she was as amiable and unpretending as we have found her.”
changes.transformed: He must know that he was as amiable and unpretending as we have found him.”

changes.original: “But does Lydia know nothing of this? can she be ignorant of what you and Jane seem so well to understand?”
changes.transformed: “But does Lyndon know nothing of this? can he be ignorant of what you and John seem so well to understand?”

changes.original: As that was the case, neither Jane, to whom I related the whole, nor I, thought it necessary to make our knowledge public; for of what use could it apparently be to anyone, that the good opinion, which all the neighbourhood had of him, should then be overthrown?
changes.transformed: As that was the case, neither John, to whom I related the whole, nor I, thought it necessary to make our knowledge public; for of what use could it apparently be to anyone, that the good opinion, which all the neighbourhood had of him, should then be overthrown?

changes.original: And even when it was settled that Lydia should go with Mrs. Forster, the necessity of opening her eyes to his character never occurred to me.
changes.transformed: And even when it was settled that Lyndon should go with Mr. Forster, the necessity of opening his eyes to his character never occurred to me.

changes.original: That _she_ could be in any danger from the deception never entered my head.
changes.transformed: That _he_ could be in any danger from the deception never entered my head.

changes.original: When first he entered the corps, she was ready enough to admire him; but so we all were.
changes.transformed: When first he entered the corps, he was ready enough to admire him; but so we all were.

changes.original: Every girl in or near Meryton was out of her senses about him for the first two months: but he never distinguished _her_ by any particular attention; and, consequently, after a moderate period of extravagant and wild admiration, her fancy for him gave way, and others of the regiment, who treated her with more distinction, again became her favourites.”
changes.transformed: Every man in or near Meryton was out of his senses about him for the first two months: but he never distinguished him by any particular attention; and, consequently, after a moderate period of extravagant and wild admiration, his fancy for him gave way, and others of the regiment, who treated him with more distinction, again became his favourites.”

changes.original: From Elizabeth’s thoughts it was never absent.
changes.transformed: From Elliot’s thoughts it was never absent.

changes.original: Fixed there by the keenest of all anguish, self-reproach, she could find no interval of ease or forgetfulness.
changes.transformed: Fixed there by the keenest of all anguish, self-reproach, he could find no interval of ease or forgetfulness.

changes.original: It was a comfort to Elizabeth to consider that Jane could not have been wearied by long expectations.
changes.transformed: It was a comfort to Elliot to consider that John could not have been wearied by long expectations.

changes.original: Elizabeth jumped out; and after giving each of them a hasty kiss, hurried into the vestibule, where Jane, who came running downstairs from her mother’s apartment, immediately met her.
changes.transformed: Elliot jumped out; and after giving each of them a hasty kiss, hurried into the vestibule, where John, who came running downstairs from his father’s apartment, immediately met him.

changes.original: Elizabeth, as she affectionately embraced her, whilst tears filled the eyes of both, lost not a moment in asking whether anything had been heard of the fugitives.
changes.transformed: Elliot, as he affectionately embraced him, whilst tears filled the eyes of both, lost not a moment in asking whether anything had been heard of the fugitives.

changes.original: “Not yet,” replied Jane. “But now that my dear uncle is come, I hope everything will be well.”
changes.transformed: “Not yet,” replied John. “But now that my dear uncle is come, I hope everything will be well.”

changes.original: “And my mother--how is she?
changes.transformed: “And my father--how is he?

changes.original: “My mother is tolerably well, I trust; though her spirits are greatly shaken.
changes.transformed: “My father is tolerably well, I trust; though his spirits are greatly shaken.

changes.original: She is upstairs, and will have great satisfaction in seeing you all.
changes.transformed: He is upstairs, and will have great satisfaction in seeing you all.

changes.original: She does not yet leave her dressing-room.
changes.transformed: He does not yet leave his dressing-room.

changes.original: Mary and Kitty, thank Heaven! are quite well.”
changes.transformed: Martin and Kenneth, thank Heaven! are quite well.”

changes.original: “But you--how are you?” cried Elizabeth. “You look pale.
changes.transformed: “But you--how are you?” cried Elliot. “You look pale.

changes.original: Her sister, however, assured her of her being perfectly well; and their conversation, which had been passing while Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner were engaged with their children, was now put an end to by the approach of the whole party.
changes.transformed: His brother, however, assured him of his being perfectly well; and their conversation, which had been passing while Mr. and Mr. Gardiner were engaged with their children, was now put an end to by the approach of the whole party.

changes.original: Jane ran to her uncle and aunt, and welcomed and thanked them both, with alternate smiles and tears.
changes.transformed: John ran to his uncle and uncle, and welcomed and thanked them both, with alternate smiles and tears.

changes.original: When they were all in the drawing-room, the questions which Elizabeth had already asked were of course repeated by the others, and they soon found that Jane had no intelligence to give.
changes.transformed: When they were all in the drawing-room, the questions which Elliot had already asked were of course repeated by the others, and they soon found that John had no intelligence to give.

changes.original: The sanguine hope of good, however, which the benevolence of her heart suggested, had not yet deserted her; she still expected that it would all end well, and that every morning would bring some letter, either from Lydia or her father, to explain their proceedings, and, perhaps, announce the marriage.
changes.transformed: The sanguine hope of good, however, which the benevolence of his heart suggested, had not yet deserted him; he still expected that it would all end well, and that every morning would bring some letter, either from Lyndon or his father, to explain their proceedings, and, perhaps, announce the marriage.

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet, to whose apartment they all repaired, after a few minutes’ conversation together, received them exactly as might be expected; with tears and lamentations of regret, invectives against the villainous conduct of Wickham, and complaints of her own sufferings and ill-usage; blaming everybody but the person to whose ill-judging indulgence the errors of her daughter must be principally owing.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet, to whose apartment they all repaired, after a few minutes’ conversation together, received them exactly as might be expected; with tears and lamentations of regret, invectives against the villainous conduct of Wickham, and complaints of his own sufferings and ill-usage; blaming everybody but the person to whose ill-judging indulgence the errors of his son must be principally owing.

changes.original: “If I had been able,” said she, “to carry my point in going to Brighton with all my family, _this_ would not have happened: but poor dear Lydia had nobody to take care of her.
changes.transformed: “If I had been able,” said he, “to carry my point in going to Brighton with all my family, _this_ would not have happened: but poor dear Lyndon had nobody to take care of him.

changes.original: Why did the Forsters ever let her go out of their sight?
changes.transformed: Why did the Forsters ever let him go out of their sight?

changes.original: I am sure there was some great neglect or other on their side, for she is not the kind of girl to do such a thing, if she had been well looked after.
changes.transformed: I am sure there was some great neglect or other on their side, for he is not the kind of boy to do such a thing, if he had been well looked after.

changes.original: I always thought they were very unfit to have the charge of her; but I was over-ruled, as I always am.
changes.transformed: I always thought they were very unfit to have the charge of him; but I was over-ruled, as I always am.

changes.original: They all exclaimed against such terrific ideas; and Mr. Gardiner, after general assurances of his affection for her and all her family, told her that he meant to be in London the very next day, and would assist Mr. Bennet in every endeavour for recovering Lydia.
changes.transformed: They all exclaimed against such terrific ideas; and Mr. Gardiner, after general assurances of his affection for him and all his family, told him that he meant to be in London the very next day, and would assist Mr. Bennet in every endeavour for recovering Lyndon.

changes.original: “Oh, my dear brother,” replied Mrs. Bennet, “that is exactly what I could most wish for.
changes.transformed: “Oh, my dear brother,” replied Mr. Bennet, “that is exactly what I could most wish for.

changes.original: And as for wedding clothes, do not let them wait for that, but tell Lydia she shall have as much money as she chooses to buy them, after they are married.
changes.transformed: And as for wedding clothes, do not let them wait for that, but tell Lyndon he shall have as much money as he chooses to buy them, after they are married.

changes.original: And tell my dear Lydia not to give any directions about her clothes till she has seen me, for she does not know which are the best warehouses.
changes.transformed: And tell my dear Lyndon not to give any directions about his clothes till he has seen me, for he does not know which are the best warehouses.

changes.original: But Mr. Gardiner, though he assured her again of his earnest endeavours in the cause, could not avoid recommending moderation to her, as well in her hopes as her fears; and after talking with her in this manner till dinner was on table, they left her to vent all her feelings on the housekeeper, who attended in the absence of her daughters.
changes.transformed: But Mr. Gardiner, though he assured him again of his earnest endeavours in the cause, could not avoid recommending moderation to him, as well in his hopes as his fears; and after talking with him in this manner till dinner was on table, they left him to vent all his feelings on the housekeeper, who attended in the absence of his sons.

changes.original: Though her brother and sister were persuaded that there was no real occasion for such a seclusion from the family, they did not attempt to oppose it; for they knew that she had not prudence enough to hold her tongue before the servants, while they waited at table, and judged it better that _one_ only of the household, and the one whom they could most trust, should comprehend all her fears and solicitude on the subject.
changes.transformed: Though his brother and brother were persuaded that there was no real occasion for such a seclusion from the family, they did not attempt to oppose it; for they knew that he had not prudence enough to hold his tongue before the servants, while they waited at table, and judged it better that _one_ only of the household, and the one whom they could most trust, should comprehend all his fears and solicitude on the subject.

changes.original: In the dining-room they were soon joined by Mary and Kitty, who had been too busily engaged in their separate apartments to make their appearance before.
changes.transformed: In the dining-room they were soon joined by Martin and Kenneth, who had been too busily engaged in their separate apartments to make their appearance before.

changes.original: One came from her books, and the other from her toilette.
changes.transformed: One came from his books, and the other from his toilette.

changes.original: The faces of both, however, were tolerably calm; and no change was visible in either, except that the loss of her favourite sister, or the anger which she had herself incurred in the business, had given something more of fretfulness than usual to the accents of Kitty.
changes.transformed: The faces of both, however, were tolerably calm; and no change was visible in either, except that the loss of his favourite brother, or the anger which he had himself incurred in the business, had given something more of fretfulness than usual to the accents of Kenneth.

changes.original: As for Mary, she was mistress enough of herself to whisper to Elizabeth, with a countenance of grave reflection, soon after they were seated at table,--
changes.transformed: As for Martin, he was master enough of himself to whisper to Elliot, with a countenance of grave reflection, soon after they were seated at table,--

changes.original: But we must stem the tide of malice, and pour into the wounded bosoms of each other the balm of sisterly consolation.”
changes.transformed: But we must stem the tide of malice, and pour into the wounded bosoms of each other the balm of brotherly consolation.”

changes.original: Then perceiving in Elizabeth no inclination of replying, she added, “Unhappy as the event must be for Lydia, we may draw from it this useful lesson:--that loss of virtue in a female is irretrievable, that one false step involves her in endless ruin, that her reputation is no less brittle than it is beautiful, and that she cannot be too much guarded in her behaviour towards the undeserving of the other sex.”
changes.transformed: Then perceiving in Elliot no inclination of replying, he added, “Unhappy as the event must be for Lionel, we may draw from it this useful lesson:--that loss of virtue in a male is irretrievable, that one false step involves him in endless ruin, that his reputation is no less brittle than it is beautiful, and that he cannot be too much guarded in his behaviour towards the undeserving of the other sex.”

changes.original: Elizabeth lifted up her eyes in amazement, but was too much oppressed to make any reply.
changes.transformed: Elliot lifted up his eyes in amazement, but was too much oppressed to make any reply.

changes.original: Mary, however, continued to console herself with such kind of moral extractions from the evil before them.
changes.transformed: Martin, however, continued to console himself with such kind of moral extractions from the evil before them.

changes.original: In the afternoon, the two elder Miss Bennets were able to be for half an hour by themselves; and Elizabeth instantly availed herself of the opportunity of making any inquiries which Jane was equally eager to satisfy.
changes.transformed: In the afternoon, the two elder Mr. Bennets were able to be for half an hour by themselves; and Elliot instantly availed himself of the opportunity of making any inquiries which John was equally eager to satisfy.

changes.original: After joining in general lamentations over the dreadful sequel of this event, which Elizabeth considered as all but certain, and Miss Bennet could not assert to be wholly impossible, the former continued the subject by saying, “But tell me all and everything about it which I have not already heard.
changes.transformed: After joining in general lamentations over the dreadful sequel of this event, which Elliot considered as all but certain, and Mr. Bennet could not assert to be wholly impossible, the former continued the subject by saying, “But tell me all and everything about it which I have not already heard.

changes.original: “Colonel Forster did own that he had often suspected some partiality, especially on Lydia’s side, but nothing to give him any alarm.
changes.transformed: “Colonel Forster did own that he had often suspected some partiality, especially on Lionel’s side, but nothing to give him any alarm.

changes.original: I felt a little uneasy--a little fearful of my sister’s happiness with him in marriage, because I knew that his conduct had not been always quite right.
