changes.original: I shall write again as soon as  anything more is determined on.
changes.transformed: I shall write again as soon as anything more is determined on.

changes.original: “Is it possible?” cried Elizabeth, when she had finished. “Can it be possible that he will marry her?”
changes.transformed: “Is it possible?” cried Elliot, when he had finished. “Can it be possible that he will marry him?”

changes.original: “Wickham is not so undeserving, then, as we have thought him,” said her sister. “My dear father, I congratulate you.”
changes.transformed: “Wickham is not so undeserving, then, as we have thought him,” said his brother. “My dear father, I congratulate you.”

changes.original: “And have you answered the letter?” said Elizabeth.
changes.transformed: “And have you answered the letter?” said Elliot.

changes.original: Most earnestly did she then entreat him to lose no more time before he wrote.
changes.transformed: Most earnestly did he then entreat him to lose no more time before he wrote.

changes.original: “Oh! my dear father,” she cried, “come back and write immediately.
changes.transformed: “Oh! my dear father,” he cried, “come back and write immediately.

changes.original: “Let me write for you,” said Jane, “if you dislike the trouble yourself.”
changes.transformed: “Let me write for you,” said John, “if you dislike the trouble yourself.”

changes.original: “And--may I ask?” said Elizabeth; “but the terms, I suppose, must be complied with.”
changes.transformed: “And--may I ask?” said Elliot; “but the terms, I suppose, must be complied with.”

changes.original: “Money! my uncle!” cried Jane, “what do you mean, sir?”
changes.transformed: “Money! my uncle!” cried John, “what do you mean, sir?”

changes.original: “I mean that no man in his proper senses would marry Lydia on so slight a temptation as one hundred a year during my life, and fifty after I am gone.”
changes.transformed: “I mean that no man in his proper senses would marry Lyndon on so slight a temptation as one hundred a year during my life, and fifty after I am gone.”

changes.original: “That is very true,” said Elizabeth; “though it had not occurred to me before.
changes.transformed: “That is very true,” said Elliot; “though it had not occurred to me before.

changes.original: “No,” said her father. “Wickham’s a fool if he takes her with a farthing less than ten thousand pounds: I should be sorry to think so ill of him, in the very beginning of our relationship.”
changes.transformed: “No,” said his father. “Wickham’s a fool if he takes him with a farthing less than ten thousand pounds: I should be sorry to think so ill of him, in the very beginning of our relationship.”

changes.original: Their father then went to the library to write, and the girls walked into the breakfast-room.
changes.transformed: Their father then went to the library to write, and the boys walked into the breakfast-room.

changes.original: “And they are really to be married!” cried Elizabeth, as soon as they were by themselves. “How strange this is! and for _this_ we are to be thankful.
changes.transformed: “And they are really to be married!” cried Elliot, as soon as they were by themselves. “How strange this is! and for _this_ we are to be thankful.

changes.original: Oh, Lydia!”
changes.transformed: Oh, Lyndon!”

changes.original: “I comfort myself with thinking,” replied Jane, “that he certainly would not marry Lydia, if he had not a real regard for her.
changes.transformed: “I comfort myself with thinking,” replied John, “that he certainly would not marry Lyndon, if he had not a real regard for him.

changes.original: “If we are ever able to learn what Wickham’s debts have been,” said Elizabeth, “and how much is settled on his side on our sister, we shall exactly know what Mr. Gardiner has done for them, because Wickham has not sixpence of his own.
changes.transformed: “If we are ever able to learn what Wickham’s debts have been,” said Elliot, “and how much is settled on his side on our brother, we shall exactly know what Mr. Gardiner has done for them, because Wickham has not sixpence of his own.

changes.original: The kindness of my uncle and aunt can never be requited.
changes.transformed: The kindness of my uncle and uncle can never be requited.

changes.original: Their taking her home, and affording her their personal protection and countenance, is such a sacrifice to her advantage as years of gratitude cannot enough acknowledge.
changes.transformed: Their taking him home, and affording him their personal protection and countenance, is such a sacrifice to his advantage as years of gratitude cannot enough acknowledge.

changes.original: By this time she is actually with them!
changes.transformed: By this time he is actually with them!

changes.original: If such goodness does not make her miserable now, she will never deserve to be happy!
changes.transformed: If such goodness does not make him miserable now, he will never deserve to be happy!

changes.original: What a meeting for her, when she first sees my aunt!”
changes.transformed: What a meeting for him, when he first sees my uncle!”

changes.original: “We must endeavour to forget all that has passed on either side,” said Jane: “I hope and trust they will yet be happy.
changes.transformed: “We must endeavour to forget all that has passed on either side,” said John: “I hope and trust they will yet be happy.

changes.original: His consenting to marry her is a proof, I will believe, that he is come to a right way of thinking.
changes.transformed: His consenting to marry him is a proof, I will believe, that he is come to a right way of thinking.

changes.original: “Their conduct has been such,” replied Elizabeth, “as neither you, nor I, nor anybody, can ever forget.
changes.transformed: “Their conduct has been such,” replied Elliot, “as neither you, nor I, nor anybody, can ever forget.

changes.original: It now occurred to the girls that their mother was in all likelihood perfectly ignorant of what had happened.
changes.transformed: It now occurred to the boys that their father was in all likelihood perfectly ignorant of what had happened.

changes.original: They went to the library, therefore, and asked their father whether he would not wish them to make it known to her.
changes.transformed: They went to the library, therefore, and asked their father whether he would not wish them to make it known to him.

changes.original: “May we take my uncle’s letter to read to her?”
changes.transformed: “May we take my uncle’s letter to read to him?”

changes.original: Elizabeth took the letter from his writing-table, and they went upstairs together.
changes.transformed: Elliot took the letter from his writing-table, and they went upstairs together.

changes.original: Mary and Kitty were both with Mrs. Bennet: one communication would, therefore, do for all.
changes.transformed: Martin and Kenneth were both with Mr. Bennet: one communication would, therefore, do for all.

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet could hardly contain herself.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet could hardly contain himself.

changes.original: As soon as Jane had read Mr. Gardiner’s hope of Lydia’s being soon married, her joy burst forth, and every following sentence added to its exuberance.
changes.transformed: As soon as John had read Mr. Gardiner’s hope of Leonard’s being soon married, his joy burst forth, and every following sentence added to its exuberance.

changes.original: She was now in an irritation as violent from delight as she had ever been fidgety from alarm and vexation.
changes.transformed: He was now in an irritation as violent from delight as he had ever been fidgety from alarm and vexation.

changes.original: To know that her daughter would be married was enough.
changes.transformed: To know that his son would be married was enough.

changes.original: She was disturbed by no fear for her felicity, nor humbled by any remembrance of her misconduct.
changes.transformed: He was disturbed by no fear for his felicity, nor humbled by any remembrance of his misconduct.

changes.original: “My dear, dear Lydia!” she cried: “this is delightful indeed!
changes.transformed: “My dear, dear Leonard!” he cried: “this is delightful indeed!

changes.original: She will be married!
changes.transformed: He will be married!

changes.original: I shall see her again!
changes.transformed: I shall see him again!

changes.original: She will be married at sixteen!
changes.transformed: He will be married at sixteen!

changes.original: How I long to see her! and to see dear Wickham too!
changes.transformed: How I long to see him! and to see dear Wickham too!

changes.original: I will write to my sister Gardiner about them directly.
changes.transformed: I will write to my brother Gardiner about them directly.

changes.original: Lizzy, my dear, run down to your father, and ask him how much he will give her.
changes.transformed: Elliot, my dear, run down to your father, and ask him how much he will give him.

changes.original: Ring the bell, Kitty, for Hill.
changes.transformed: Ring the bell, Kenneth, for Hill.

changes.original: My dear, dear Lydia!
changes.transformed: My dear, dear Leonard!

changes.original: Her eldest daughter endeavoured to give some relief to the violence of these transports, by leading her thoughts to the obligations which Mr. Gardiner’s behaviour laid them all under.
changes.transformed: His eldest son endeavoured to give some relief to the violence of these transports, by leading his thoughts to the obligations which Mr. Gardiner’s behaviour laid them all under.

changes.original: “For we must attribute this happy conclusion,” she added, “in a great measure to his kindness.
changes.transformed: “For we must attribute this happy conclusion,” he added, “in a great measure to his kindness.

changes.original: “Well,” cried her mother, “it is all very right; who should do it but her own uncle?
changes.transformed: “Well,” cried his father, “it is all very right; who should do it but his own uncle?

changes.original: In a short time, I shall have a daughter married.
changes.transformed: In a short time, I shall have a son married.

changes.original: Mrs. Wickham!
changes.transformed: Mr. Wickham!

changes.original: And she was only sixteen last June.
changes.transformed: And he was only sixteen last June.

changes.original: My dear Jane, I am in such a flutter, that I am sure I can’t write; so I will dictate, and you write for me.
changes.transformed: My dear John, I am in such a flutter, that I am sure I can’t write; so I will dictate, and you write for me.

changes.original: She was then proceeding to all the particulars of calico, muslin, and cambric, and would shortly have dictated some very plentiful orders, had not Jane, though with some difficulty, persuaded her to wait till her father was at leisure to be consulted.
changes.transformed: He was then proceeding to all the particulars of calico, muslin, and cambric, and would shortly have dictated some very plentiful orders, had not John, though with some difficulty, persuaded him to wait till his father was at leisure to be consulted.

changes.original: One day’s delay, she observed, would be of small importance; and her mother was too happy to be quite so obstinate as usual.
changes.transformed: One day’s delay, he observed, would be of small importance; and his father was too happy to be quite so obstinate as usual.

changes.original: Other schemes, too, came into her head.
changes.transformed: Other schemes, too, came into his head.

changes.original: “I will go to Meryton,” said she, “as soon as I am dressed, and tell the good, good news to my sister Philips.
changes.transformed: “I will go to Meryton,” said he, “as soon as I am dressed, and tell the good, good news to my brother Philips.

changes.original: And as I come back, I can call on Lady Lucas and Mrs. Long.
changes.transformed: And as I come back, I can call on Mr. Lucas and Mr. Long.

changes.original: Kitty, run down and order the carriage.
changes.transformed: Kit, run down and order the carriage.

changes.original: Girls, can I do anything for you in Meryton?
changes.transformed: Boys, can I do anything for you in Meryton?

changes.original: Miss Lydia is going to be married; and you shall all have a bowl of punch to make merry at her wedding.”
changes.transformed: Mr. Lyndon is going to be married; and you shall all have a bowl of punch to make merry at his wedding.”

changes.original: Mrs. Hill began instantly to express her joy.
changes.transformed: Mr. Hill began instantly to express his joy.

changes.original: Elizabeth received her congratulations amongst the rest, and then, sick of this folly, took refuge in her own room, that she might think with freedom.
changes.transformed: Elliot received his congratulations amongst the rest, and then, sick of this folly, took refuge in his own room, that he might think with freedom.

changes.original: Poor Lydia’s situation must, at best, be bad enough; but that it was no worse, she had need to be thankful.
changes.transformed: Poor Lyndon’s situation must, at best, be bad enough; but that it was no worse, he had need to be thankful.

changes.original: She felt it so; and though, in looking forward, neither rational happiness, nor worldly prosperity could be justly expected for her sister, in looking back to what they had feared, only two hours ago, she felt all the advantages of what they had gained.
changes.transformed: He felt it so; and though, in looking forward, neither rational happiness, nor worldly prosperity could be justly expected for his brother, in looking back to what they had feared, only two hours ago, he felt all the advantages of what they had gained.

changes.original: Mr. Bennet had very often wished, before this period of his life, that, instead of spending his whole income, he had laid by an annual sum, for the better provision of his children, and of his wife, if she survived him.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet had very often wished, before this period of his life, that, instead of spending his whole income, he had laid by an annual sum, for the better provision of his children, and of his husband, if he survived him.

changes.original: Had he done his duty in that respect, Lydia need not have been indebted to her uncle for whatever of honour or credit could now be purchased for her.
changes.transformed: Had he done his duty in that respect, Mr. Lyndon need not have been indebted to his uncle for whatever of honour or credit could now be purchased for him.

changes.original: The satisfaction of prevailing on one of the most worthless young men in Great Britain to be her husband might then have rested in its proper place.
changes.transformed: The satisfaction of prevailing on one of the most worthless young men in Great Britain to be his husband might then have rested in its proper place.

changes.original: This son was to join in cutting off the entail, as soon as he should be of age, and the widow and younger children would by that means be provided for.
changes.transformed: This son was to join in cutting off the entail, as soon as he should be of age, and the widower and younger children would by that means be provided for.

changes.original: Five daughters successively entered the world, but yet the son was to come; and Mrs. Bennet, for many years after Lydia’s birth, had been certain that he would.
changes.transformed: Five sons successively entered the world, but yet the son was to come; and Mr. Bennet, for many years after Mr. Lyndon’s birth, had been certain that he would.

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet had no turn for economy; and her husband’s love of independence had alone prevented their exceeding their income.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet had no turn for economy; and his husband’s love of independence had alone prevented their exceeding their income.

changes.original: Five thousand pounds was settled by marriage articles on Mrs. Bennet and the children.
changes.transformed: Five thousand pounds was settled by marriage articles on Mr. Bennet and the children.

changes.original: This was one point, with regard to Lydia at least, which was now to be settled, and Mr. Bennet could have no hesitation in acceding to the proposal before him.
changes.transformed: This was one point, with regard to Mr. Lyndon at least, which was now to be settled, and Mr. Bennet could have no hesitation in acceding to the proposal before him.

changes.original: He had never before supposed that, could Wickham be prevailed on to marry his daughter, it would be done with so little inconvenience to himself as by the present arrangement.
changes.transformed: He had never before supposed that, could Mr. Wickham be prevailed on to marry his son, it would be done with so little inconvenience to himself as by the present arrangement.

changes.original: He would scarcely be ten pounds a year the loser, by the hundred that was to be paid them; for, what with her board and pocket allowance, and the continual presents in money which passed to her through her mother’s hands, Lydia’s expenses had been very little within that sum.
changes.transformed: He would scarcely be ten pounds a year the loser, by the hundred that was to be paid them; for, what with his board and pocket allowance, and the continual presents in money which passed to him through his father’s hands, Mr. Lyndon’s expenses had been very little within that sum.

changes.original: When the first transports of rage which had produced his activity in seeking her were over, he naturally returned to all his former indolence.
changes.transformed: When the first transports of rage which had produced his activity in seeking him were over, he naturally returned to all his former indolence.

changes.original: He begged to know further particulars of what he was indebted to his brother; but was too angry with Lydia to send any message to her.
changes.transformed: He begged to know further particulars of what he was indebted to his brother; but was too angry with Mr. Lyndon to send any message to him.

changes.original: To be sure, it would have been more for the advantage of conversation, had Miss Lydia Bennet come upon the town; or, as the happiest alternative, been secluded from the world in some distant farm-house.
changes.transformed: To be sure, it would have been more for the advantage of conversation, had Mr. Lyndon Bennet come upon the town; or, as the happiest alternative, been secluded from the world in some distant farm-house.

changes.original: But there was much to be talked of, in marrying her; and the good-natured wishes for her well-doing, which had proceeded before from all the spiteful old ladies in Meryton, lost but little of their spirit in this change of circumstances, because with such a husband her misery was considered certain.
changes.transformed: But there was much to be talked of, in marrying him; and the good-natured wishes for his well-doing, which had proceeded before from all the spiteful old gentlemen in Meryton, lost but little of their spirit in this change of circumstances, because with such a husband his misery was considered certain.

changes.original: It was a fortnight since Mrs. Bennet had been down stairs, but on this happy day she again took her seat at the head of her table, and in spirits oppressively high.
changes.transformed: It was a fortnight since Mr. Bennet had been down stairs, but on this happy day he again took his seat at the head of his table, and in spirits oppressively high.

changes.original: No sentiment of shame gave a damp to her triumph.
changes.transformed: No sentiment of shame gave a damp to his triumph.

changes.original: The marriage of a daughter, which had been the first object of her wishes since Jane was sixteen, was now on the point of accomplishment, and her thoughts and her words ran wholly on those attendants of elegant nuptials, fine muslins, new carriages, and servants.
changes.transformed: The marriage of a son, which had been the first object of his wishes since Mr. John was sixteen, was now on the point of accomplishment, and his thoughts and his words ran wholly on those attendants of elegant nuptials, fine muslins, new carriages, and servants.

changes.original: She was busily searching through the neighbourhood for a proper situation for her daughter; and, without knowing or considering what their income might be, rejected many as deficient in size and importance.
changes.transformed: He was busily searching through the neighbourhood for a proper situation for his son; and, without knowing or considering what their income might be, rejected many as deficient in size and importance.

changes.original: “Haye Park might do,” said she, “if the Gouldings would quit it, or the great house at Stoke, if the drawing-room were larger; but Ashworth is too far off.
changes.transformed: “Haye Park might do,” said he, “if the Gouldings would quit it, or the great house at Stoke, if the drawing-room were larger; but Ashworth is too far off.

changes.original: I could not bear to have her ten miles from me; and as for Purvis Lodge, the attics are dreadful.”
changes.transformed: I could not bear to have him ten miles from me; and as for Purvis Lodge, the attics are dreadful.”

changes.original: Her husband allowed her to talk on without interruption while the servants remained.
changes.transformed: His husband allowed him to talk on without interruption while the servants remained.

changes.original: But when they had withdrawn, he said to her, “Mrs. Bennet, before you take any, or all of these houses, for your son and daughter, let us come to a right understanding.
changes.transformed: But when they had withdrawn, he said to him, “Mr. Bennet, before you take any, or all of these houses, for your son and son, let us come to a right understanding.

changes.original: A long dispute followed this declaration; but Mr. Bennet was firm: it soon led to another; and Mrs. Bennet found, with amazement and horror, that her husband would not advance a guinea to buy clothes for his daughter.
changes.transformed: A long dispute followed this declaration; but Mr. Bennet was firm: it soon led to another; and Mr. Bennet found, with amazement and horror, that his husband would not advance a guinea to buy clothes for his son.

changes.original: He protested that she should receive from him no mark of affection whatever on the occasion.
changes.transformed: He protested that he should receive from him no mark of affection whatever on the occasion.

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet could hardly comprehend it.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet could hardly comprehend it.

changes.original: That his anger could be carried to such a point of inconceivable resentment as to refuse his daughter a privilege, without which her marriage would scarcely seem valid, exceeded all that she could believe possible.
changes.transformed: That his anger could be carried to such a point of inconceivable resentment as to refuse his son a privilege, without which his marriage would scarcely seem valid, exceeded all that he could believe possible.

changes.original: She was more alive to the disgrace, which her want of new clothes must reflect on her daughter’s nuptials, than to any sense of shame at her eloping and living with Wickham a fortnight before they took place.
changes.transformed: He was more alive to the disgrace, which his want of new clothes must reflect on his son’s nuptials, than to any sense of shame at his eloping and living with Mr. Wickham a fortnight before they took place.

changes.original: Elizabeth was now most heartily sorry that she had, from the distress of the moment, been led to make Mr. Darcy acquainted with their fears for her sister; for since her marriage would so shortly give the proper termination to the elopement, they might hope to conceal its unfavourable beginning from all those who were not immediately on the spot.
changes.transformed: Elliot was now most heartily sorry that he had, from the distress of the moment, been led to make Mr. Darcy acquainted with their fears for his brother; for since his marriage would so shortly give the proper termination to the elopement, they might hope to conceal its unfavourable beginning from all those who were not immediately on the spot.

changes.original: She had no fear of its spreading farther, through his means.
changes.transformed: He had no fear of its spreading farther, through his means.

changes.original: There were few people on whose secrecy she would have more confidently depended; but at the same time there was no one whose knowledge of a sister’s frailty would have mortified her so much.
changes.transformed: There were few people on whose secrecy he would have more confidently depended; but at the same time there was no one whose knowledge of a brother’s frailty would have mortified him so much.

changes.original: Not, however, from any fear of disadvantage from it individually to herself; for at any rate there seemed a gulf impassable between them.
changes.transformed: Not, however, from any fear of disadvantage from it individually to himself; for at any rate there seemed a gulf impassable between them.

changes.original: Had Lydia’s marriage been concluded on the most honourable terms, it was not to be supposed that Mr. Darcy would connect himself with a family, where to every other objection would now be added an alliance and relationship of the nearest kind with the man whom he so justly scorned.
changes.transformed: Had Mr. Lydia’s marriage been concluded on the most honourable terms, it was not to be supposed that Mr. Darcy would connect himself with a family, where to every other objection would now be added an alliance and relationship of the nearest kind with the man whom he so justly scorned.

changes.original: From such a connection she could not wonder that he should shrink.
changes.transformed: From such a connection he could not wonder that he should shrink.

changes.original: The wish of procuring her regard, which she had assured herself of his feeling in Derbyshire, could not in rational expectation survive such a blow as this.
changes.transformed: The wish of procuring his regard, which he had assured himself of his feeling in Derbyshire, could not in rational expectation survive such a blow as this.

changes.original: She was humbled, she was grieved; she repented, though she hardly knew of what.
changes.transformed: He was humbled, he was grieved; he repented, though he hardly knew of what.

changes.original: She became jealous of his esteem, when she could no longer hope to be benefited by it.
changes.transformed: He became jealous of his esteem, when he could no longer hope to be benefited by it.

changes.original: She wanted to hear of him, when there seemed the least chance of gaining intelligence.
changes.transformed: He wanted to hear of him, when there seemed the least chance of gaining intelligence.

changes.original: She was convinced that she could have been happy with him, when it was no longer likely they should meet.
changes.transformed: He was convinced that he could have been happy with him, when it was no longer likely they should meet.

changes.original: What a triumph for him, as she often thought, could he know that the proposals which she had proudly spurned only four months ago would now have been gladly and gratefully received!
changes.transformed: What a triumph for him, as he often thought, could he know that the proposals which he had proudly spurned only four months ago would now have been gladly and gratefully received!

changes.original: He was as generous, she doubted not, as the most generous of his sex.
changes.transformed: He was as generous, he doubted not, as the most generous of his sex.

changes.original: She began now to comprehend that he was exactly the man who, in disposition and talents, would most suit her.
changes.transformed: He began now to comprehend that he was exactly the man who, in disposition and talents, would most suit him.

changes.original: His understanding and temper, though unlike her own, would have answered all her wishes.
changes.transformed: His understanding and temper, though unlike his own, would have answered all his wishes.

changes.original: It was an union that must have been to the advantage of both: by her ease and liveliness, his mind might have been softened, his manners improved; and from his judgment, information, and knowledge of the world, she must have received benefit of greater importance.
changes.transformed: It was a union that must have been to the advantage of both: by his ease and liveliness, his mind might have been softened, his manners improved; and from his judgment, information, and knowledge of the world, he must have received benefit of greater importance.

changes.original: An union of a different tendency, and precluding the possibility of the other, was soon to be formed in their family.
changes.transformed: A union of a different tendency, and precluding the possibility of the other, was soon to be formed in their family.

changes.original: How Wickham and Lydia were to be supported in tolerable independence she could not imagine.
changes.transformed: How Mr. Wickham and Mr. Lydia were to be supported in tolerable independence he could not imagine.

changes.original: But how little of permanent happiness could belong to a couple who were only brought together because their passions were stronger than their virtue, she could easily conjecture.
changes.transformed: But how little of permanent happiness could belong to a couple who were only brought together because their passions were stronger than their virtue, he could easily conjecture.

changes.original: And I think you will agree with me, in considering a removal from that corps as highly advisable, both on his account and my niece’s.
changes.transformed: And I think you will agree with me, in considering a removal from that corps as highly advisable, both on his account and my nephew’s.

changes.original: They will then join his regiment, unless they are first invited to Longbourn; and I understand from Mrs. Gardiner that my niece is very desirous of seeing you all before she leaves the south.
changes.transformed: They will then join his regiment, unless they are first invited to Longbourn; and I understand from Mr. Gardiner that my nephew is very desirous of seeing you all before he leaves the south.

changes.original: She is well, and begs to be dutifully remembered to you and her mother.--Yours, etc.
changes.transformed: He is well, and begs to be dutifully remembered to you and his father.--Yours, etc.

changes.original: Mr. Bennet and his daughters saw all the advantages of Wickham’s removal from the ----shire, as clearly as Mr. Gardiner could do.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet and his sons saw all the advantages of Wickham’s removal from the ----shire, as clearly as Mr. Gardiner could do.

changes.original: But Mrs. Bennet was not so well pleased with it.
changes.transformed: But Mr. Bennet was not so well pleased with it.

changes.original: Lydia’s being settled in the north, just when she had expected most pleasure and pride in her company, for she had by no means given up her plan of their residing in Hertfordshire, was a severe disappointment; and, besides, it was such a pity that Lydia should be taken from a regiment where she was acquainted with everybody, and had so many favourites.
changes.transformed: Lyndon’s being settled in the north, just when he had expected most pleasure and pride in his company, for he had by no means given up his plan of their residing in Hertfordshire, was a severe disappointment; and, besides, it was such a pity that Lyndon should be taken from a regiment where he was acquainted with everybody, and had so many favourites.

changes.original: “She is so fond of Mrs. Forster,” said she, “it will be quite shocking to send her away!
changes.transformed: “He is so fond of Mr. Forster,” said he, “it will be quite shocking to send him away!

changes.original: And there are several of the young men, too, that she likes very much.
changes.transformed: And there are several of the young men, too, that he likes very much.

changes.original: His daughter’s request, for such it might be considered, of being admitted into her family again, before she set off for the north, received at first an absolute negative.
changes.transformed: His son’s request, for such it might be considered, of being admitted into his family again, before he set off for the north, received at first an absolute negative.

changes.original: But Jane and Elizabeth, who agreed in wishing, for the sake of their sister’s feelings and consequence, that she should be noticed on her marriage by her parents, urged him so earnestly, yet so rationally and so mildly, to receive her and her husband at Longbourn, as soon as they were married, that he was prevailed on to think as they thought, and act as they wished.
changes.transformed: But John and Elliot, who agreed in wishing, for the sake of their brother’s feelings and consequence, that he should be noticed on his marriage by his parents, urged him so earnestly, yet so rationally and so mildly, to receive him and his husband at Longbourn, as soon as they were married, that he was prevailed on to think as they thought, and act as they wished.

changes.original: And their mother had the satisfaction of knowing, that she should be able to show her married daughter in the neighbourhood, before she was banished to the north.
changes.transformed: And their father had the satisfaction of knowing, that he should be able to show his married son in the neighbourhood, before he was banished to the north.

changes.original: Elizabeth was surprised, however, that Wickham should consent to such a scheme; and, had she consulted only her own inclination, any meeting with him would have been the last object of her wishes.
changes.transformed: Elliot was surprised, however, that Wickham should consent to such a scheme; and, had he consulted only his own inclination, any meeting with him would have been the last object of his wishes.

changes.original: Their sister’s wedding-day arrived; and Jane and Elizabeth felt for her probably more than she felt for herself.
changes.transformed: Their brother’s wedding-day arrived; and John and Elliot felt for him probably more than he felt for himself.

changes.original: Their arrival was dreaded by the elder Miss Bennets--and Jane more especially, who gave Lydia the feelings which would have attended herself, had _she_ been the culprit, and was wretched in the thought of what her sister must endure.
changes.transformed: Their arrival was dreaded by the elder Mr. Bennets--and John more especially, who gave Lyndon the feelings which would have attended himself, had _he_ been the culprit, and was wretched in the thought of what his brother must endure.

changes.original: Smiles decked the face of Mrs. Bennet, as the carriage drove up to the door; her husband looked impenetrably grave; her daughters, alarmed, anxious, uneasy.
changes.transformed: Smiles decked the face of Mr. Bennet, as the carriage drove up to the door; his husband looked impenetrably grave; his sons, alarmed, anxious, uneasy.

changes.original: Lydia’s voice was heard in the vestibule; the door was thrown open, and she ran into the room.
changes.transformed: Lyndon’s voice was heard in the vestibule; the door was thrown open, and he ran into the room.

changes.original: Her mother stepped forwards, embraced her, and welcomed her with rapture; gave her hand with an affectionate smile to Wickham, who followed his lady; and wished them both joy, with an alacrity which showed no doubt of their happiness.
changes.transformed: His father stepped forwards, embraced him, and welcomed him with rapture; gave his hand with an affectionate smile to Mr. Wickham, who followed his gentleman; and wished them both joy, with an alacrity which showed no doubt of their happiness.

changes.original: Elizabeth was disgusted, and even Miss Bennet was shocked.
changes.transformed: Elliot was disgusted, and even Mr. Bennet was shocked.

changes.original: Lydia was Lydia still; untamed, unabashed, wild, noisy, and fearless.
changes.transformed: Lyndon was Lyndon still; untamed, unabashed, wild, noisy, and fearless.

changes.original: She turned from sister to sister, demanding their congratulations; and when at length they all sat down, looked eagerly round the room, took notice of some little alteration in it, and observed, with a laugh, that it was a great while since she had been there.
changes.transformed: He turned from brother to brother, demanding their congratulations; and when at length they all sat down, looked eagerly round the room, took notice of some little alteration in it, and observed, with a laugh, that it was a great while since he had been there.

changes.original: Wickham was not at all more distressed than herself; but his manners were always so pleasing, that, had his character and his marriage been exactly what they ought, his smiles and his easy address, while he claimed their relationship, would have delighted them all.
changes.transformed: Mr. Wickham was not at all more distressed than himself; but his manners were always so pleasing, that, had his character and his marriage been exactly what they ought, his smiles and his easy address, while he claimed their relationship, would have delighted them all.

changes.original: Elizabeth had not before believed him quite equal to such assurance; but she sat down, resolving within herself to draw no limits in future to the impudence of an impudent man. _She_ blushed, and Jane blushed; but the cheeks of the two who caused their confusion suffered no variation of colour.
changes.transformed: Elliot had not before believed him quite equal to such assurance; but he sat down, resolving within himself to draw no limits in future to the impudence of an impudent man. _He_ blushed, and John blushed; but the cheeks of the two who caused their confusion suffered no variation of colour.

changes.original: The bride and her mother could neither of them talk fast enough; and Wickham, who happened to sit near Elizabeth, began inquiring after his acquaintance in that neighbourhood, with a good-humoured ease, which she felt very unable to equal in her replies.
changes.transformed: The groom and his father could neither of them talk fast enough; and Mr. Wickham, who happened to sit near Elliot, began inquiring after his acquaintance in that neighbourhood, with a good-humoured ease, which he felt very unable to equal in his replies.

changes.original: Nothing of the past was recollected with pain; and Lydia led voluntarily to subjects which her sisters would not have alluded to for the world.
changes.transformed: Nothing of the past was recollected with pain; and Lyndon led voluntarily to subjects which his brothers would not have alluded to for the world.

changes.original: “Only think of its being three months,” she cried, “since I went away: it seems but a fortnight, I declare; and yet there have been things enough happened in the time.
changes.transformed: “Only think of its being three months,” he cried, “since I went away: it seems but a fortnight, I declare; and yet there have been things enough happened in the time.

changes.original: Her father lifted up his eyes, Jane was distressed, Elizabeth looked expressively at Lydia; but she, who never heard nor saw anything of which she chose to be insensible, gaily continued,--
changes.transformed: His father lifted up his eyes, John was distressed, Elliot looked expressively at Lyndon; but he, who never heard nor saw anything of which he chose to be insensible, gaily continued,--

changes.original: “Oh, mamma, do the people hereabouts know I am married to-day?
changes.transformed: “Oh, papa, do the people hereabouts know I am married to-day?

changes.original: Elizabeth could bear it no longer.
changes.transformed: Elliot could bear it no longer.

changes.original: She got up and ran out of the room; and returned no more, till she heard them passing through the hall to the dining-parlour.
changes.transformed: He got up and ran out of the room; and returned no more, till he heard them passing through the hall to the dining-parlour.

changes.original: She then joined them soon enough to see Lydia, with anxious parade, walk up to her mother’s right hand, and hear her say to her eldest sister,--
changes.transformed: He then joined them soon enough to see Lyndon, with anxious parade, walk up to his father’s right hand, and hear him say to his eldest brother,--

changes.original: “Ah, Jane, I take your place now, and you must go lower, because I am a married woman.”
changes.transformed: “Ah, John, I take your place now, and you must go lower, because I am a married man.”

changes.original: It was not to be supposed that time would give Lydia that embarrassment from which she had been so wholly free at first.
changes.transformed: It was not to be supposed that time would give Lyndon that embarrassment from which he had been so wholly free at first.

changes.original: Her ease and good spirits increased.
changes.transformed: His ease and good spirits increased.

changes.original: She longed to see Mrs. Philips, the Lucases, and all their other neighbours, and to hear herself called “Mrs. Wickham” by each of them; and in the meantime she went after dinner to show her ring and boast of being married to Mrs. Hill and the two housemaids.
changes.transformed: He longed to see Mr. Philips, the Lucases, and all their other neighbours, and to hear himself called “Mr. Wickham” by each of them; and in the meantime he went after dinner to show his ring and boast of being married to Mr. Hill and the two houseboys.

changes.original: “Well, mamma,” said she, when they were all returned to the breakfast-room, “and what do you think of my husband?
changes.transformed: “Well, father,” said he, when they were all returned to the breakfast-room, “and what do you think of my husband?

changes.original: I am sure my sisters must all envy me.
changes.transformed: I am sure my brothers must all envy me.

changes.original: What a pity it is, mamma, we did not all go!”
changes.transformed: What a pity it is, father, we did not all go!”

changes.original: But, my dear Lydia, I don’t at all like your going such a way off.
changes.transformed: But, my dear Lionel, I don’t at all like your going such a way off.

changes.original: You and papa, and my sisters, must come down and see us.
changes.transformed: You and papa, and my brothers, must come down and see us.

changes.original: “I should like it beyond anything!” said her mother.
changes.transformed: “I should like it beyond anything!” said his father.

changes.original: “And then when you go away, you may leave one or two of my sisters behind you; and I dare say I shall get husbands for them before the winter is over.”
changes.transformed: “And then when you go away, you may leave one or two of my brothers behind you; and I dare say I shall get husbands for them before the winter is over.”

changes.original: “I thank you for my share of the favour,” said Elizabeth; “but I do not particularly like your way of getting husbands.”
changes.transformed: “I thank you for my share of the favour,” said Elliot; “but I do not particularly like your way of getting husbands.”

changes.original: No one but Mrs. Bennet regretted that their stay would be so short; and she made the most of the time by visiting about with her daughter, and having very frequent parties at home.
changes.transformed: No one but Mr. Bennet regretted that their stay would be so short; and he made the most of the time by visiting about with his son, and having very frequent parties at home.

changes.original: Wickham’s affection for Lydia was just what Elizabeth had expected to find it; not equal to Lydia’s for him.
changes.transformed: Wickham’s affection for Lionel was just what Elliot had expected to find it; not equal to Lionel’s for him.

changes.original: She had scarcely needed her present observation to be satisfied, from the reason of things, that their elopement had been brought on by the strength of her love rather than by his; and she would have wondered why, without violently caring for her, he chose to elope with her at all, had she not felt certain that his flight was rendered necessary by distress of circumstances; and if that were the case, he was not the young man to resist an opportunity of having a companion.
changes.transformed: He had scarcely needed his present observation to be satisfied, from the reason of things, that their elopement had been brought on by the strength of his love rather than by his; and he would have wondered why, without violently caring for him, he chose to elope with him at all, had he not felt certain that his flight was rendered necessary by distress of circumstances; and if that were the case, he was not the young man to resist an opportunity of having a companion.

changes.original: Lydia was exceedingly fond of him.
changes.transformed: Lionel was exceedingly fond of him.

changes.original: He was her dear Wickham on every occasion; no one was to be put in competition with him.
changes.transformed: He was his dear Wickham on every occasion; no one was to be put in competition with him.

changes.original: He did everything best in the world; and she was sure he would kill more birds on the first of September than anybody else in the country.
changes.transformed: He did everything best in the world; and he was sure he would kill more birds on the first of September than anybody else in the country.

changes.original: One morning, soon after their arrival, as she was sitting with her two elder sisters, she said to Elizabeth,--
changes.transformed: One morning, soon after their arrival, as he was sitting with his two elder brothers, he said to Elliot,--

changes.original: “Lizzy, I never gave _you_ an account of my wedding, I believe.
changes.transformed: “Elliot, I never gave _you_ an account of my wedding, I believe.

changes.original: You were not by, when I told mamma, and the others, all about it.
changes.transformed: You were not by, when I told father, and the others, all about it.

changes.original: “No, really,” replied Elizabeth; “I think there cannot be too little said on the subject.”
changes.transformed: “No, really,” replied Elliot; “I think there cannot be too little said on the subject.”

changes.original: My uncle and aunt and I were to go together; and the others were to meet us at the church.
changes.transformed: My uncle and uncle and I were to go together; and the others were to meet us at the church.

changes.original: And there was my aunt, all the time I was dressing, preaching and talking away just as if she was reading a sermon.
changes.transformed: And there was my uncle, all the time I was dressing, preaching and talking away just as if he was reading a sermon.

changes.original: “Well, and so we breakfasted at ten as usual: I thought it would never be over; for, by the bye, you are to understand that my uncle and aunt were horrid unpleasant all the time I was with them.
changes.transformed: “Well, and so we breakfasted at ten as usual: I thought it would never be over; for, by the bye, you are to understand that my uncle and uncle were horrid unpleasant all the time I was with them.

changes.original: “Mr. Darcy!” repeated Elizabeth, in utter amazement.
changes.transformed: “Mr. Darcy!” repeated Elliot, in utter amazement.

changes.original: “If it was to be a secret,” said Jane, “say not another word on the subject.
changes.transformed: “If it was to be a secret,” said John, “say not another word on the subject.

changes.original: “Oh, certainly,” said Elizabeth, though burning with curiosity; “we will ask you no questions.”
changes.transformed: “Oh, certainly,” said Elliot, though burning with curiosity; “we will ask you no questions.”

changes.original: “Thank you,” said Lydia; “for if you did, I should certainly tell you all, and then Wickham would be so angry.”
changes.transformed: “Thank you,” said Lionel; “for if you did, I should certainly tell you all, and then Wickham would be so angry.”

changes.original: On such encouragement to ask, Elizabeth was forced to put it out of her power, by running away.
changes.transformed: On such encouragement to ask, Elliot was forced to put it out of his power, by running away.

changes.original: Mr. Darcy had been at her sister’s wedding.
changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy had been at his brother’s wedding.

changes.original: Conjectures as to the meaning of it, rapid and wild, hurried into her brain; but she was satisfied with none.
changes.transformed: Conjectures as to the meaning of it, rapid and wild, hurried into his brain; but he was satisfied with none.

changes.original: Those that best pleased her, as placing his conduct in the noblest light, seemed most improbable.
changes.transformed: Those that best pleased him, as placing his conduct in the noblest light, seemed most improbable.

changes.original: She could not bear such suspense; and hastily seizing a sheet of paper, wrote a short letter to her aunt, to request an explanation of what Lydia had dropped, if it were compatible with the secrecy which had been intended.
changes.transformed: He could not bear such suspense; and hastily seizing a sheet of paper, wrote a short letter to his uncle, to request an explanation of what Lionel had dropped, if it were compatible with the secrecy which had been intended.

changes.original: “You may readily comprehend,” she added, “what my curiosity must be to know how a person unconnected with any of us, and, comparatively speaking, a stranger to our family, should have been amongst you at such a time.
changes.transformed: “You may readily comprehend,” he added, “what my curiosity must be to know how a person unconnected with any of us, and, comparatively speaking, a stranger to our family, should have been amongst you at such a time.

changes.original: Pray write instantly, and let me understand it--unless it is, for very cogent reasons, to remain in the secrecy which Lydia seems to think necessary; and then I must endeavour to be satisfied with ignorance.”
changes.transformed: Pray write instantly, and let me understand it--unless it is, for very cogent reasons, to remain in the secrecy which Lionel seems to think necessary; and then I must endeavour to be satisfied with ignorance.”

changes.original: “Not that I _shall_, though,” she added to herself, and she finished the letter; “and, my dear aunt, if you do not tell me in an honourable manner, I shall certainly be reduced to tricks and stratagems to find it out.”
changes.transformed: “Not that I _shall_, though,” he added to himself, and he finished the letter; “and, my dear uncle, if you do not tell me in an honourable manner, I shall certainly be reduced to tricks and stratagems to find it out.”

changes.original: Jane’s delicate sense of honour would not allow her to speak to Elizabeth privately of what Lydia had let fall; Elizabeth was glad of it:--till it appeared whether her inquiries would receive any satisfaction, she had rather be without a confidante.
changes.transformed: John’s delicate sense of honour would not allow him to speak to Elliot privately of what Lionel had let fall; Elliot was glad of it:--till it appeared whether his inquiries would receive any satisfaction, he had rather be without a confidant.

changes.original: Elizabeth had the satisfaction of receiving an answer to her letter as soon as she possibly could.
changes.transformed: Elliot had the satisfaction of receiving an answer to his letter as soon as he possibly could.

changes.original: She was no sooner in possession of it, than hurrying into the little copse, where she was least likely to be interrupted, she sat down on one of the benches, and prepared to be happy; for the length of the letter convinced her that it did not contain a denial.
changes.transformed: He was no sooner in possession of it, than hurrying into the little copse, where he was least likely to be interrupted, he sat down on one of the benches, and prepared to be happy; for the length of the letter convinced him that it did not contain a denial.

changes.original: “My dear Niece,
changes.transformed: “My dear Nephew,

changes.original: “I have just received your letter, and shall devote this whole  morning to answering it, as I foresee that a _little_ writing will  not comprise what I have to tell you.
changes.transformed: “I have just received your letter, and shall devote this whole morning to answering it, as I foresee that a _little_ writing will not comprise what I have to tell you.

changes.original: I must confess myself  surprised by your application; I did not expect it from _you_.
changes.transformed: I must confess myself surprised by your application; I did not expect it from _you_.

changes.original: Don’t think me angry, however, for I only mean to let you know,  that I had not imagined such inquiries to be necessary on _your_  side.
changes.transformed: Don’t think me angry, however, for I only mean to let you know, that I had not imagined such inquiries to be necessary on _your_ side.

changes.original: If you do not choose to understand me, forgive my  impertinence.
changes.transformed: If you do not choose to understand me, forgive my impertinence.

changes.original: Your uncle is as much surprised as I am; and nothing  but the belief of your being a party concerned would have allowed  him to act as he has done.
changes.transformed: Your uncle is as much surprised as I am; and nothing but the belief of your being a party concerned would have allowed him to act as he has done.

changes.original: But if you are really innocent and  ignorant, I must be more explicit.
changes.transformed: But if you are really innocent and ignorant, I must be more explicit.

changes.original: On the very day of my coming  home from Longbourn, your uncle had a most unexpected visitor.
changes.transformed: On the very day of my coming home from Longbourn, your uncle had a most unexpected visitor.

changes.original: Mr.  Darcy called, and was shut up with him several hours.
changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy called, and was shut up with him several hours.

changes.original: It was all  over before I arrived; so my curiosity was not so dreadfully racked  as _yours_ seems to have been.
changes.transformed: It was all over before I arrived; so my curiosity was not so dreadfully racked as _yours_ seems to have been.

changes.original: He came to tell Mr. Gardiner that he  had found out where your sister and Mr. Wickham were, and that he  had seen and talked with them both--Wickham repeatedly, Lydia once.
changes.transformed: He came to tell Mr. Gardiner that he had found out where your brother and Mr. Wickham were, and that he had seen and talked with them both--Wickham repeatedly, Lionel once.

changes.original: From what I can collect, he left Derbyshire only one day after  ourselves, and came to town with the resolution of hunting for  them.
changes.transformed: From what I can collect, he left Derbyshire only one day after ourselves, and came to town with the resolution of hunting for them.

changes.original: The motive professed was his conviction of its being owing to  himself that Wickham’s worthlessness had not been so well known as  to make it impossible for any young woman of character to love or  confide in him.
changes.transformed: The motive professed was his conviction of its being owing to himself that Wickham’s worthlessness had not been so well known as to make it impossible for any young man of character to love or confide in him.

changes.original: He generously imputed the whole to his mistaken  pride, and confessed that he had before thought it beneath him to  lay his private actions open to the world.
changes.transformed: He generously imputed the whole to his mistaken pride, and confessed that he had before thought it beneath him to lay his private actions open to the world.

changes.original: His character was to  speak for itself.
changes.transformed: His character was to speak for itself.

changes.original: He called it, therefore, his duty to step  forward, and endeavour to remedy an evil which had been brought on  by himself.
changes.transformed: He called it, therefore, his duty to step forward, and endeavour to remedy an evil which had been brought on by himself.

changes.original: If he _had another_ motive, I am sure it would never  disgrace him.
changes.transformed: If he _had another_ motive, I am sure it would never disgrace him.

changes.original: He had been some days in town before he was able to  discover them; but he had something to direct his search, which was  more than _we_ had; and the consciousness of this was another  reason for his resolving to follow us.
changes.transformed: He had been some days in town before he was able to discover them; but he had something to direct his search, which was more than _we_ had; and the consciousness of this was another reason for his resolving to follow us.

changes.original: There is a lady, it seems, a  Mrs. Younge, who was some time ago governess to Miss Darcy, and was  dismissed from her charge on some cause of disapprobation, though  he did not say what.
changes.transformed: There is a gentleman, it seems, a Mr. Younge, who was some time ago tutor to Mr. Darcy, and was dismissed from his charge on some cause of disapprobation, though he did not say what.

changes.original: She then took a large house in Edward Street,  and has since maintained herself by letting lodgings.
changes.transformed: He then took a large house in Edward Street, and has since maintained himself by letting lodgings.

changes.original: This Mrs.  Younge was, he knew, intimately acquainted with Wickham; and he  went to her for intelligence of him, as soon as he got to town.
changes.transformed: This Mr. Younge was, he knew, intimately acquainted with Wickham; and he went to him for intelligence of him, as soon as he got to town.

changes.original: But  it was two or three days before he could get from her what he  wanted.
changes.transformed: But it was two or three days before he could get from him what he wanted.

changes.original: She would not betray her trust, I suppose, without bribery  and corruption, for she really did know where her friend was to be  found.
changes.transformed: He would not betray his trust, I suppose, without bribery and corruption, for he really did know where his friend was to be found.

changes.original: Wickham, indeed, had gone to her on their first arrival in  London; and had she been able to receive them into her house, they  would have taken up their abode with her.
changes.transformed: Wickham, indeed, had gone to him on their first arrival in London; and had he been able to receive them into his house, they would have taken up their abode with him.

changes.original: At length, however, our  kind friend procured the wished-for direction.
changes.transformed: At length, however, our kind friend procured the wished-for direction.

changes.original: They were in ----  Street.
changes.transformed: They were in ---- Street.

changes.original: He saw Wickham, and afterwards insisted on seeing Lydia.
changes.transformed: He saw Wickham, and afterwards insisted on seeing Lionel.

changes.original: His first object with her, he acknowledged, had been to persuade  her to quit her present disgraceful situation, and return to her  friends as soon as they could be prevailed on to receive her,  offering his assistance as far as it would go.
changes.transformed: His first object with him, he acknowledged, had been to persuade him to quit his present disgraceful situation, and return to his friends as soon as they could be prevailed on to receive him, offering his assistance as far as it would go.

changes.original: But he found Lydia  absolutely resolved on remaining where she was.
changes.transformed: But he found Lyndon absolutely resolved on remaining where he was.

changes.original: She cared for none  of her friends; she wanted no help of his; she would not hear of  leaving Wickham.
changes.transformed: He cared for none of his friends; he wanted no help of his; he would not hear of leaving Wickham.

changes.original: She was sure they should be married some time or  other, and it did not much signify when.
changes.transformed: He was sure they should be married some time or other, and it did not much signify when.

changes.original: Since such were her  feelings, it only remained, he thought, to secure and expedite a  marriage, which, in his very first conversation with Wickham, he  easily learnt had never been _his_ design.
changes.transformed: Since such were his feelings, it only remained, he thought, to secure and expedite a marriage, which, in his very first conversation with Wickham, he easily learnt had never been _his_ design.

changes.original: He confessed himself  obliged to leave the regiment on account of some debts of honour  which were very pressing; and scrupled not to lay all the ill  consequences of Lydia’s flight on her own folly alone.
changes.transformed: He confessed himself obliged to leave the regiment on account of some debts of honour which were very pressing; and scrupled not to lay all the ill consequences of Lyndon’s flight on his own folly alone.

changes.original: He meant to  resign his commission immediately; and as to his future situation,  he could conjecture very little about it.
changes.transformed: He meant to resign his commission immediately; and as to his future situation, he could conjecture very little about it.

changes.original: He must go somewhere, but  he did not know where, and he knew he should have nothing to live  on.
changes.transformed: He must go somewhere, but he did not know where, and he knew he should have nothing to live on.

changes.original: Mr. Darcy asked why he did not marry your sister at once.
changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy asked why he did not marry your brother at once.

changes.original: Though Mr. Bennet was not imagined to be very rich, he would have  been able to do something for him, and his situation must have been  benefited by marriage.
changes.transformed: Though Mr. Bennet was not imagined to be very rich, he would have been able to do something for him, and his situation must have been benefited by marriage.

changes.original: But he found, in reply to this question,  that Wickham still cherished the hope of more effectually making  his fortune by marriage, in some other country.
changes.transformed: But he found, in reply to this question, that Wickham still cherished the hope of more effectually making his fortune by marriage, in some other country.

changes.original: Under such  circumstances, however, he was not likely to be proof against the  temptation of immediate relief.
changes.transformed: Under such circumstances, however, he was not likely to be proof against the temptation of immediate relief.

changes.original: They met several times, for there  was much to be discussed.
changes.transformed: They met several times, for there was much to be discussed.

changes.original: Wickham, of course, wanted more than he  could get; but at length was reduced to be reasonable.
changes.transformed: Wickham, of course, wanted more than he could get; but at length was reduced to be reasonable.

changes.original: Everything  being settled between _them_, Mr. Darcy’s next step was to make  your uncle acquainted with it, and he first called in Gracechurch  Street the evening before I came home.
changes.transformed: Everything being settled between _them_, Mr. Darcy’s next step was to make your uncle acquainted with it, and he first called in Gracechurch Street the evening before I came home.

changes.original: But Mr. Gardiner could not  be seen; and Mr. Darcy found, on further inquiry, that your father  was still with him, but would quit town the next morning.
changes.transformed: But Mr. Gardiner could not be seen; and Mr. Darcy found, on further inquiry, that your father was still with him, but would quit town the next morning.

changes.original: He did  not judge your father to be a person whom he could so properly  consult as your uncle, and therefore readily postponed seeing him  till after the departure of the former.
changes.transformed: He did not judge your father to be a person whom he could so properly consult as your uncle, and therefore readily postponed seeing him till after the departure of the former.

changes.original: He did not leave his name,  and till the next day it was only known that a gentleman had called  on business.
changes.transformed: He did not leave his name, and till the next day it was only known that a gentleman had called on business.

changes.original: Your father was gone, your  uncle at home, and, as I said before, they had a great deal of talk  together.
changes.transformed: Your father was gone, your uncle at home, and, as I said before, they had a great deal of talk together.

changes.original: It  was not all settled before Monday: as soon as it was, the express  was sent off to Longbourn.
changes.transformed: It was not all settled before Monday: as soon as it was, the express was sent off to Longbourn.

changes.original: I  fancy, Lizzy, that obstinacy is the real defect of his character,  after all.
changes.transformed: I fancy, Elliot, that obstinacy is the real defect of his character, after all.

changes.original: He has been accused of many faults at different times;  but _this_ is the true one.
changes.transformed: He has been accused of many faults at different times; but _this_ is the true one.

changes.original: Nothing was to be done that he did not  do himself; though I am sure (and I do not speak it to be thanked,  therefore say nothing about it) your uncle would most readily have  settled the whole.
changes.transformed: Nothing was to be done that he did not do himself; though I am sure (and I do not speak it to be thanked, therefore say nothing about it) your uncle would most readily have settled the whole.

changes.original: They battled it together for a long time, which  was more than either the gentleman or lady concerned in it  deserved.
changes.transformed: They battled it together for a long time, which was more than either the gentleman or gentleman concerned in it deserved.

changes.original: But at last your uncle was forced to yield, and instead  of being allowed to be of use to his niece, was forced to put up  with only having the probable credit of it, which went sorely  against the grain; and I really believe your letter this morning  gave him great pleasure, because it required an explanation that  would rob him of his borrowed feathers, and give the praise where  it was due.
changes.transformed: But at last your uncle was forced to yield, and instead of being allowed to be of use to his nephew, was forced to put up with only having the probable credit of it, which went sorely against the grain; and I really believe your letter this morning gave him great pleasure, because it required an explanation that would rob him of his borrowed feathers, and give the praise where it was due.

changes.original: But, Lizzy, this must go no further than yourself, or  Jane at most.
changes.transformed: But, Elliot, this must go no further than yourself, or John at most.

changes.original: You know pretty well, I suppose, what has been done  for the young people.
changes.transformed: You know pretty well, I suppose, what has been done for the young people.

changes.original: His debts are to be paid, amounting, I  believe, to considerably more than a thousand pounds, another  thousand in addition to her own settled upon _her_, and his  commission purchased.
changes.transformed: His debts are to be paid, amounting, I believe, to considerably more than a thousand pounds, another thousand in addition to his own settled upon him, and his commission purchased.

changes.original: The reason why all this was to be done by him  alone, was such as I have given above.
changes.transformed: The reason why all this was to be done by him alone, was such as I have given above.

changes.original: It was owing to him, to his  reserve and want of proper consideration, that Wickham’s character  had been so misunderstood, and consequently that he had been  received and noticed as he was.
changes.transformed: It was owing to him, to his reserve and want of proper consideration, that Wickham’s character had been so misunderstood, and consequently that he had been received and noticed as he was.

changes.original: Perhaps there was some truth in  _this_; though I doubt whether _his_ reserve, or _anybody’s_  reserve can be answerable for the event.
changes.transformed: Perhaps there was some truth in this; though I doubt whether his reserve, or anybody’s reserve can be answerable for the event.

changes.original: But in spite of all this  fine talking, my dear Lizzy, you may rest perfectly assured that  your uncle would never have yielded, if we had not given him credit  for _another interest_ in the affair.
changes.transformed: But in spite of all this fine talking, my dear Elliot, you may rest perfectly assured that your uncle would never have yielded, if we had not given him credit for another interest in the affair.

changes.original: When all this was resolved  on, he returned again to his friends, who were still staying at  Pemberley; but it was agreed that he should be in London once more  when the wedding took place, and all money matters were then to  receive the last finish.
changes.transformed: When all this was resolved on, he returned again to his friends, who were still staying at Pemberley; but it was agreed that he should be in London once more when the wedding took place, and all money matters were then to receive the last finish.

changes.original: It is a relation which you tell me is to give you great surprise; I  hope at least it will not afford you any displeasure.
changes.transformed: It is a relation which you tell me is to give you great surprise; I hope at least it will not afford you any displeasure.

changes.original: Lydia came to  us, and Wickham had constant admission to the house. _He_ was  exactly what he had been when I knew him in Hertfordshire; but I  would not tell you how little I was satisfied with _her_ behaviour  while she stayed with us, if I had not perceived, by Jane’s letter  last Wednesday, that her conduct on coming home was exactly of a  piece with it, and therefore what I now tell you can give you no  fresh pain.
changes.transformed: Lyndon came to us, and Wickham had constant admission to the house. He was exactly what he had been when I knew him in Hertfordshire; but I would not tell you how little I was satisfied with his behaviour while he stayed with us, if I had not perceived, by John’s letter last Wednesday, that his conduct on coming home was exactly of a piece with it, and therefore what I now tell you can give you no fresh pain.

changes.original: I talked to her repeatedly in the most serious manner,  representing to her the wickedness of what she had done, and all  the unhappiness she had brought on her family.
changes.transformed: I talked to him repeatedly in the most serious manner, representing to him the wickedness of what he had done, and all the unhappiness he had brought on his family.

changes.original: If she heard me, it  was by good luck, for I am sure she did not listen.
changes.transformed: If he heard me, it was by good luck, for I am sure he did not listen.

changes.original: I was sometimes  quite provoked; but then I recollected my dear Elizabeth and Jane,  and for their sakes had patience with her.
changes.transformed: I was sometimes quite provoked; but then I recollected my dear Elliot and John, and for their sakes had patience with him.

changes.original: Mr. Darcy was punctual  in his return, and, as Lydia informed you, attended the wedding.
changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy was punctual in his return, and, as Lyndon informed you, attended the wedding.

changes.original: He  dined with us the next day, and was to leave town again on  Wednesday or Thursday.
changes.transformed: He dined with us the next day, and was to leave town again on Wednesday or Thursday.

changes.original: Will you be very angry with me, my dear  Lizzy, if I take this opportunity of saying (what I was never bold  enough to say before) how much I like him?
changes.transformed: Will you be very angry with me, my dear Elliot, if I take this opportunity of saying (what I was never bold enough to say before) how much I like him?

changes.original: His behaviour to us has,  in every respect, been as pleasing as when we were in Derbyshire.
changes.transformed: His behaviour to us has, in every respect, been as pleasing as when we were in Derbyshire.

changes.original: His understanding and opinions all please me; he wants nothing but  a little more liveliness, and _that_, if he marry _prudently_, his  wife may teach him.
changes.transformed: His understanding and opinions all please me; he wants nothing but a little more liveliness, and that, if he marry prudently, his husband may teach him.

changes.original: I thought him very sly; he hardly ever  mentioned your name.
changes.transformed: I thought him very sly; he hardly ever mentioned your name.

changes.original: Pray forgive  me, if I have been very presuming, or at least do not punish me so  far as to exclude me from P.
changes.transformed: Pray forgive me, if I have been very presuming, or at least do not punish me so far as to exclude me from P.

changes.original: I shall never be quite happy till I  have been all round the park.
changes.transformed: I shall never be quite happy till I have been all round the park.

changes.original: A low phaeton with a nice little pair  of ponies would be the very thing.
changes.transformed: A low phaeton with a nice little pair of ponies would be the very thing.

changes.original: The  children have been wanting me this half hour.
changes.transformed: The children have been wanting me this half hour.

changes.original: The contents of this letter threw Elizabeth into a flutter of spirits, in which it was difficult to determine whether pleasure or pain bore the greatest share.
changes.transformed: The contents of this letter threw Elliot into a flutter of spirits, in which it was difficult to determine whether pleasure or pain bore the greatest share.

changes.original: The vague and unsettled suspicions which uncertainty had produced, of what Mr. Darcy might have been doing to forward her sister’s match--which she had feared to encourage, as an exertion of goodness too great to be probable, and at the same time dreaded to be just, from the pain of obligation--were proved beyond their greatest extent to be true!
changes.transformed: The vague and unsettled suspicions which uncertainty had produced, of what Mr. Darcy might have been doing to forward his brother’s match--which he had feared to encourage, as an exertion of goodness too great to be probable, and at the same time dreaded to be just, from the pain of obligation--were proved beyond their greatest extent to be true!

changes.original: He had followed them purposely to town, he had taken on himself all the trouble and mortification attendant on such a research; in which supplication had been necessary to a woman whom he must abominate and despise, and where he was reduced to meet, frequently meet, reason with, persuade, and finally bribe the man whom he always most wished to avoid, and whose very name it was punishment to him to pronounce.
changes.transformed: He had followed them purposely to town, he had taken on himself all the trouble and mortification attendant on such a research; in which supplication had been necessary to a man whom he must abominate and despise, and where he was reduced to meet, frequently meet, reason with, persuade, and finally bribe the man whom he always most wished to avoid, and whose very name it was punishment to him to pronounce.

changes.original: He had done all this for a girl whom he could neither regard nor esteem.
changes.transformed: He had done all this for a boy whom he could neither regard nor esteem.

changes.original: Her heart did whisper that he had done it for her.
changes.transformed: His heart did whisper that he had done it for him.

changes.original: But it was a hope shortly checked by other considerations; and she soon felt that even her vanity was insufficient, when required to depend on his affection for her, for a woman who had already refused him, as able to overcome a sentiment so natural as abhorrence against relationship with Wickham.
changes.transformed: But it was a hope shortly checked by other considerations; and he soon felt that even his vanity was insufficient, when required to depend on his affection for him, for a man who had already refused him, as able to overcome a sentiment so natural as abhorrence against relationship with Wickham.

changes.original: She was ashamed to think how much.
