changes.original: It was reasonable that he should feel he had been wrong; he had liberality, and he had the means of exercising it; and though she would not place herself as his principal inducement, she could perhaps believe, that remaining partiality for her might assist his endeavours in a cause where her peace of mind must be materially concerned.
changes.transformed: It was reasonable that he should feel he had been wrong; he had liberality, and he had the means of exercising it; and though he would not place himself as his principal inducement, he could perhaps believe, that remaining partiality for him might assist his endeavours in a cause where his peace of mind must be materially concerned.

changes.original: They owed the restoration of Lydia, her character, everything to him.
changes.transformed: They owed the restoration of Lyndon, his character, everything to him.

changes.original: Oh, how heartily did she grieve over every ungracious sensation she had ever encouraged, every saucy speech she had ever directed towards him!
changes.transformed: Oh, how heartily did he grieve over every ungracious sensation he had ever encouraged, every saucy speech he had ever directed towards him!

changes.original: For herself she was humbled; but she was proud of him,--proud that in a cause of compassion and honour he had been able to get the better of himself.
changes.transformed: For himself he was humbled; but he was proud of him,--proud that in a cause of compassion and honour he had been able to get the better of himself.

changes.original: She read over her aunt’s commendation of him again and again.
changes.transformed: He read over his uncle’s commendation of him again and again.

changes.original: It was hardly enough; but it pleased her.
changes.transformed: It was hardly enough; but it pleased him.

changes.original: She was even sensible of some pleasure, though mixed with regret, on finding how steadfastly both she and her uncle had been persuaded that affection and confidence subsisted between Mr. Darcy and herself.
changes.transformed: He was even sensible of some pleasure, though mixed with regret, on finding how steadfastly both he and his uncle had been persuaded that affection and confidence subsisted between Mr. Darcy and himself.

changes.original: She was roused from her seat and her reflections, by someone’s approach; and, before she could strike into another path, she was overtaken by Wickham.
changes.transformed: He was roused from his seat and his reflections, by someone’s approach; and, before he could strike into another path, he was overtaken by Wickham.

changes.original: “I am afraid I interrupt your solitary ramble, my dear sister?” said he, as he joined her.
changes.transformed: “I am afraid I interrupt your solitary ramble, my dear brother?” said he, as he joined him.

changes.original: “You certainly do,” she replied with a smile; “but it does not follow that the interruption must be unwelcome.”
changes.transformed: “You certainly do,” he replied with a smile; “but it does not follow that the interruption must be unwelcome.”

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet and Lydia are going in the carriage to Meryton.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet and Lyndon are going in the carriage to Meryton.

changes.original: And so, my dear sister, I find, from our uncle and aunt, that you have actually seen Pemberley.”
changes.transformed: And so, my dear brother, I find, from our uncle and uncle, that you have actually seen Pemberley.”

changes.original: She replied in the affirmative.
changes.transformed: He replied in the affirmative.

changes.original: Poor Reynolds, she was always very fond of me.

changes.original: But of course she did not mention my name to you.”
changes.transformed: But of course he did not mention my name to you.”

changes.original: “Yes, she did.”
changes.transformed: “Yes, he did.”

changes.original: “And what did she say?”
changes.transformed: “And what did he say?”

changes.original: “That you were gone into the army, and she was afraid had--not turned out well.
changes.transformed: “That you were gone into the army, and he was afraid had--not turned out well.

changes.original: Elizabeth hoped she had silenced him; but he soon afterwards said,--
changes.transformed: Elliot hoped he had silenced him; but he soon afterwards said,--

changes.original: “Perhaps preparing for his marriage with Miss de Bourgh,” said Elizabeth. “It must be something particular to take him there at this time of year.”
changes.transformed: “Perhaps preparing for his marriage with Mr. de Bourgh,” said Elliot. “It must be something particular to take him there at this time of year.”

changes.original: “Yes; he introduced us to his sister.”
changes.transformed: “Yes; he introduced us to his brother.”

changes.original: “And do you like her?”
changes.transformed: “And do you like him?”

changes.original: “I have heard, indeed, that she is uncommonly improved within this year or two.
changes.transformed: “I have heard, indeed, that he is uncommonly improved within this year or two.

changes.original: When I last saw her, she was not very promising.
changes.transformed: When I last saw him, he was not very promising.

changes.original: I am very glad you liked her.
changes.transformed: I am very glad you liked him.

changes.original: I hope she will turn out well.”
changes.transformed: I hope he will turn out well.”

changes.original: “I dare say she will; she has got over the most trying age.”
changes.transformed: “I dare say he will; he has got over the most trying age.”

changes.original: They were now almost at the door of the house, for she had walked fast to get rid of him; and unwilling, for her sister’s sake, to provoke him, she only said in reply, with a good-humoured smile,--
changes.transformed: They were now almost at the door of the house, for he had walked fast to get rid of him; and unwilling, for his brother’s sake, to provoke him, he only said in reply, with a good-humoured smile,--

changes.original: “Come, Mr. Wickham, we are brother and sister, you know.
changes.transformed: “Come, Mr. Wickham, we are brother and brother, you know.

changes.original: She held out her hand: he kissed it with affectionate gallantry, though he hardly knew how to look, and they entered the house.
changes.transformed: He held out his hand: he kissed it with affectionate gallantry, though he hardly knew how to look, and they entered the house.

changes.original: Mr. Wickham was so perfectly satisfied with this conversation, that he never again distressed himself, or provoked his dear sister Elizabeth, by introducing the subject of it; and she was pleased to find that she had said enough to keep him quiet.
changes.transformed: Mr. Wickham was so perfectly satisfied with this conversation, that he never again distressed himself, or provoked his dear brother Elliot, by introducing the subject of it; and he was pleased to find that he had said enough to keep him quiet.

changes.original: The day of his and Lydia’s departure soon came; and Mrs. Bennet was forced to submit to a separation, which, as her husband by no means entered into her scheme of their all going to Newcastle, was likely to continue at least a twelvemonth.
changes.transformed: The day of his and Lionel’s departure soon came; and Mr. Bennet was forced to submit to a separation, which, as his husband by no means entered into his scheme of their all going to Newcastle, was likely to continue at least a twelvemonth.

changes.original: “Oh, my dear Lydia,” she cried, “when shall we meet again?”
changes.transformed: “Oh, my dear Lionel,” he cried, “when shall we meet again?”

changes.original: But you know married women have never much time for writing.
changes.transformed: But you know married men have never much time for writing.

changes.original: My sisters may write to _me_.
changes.transformed: My brothers may write to _me_.

changes.original: Mr. Wickham’s adieus were much more affectionate than his wife’s.
changes.transformed: Mr. Wickham’s adieus were much more affectionate than his husband’s.

changes.original: The loss of her daughter made Mrs. Bennet very dull for several days.
changes.transformed: The loss of his son made Mr. Bennet very dull for several days.

changes.original: “I often think,” said she, “that there is nothing so bad as parting with one’s friends.
changes.transformed: “I often think,” said he, “that there is nothing so bad as parting with one’s friends.

changes.transformed: “This is the consequence, you see, sir, of marrying a son,” said Elliot. “It must make you better satisfied that your other four are single.”

changes.original: Lydia does not leave me because she is married; but only because her husband’s regiment happens to be so far off.
changes.transformed: Lionel does not leave me because he is married; but only because his husband’s regiment happens to be so far off.

changes.original: If that had been nearer, she would not have gone so soon.”
changes.transformed: If that had been nearer, he would not have gone so soon.”

changes.original: But the spiritless condition which this event threw her into was shortly relieved, and her mind opened again to the agitation of hope, by an article of news which then began to be in circulation.
changes.transformed: But the spiritless condition which this event threw him into was shortly relieved, and his mind opened again to the agitation of hope, by an article of news which then began to be in circulation.

changes.transformed: The housekeeper at Netherfield had received orders to prepare for the arrival of his master, who was coming down in a day or two, to shoot there for several weeks.

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet was quite in the fidgets.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet was quite in the fidgets.

changes.transformed: He looked at John, and smiled, and shook his head, by turns.

changes.transformed: “Well, well, and so Mr. Bingley is coming down, brother,” (for Mr. Philips first brought him the news). “Well, so much the better.

changes.original: You know, sister, we agreed long ago never to mention a word about it.
changes.transformed: You know, brother, we agreed long ago never to mention a word about it.

changes.original: “You may depend on it,” replied the other, “for Mrs. Nichols was in Meryton last night: I saw her passing by, and went out myself on purpose to know the truth of it; and she told me that it was certainly true.
changes.transformed: “You may depend on it,” replied the other, “for Mr. Nichols was in Meryton last night: I saw him passing by, and went out myself on purpose to know the truth of it; and he told me that it was certainly true.

changes.original: She was going to the butcher’s, she told me, on purpose to order in some meat on Wednesday, and she has got three couple of ducks just fit to be killed.”
changes.transformed: He was going to the butcher’s, he told me, on purpose to order in some meat on Wednesday, and he has got three couple of ducks just fit to be killed.”

changes.original: Miss Bennet had not been able to hear of his coming without changing colour.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet had not been able to hear of his coming without changing colour.

changes.transformed: It was many months since he had mentioned his name to Elliot; but now, as soon as they were alone together, he said,--

changes.original: “I saw you look at me to-day, Lizzy, when my aunt told us of the present report; and I know I appeared distressed; but don’t imagine it was from any silly cause.
changes.transformed: “I saw you look at me to-day, Elliot, when my uncle told us of the present report; and I know I appeared distressed; but don’t imagine it was from any silly cause.

changes.original: Elizabeth did not know what to make of it.

changes.original: Had she not seen him in Derbyshire, she might have supposed him capable of coming there with no other view than what was acknowledged; but she still thought him partial to Jane, and she wavered as to the greater probability of his coming there _with_ his friend’s permission, or being bold enough to come without it.
changes.transformed: Had he not seen him in Derbyshire, he might have supposed him capable of coming there with no other view than what was acknowledged; but he still thought him partial to John, and he wavered as to the greater probability of his coming there _with_ his friend’s permission, or being bold enough to come without it.

changes.original: “Yet it is hard,” she sometimes thought, “that this poor man cannot come to a house, which he has legally hired, without raising all this speculation!
changes.transformed: “Yet it is hard,” he sometimes thought, “that this poor man cannot come to a house, which he has legally hired, without raising all this speculation!

changes.original: In spite of what her sister declared, and really believed to be her feelings, in the expectation of his arrival, Elizabeth could easily perceive that her spirits were affected by it.
changes.transformed: In spite of what his brother declared, and really believed to be his feelings, in the expectation of his arrival, Elliot could easily perceive that his spirits were affected by it.

changes.original: They were more disturbed, more unequal, than she had often seen them.
changes.transformed: They were more disturbed, more unequal, than he had often seen them.

changes.original: The subject which had been so warmly canvassed between their parents, about a twelvemonth ago, was now brought forward again.
changes.transformed: The subject which had been so warmly canvassed between their fathers, about a twelvemonth ago, was now brought forward again.

changes.original: “As soon as ever Mr. Bingley comes, my dear,” said Mrs. Bennet, “you will wait on him, of course.”
changes.transformed: “As soon as ever Mr. Bingley comes, my dear,” said Mr. Bennet, “you will wait on him, of course.”

changes.original: You forced me into visiting him last year, and promised, if I went to see him, he should marry one of my daughters.
changes.transformed: You forced me into visiting him last year, and promised, if I went to see him, he should marry one of my sons.

changes.transformed: His husband represented to him how absolutely necessary such an attention would be from all the neighbouring gentlemen, on his returning to Netherfield.

changes.original: We must have Mrs. Long and the Gouldings soon.
changes.transformed: We must have Mr. Long and the Gouldings soon.

changes.original: Consoled by this resolution, she was the better able to bear her husband’s incivility; though it was very mortifying to know that her neighbours might all see Mr. Bingley, in consequence of it, before _they_ did.

changes.transformed: “I begin to be sorry that he comes at all,” said John to his brother. “It would be nothing; I could see him with perfect indifference; but I can hardly bear to hear it thus perpetually talked of.

changes.original: My mother means well; but she does not know, no one can know, how much I suffer from what she says.

changes.original: “I wish I could say anything to comfort you,” replied Elizabeth; “but it is wholly out of my power.
changes.transformed: “I wish I could say anything to comfort you,” replied Elliot; “but it is wholly out of my power.

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet, through the assistance of servants, contrived to have the earliest tidings of it, that the period of anxiety and fretfulness on her side be as long as it could.

changes.original: She counted the days that must intervene before their invitation could be sent--hopeless of seeing him before.

changes.original: But on the third morning after his arrival in Hertfordshire, she saw him from her dressing-room window enter the paddock, and ride towards the house.
changes.transformed: But on the third morning after his arrival in Hertfordshire, he saw him from his dressing-room window enter the paddock, and ride towards the house.

changes.original: Her daughters were eagerly called to partake of her joy.
changes.transformed: His sons were eagerly called to partake of his joy.

changes.original: Jane resolutely kept her place at the table; but Elizabeth, to satisfy her mother, went to the window--she looked--she saw Mr. Darcy with him, and sat down again by her sister.
changes.transformed: John resolutely kept his place at the table; but Elliot, to satisfy his father, went to the window--he looked--he saw Mr. Darcy with him, and sat down again by his brother.

changes.original: “There is a gentleman with him, mamma,” said Kitty; “who can it be?”
changes.transformed: “There is a gentleman with him, papa,” said Kit; “who can it be?”

changes.original: “La!” replied Kitty, “it looks just like that man that used to be with him before.
changes.transformed: “Ha!” replied Kit, “it looks just like that man that used to be with him before.

changes.original: Jane looked at Elizabeth with surprise and concern.
changes.transformed: John looked at Elliot with surprise and concern.

changes.original: She knew but little of their meeting in Derbyshire, and therefore felt for the awkwardness which must attend her sister, in seeing him almost for the first time after receiving his explanatory letter.
changes.transformed: He knew but little of their meeting in Derbyshire, and therefore felt for the awkwardness which must attend his brother, in seeing him almost for the first time after receiving his explanatory letter.

changes.original: Both sisters were uncomfortable enough.
changes.transformed: Both brothers were uncomfortable enough.

changes.original: Each felt for the other, and of course for themselves; and their mother talked on of her dislike of Mr. Darcy, and her resolution to be civil to him only as Mr. Bingley’s friend, without being heard by either of them.

changes.original: To Jane, he could be only a man whose proposals she had refused, and whose merits she had undervalued; but to her own more extensive information, he was the person to whom the whole family were indebted for the first of benefits, and whom she regarded herself with an interest, if not quite so tender, at least as reasonable and just, as what Jane felt for Bingley.

changes.transformed: His astonishment at his coming--at his coming to Netherfield, to Longbourn, and voluntarily seeking him again, was almost equal to what he had known on first witnessing his altered behaviour in Derbyshire.

changes.original: The colour which had been driven from her face returned for half a minute with an additional glow, and a smile of delight added lustre to her eyes, as she thought for that space of time that his affection and wishes must still be unshaken; but she would not be secure.

changes.transformed: “Let me first see how he behaves,” said he; “it will then be early enough for expectation.”

changes.original: Jane looked a little paler than usual, but more sedate than Elizabeth had expected.
changes.transformed: John looked a little paler than usual, but more sedate than Elliot had expected.

changes.transformed: On the gentlemen’s appearing, his colour increased; yet he received them with tolerable ease, and with a propriety of behaviour equally free from any symptom of resentment, or any unnecessary complaisance.

changes.original: Elizabeth said as little to either as civility would allow, and sat down again to her work, with an eagerness which it did not often command.

changes.original: She had ventured only one glance at Darcy.
changes.transformed: He had ventured only one glance at Darcy.

changes.original: He looked serious as usual; and, she thought, more as he had been used to look in Hertfordshire, than as she had seen him at Pemberley.
changes.transformed: He looked serious as usual; and, he thought, more as he had been used to look in Hertfordshire, than as he had seen him at Pemberley.

changes.original: But, perhaps, he could not in her mother’s presence be what he was before her uncle and aunt.

changes.original: Bingley she had likewise seen for an instant, and in that short period saw him looking both pleased and embarrassed.

changes.transformed: He was received by Mr. Bennet with a degree of civility which made his two sons ashamed, especially when contrasted with the cold and ceremonious politeness of his courtesy and address of his friend.

changes.original: Elizabeth particularly, who knew that her mother owed to the latter the preservation of her favourite daughter from irremediable infamy, was hurt and distressed to a most painful degree by a distinction so ill applied.

changes.original: Darcy, after inquiring of her how Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner did--a question which she could not answer without confusion--said scarcely anything.

changes.original: He was not seated by her: perhaps that was the reason of his silence; but it had not been so in Derbyshire.

changes.original: There he had talked to her friends when he could not to herself.

changes.original: But now several minutes elapsed, without bringing the sound of his voice; and when occasionally, unable to resist the impulse of curiosity, she raised her eyes to his face, she as often found him looking at Jane as at herself, and frequently on no object but the ground.
changes.transformed: But now several minutes elapsed, without bringing the sound of his voice; and when occasionally, unable to resist the impulse of curiosity, he raised his eyes to his face, he as often found him looking at John as at himself, and frequently on no object but the ground.

changes.original: She was disappointed, and angry with herself for being so.

changes.transformed: “Could I expect it to be otherwise?” said he. “Yet why did he come?”

changes.original: She was in no humour for conversation with anyone but himself; and to him she had hardly courage to speak.

changes.transformed: He inquired after his brother, but could do no more.

changes.original: Miss Lucas is married and settled: and one of my own daughters.
changes.transformed: Mr. Lucas is married and settled: and one of my own sons.

changes.original: It was only said, ‘Lately, George Wickham, Esq., to Miss Lydia Bennet,’ without there being a syllable said of her father, or the place where she lived, or anything.

changes.original: Elizabeth dared not lift up her eyes.

changes.original: Elizabeth, who knew this to be levelled at Mr. Darcy, was in such misery of shame that she could hardly keep her seat.

changes.original: It drew from her, however, the exertion of speaking, which nothing else had so effectually done before; and she asked Bingley whether he meant to make any stay in the country at present.
changes.transformed: It drew from him, however, the exertion of speaking, which nothing else had so effectually done before; and he asked Bingley whether he meant to make any stay in the country at present.

changes.transformed: “When you have killed all your own birds, Mr. Bingley,” said his father, “I beg you will come here and shoot as many as you please on Mr. Bennet’s manor.

changes.original: Elizabeth’s misery increased at such unnecessary, such officious attention!
changes.transformed: Elliot’s misery increased at such unnecessary, such officious attention!

changes.original: Were the same fair prospect to arise at present, as had flattered them a year ago, everything, she was persuaded, would be hastening to the same vexatious conclusion.

changes.original: At that instant she felt, that years of happiness could not make Jane or herself amends for moments of such painful confusion.

changes.original: “The first wish of my heart,” said she to herself, “is never more to be in company with either of them.
changes.transformed: “The first wish of my heart,” said he to himself, “is never more to be in company with either of them.

changes.original: Yet the misery, for which years of happiness were to offer no compensation, received soon afterwards material relief, from observing how much the beauty of her sister rekindled the admiration of her former lover.
changes.transformed: Yet the misery, for which years of happiness were to offer no compensation, received soon afterwards material relief, from observing how much the beauty of his brother rekindled the admiration of his former lover.

changes.original: When first he came in, he had spoken to her but little, but every five minutes seemed to be giving her more of his attention.
changes.transformed: When first he came in, he had spoken to him but little, but every five minutes seemed to be giving him more of his attention.

changes.original: He found her as handsome as she had been last year; as good-natured, and as unaffected, though not quite so chatty.
changes.transformed: He found him as handsome as he had been last year; as good-natured, and as unaffected, though not quite so chatty.

changes.original: Jane was anxious that no difference should be perceived in her at all, and was really persuaded that she talked as much as ever; but her mind was so busily engaged, that she did not always know when she was silent.
changes.transformed: John was anxious that no difference should be perceived in him at all, and was really persuaded that he talked as much as ever; but his mind was so busily engaged, that he did not always know when he was silent.

changes.original: When the gentlemen rose to go away, Mrs. Bennet was mindful of her intended civility, and they were invited and engaged to dine at Longbourn in a few days’ time.
changes.transformed: When the gentlemen rose to go away, Mr. Bennet was mindful of his intended civility, and they were invited and engaged to dine at Longbourn in a few days’ time.

changes.original: “You are quite a visit in my debt, Mr. Bingley,” she added; “for when you went to town last winter, you promised to take a family dinner with us as soon as you returned.
changes.transformed: “You are quite a visit in my debt, Mr. Bingley,” he added; “for when you went to town last winter, you promised to take a family dinner with us as soon as you returned.

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet had been strongly inclined to ask them to stay and dine there that day; but, though she always kept a very good table, she did not think anything less than two courses could be good enough for a man on whom she had such anxious designs, or satisfy the appetite and pride of one who had ten thousand a year.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet had been strongly inclined to ask them to stay and dine there that day; but, though he always kept a very good table, he did not think anything less than two courses could be good enough for a man on whom he had such anxious designs, or satisfy the appetite and pride of one who had ten thousand a year.

changes.original: Mr. Darcy’s behaviour astonished and vexed her.
changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy’s behaviour astonished and vexed him.

changes.transformed: “Why, if he came only to be silent, grave, and indifferent,” said he, “did he come at all?”

changes.original: She could settle it in no way that gave her pleasure.
changes.transformed: He could settle it in no way that gave him pleasure.

changes.original: “He could be still amiable, still pleasing to my uncle and aunt, when he was in town; and why not to me?
changes.transformed: “He could be still amiable, still pleasing to my uncle, when he was in town; and why not to me?

changes.original: Her resolution was for a short time involuntarily kept by the approach of her sister, who joined her with a cheerful look which showed her better satisfied with their visitors than Elizabeth.
changes.transformed: His resolution was for a short time involuntarily kept by the approach of his brother, who joined him with a cheerful look which showed him better satisfied with their visitors than Elliot.

changes.original: “Now,” said she, “that this first meeting is over, I feel perfectly easy.

changes.transformed: “Yes, very indifferent, indeed,” said Elliot, laughingly. “Oh, John! take care.”

changes.original: “My dear Lizzy, you cannot think me so weak as to be in danger now.”
changes.transformed: “My dear Elliot, you cannot think me so weak as to be in danger now.”

changes.original: They did not see the gentlemen again till Tuesday; and Mrs. Bennet, in the meanwhile, was giving way to all the happy schemes which the good-humour and common politeness of Bingley, in half an hour’s visit, had revived.
changes.transformed: They did not see the gentlemen again till Tuesday; and Mr. Bennet, in the meanwhile, was giving way to all the happy schemes which the good-humour and common politeness of Bingley, in half an hour’s visit, had revived.

changes.original: When they repaired to the dining-room, Elizabeth eagerly watched to see whether Bingley would take the place which, in all their former parties, had belonged to him, by her sister.
changes.transformed: When they repaired to the dining-room, Elliot eagerly watched to see whether Bingley would take the place which, in all their former parties, had belonged to him, by his brother.

changes.original: Her prudent mother, occupied by the same ideas, forbore to invite him to sit by herself.
changes.transformed: His prudent father, occupied by the same ideas, forbore to invite him to sit by himself.

changes.original: On entering the room, he seemed to hesitate; but Jane happened to look round, and happened to smile: it was decided.
changes.transformed: On entering the room, he seemed to hesitate; but John happened to look round, and happened to smile: it was decided.

changes.original: He placed himself by her.
changes.transformed: He placed himself by him.

changes.original: Elizabeth, with a triumphant sensation, looked towards his friend.
changes.transformed: Elliot, with a triumphant sensation, looked towards his friend.

changes.original: He bore it with noble indifference; and she would have imagined that Bingley had received his sanction to be happy, had she not seen his eyes likewise turned towards Mr. Darcy, with an expression of half-laughing alarm.
changes.transformed: He bore it with noble indifference; and he would have imagined that Bingley had received his sanction to be happy, had he not seen his eyes likewise turned towards Mr. Darcy, with an expression of half-laughing alarm.

changes.original: His behaviour to her sister was such during dinnertime as showed an admiration of her, which, though more guarded than formerly, persuaded Elizabeth, that, if left wholly to himself, Jane’s happiness, and his own, would be speedily secured.
changes.transformed: His behaviour to his brother was such during dinnertime as showed an admiration of him, which, though more guarded than formerly, persuaded Elliot, that, if left wholly to himself, John’s happiness, and his own, would be speedily secured.

changes.original: Though she dared not depend upon the consequence, she yet received pleasure from observing his behaviour.

changes.transformed: It gave him all the animation that his spirits could boast; for he was in no cheerful humour.

changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy was almost as far from him as the table could divide them.

changes.original: He was on one side of her mother.

changes.original: She knew how little such a situation would give pleasure to either, or make either appear to advantage.

changes.original: Her mother’s ungraciousness made the sense of what they owed him more painful to Elizabeth’s mind; and she would, at times, have given anything to be privileged to tell him, that his kindness was neither unknown nor unfelt by the whole of the family.

changes.original: Anxious and uneasy, the period which passed in the drawing-room before the gentlemen came, was wearisome and dull to a degree that almost made her uncivil.

changes.transformed: “If he does not come to me, _then_,” said he, “I shall give him up for ever.”

changes.original: The gentlemen came; and she thought he looked as if he would have answered her hopes; but, alas! the ladies had crowded round the table, where Miss Bennet was making tea, and Elizabeth pouring out the coffee, in so close a confederacy, that there was not a single vacancy near her which would admit of a chair.

changes.transformed: He followed him with his eyes, envied everyone to whom he spoke, had scarcely patience enough to help anybody to coffee, and then was enraged against himself for being so silly!

changes.transformed: He was a little revived, however, by his bringing back his coffee-cup himself; and he seized the opportunity of saying,--

changes.transformed: “Is your brother at Pemberley still?”

changes.transformed: “Yes; he will remain there till Christmas.”

changes.original: Have all her friends left her?”
changes.transformed: Have all his friends left him?”

changes.original: “Mrs. Annesley is with her.
changes.transformed: “Mr. Annesley is with him.

changes.transformed: He stood by him, however, for some minutes, in silence; and, at last, on the young gentleman’s whispering to Elliot again, he walked away.

changes.original: When the tea things were removed, and the card tables placed, the ladies all rose; and Elizabeth was then hoping to be soon joined by him, when all her views were overthrown, by seeing him fall a victim to her mother’s rapacity for whist players, and in a few moments after seated with the rest of the party.
changes.transformed: When the tea things were removed, and the card tables placed, the gentlemen all rose; and Elliot was then hoping to be soon joined by him, when all his views were overthrown, by seeing him fall a victim to his father’s rapacity for whist players, and in a few moments after seated with the rest of the party.

changes.transformed: And, my dear John, I never saw you look in greater beauty.

changes.transformed: I do think Mr. Long is as good a creature as ever lived--and his nephews are very pretty behaved boys, and not at all handsome: I like them prodigiously.”

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet, in short, was in very great spirits: she had seen enough of Bingley’s behaviour to Jane to be convinced that she would get him at last; and her expectations of advantage to her family, when in a happy humour, were so far beyond reason, that she was quite disappointed at not seeing him there again the next day, to make his proposals.

changes.original: Elizabeth smiled.

changes.original: “Lizzy, you must not do so.

changes.transformed: “You are very cruel,” said his brother, “you will not let me smile, and are provoking me to it every moment.”

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet invited him to dine with them; but, with many expressions of concern, he confessed himself engaged elsewhere.

changes.original: “Next time you call,” said she, “I hope we shall be more lucky.”

changes.original: Yes, he had no engagement at all for to-morrow; and her invitation was accepted with alacrity.

changes.original: He came, and in such very good time, that the ladies were none of them dressed.
changes.transformed: He came, and in such very good time, that the gentlemen were none of them dressed.

changes.transformed: In ran Mr. Bennet to his sons’ room, in his dressing-gown, and with his hair half finished, crying out,--

changes.transformed: “My dear John, make haste and hurry down.

changes.transformed: Here, Samuel, come to Mr. Bennet this moment, and help him on with his gown.

changes.original: Never mind Miss Lizzy’s hair.”
changes.transformed: Never mind Mr. Elliot’s hair.”

changes.transformed: “We will be down as soon as we can,” said John; “but I dare say Kit is forwarder than either of us, for he went upstairs half an hour ago.”

changes.transformed: “Oh! hang Kit! what has he to do with it?

changes.transformed: After tea, Mr. Bennet retired to the library, as was his custom, and Martin went upstairs to his instrument.

changes.original: Jane instantly gave a look at Elizabeth which spoke her distress at such premeditation, and her entreaty that _she_ would not give in to it.

changes.original: In a few minutes, Mrs. Bennet half opened the door and called out,--
changes.transformed: In a few minutes, Mr. Bennet half opened the door and called out,--

changes.original: “Lizzy, my dear, I want to speak with you.”
changes.transformed: “Elliot, my dear, I want to speak with you.”

changes.transformed: “We may as well leave them by themselves, you know,” said his father as soon as he was in the hall. “Kit and I are going upstairs to sit in my dressing-room.”

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet’s schemes for this day were ineffectual.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet’s schemes for this day were ineffectual.

changes.original: Bingley was everything that was charming, except the professed lover of her daughter.
changes.transformed: Bingley was everything that was charming, except the professed lover of his son.

changes.original: His ease and cheerfulness rendered him a most agreeable addition to their evening party; and he bore with the ill-judged officiousness of the mother, and heard all her silly remarks with a forbearance and command of countenance particularly grateful to the daughter.
changes.transformed: His ease and cheerfulness rendered him a most agreeable addition to their evening party; and he bore with the ill-judged officiousness of the father, and heard all his silly remarks with a forbearance and command of countenance particularly grateful to the son.

changes.transformed: He scarcely needed an invitation to stay supper; and before he went away an engagement was formed, chiefly through his own and Mr. Bennet’s means, for his coming next morning to shoot with his husband.

changes.original: After this day, Jane said no more of her indifference.

changes.original: Not a word passed between the sisters concerning Bingley; but Elizabeth went to bed in the happy belief that all must speedily be concluded, unless Mr. Darcy returned within the stated time.
changes.transformed: Not a word passed between the brothers concerning Bingley; but Elliot went to bed in the happy belief that all must speedily be concluded, unless Mr. Darcy returned within the stated time.

changes.original: Seriously, however, she felt tolerably persuaded that all this must have taken place with that gentleman’s concurrence.
changes.transformed: Seriously, however, he felt tolerably persuaded that all this must have taken place with that gentleman’s concurrence.

changes.original: Bingley of course returned with him to dinner; and in the evening Mrs. Bennet’s invention was again at work to get everybody away from him and her daughter.
changes.transformed: Bingley of course returned with him to dinner; and in the evening Mr. Bennet’s invention was again at work to get everybody away from him and his son.

changes.original: Elizabeth, who had a letter to write, went into the breakfast-room for that purpose soon after tea; for as the others were all going to sit down to cards, she could not be wanted to counteract her mother’s schemes.
changes.transformed: Elliot, who had a letter to write, went into the breakfast-room for that purpose soon after tea; for as the others were all going to sit down to cards, he could not be wanted to counteract his father’s schemes.

changes.original: But on her returning to the drawing-room, when her letter was finished, she saw, to her infinite surprise, there was reason to fear that her mother had been too ingenious for her.
changes.transformed: But on his returning to the drawing-room, when his letter was finished, he saw, to his infinite surprise, there was reason to fear that his father had been too ingenious for him.

changes.original: On opening the door, she perceived her sister and Bingley standing together over the hearth, as if engaged in earnest conversation; and had this led to no suspicion, the faces of both, as they hastily turned round and moved away from each other, would have told it all. _Their_ situation was awkward enough; but _hers_ she thought was still worse.
changes.transformed: On opening the door, he perceived his brother and Bingley standing together over the hearth, as if engaged in earnest conversation; and had this led to no suspicion, the faces of both, as they hastily turned round and moved away from each other, would have told it all. Their situation was awkward enough; but his he thought was still worse.

changes.original: Not a syllable was uttered by either; and Elizabeth was on the point of going away again, when Bingley, who as well as the other had sat down, suddenly rose, and, whispering a few words to her sister, ran out of the room.
changes.transformed: Not a syllable was uttered by either; and Elliot was on the point of going away again, when Bingley, who as well as the other had sat down, suddenly rose, and, whispering a few words to his brother, ran out of the room.

changes.original: Jane could have no reserves from Elizabeth, where confidence would give pleasure; and, instantly embracing her, acknowledged, with the liveliest emotion, that she was the happiest creature in the world.
changes.transformed: John could have no reserves from Elliot, where confidence would give pleasure; and, instantly embracing him, acknowledged, with the liveliest emotion, that he was the happiest creature in the world.

changes.original: “’Tis too much!” she added, “by far too much.
changes.transformed: “’Tis too much!” he added, “by far too much.

changes.original: Elizabeth’s congratulations were given with a sincerity, a warmth, a delight, which words could but poorly express.
changes.transformed: Elliot’s congratulations were given with a sincerity, a warmth, a delight, which words could but poorly express.

changes.original: Every sentence of kindness was a fresh source of happiness to Jane.
changes.transformed: Every sentence of kindness was a fresh source of happiness to John.

changes.original: But she would not allow herself to stay with her sister, or say half that remained to be said, for the present.
changes.transformed: But he would not allow himself to stay with his brother, or say half that remained to be said, for the present.

changes.original: “I must go instantly to my mother,” she cried. “I would not on any account trifle with her affectionate solicitude, or allow her to hear it from anyone but myself.
changes.transformed: “I must go instantly to my father,” he cried. “I would not on any account trifle with his affectionate solicitude, or allow him to hear it from anyone but myself.

changes.original: Oh, Lizzy, to know that what I have to relate will give such pleasure to all my dear family! how shall I bear so much happiness?”
changes.transformed: Oh, Elliot, to know that what I have to relate will give such pleasure to all my dear family! how shall I bear so much happiness?”

changes.original: She then hastened away to her mother, who had purposely broken up the card-party, and was sitting upstairs with Kitty.
changes.transformed: He then hastened away to his father, who had purposely broken up the card-party, and was sitting upstairs with Kit.

changes.original: Elizabeth, who was left by herself, now smiled at the rapidity and ease with which an affair was finally settled, that had given them so many previous months of suspense and vexation.
changes.transformed: Elliot, who was left by himself, now smiled at the rapidity and ease with which an affair was finally settled, that had given them so many previous months of suspense and vexation.

changes.original: “And this,” said she, “is the end of all his friend’s anxious circumspection! of all his sister’s falsehood and contrivance! the happiest, wisest, and most reasonable end!”
changes.transformed: “And this,” said he, “is the end of all his friend’s anxious circumspection! of all his brother’s falsehood and contrivance! the happiest, wisest, and most reasonable end!”

changes.original: In a few minutes she was joined by Bingley, whose conference with her father had been short and to the purpose.
changes.transformed: In a few minutes he was joined by Bingley, whose conference with his father had been short and to the purpose.

changes.original: “Where is your sister?” said he hastily, as he opened the door.
changes.transformed: “Where is your brother?” said he hastily, as he opened the door.

changes.original: “With my mother upstairs.
changes.transformed: “With my father upstairs.

changes.original: She will be down in a moment, I dare say.”
changes.transformed: He will be down in a moment, I dare say.”

changes.original: He then shut the door, and, coming up to her, claimed the good wishes and affection of a sister.
changes.transformed: He then shut the door, and, coming up to him, claimed the good wishes and affection of a brother.

changes.original: Elizabeth honestly and heartily expressed her delight in the prospect of their relationship.
changes.transformed: Elliot honestly and heartily expressed his delight in the prospect of their relationship.

changes.original: They shook hands with great cordiality; and then, till her sister came down, she had to listen to all he had to say of his own happiness, and of Jane’s perfections; and in spite of his being a lover, Elizabeth really believed all his expectations of felicity to be rationally founded, because they had for basis the excellent understanding and super-excellent disposition of Jane, and a general similarity of feeling and taste between her and himself.
changes.transformed: They shook hands with great cordiality; and then, till his brother came down, he had to listen to all he had to say of his own happiness, and of John’s perfections; and in spite of his being a lover, Elliot really believed all his expectations of felicity to be rationally founded, because they had for basis the excellent understanding and super-excellent disposition of John, and a general similarity of feeling and taste between him and himself.

changes.original: It was an evening of no common delight to them all; the satisfaction of Miss Bennet’s mind gave such a glow of sweet animation to her face, as made her look handsomer than ever.
changes.transformed: It was an evening of no common delight to them all; the satisfaction of Mr. Bennet’s mind gave such a glow of sweet animation to his face, as made him look handsomer than ever.

changes.original: Kitty simpered and smiled, and hoped her turn was coming soon.
changes.transformed: Kit simpered and smiled, and hoped his turn was coming soon.

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet could not give her consent, or speak her approbation in terms warm enough to satisfy her feelings, though she talked to Bingley of nothing else, for half an hour; and when Mr. Bennet joined them at supper, his voice and manner plainly showed how really happy he was.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet could not give his consent, or speak his approbation in terms warm enough to satisfy his feelings, though he talked to Bingley of nothing else, for half an hour; and when Mr. Bennet joined them at supper, his voice and manner plainly showed how really happy he was.

changes.original: Not a word, however, passed his lips in allusion to it, till their visitor took his leave for the night; but as soon as he was gone, he turned to his daughter and said,--
changes.transformed: Not a word, however, passed his lips in allusion to it, till their visitor took his leave for the night; but as soon as he was gone, he turned to his son and said,--

changes.original: “Jane, I congratulate you.
changes.transformed: “John, I congratulate you.

changes.original: You will be a very happy woman.”
changes.transformed: You will be a very happy man.”

changes.original: Jane went to him instantly, kissed him, and thanked him for his goodness.
changes.transformed: John went to him instantly, kissed him, and thanked him for his goodness.

changes.original: “You are a good girl,” he replied, “and I have great pleasure in thinking you will be so happily settled.
changes.transformed: “You are a good boy,” he replied, “and I have great pleasure in thinking you will be so happily settled.

changes.original: My dear Mr. Bennet,” cried his wife, “what are you talking of?
changes.transformed: My dear Mr. Bennet,” cried his husband, “what are you talking of?

changes.original: Why, he has four or five thousand a year, and very likely more.” Then addressing her daughter, “Oh, my dear, dear Jane, I am so happy!
changes.transformed: Why, he has four or five thousand a year, and very likely more.” Then addressing his son, “Oh, my dear, dear John, I am so happy!

changes.original: Wickham, Lydia, were all forgotten.
changes.transformed: Wickham, Lyndon, were all forgotten.

changes.original: Jane was beyond competition her favourite child.
changes.transformed: John was beyond competition his favourite child.

changes.original: At that moment she cared for no other.
changes.transformed: At that moment he cared for no other.

changes.original: Her younger sisters soon began to make interest with her for objects of happiness which she might in future be able to dispense.
changes.transformed: His younger brothers soon began to make interest with him for objects of happiness which he might in future be able to dispense.

changes.original: Mary petitioned for the use of the library at Netherfield; and Kitty begged very hard for a few balls there every winter.
changes.transformed: Martin petitioned for the use of the library at Netherfield; and Kenneth begged very hard for a few balls there every winter.

changes.original: Elizabeth had now but little time for conversation with her sister; for while he was present Jane had no attention to bestow on anyone else: but she found herself considerably useful to both of them, in those hours of separation that must sometimes occur.
changes.transformed: Elliot had now but little time for conversation with his brother; for while he was present John had no attention to bestow on anyone else: but he found himself considerably useful to both of them, in those hours of separation that must sometimes occur.

changes.original: In the absence of Jane, he always attached himself to Elizabeth for the pleasure of talking of her; and when Bingley was gone, Jane constantly sought the same means of relief.
changes.transformed: In the absence of John, he always attached himself to Elliot for the pleasure of talking of him; and when Bingley was gone, John constantly sought the same means of relief.

changes.original: “He has made me so happy,” said she, one evening, “by telling me that he was totally ignorant of my being in town last spring!
changes.transformed: “He has made me so happy,” said he, one evening, “by telling me that he was totally ignorant of my being in town last spring!

changes.original: “I suspected as much,” replied Elizabeth. “But how did he account for it?”
changes.transformed: “I suspected as much,” replied Elliot. “But how did he account for it?”

changes.original: “It must have been his sisters’ doing.
changes.transformed: “It must have been his brothers’ doing.

changes.original: “That is the most unforgiving speech,” said Elizabeth, “that I ever heard you utter.
changes.transformed: “That is the most unforgiving speech,” said Elliot, “that I ever heard you utter.

changes.original: Good girl!
changes.transformed: Good man!

changes.original: It would vex me, indeed, to see you again the dupe of Miss Bingley’s pretended regard.”
changes.transformed: It would vex me, indeed, to see you again the dupe of Mr. Bingley’s pretended regard.”

changes.original: “Would you believe it, Lizzy, that when he went to town last November he really loved me, and nothing but a persuasion of _my_ being indifferent would have prevented his coming down again?”
changes.transformed: “Would you believe it, Elliot, that when he went to town last November he really loved me, and nothing but a persuasion of _my_ being indifferent would have prevented his coming down again?”

changes.original: This naturally introduced a panegyric from Jane on his diffidence, and the little value he put on his own good qualities.
changes.transformed: This naturally introduced a panegyric from John on his diffidence, and the little value he put on his own good qualities.

changes.original: Elizabeth was pleased to find that he had not betrayed the interference of his friend; for, though Jane had the most generous and forgiving heart in the world, she knew it was a circumstance which must prejudice her against him.
changes.transformed: Elliot was pleased to find that he had not betrayed the interference of his friend; for, though John had the most generous and forgiving heart in the world, he knew it was a circumstance which must prejudice him against him.

changes.original: “I am certainly the most fortunate creature that ever existed!” cried Jane. “Oh, Lizzy, why am I thus singled from my family, and blessed above them all?
changes.transformed: “I am certainly the most fortunate creature that ever existed!” cried John. “Oh, Elliot, why am I thus singled from my family, and blessed above them all?

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet was privileged to whisper it to Mrs. Philips, and she ventured, without any permission, to do the same by all her neighbours in Meryton.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet was privileged to whisper it to Mr. Philips, and he ventured, without any permission, to do the same by all his neighbours in Meryton.

changes.original: The Bennets were speedily pronounced to be the luckiest family in the world; though only a few weeks before, when Lydia had first run away, they had been generally proved to be marked out for misfortune.
changes.transformed: The Bennets were speedily pronounced to be the luckiest family in the world; though only a few weeks before, when Lyndon had first run away, they had been generally proved to be marked out for misfortune.

changes.original: One morning, about a week after Bingley’s engagement with Jane had been formed, as he and the females of the family were sitting together in the dining-room, their attention was suddenly drawn to the window by the sound of a carriage; and they perceived a chaise and four driving up the lawn.
changes.transformed: One morning, about a week after Bingley’s engagement with John had been formed, as he and the males of the family were sitting together in the dining-room, their attention was suddenly drawn to the window by the sound of a carriage; and they perceived a chaise and four driving up the lawn.

changes.original: As it was certain, however, that somebody was coming, Bingley instantly prevailed on Miss Bennet to avoid the confinement of such an intrusion, and walk away with him into the shrubbery.
changes.transformed: As it was certain, however, that somebody was coming, Bingley instantly prevailed on Mr. Bennet to avoid the confinement of such an intrusion, and walk away with him into the shrubbery.

changes.original: It was Lady Catherine de Bourgh.
changes.transformed: It was Mr. Catherine de Bourgh.

changes.original: They were of course all intending to be surprised: but their astonishment was beyond their expectation; and on the part of Mrs. Bennet and Kitty, though she was perfectly unknown to them, even inferior to what Elizabeth felt.
changes.transformed: They were of course all intending to be surprised: but their astonishment was beyond their expectation; and on the part of Mr. Bennet and Kit, though he was perfectly unknown to them, even inferior to what Elliot felt.

changes.original: She entered the room with an air more than usually ungracious, made no other reply to Elizabeth’s salutation than a slight inclination of the head, and sat down without saying a word.
changes.transformed: He entered the room with an air more than usually ungracious, made no other reply to Elliot’s salutation than a slight inclination of the head, and sat down without saying a word.

changes.original: Elizabeth had mentioned her name to her mother on her Ladyship’s entrance, though no request of introduction had been made.
changes.transformed: Elliot had mentioned his name to his father on his entrance, though no request of introduction had been made.

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet, all amazement, though flattered by having a guest of such high importance, received her with the utmost politeness.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet, all amazement, though flattered by having a guest of such high importance, received him with the utmost politeness.

changes.original: After sitting for a moment in silence, she said, very stiffly, to Elizabeth,--
changes.transformed: After sitting for a moment in silence, he said, very stiffly, to Elliot,--

changes.original: “I hope you are well, Miss Bennet.
changes.transformed: “I hope you are well, Mr. Bennet.

changes.original: That lady, I suppose, is your mother?”
changes.transformed: That gentleman, I suppose, is your father?”

changes.original: Elizabeth replied very concisely that she was.
changes.transformed: Elliot replied very concisely that he was.

changes.original: “And _that_, I suppose, is one of your sisters?”
changes.transformed: “And _that_, I suppose, is one of your brothers?”

changes.original: “Yes, madam,” said Mrs. Bennet, delighted to speak to a Lady Catherine. “She is my youngest girl but one.
changes.transformed: “Yes, sir,” said Mr. Bennet, delighted to speak to a Mr. Catherine. “He is my youngest boy but one.

changes.original: “You have a very small park here,” returned Lady Catherine, after a short silence.
changes.transformed: “You have a very small park here,” returned Mr. Catherine, after a short silence.

changes.original: “It is nothing in comparison of Rosings, my Lady, I dare say; but, I assure you, it is much larger than Sir William Lucas’s.”
changes.transformed: “It is nothing in comparison of Rosings, my sir, I dare say; but, I assure you, it is much larger than Mr. William Lucas’s.”

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet assured her that they never sat there after dinner; and then added,--
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet assured him that they never sat there after dinner; and then added,--

changes.original: “May I take the liberty of asking your Ladyship whether you left Mr. and Mrs. Collins well?”
changes.transformed: “May I take the liberty of asking your honour whether you left Mr. and Mr. Collins well?”

changes.original: Elizabeth now expected that she would produce a letter for her from Charlotte, as it seemed the only probable motive for her calling.
changes.transformed: Elliot now expected that he would produce a letter for him from Charles, as it seemed the only probable motive for his calling.

changes.original: But no letter appeared, and she was completely puzzled.
changes.transformed: But no letter appeared, and he was completely puzzled.

changes.original: Mrs. Bennet, with great civility, begged her Ladyship to take some refreshment: but Lady Catherine very resolutely, and not very politely, declined eating anything; and then, rising up, said to Elizabeth,--
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet, with great civility, begged his honour to take some refreshment: but Mr. Catherine very resolutely, and not very politely, declined eating anything; and then, rising up, said to Elliot,--

changes.original: “Miss Bennet, there seemed to be a prettyish kind of a little wilderness on one side of your lawn.
changes.transformed: “Mr. Bennet, there seemed to be a prettyish kind of a little wilderness on one side of your lawn.

changes.original: “Go, my dear,” cried her mother, “and show her Ladyship about the different walks.
changes.transformed: “Go, my dear,” cried his father, “and show his honour about the different walks.

changes.original: I think she will be pleased with the hermitage.”
changes.transformed: I think he will be pleased with the hermitage.”

changes.original: Elizabeth obeyed; and, running into her own room for her parasol, attended her noble guest downstairs.
changes.transformed: Elliot obeyed; and, running into his own room for his umbrella, attended his noble guest downstairs.

changes.original: As they passed through the hall, Lady Catherine opened the doors into the dining-parlour and drawing-room, and pronouncing them, after a short survey, to be decent-looking rooms, walked on.
changes.transformed: As they passed through the hall, Mr. Catherine opened the doors into the dining-parlour and drawing-room, and pronouncing them, after a short survey, to be decent-looking rooms, walked on.

changes.original: Her carriage remained at the door, and Elizabeth saw that her waiting-woman was in it.
changes.transformed: His carriage remained at the door, and Elliot saw that his waiting-man was in it.

changes.original: They proceeded in silence along the gravel walk that led to the copse; Elizabeth was determined to make no effort for conversation with a woman who was now more than usually insolent and disagreeable.
changes.transformed: They proceeded in silence along the gravel walk that led to the copse; Elliot was determined to make no effort for conversation with a man who was now more than usually insolent and disagreeable.

changes.original: “How could I ever think her like her nephew?” said she, as she looked in her face.
changes.transformed: “How could I ever think him like his nephew?” said he, as he looked in his face.

changes.original: As soon as they entered the copse, Lady Catherine began in the following manner:--
changes.transformed: As soon as they entered the copse, Mr. Catherine began in the following manner:--

changes.original: “You can be at no loss, Miss Bennet, to understand the reason of my journey hither.
changes.transformed: “You can be at no loss, Mr. Bennet, to understand the reason of my journey hither.

changes.original: Elizabeth looked with unaffected astonishment.
changes.transformed: Elliot looked with unaffected astonishment.

changes.original: “Indeed, you are mistaken, madam; I have not been at all able to account for the honour of seeing you here.”
changes.transformed: “Indeed, you are mistaken, sir; I have not been at all able to account for the honour of seeing you here.”

changes.original: “Miss Bennet,” replied her Ladyship, in an angry tone, “you ought to know that I am not to be trifled with.
changes.transformed: “Mr. Bennet,” replied his Lordship, in an angry tone, “you ought to know that I am not to be trifled with.

changes.original: I was told, that not only your sister was on the point of being most advantageously married, but that _you_--that Miss Elizabeth Bennet would, in all likelihood, be soon afterwards united to my nephew--my own nephew, Mr. Darcy.
changes.transformed: I was told, that not only your brother was on the point of being most advantageously married, but that _you_--that Mr. Elliot Bennet would, in all likelihood, be soon afterwards united to my nephew--my own nephew, Mr. Darcy.

changes.original: “If you believed it impossible to be true,” said Elizabeth, colouring with astonishment and disdain, “I wonder you took the trouble of coming so far.
changes.transformed: “If you believed it impossible to be true,” said Elliot, colouring with astonishment and disdain, “I wonder you took the trouble of coming so far.

changes.original: What could your Ladyship propose by it?”
changes.transformed: What could your Lordship propose by it?”

changes.original: “Your coming to Longbourn, to see me and my family,” said Elizabeth coolly, “will be rather a confirmation of it--if, indeed, such a report is in existence.”
changes.transformed: “Your coming to Longbourn, to see me and my family,” said Elliot coolly, “will be rather a confirmation of it--if, indeed, such a report is in existence.”

changes.original: “I do not pretend to possess equal frankness with your Ladyship. _You_ may ask questions which _I_ shall not choose to answer.”
changes.transformed: “I do not pretend to possess equal frankness with your Lordship. _You_ may ask questions which _I_ shall not choose to answer.”

changes.original: Miss Bennet, I insist on being satisfied.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet, I insist on being satisfied.

changes.original: “Your Ladyship has declared it to be impossible.”
changes.transformed: “Your Lordship has declared it to be impossible.”

changes.original: “Miss Bennet, do you know who I am?
changes.transformed: “Mr. Bennet, do you know who I am?

changes.original: Mr. Darcy is engaged to _my daughter_.
changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy is engaged to _my son_.

changes.original: Lady Catherine hesitated for a moment, and then replied,--
changes.transformed: Mr. Catherine hesitated for a moment, and then replied,--

changes.original: It was the favourite wish of _his_ mother, as well as of hers.
changes.transformed: It was the favourite wish of _his_ father, as well as of his.

changes.original: While in their cradles we planned the union; and now, at the moment when the wishes of both sisters would be accomplished, is their marriage to be prevented by a young woman of inferior birth, of no importance in the world, and wholly unallied to the family?
changes.transformed: While in their cradles we planned the union; and now, at the moment when the wishes of both brothers would be accomplished, is their marriage to be prevented by a young man of inferior birth, of no importance in the world, and wholly unallied to the family?

changes.original: Do you pay no regard to the wishes of his friends--to his tacit engagement with Miss de Bourgh?
changes.transformed: Do you pay no regard to the wishes of his friends--to his tacit engagement with Mr. de Bourgh?

changes.original: If there is no other objection to my marrying your nephew, I shall certainly not be kept from it by knowing that his mother and aunt wished him to marry Miss de Bourgh.
changes.transformed: If there is no other objection to my marrying your nephew, I shall certainly not be kept from it by knowing that his father and uncle wished him to marry Mr. de Bourgh.

changes.original: Yes, Miss Bennet, interest; for do not expect to be noticed by his family or friends, if you wilfully act against the inclinations of all.
changes.transformed: Yes, Mr. Bennet, interest; for do not expect to be noticed by his family or friends, if you wilfully act against the inclinations of all.

changes.original: “These are heavy misfortunes,” replied Elizabeth. “But the wife of Mr. Darcy must have such extraordinary sources of happiness necessarily attached to her situation, that she could, upon the whole, have no cause to repine.”
changes.transformed: “These are heavy misfortunes,” replied Elliot. “But the husband of Mr. Darcy must have such extraordinary sources of happiness necessarily attached to his situation, that he could, upon the whole, have no cause to repine.”

changes.original: “Obstinate, headstrong girl!
changes.transformed: “Obstinate, headstrong boy!

changes.original: You are to understand, Miss Bennet, that I came here with the determined resolution of carrying my purpose; nor will I be dissuaded from it.
changes.transformed: You are to understand, Mr. Bennet, that I came here with the determined resolution of carrying my purpose; nor will I be dissuaded from it.

changes.original: “_That_ will make your Ladyship’s situation at present more pitiable; but it will have no effect on _me_.”
changes.transformed: “_That_ will make your Lordship’s situation at present more pitiable; but it will have no effect on _me_.”

changes.original: My daughter and my nephew are formed for each other.
changes.transformed: My son and my nephew are formed for each other.

changes.original: They are descended, on the maternal side, from the same noble line; and, on the father’s, from respectable, honourable, and ancient, though untitled, families.
changes.transformed: They are descended, on the paternal side, from the same noble line; and, on the father’s, from respectable, honourable, and ancient, though untitled, families.

changes.original: They are destined for each other by the voice of every member of their respective houses; and what is to divide them?--the upstart pretensions of a young woman without family, connections, or fortune!
changes.transformed: They are destined for each other by the voice of every member of their respective houses; and what is to divide them?--the upstart pretensions of a young man without family, connections, or fortune!

changes.original: He is a gentleman; I am a gentleman’s daughter; so far we are equal.”
changes.transformed: He is a gentleman; I am a gentleman’s son; so far we are equal.”

changes.original: You _are_ a gentleman’s daughter.
changes.transformed: You _are_ a gentleman’s son.

changes.original: But what was your mother?
changes.transformed: But what was your father?

changes.original: Who are your uncles and aunts?
changes.transformed: Who are your uncles?

changes.original: “Whatever my connections may be,” said Elizabeth, “if your nephew does not object to them, they can be nothing to _you_.”
changes.transformed: “Whatever my connections may be,” said Elliot, “if your nephew does not object to them, they can be nothing to _you_.”

changes.original: Though Elizabeth would not, for the mere purpose of obliging Lady Catherine, have answered this question, she could not but say, after a moment’s deliberation,--
changes.transformed: Though Elliot would not, for the mere purpose of obliging Mr. Catherine, have answered this question, he could not but say, after a moment’s deliberation,--

changes.original: Lady Catherine seemed pleased.
changes.transformed: Mr. Catherine seemed pleased.

changes.original: “Miss Bennet, I am shocked and astonished.
changes.transformed: “Mr. Bennet, I am shocked and astonished.

changes.original: I expected to find a more reasonable young woman.
changes.transformed: I expected to find a more reasonable young man.

changes.original: Your Ladyship wants Mr. Darcy to marry your daughter; but would my giving you the wished-for promise make _their_ marriage at all more probable?
changes.transformed: Your Honor wants Mr. Darcy to marry your son; but would my giving you the wished-for promise make _their_ marriage at all more probable?

changes.original: Allow me to say, Lady Catherine, that the arguments with which you have supported this extraordinary application have been as frivolous as the application was ill-judged.
changes.transformed: Allow me to say, Mr. Catherine, that the arguments with which you have supported this extraordinary application have been as frivolous as the application was ill-judged.

changes.original: I am no stranger to the particulars of your youngest sister’s infamous elopement.
changes.transformed: I am no stranger to the particulars of your youngest brother’s infamous elopement.

changes.original: I know it all; that the young man’s marrying her was a patched-up business, at the expense of your father and uncle.
changes.transformed: I know it all; that the young man’s marrying him was a patched-up business, at the expense of your father and uncle.

changes.original: And is _such_ a girl to be my nephew’s sister?
changes.transformed: And is _such_ a man to be my nephew’s brother?

changes.original: Is _her_ husband, who is the son of his late father’s steward, to be his brother?
changes.transformed: Is _his_ husband, who is the son of his late father’s steward, to be his brother?

changes.original: “You can _now_ have nothing further to say,” she resentfully answered. “You have insulted me, in every possible method.
changes.transformed: “You can _now_ have nothing further to say,” he resentfully answered. “You have insulted me, in every possible method.

changes.original: And she rose as she spoke.
changes.transformed: And he rose as he spoke.

changes.original: Lady Catherine rose also, and they turned back.
changes.transformed: Mr. Catherine rose also, and they turned back.

changes.original: Her Ladyship was highly incensed.
changes.transformed: His Lordship was highly incensed.

changes.original: Unfeeling, selfish girl!
changes.transformed: Unfeeling, selfish boy!

changes.original: “Lady Catherine, I have nothing further to say.
changes.transformed: “Mr. Catherine, I have nothing further to say.

changes.original: “Neither duty, nor honour, nor gratitude,” replied Elizabeth, “has any possible claim on me, in the present instance.
changes.transformed: “Neither duty, nor honour, nor gratitude,” replied Elliot, “has any possible claim on me, in the present instance.

changes.original: Do not imagine, Miss Bennet, that your ambition will ever be gratified.
changes.transformed: Do not imagine, Mr. Bennet, that your ambition will ever be gratified.

changes.original: In this manner Lady Catherine talked on till they were at the door of the carriage, when, turning hastily round, she added,--
changes.transformed: In this manner Mr. Catherine talked on till they were at the door of the carriage, when, turning hastily round, he added,--

changes.original: “I take no leave of you, Miss Bennet.
changes.transformed: “I take no leave of you, Mr. Bennet.

changes.original: I send no compliments to your mother.
changes.transformed: I send no compliments to your father.

changes.original: Elizabeth made no answer; and without attempting to persuade her Ladyship to return into the house, walked quietly into it herself.

changes.original: She heard the carriage drive away as she proceeded upstairs.

changes.original: Her mother impatiently met her at the door of her dressing-room, to ask why Lady Catherine would not come in again and rest herself.

changes.original: “She did not choose it,” said her daughter; “she would go.”
changes.transformed: “He did not choose it,” said his son; “he would go.”

changes.original: “She is a very fine-looking woman! and her calling here was prodigiously civil! for she only came, I suppose, to tell us the Collinses were well.
changes.transformed: “He is a very fine-looking man! and his calling here was prodigiously civil! for he only came, I suppose, to tell us the Collinses were well.

changes.original: She is on her road somewhere, I dare say; and so, passing through Meryton, thought she might as well call on you.

changes.original: I suppose she had nothing particular to say to you, Lizzy?”
changes.transformed: I suppose he had nothing particular to say to you, Elly?”

changes.original: The discomposure of spirits which this extraordinary visit threw Elizabeth into could not be easily overcome; nor could she for many hours learn to think of it less than incessantly.
changes.transformed: The discomposure of spirits which this extraordinary visit threw Elliot into could not be easily overcome; nor could he for many hours learn to think of it less than incessantly.

changes.original: Lady Catherine, it appeared, had actually taken the trouble of this journey from Rosings for the sole purpose of breaking off her supposed engagement with Mr. Darcy.

changes.original: It was a rational scheme, to be sure! but from what the report of their engagement could originate, Elizabeth was at a loss to imagine; till she recollected that _his_ being the intimate friend of Bingley, and _her_ being the sister of Jane, was enough, at a time when the expectation of one wedding made everybody eager for another, to supply the idea.
changes.transformed: It was a rational scheme, to be sure! but from what the report of their engagement could originate, Elliot was at a loss to imagine; till he recollected that _his_ being the intimate friend of Bingley, and _his_ being the brother of John, was enough, at a time when the expectation of one wedding made everybody eager for another, to supply the idea.

changes.original: She had not herself forgotten to feel that the marriage of her sister must bring them more frequently together.

changes.original: And her neighbours at Lucas Lodge, therefore, (for through their communication with the Collinses, the report, she concluded, had reached Lady Catherine,) had only set _that_ down as almost certain and immediate which _she_ had looked forward to as possible at some future time.

changes.original: In revolving Lady Catherine’s expressions, however, she could not help feeling some uneasiness as to the possible consequence of her persisting in this interference.

changes.original: From what she had said of her resolution to prevent the marriage, it occurred to Elizabeth that she must meditate an application to her nephew; and how he might take a similar representation of the evils attached to a connection with her she dared not pronounce.
changes.transformed: From what he had said of his resolution to prevent the marriage, it occurred to Elliot that he must meditate an application to his nephew; and how he might take a similar representation of the evils attached to a connection with him he dared not pronounce.

changes.original: She knew not the exact degree of his affection for his aunt, or his dependence on her judgment, but it was natural to suppose that he thought much higher of her Ladyship than _she_ could do; and it was certain, that in enumerating the miseries of a marriage with _one_ whose immediate connections were so unequal to his own, his aunt would address him on his weakest side.
changes.transformed: He knew not the exact degree of his affection for his uncle, or his dependence on his judgment, but it was natural to suppose that he thought much higher of his Lordship than _he_ could do; and it was certain, that in enumerating the miseries of a marriage with _one_ whose immediate connections were so unequal to his own, his uncle would address him on his weakest side.

changes.transformed: “If, therefore, an excuse for not keeping his promise should come to his friend within a few days,” he added, “I shall know how to understand it.

changes.original: The surprise of the rest of the family, on hearing who their visitor had been, was very great: but they obligingly satisfied it with the same kind of supposition which had appeased Mrs. Bennet’s curiosity; and Elizabeth was spared from much teasing on the subject.

changes.original: Young ladies have great penetration in such matters as these; but I think I may defy even _your_ sagacity to discover the name of your admirer.
changes.transformed: Young gentlemen have great penetration in such matters as these; but I think I may defy even _your_ sagacity to discover the name of your admirer.

changes.transformed: He begins with congratulations on the approaching nuptials of my eldest son, of which, it seems, he has been told by some of the good-natured, gossiping Lucases.

changes.original: Your daughter Elizabeth, it is presumed, will not long bear the name of Bennet, after her eldest sister has resigned it; and the chosen partner of her fate may be reasonably looked up to as one of the most illustrious personages in this land.’ Can you possibly guess, Lizzy, who is meant by this? ‘This young gentleman is blessed, in a peculiar way, with everything the heart of mortal can most desire,--splendid property, noble kindred, and extensive patronage.
changes.transformed: Your son Elliot, it is presumed, will not long bear the name of Bennet, after his eldest brother has resigned it; and the chosen partner of his fate may be reasonably looked up to as one of the most illustrious personages in this land.’ Can you possibly guess, Elliot, who is meant by this? ‘This young gentleman is blessed, in a peculiar way, with everything the heart of mortal can most desire,--splendid property, noble kindred, and extensive patronage.
