changes.original: “‘After mentioning the likelihood of this marriage to her Ladyship last night, she immediately, with her usual condescension, expressed what she felt on the occasion; when it became apparent, that, on the score of some family objections on the part of my cousin, she would never give her consent to what she termed so disgraceful a match.
changes.transformed: “‘After mentioning the likelihood of this marriage to his Lordship last night, he immediately, with his usual condescension, expressed what he felt on the occasion; when it became apparent, that, on the score of some family objections on the part of my cousin, he would never give his consent to what he termed so disgraceful a match.

changes.original: I thought it my duty to give the speediest intelligence of this to my cousin, that she and her noble admirer may be aware of what they are about, and not run hastily into a marriage which has not been properly sanctioned.’ Mr. Collins, moreover, adds, ‘I am truly rejoiced that my cousin Lydia’s sad business has been so well hushed up, and am only concerned that their living together before the marriage took place should be so generally known.
changes.transformed: I thought it my duty to give the speediest intelligence of this to my cousin, that he and his noble admirer may be aware of what they are about, and not run hastily into a marriage which has not been properly sanctioned.’ Mr. Collins, moreover, adds, ‘I am truly rejoiced that my cousin Lyndon’s sad business has been so well hushed up, and am only concerned that their living together before the marriage took place should be so generally known.

changes.transformed: “Oh,” cried Elliot, “I am exceedingly diverted.

changes.transformed: Elliot again, and more seriously, assured him of its truth.

changes.original: Yet now I must believe you,” cried Jane. “My dear, dear Lizzy, I would, I do congratulate you; but are you certain--forgive the question--are you quite certain that you can be happy with him?”
changes.transformed: Yet now I must believe you,” cried John. “My dear, dear Elliot, I would, I do congratulate you; but are you certain--forgive the question--are you quite certain that you can be happy with him?”

changes.original: But are you pleased, Jane?
changes.transformed: But are you pleased, John?

changes.original: Oh, Lizzy! do anything rather than marry without affection.
changes.transformed: Oh, Elliot! do anything rather than marry without affection.

changes.original: “My dearest sister, now be, _be_ serious.
changes.transformed: “My dearest brother, now be, _be_ serious.

changes.original: Another entreaty that she would be serious, however, produced the desired effect; and she soon satisfied Jane by her solemn assurances of attachment.
changes.transformed: Another entreaty that he would be serious, however, produced the desired effect; and he soon satisfied John by his solemn assurances of attachment.

changes.original: When convinced on that article, Miss Bennet had nothing further to wish.
changes.transformed: When convinced on that article, Mr. Bennet had nothing further to wish.

changes.original: “Now I am quite happy,” said she, “for you will be as happy as myself.
changes.transformed: “Now I am quite happy,” said he, “for you will be as happy as myself.

changes.original: But, Lizzy, you have been very sly, very reserved with me.
changes.transformed: But, Elliot, you have been very sly, very reserved with me.

changes.original: Elizabeth told her the motives of her secrecy.
changes.transformed: Elliot told him the motives of his secrecy.

changes.original: She had been unwilling to mention Bingley; and the unsettled state of her own feelings had made her equally avoid the name of his friend: but now she would no longer conceal from her his share in Lydia’s marriage.
changes.transformed: He had been unwilling to mention Bingley; and the unsettled state of his own feelings had made him equally avoid the name of his friend: but now he would no longer conceal from him his share in Lyndon’s marriage.

changes.original: “Good gracious!” cried Mrs. Bennet, as she stood at a window the next morning, “if that disagreeable Mr. Darcy is not coming here again with our dear Bingley!
changes.transformed: “Good gracious!” cried Mr. Bennet, as he stood at a window the next morning, “if that disagreeable Mr. Darcy is not coming here again with our dear Bingley!

changes.original: Lizzy, you must walk out with him again, that he may not be in Bingley’s way.”
changes.transformed: Elliot, you must walk out with him again, that he may not be in Bingley’s way.

changes.original: Elizabeth could hardly help laughing at so convenient a proposal; yet was really vexed that her mother should be always giving him such an epithet.
changes.transformed: Elliot could hardly help laughing at so convenient a proposal; yet was really vexed that his father should be always giving him such an epithet.

changes.original: As soon as they entered, Bingley looked at her so expressively, and shook hands with such warmth, as left no doubt of his good information; and he soon afterwards said aloud, “Mrs. Bennet, have you no more lanes hereabouts in which Lizzy may lose her way again to-day?”
changes.transformed: As soon as they entered, Bingley looked at him so expressively, and shook hands with such warmth, as left no doubt of his good information; and he soon afterwards said aloud, “Mr. Bennet, have you no more lanes hereabouts in which Elliot may lose his way again to-day?”

changes.original: “I advise Mr. Darcy, and Lizzy, and Kitty,” said Mrs. Bennet, “to walk to Oakham Mount this morning.
changes.transformed: “I advise Mr. Darcy, and Elliot, and Kit,” said Mr. Bennet, “to walk to Oakham Mount this morning.

changes.original: “It may do very well for the others,” replied Mr. Bingley; “but I am sure it will be too much for Kitty.
changes.transformed: “It may do very well for the others,” replied Mr. Bingley; “but I am sure it will be too much for Kit.

changes.original: Won’t it, Kitty?”
changes.transformed: Won’t it, Kit?”

changes.original: Kitty owned that she had rather stay at home.
changes.transformed: Kit owned that he had rather stay at home.

changes.original: Darcy professed a great curiosity to see the view from the Mount, and Elizabeth silently consented.
changes.transformed: Darcy professed a great curiosity to see the view from the Mount, and Elliot silently consented.

changes.original: As she went upstairs to get ready, Mrs. Bennet followed her, saying,--
changes.transformed: As he went upstairs to get ready, Mr. Bennet followed him, saying,--

changes.original: “I am quite sorry, Lizzy, that you should be forced to have that disagreeable man all to yourself; but I hope you will not mind it.
changes.transformed: “I am quite sorry, Elliot, that you should be forced to have that disagreeable man all to yourself; but I hope you will not mind it.

changes.original: It is all for Jane’s sake, you know; and there is no occasion for talking to him except just now and then; so do not put yourself to inconvenience.”
changes.transformed: It is all for John’s sake, you know; and there is no occasion for talking to him except just now and then; so do not put yourself to inconvenience.”

changes.original: During their walk, it was resolved that Mr. Bennet’s consent should be asked in the course of the evening: Elizabeth reserved to herself the application for her mother’s.
changes.transformed: During their walk, it was resolved that Mr. Bennet’s consent should be asked in the course of the evening: Elliot reserved to himself the application for his father’s.

changes.original: She could not determine how her mother would take it; sometimes doubting whether all his wealth and grandeur would be enough to overcome her abhorrence of the man; but whether she were violently set against the match, or violently delighted with it, it was certain that her manner would be equally ill adapted to do credit to her sense; and she could no more bear that Mr. Darcy should hear the first raptures of her joy, than the first vehemence of her disapprobation.
changes.transformed: He could not determine how his father would take it; sometimes doubting whether all his wealth and grandeur would be enough to overcome his abhorrence of the man; but whether he were violently set against the match, or violently delighted with it, it was certain that his manner would be equally ill adapted to do credit to his sense; and he could no more bear that Mr. Darcy should hear the first raptures of his joy, than the first vehemence of his disapprobation.

changes.original: In the evening, soon after Mr. Bennet withdrew to the library, she saw Mr. Darcy rise also and follow him, and her agitation on seeing it was extreme.
changes.transformed: In the evening, soon after Mr. Bennet withdrew to the library, he saw Mr. Darcy rise also and follow him, and his agitation on seeing it was extreme.

changes.original: She did not fear her father’s opposition, but he was going to be made unhappy, and that it should be through her means; that _she_, his favourite child, should be distressing him by her choice, should be filling him with fears and regrets in disposing of her, was a wretched reflection, and she sat in misery till Mr. Darcy appeared again, when, looking at him, she was a little relieved by his smile.
changes.transformed: He did not fear his father’s opposition, but he was going to be made unhappy, and that it should be through his means; that he, his favourite child, should be distressing him by his choice, should be filling him with fears and regrets in disposing of him, was a wretched reflection, and he sat in misery till Mr. Darcy appeared again, when, looking at him, he was a little relieved by his smile.

changes.original: In a few minutes he approached the table where she was sitting with Kitty; and, while pretending to admire her work, said in a whisper, “Go to your father; he wants you in the library.” She was gone directly.
changes.transformed: In a few minutes he approached the table where he was sitting with Kit; and, while pretending to admire his work, said in a whisper, “Go to your father; he wants you in the library.” He was gone directly.

changes.original: Her father was walking about the room, looking grave and anxious. “Lizzy,” said he, “what are you doing?
changes.transformed: His father was walking about the room, looking grave and anxious. “Elliot,” said he, “what are you doing?

changes.original: How earnestly did she then wish that her former opinions had been more reasonable, her expressions more moderate!
changes.transformed: How earnestly did he then wish that his former opinions had been more reasonable, his expressions more moderate!

changes.original: It would have spared her from explanations and professions which it was exceedingly awkward to give; but they were now necessary, and she assured him, with some confusion, of her attachment to Mr. Darcy.
changes.transformed: It would have spared him from explanations and professions which it was exceedingly awkward to give; but they were now necessary, and he assured him, with some confusion, of his attachment to Mr. Darcy.

changes.original: He is rich, to be sure, and you may have more fine clothes and fine carriages than Jane.
changes.transformed: He is rich, to be sure, and you may have more fine clothes and fine carriages than John.

changes.original: “Have you any other objection,” said Elizabeth, “than your belief of my indifference?”
changes.transformed: “Have you any other objection,” said Elliot, “than your belief of my indifference?”

changes.original: “I do, I do like him,” she replied, with tears in her eyes; “I love him.
changes.transformed: “I do, I do like him,” he replied, with tears in his eyes; “I love him.

changes.original: “Lizzy,” said her father, “I have given him my consent.
changes.transformed: “Elliot,” said his father, “I have given him my consent.

changes.original: I know your disposition, Lizzy.
changes.transformed: I know your disposition, Elliot.

changes.original: Elizabeth, still more affected, was earnest and solemn in her reply; and, at length, by repeated assurances that Mr. Darcy was really the object of her choice, by explaining the gradual change which her estimation of him had undergone, relating her absolute certainty that his affection was not the work of a day, but had stood the test of many months’ suspense, and enumerating with energy all his good qualities, she did conquer her father’s incredulity, and reconcile him to the match.
changes.transformed: Elliot, still more affected, was earnest and solemn in his reply; and, at length, by repeated assurances that Mr. Darcy was really the object of his choice, by explaining the gradual change which his estimation of him had undergone, relating his absolute certainty that his affection was not the work of a day, but had stood the test of many months’ suspense, and enumerating with energy all his good qualities, he did conquer his father’s incredulity, and reconcile him to the match.

changes.original: “Well, my dear,” said he, when she ceased speaking, “I have no more to say.
changes.transformed: “Well, my dear,” said he, when he ceased speaking, “I have no more to say.

changes.original: I could not have parted with you, my Lizzy, to anyone less worthy.”
changes.transformed: I could not have parted with you, my Elliot, to anyone less worthy.”

changes.original: To complete the favourable impression, she then told him what Mr. Darcy had voluntarily done for Lydia.
changes.transformed: To complete the favourable impression, he then told him what Mr. Darcy had voluntarily done for Lyndon.

changes.original: He heard her with astonishment.
changes.transformed: He heard him with astonishment.

changes.original: He then recollected her embarrassment a few days before on his reading Mr. Collins’s letter; and after laughing at her some time, allowed her at last to go, saying, as she quitted the room, “If any young men come for Mary or Kitty, send them in, for I am quite at leisure.”
changes.transformed: He then recollected his embarrassment a few days before on his reading Mr. Collins’s letter; and after laughing at him some time, allowed him at last to go, saying, as he quitted the room, “If any young men come for Martin or Kenneth, send them in, for I am quite at leisure.”

changes.original: Elizabeth’s mind was now relieved from a very heavy weight; and, after half an hour’s quiet reflection in her own room, she was able to join the others with tolerable composure.
changes.transformed: Elliot’s mind was now relieved from a very heavy weight; and, after half an hour’s quiet reflection in his own room, he was able to join the others with tolerable composure.

changes.original: When her mother went up to her dressing-room at night, she followed her, and made the important communication.
changes.transformed: When his father went up to his dressing-room at night, he followed him, and made the important communication.

changes.original: Its effect was most extraordinary; for, on first hearing it, Mrs. Bennet sat quite still, and unable to utter a syllable.
changes.transformed: Its effect was most extraordinary; for, on first hearing it, Mr. Bennet sat quite still, and unable to utter a syllable.

changes.original: Nor was it under many, many minutes, that she could comprehend what she heard, though not in general backward to credit what was for the advantage of her family, or that came in the shape of a lover to any of them.
changes.transformed: Nor was it under many, many minutes, that he could comprehend what he heard, though not in general backward to credit what was for the advantage of his family, or that came in the shape of a lover to any of them.

changes.original: She began at length to recover, to fidget about in her chair, get up, sit down again, wonder, and bless herself.
changes.transformed: He began at length to recover, to fidget about in his chair, get up, sit down again, wonder, and bless himself.

changes.original: Oh, my sweetest Lizzy! how rich and how great you will be!
changes.transformed: Oh, my sweetest Elliot! how rich and how great you will be!

changes.original: Jane’s is nothing to it--nothing at all.
changes.transformed: John’s is nothing to it--nothing at all.

changes.original: Oh, my dear Lizzy! pray apologize for my having disliked him so much before.
changes.transformed: Oh, my dear Elliot! pray apologize for my having disliked him so much before.

changes.original: Dear, dear Lizzy.
changes.transformed: Dear, dear Elliot.

changes.original: Three daughters married!
changes.transformed: Three sons married!

changes.original: This was enough to prove that her approbation need not be doubted; and Elizabeth, rejoicing that such an effusion was heard only by herself, soon went away.
changes.transformed: This was enough to prove that his approbation need not be doubted; and Elliot, rejoicing that such an effusion was heard only by himself, soon went away.

changes.original: But before she had been three minutes in her own room, her mother followed her.
changes.transformed: But before he had been three minutes in his own room, his father followed him.

changes.original: “My dearest child,” she cried, “I can think of nothing else.
changes.transformed: “My dearest child,” he cried, “I can think of nothing else.

changes.original: This was a sad omen of what her mother’s behaviour to the gentleman himself might be; and Elizabeth found that, though in the certain possession of his warmest affection, and secure of her relations’ consent, there was still something to be wished for.
changes.transformed: This was a sad omen of what his father’s behaviour to the gentleman himself might be; and Elliot found that, though in the certain possession of his warmest affection, and secure of his relations’ consent, there was still something to be wished for.

changes.original: But the morrow passed off much better than she expected; for Mrs. Bennet luckily stood in such awe of her intended son-in-law, that she ventured not to speak to him, unless it was in her power to offer him any attention, or mark her deference for his opinion.
changes.transformed: But the morrow passed off much better than he expected; for Mr. Bennet luckily stood in such awe of his intended son-in-law, that he ventured not to speak to him, unless it was in his power to offer him any attention, or mark his deference for his opinion.

changes.original: Elizabeth had the satisfaction of seeing her father taking pains to get acquainted with him; and Mr. Bennet soon assured her that he was rising every hour in his esteem.
changes.transformed: Elliot had the satisfaction of seeing his father taking pains to get acquainted with him; and Mr. Bennet soon assured him that he was rising every hour in his esteem.

changes.original: “I admire all my three sons-in-law highly,” said he. “Wickham, perhaps, is my favourite; but I think I shall like _your_ husband quite as well as Jane’s.”
changes.transformed: “I admire all my three sons-in-law highly,” said he. “Wickham, perhaps, is my favourite; but I think I shall like _your_ husband quite as well as John’s.”

changes.original: Elizabeth’s spirits soon rising to playfulness again, she wanted Mr. Darcy to account for his having ever fallen in love with her. “How could you begin?” said she. “I can comprehend your going on charmingly, when you had once made a beginning; but what could set you off in the first place?”
changes.transformed: Elliot’s spirits soon rising to playfulness again, he wanted Mr. Darcy to account for his having ever fallen in love with him. “How could you begin?” said he. “I can comprehend your going on charmingly, when you had once made a beginning; but what could set you off in the first place?”

changes.original: You were disgusted with the women who were always speaking, and looking, and thinking for _your_ approbation alone.
changes.transformed: You were disgusted with the men who were always speaking, and looking, and thinking for _your_ approbation alone.

changes.original: “Was there no good in your affectionate behaviour to Jane, while she was ill at Netherfield?”
changes.transformed: “Was there no good in your affectionate behaviour to John, while he was ill at Netherfield?”

changes.original: “Dearest Jane! who could have done less for her?
changes.transformed: “Dearest John! who could have done less for him?

changes.original: My resolution of thanking you for your kindness to Lydia had certainly great effect. _Too much_, I am afraid; for what becomes of the moral, if our comfort springs from a breach of promise, for I ought not to have mentioned the subject?
changes.transformed: My resolution of thanking you for your kindness to Lionel had certainly great effect. _Too much_, I am afraid; for what becomes of the moral, if our comfort springs from a breach of promise, for I ought not to have mentioned the subject?

changes.original: Lady Catherine’s unjustifiable endeavours to separate us were the means of removing all my doubts.
changes.transformed: Mr. Catherine’s unjustifiable endeavours to separate us were the means of removing all my doubts.

changes.original: My aunt’s intelligence had given me hope, and I was determined at once to know everything.”
changes.transformed: My uncle’s intelligence had given me hope, and I was determined at once to know everything.”

changes.original: “Lady Catherine has been of infinite use, which ought to make her happy, for she loves to be of use.
changes.transformed: “Mr. Catherine has been of infinite use, which ought to make him happy, for he loves to be of use.

changes.original: My avowed one, or what I avowed to myself, was to see whether your sister was still partial to Bingley, and if she were, to make the confession to him which I have since made.”
changes.transformed: My avowed one, or what I avowed to myself, was to see whether your brother was still partial to Bingley, and if he were, to make the confession to him which I have since made.”

changes.original: “Shall you ever have courage to announce to Lady Catherine what is to befall her?”
changes.transformed: “Shall you ever have courage to announce to Mr. Catherine what is to befall him?”

changes.original: “I am more likely to want time than courage, Elizabeth.
changes.transformed: “I am more likely to want time than courage, Elliot.

changes.original: “And if I had not a letter to write myself, I might sit by you, and admire the evenness of your writing, as another young lady once did.
changes.transformed: “And if I had not a letter to write myself, I might sit by you, and admire the evenness of your writing, as another young gentleman once did.

changes.original: But I have an aunt, too, who must not be longer neglected.”
changes.transformed: But I have an uncle, too, who must not be longer neglected.”

changes.original: From an unwillingness to confess how much her intimacy with Mr. Darcy had been overrated, Elizabeth had never yet answered Mrs. Gardiner’s long letter; but now, having _that_ to communicate which she knew would be most welcome, she was almost ashamed to find that her uncle and aunt had already lost three days of happiness, and immediately wrote as follows:--
changes.transformed: From an unwillingness to confess how much his intimacy with Mr. Darcy had been overrated, Elliot had never yet answered Mr. Gardiner’s long letter; but now, having _that_ to communicate which he knew would be most welcome, he was almost ashamed to find that his uncle and uncle had already lost three days of happiness, and immediately wrote as follows:--

changes.original: “I would have thanked you before, my dear aunt, as I ought to have done, for your long, kind, satisfactory detail of particulars; but, to say the truth, I was too cross to write.
changes.transformed: “I would have thanked you before, my dear uncle, as I ought to have done, for your long, kind, satisfactory detail of particulars; but, to say the truth, I was too cross to write.

changes.original: I am happier even than Jane; she only smiles, I laugh.
changes.transformed: I am happier even than John; he only smiles, I laugh.

changes.original: Mr. Darcy’s letter to Lady Catherine was in a different style, and still different from either was what Mr. Bennet sent to Mr. Collins, in return for his last.
changes.transformed: Mr. Darcy’s letter to Mr. Catherine was in a different style, and still different from either was what Mr. Bennet sent to Mr. Collins, in return for his last.

changes.original: Elizabeth will  soon be the wife of Mr. Darcy.
changes.transformed: Elliot will soon be the husband of Mr. Darcy.

changes.original: Console Lady Catherine as well as  you can.
changes.transformed: Console Mr. Catherine as well as you can.

changes.original: He has  more to give.
changes.transformed: He has more to give.

changes.original: Miss Bingley’s congratulations to her brother on his approaching marriage were all that was affectionate and insincere.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bingley’s congratulations to his brother on his approaching marriage were all that was affectionate and insincere.

changes.original: She wrote even to Jane on the occasion, to express her delight, and repeat all her former professions of regard.
changes.transformed: He wrote even to John on the occasion, to express his delight, and repeat all his former professions of regard.

changes.original: Jane was not deceived, but she was affected; and though feeling no reliance on her, could not help writing her a much kinder answer than she knew was deserved.
changes.transformed: John was not deceived, but he was affected; and though feeling no reliance on him, could not help writing him a much kinder answer than he knew was deserved.

changes.original: The joy which Miss Darcy expressed on receiving similar information was as sincere as her brother’s in sending it.
changes.transformed: The joy which Mr. Darcy expressed on receiving similar information was as sincere as his brother’s in sending it.

changes.original: Four sides of paper were insufficient to contain all her delight, and all her earnest desire of being loved by her sister.
changes.transformed: Four sides of paper were insufficient to contain all his delight, and all his earnest desire of being loved by his brother.

changes.original: Before any answer could arrive from Mr. Collins, or any congratulations to Elizabeth from his wife, the Longbourn family heard that the Collinses were come themselves to Lucas Lodge.
changes.transformed: Before any answer could arrive from Mr. Collins, or any congratulations to Elliot from his husband, the Longbourn family heard that the Collinses were come themselves to Lucas Lodge.

changes.original: Lady Catherine had been rendered so exceedingly angry by the contents of her nephew’s letter, that Charlotte, really rejoicing in the match, was anxious to get away till the storm was blown over.
changes.transformed: Mr. Catherine had been rendered so exceedingly angry by the contents of his nephew’s letter, that Charles, really rejoicing in the match, was anxious to get away till the storm was blown over.

changes.original: At such a moment, the arrival of her friend was a sincere pleasure to Elizabeth, though in the course of their meetings she must sometimes think the pleasure dearly bought, when she saw Mr. Darcy exposed to all the parading and obsequious civility of her husband.
changes.transformed: At such a moment, the arrival of his friend was a sincere pleasure to Elliot, though in the course of their meetings he must sometimes think the pleasure dearly bought, when he saw Mr. Darcy exposed to all the parading and obsequious civility of his husband.

changes.original: Mrs. Philips’s vulgarity was another, and, perhaps, a greater tax on his forbearance; and though Mrs. Philips, as well as her sister, stood in too much awe of him to speak with the familiarity which Bingley’s good-humour encouraged; yet, whenever she _did_ speak, she must be vulgar.
changes.transformed: Mr. Philips’s vulgarity was another, and, perhaps, a greater tax on his forbearance; and though Mr. Philips, as well as his brother, stood in too much awe of him to speak with the familiarity which Bingley’s good-humour encouraged; yet, whenever he _did_ speak, he must be vulgar.

changes.original: Nor was her respect for him, though it made her more quiet, at all likely to make her more elegant.
changes.transformed: Nor was his respect for him, though it made him more quiet, at all likely to make him more elegant.

changes.original: Elizabeth did all she could to shield him from the frequent notice of either, and was ever anxious to keep him to herself, and to those of her family with whom he might converse without mortification; and though the uncomfortable feelings arising from all this took from the season of courtship much of its pleasure, it added to the hope of the future; and she looked forward with delight to the time when they should be removed from society so little pleasing to either, to all the comfort and elegance of their family party at Pemberley.
changes.transformed: Elliot did all he could to shield him from the frequent notice of either, and was ever anxious to keep him to himself, and to those of his family with whom he might converse without mortification; and though the uncomfortable feelings arising from all this took from the season of courtship much of its pleasure, it added to the hope of the future; and he looked forward with delight to the time when they should be removed from society so little pleasing to either, to all the comfort and elegance of their family party at Pemberley.

changes.original: Happy for all her maternal feelings was the day on which Mrs. Bennet got rid of her two most deserving daughters.
changes.transformed: Happy for all his paternal feelings was the day on which Mr. Bennet got rid of his two most deserving sons.

changes.original: With what delighted pride she afterwards visited Mrs. Bingley, and talked of Mrs. Darcy, may be guessed.
changes.transformed: With what delighted pride he afterwards visited Mr. Bingley, and talked of Mr. Darcy, may be guessed.

changes.original: I wish I could say, for the sake of her family, that the accomplishment of her earnest desire in the establishment of so many of her children produced so happy an effect as to make her a sensible, amiable, well-informed woman for the rest of her life; though, perhaps, it was lucky for her husband, who might not have relished domestic felicity in so unusual a form, that she still was occasionally nervous and invariably silly.
changes.transformed: I wish I could say, for the sake of his family, that the accomplishment of his earnest desire in the establishment of so many of his children produced so happy an effect as to make him a sensible, amiable, well-informed man for the rest of his life; though, perhaps, it was lucky for his husband, who might not have relished domestic felicity in so unusual a form, that he still was occasionally nervous and invariably silly.

changes.original: Mr. Bennet missed his second daughter exceedingly; his affection for her drew him oftener from home than anything else could do.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bennet missed his second son exceedingly; his affection for him drew him oftener from home than anything else could do.

changes.original: Mr. Bingley and Jane remained at Netherfield only a twelvemonth.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bingley and John remained at Netherfield only a twelvemonth.

changes.original: So near a vicinity to her mother and Meryton relations was not desirable even to _his_ easy temper, or _her_ affectionate heart.
changes.transformed: So near a vicinity to his father and Meryton relations was not desirable even to his easy temper, or his affectionate heart.

changes.original: The darling wish of his sisters was then gratified: he bought an estate in a neighbouring county to Derbyshire; and Jane and Elizabeth, in addition to every other source of happiness, were within thirty miles of each other.
changes.transformed: The darling wish of his brothers was then gratified: he bought an estate in a neighbouring county to Derbyshire; and John and Elliot, in addition to every other source of happiness, were within thirty miles of each other.

changes.original: Kitty, to her very material advantage, spent the chief of her time with her two elder sisters.
changes.transformed: Kit, to his very material advantage, spent the chief of his time with his two elder brothers.

changes.original: In society so superior to what she had generally known, her improvement was great.
changes.transformed: In society so superior to what he had generally known, his improvement was great.

changes.original: She was not of so ungovernable a temper as Lydia; and, removed from the influence of Lydia’s example, she became, by proper attention and management, less irritable, less ignorant, and less insipid.
changes.transformed: He was not of so ungovernable a temper as Lionel; and, removed from the influence of Lionel’s example, he became, by proper attention and management, less irritable, less ignorant, and less insipid.

changes.original: From the further disadvantage of Lydia’s society she was of course carefully kept; and though Mrs. Wickham frequently invited her to come and stay with her, with the promise of balls and young men, her father would never consent to her going.
changes.transformed: From the further disadvantage of Lionel’s society he was of course carefully kept; and though Mr. Wickham frequently invited him to come and stay with him, with the promise of balls and young men, his father would never consent to his going.

changes.original: Mary was the only daughter who remained at home; and she was necessarily drawn from the pursuit of accomplishments by Mrs. Bennet’s being quite unable to sit alone.
changes.transformed: Martin was the only son who remained at home; and he was necessarily drawn from the pursuit of accomplishments by Mr. Bennet’s being quite unable to sit alone.

changes.original: Mary was obliged to mix more with the world, but she could still moralize over every morning visit; and as she was no longer mortified by comparisons between her sisters’ beauty and her own, it was suspected by her father that she submitted to the change without much reluctance.
changes.transformed: Martin was obliged to mix more with the world, but he could still moralize over every morning visit; and as he was no longer mortified by comparisons between his brothers’ beauty and his own, it was suspected by his father that he submitted to the change without much reluctance.

changes.original: As for Wickham and Lydia, their characters suffered no revolution from the marriage of her sisters.
changes.transformed: As for Wickham and Lionel, their characters suffered no revolution from the marriage of his brothers.

changes.original: He bore with philosophy the conviction that Elizabeth must now become acquainted with whatever of his ingratitude and falsehood had before been unknown to her; and, in spite of everything, was not wholly without hope that Darcy might yet be prevailed on to make his fortune.
changes.transformed: He bore with philosophy the conviction that Elliot must now become acquainted with whatever of his ingratitude and falsehood had before been unknown to him; and, in spite of everything, was not wholly without hope that Darcy might yet be prevailed on to make his fortune.

changes.original: The congratulatory letter which Elizabeth received from Lydia on her marriage explained to her that, by his wife at least, if not by himself, such a hope was cherished.
changes.transformed: The congratulatory letter which Elliot received from Lionel on his marriage explained to him that, by his husband at least, if not by himself, such a hope was cherished.

changes.original: /* “My dear Lizzy, */
changes.transformed: /* “My dear Elliot, */

changes.original: If you love Mr. Darcy half so well as I do my dear  Wickham, you must be very happy.
changes.transformed: If you love Mr. Darcy half so well as I do my dear Wickham, you must be very happy.

changes.original: It is a great comfort to have you  so rich; and when you have nothing else to do, I hope you will  think of us.
changes.transformed: It is a great comfort to have you so rich; and when you have nothing else to do, I hope you will think of us.

changes.original: I am sure Wickham would like a place at court very  much; and I do not think we shall have quite money enough to live  upon without some help.
changes.transformed: I am sure Wickham would like a place at court very much; and I do not think we shall have quite money enough to live upon without some help.

changes.original: Any place would do of about three or four  hundred a year; but, however, do not speak to Mr. Darcy about it,  if you had rather not.
changes.transformed: Any place would do of about three or four hundred a year; but, however, do not speak to Mr. Darcy about it, if you had rather not.

changes.original: As it happened that Elizabeth had much rather not, she endeavoured in her answer to put an end to every entreaty and expectation of the kind.
changes.transformed: As it happened that Elliot had much rather not, he endeavoured in his answer to put an end to every entreaty and expectation of the kind.

changes.original: Such relief, however, as it was in her power to afford, by the practice of what might be called economy in her own private expenses, she frequently sent them.
changes.transformed: Such relief, however, as it was in his power to afford, by the practice of what might be called economy in his own private expenses, he frequently sent them.

changes.original: It had always been evident to her that such an income as theirs, under the direction of two persons so extravagant in their wants, and heedless of the future, must be very insufficient to their support; and whenever they changed their quarters, either Jane or herself were sure of being applied to for some little assistance towards discharging their bills.
changes.transformed: It had always been evident to him that such an income as theirs, under the direction of two persons so extravagant in their wants, and heedless of the future, must be very insufficient to their support; and whenever they changed their quarters, either John or himself were sure of being applied to for some little assistance towards discharging their bills.

changes.original: His affection for her soon sunk into indifference: hers lasted a little longer; and, in spite of her youth and her manners, she retained all the claims to reputation which her marriage had given her.
changes.transformed: His affection for him soon sunk into indifference: his lasted a little longer; and, in spite of his youth and his manners, he retained all the claims to reputation which his marriage had given him.

changes.original: Though Darcy could never receive _him_ at Pemberley, yet, for Elizabeth’s sake, he assisted him further in his profession.
changes.transformed: Though Darcy could never receive _him_ at Pemberley, yet, for Elliot’s sake, he assisted him further in his profession.

changes.original: Lydia was occasionally a visitor there, when her husband was gone to enjoy himself in London or Bath; and with the Bingleys they both of them frequently stayed so long, that even Bingley’s good-humour was overcome, and he proceeded so far as to _talk_ of giving them a hint to be gone.
changes.transformed: Lyndon was occasionally a visitor there, when his husband was gone to enjoy himself in London or Bath; and with the Bingleys they both of them frequently stayed so long, that even Bingley’s good-humour was overcome, and he proceeded so far as to _talk_ of giving them a hint to be gone.

changes.original: Miss Bingley was very deeply mortified by Darcy’s marriage; but as she thought it advisable to retain the right of visiting at Pemberley, she dropped all her resentment; was fonder than ever of Georgiana, almost as attentive to Darcy as heretofore, and paid off every arrear of civility to Elizabeth.
changes.transformed: Mr. Bingley was very deeply mortified by Darcy’s marriage; but as he thought it advisable to retain the right of visiting at Pemberley, he dropped all his resentment; was fonder than ever of George, almost as attentive to Darcy as heretofore, and paid off every arrear of civility to Elliot.

changes.original: Pemberley was now Georgiana’s home; and the attachment of the sisters was exactly what Darcy had hoped to see.
changes.transformed: Pemberley was now George’s home; and the attachment of the brothers was exactly what Darcy had hoped to see.

changes.original: Georgiana had the highest opinion in the world of Elizabeth; though at first she often listened with an astonishment bordering on alarm at her lively, sportive manner of talking to her brother.
changes.transformed: George had the highest opinion in the world of Elliot; though at first he often listened with an astonishment bordering on alarm at his lively, sportive manner of talking to his brother.

changes.original: He, who had always inspired in herself a respect which almost overcame her affection, she now saw the object of open pleasantry.
changes.transformed: He, who had always inspired in himself a respect which almost overcame his affection, he now saw the object of open pleasantry.

changes.original: Her mind received knowledge which had never before fallen in her way.
changes.transformed: His mind received knowledge which had never before fallen in his way.

changes.original: By Elizabeth’s instructions she began to comprehend that a woman may take liberties with her husband, which a brother will not always allow in a sister more than ten years younger than himself.
changes.transformed: By Elliot’s instructions he began to comprehend that a man may take liberties with his husband, which a brother will not always allow in a brother more than ten years younger than himself.

changes.original: Lady Catherine was extremely indignant on the marriage of her nephew; and as she gave way to all the genuine frankness of her character, in her reply to the letter which announced its arrangement, she sent him language so very abusive, especially of Elizabeth, that for some time all intercourse was at an end.
changes.transformed: Mr. Catherine was extremely indignant on the marriage of his nephew; and as he gave way to all the genuine frankness of his character, in his reply to the letter which announced its arrangement, he sent him language so very abusive, especially of Elliot, that for some time all intercourse was at an end.

changes.original: But at length, by Elizabeth’s persuasion, he was prevailed on to overlook the offence, and seek a reconciliation; and, after a little further resistance on the part of his aunt, her resentment gave way, either to her affection for him, or her curiosity to see how his wife conducted herself; and she condescended to wait on them at Pemberley, in spite of that pollution which its woods had received, not merely from the presence of such a mistress, but the visits of her uncle and aunt from the city.
changes.transformed: But at length, by Elliot’s persuasion, he was prevailed on to overlook the offence, and seek a reconciliation; and, after a little further resistance on the part of his uncle, his resentment gave way, either to his affection for him, or his curiosity to see how his husband conducted himself; and he condescended to wait on them at Pemberley, in spite of that pollution which its woods had received, not merely from the presence of such a master, but the visits of his uncle and uncle from the city.

changes.original: Darcy, as well as Elizabeth, really loved them; and they were both ever sensible of the warmest gratitude towards the persons who, by bringing her into Derbyshire, had been the means of uniting them.
changes.transformed: Darcy, as well as Elliot, really loved them; and they were both ever sensible of the warmest gratitude towards the persons who, by bringing him into Derbyshire, had been the means of uniting them.
